subject: Happening Tomorrow: Reinvent. Reintroduce. Reclaim Your Brilliance at the March Community Call
body:
​
​
​
Hi there,
I know we’ve mentioned the 
March Community Call
 
a few times this month already, and if you’ve already seen the invite, thank you for holding space. We truly hope you’ll join us.
If you’re seeing this for the first time, I hope you’ll consider joining us.
Tomorrow, 
Wednesday, March 27 at 12:00 PM ET | 9:00 AM PT
,
 
we continue that tradition with the 
March Community Call
, where I’ll be joined by the incredible 
Dr. Yvette Burton
 for a candid, actionable conversation about navigating through change. 
Register Here
But I want to take a moment to do more than just promote an event. I want to share 
why
 we continue to return to this monthly gathering, and why it still matters so deeply to me and to this community.
Every week, I hear from people in this community asking:
“Where can I go to reflect, grow, and be real about what I’m navigating?”
“Is there still space for the deep, human conversations?”
“Who is holding the line on inclusion, reinvention, and leading with purpose?”
This call is that space.
Our 
community calls
 were born during a time of disruption—when the world felt especially heavy and disorienting. We didn’t know what would come next, but we knew we needed one another. And from those beginnings, something powerful took root.
Over the years, these calls have become a steady anchor. This is a place to learn, to breathe, to reconnect with purpose, and to feel less alone as we each navigate change in our lives and work.
Come as you are. Bring your questions, your reflections, and your hopes for what’s next.
Can’t wait to see you there.
​
In solidarity,
​
Jennifer Brown
CEO & Founder, 
Jennifer Brown Speaks
​
Author, 
Inclusion
, 
How to Be an Inclusive Leader
, and 
Beyond Diversity
​
Host, 
The Will To Change
 Podcast
​
Unsubscribe
 | 
Update your profile
 | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

subject: Voter turnout for property tax increases
body:
Plus, saunas are hot again. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Wednesday - March 26, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Bianca Cseke
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! It’s Wednesday, and so much for giving my wallet a break from concerts this year: 
Lady Gaga
 just announced a new tour with two Chicago stops. Here’s what you need to know today.
  
1.
Turnout for ballot questions hitting voters’ wallets came down to race and wealth disparities
 
Though many people complain about new property taxes, only a few vote on whether to add them. Of that slim minority, voter turnout is highest in areas that are predominately white, wealthy and mostly homeowners. Turnout is lowest in poorer areas with more minorities and renters.
That’s according to a new report from the Cook County Treasurer’s office, which for the first time analyzed the demographic trends behind voter turnout disparities.
Cook County Treasurer Maria Pappas said the disparity in voting trends is worth considering in the upcoming April 1 consolidated elections in the Cook County suburbs, where more than $200 million in taxes and debts are on the ballot.
Last year, 26 tax-related referendums out of 35 total passed in the March presidential primary and November general elections. The referendums included 14 municipal bonds creating $563 million in new debt and more than $4.5 million in new property tax levies in three districts.
In Chicago, the Bring Chicago Home referendum failed by a four-point margin in the presidential primary. Mayor Brandon Johnson’s so-called “mansion tax” on property transfers worth more than $1 million would have addressed homelessness. Only 23.5% of Chicago voters weighed in on the measure, according to the analysis. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
2.
A Chicago Archdiocese lawsuit alleges a conspiracy to file false sex abuse claims against a defrocked priest
 
The lawsuit is a counterclaim against several cases involving convicted child molester and former priest Daniel McCormack, which were filed in late December and are still pending, according to court records.
The defendants are listed as John Does to comply with various court orders. Many live on the West Side, and some are related to one another. The web of connected individuals includes more than two dozen people, according to the archdiocese.
Beginning about 2012, the two ringleaders of the alleged racket directed conspirators to claim they came into contact with McCormack at church or through a basketball team McCormack coached, my Chicago Sun-Times colleague Emmanuel Camarillo reports.
In exchange for “scripts,” the men received a cut of the settlements. They did this because they blew through the money they received from their own settlements over alleged sexual abuse claims against McCormack, the suit says.
“We trust and believe people when they come forward with abuse claims. These individuals have violated that trust and have attempted to take advantage of it,” James Geoly, general counsel for the archdiocese, said in a statement. “We have a duty to oppose claims we know are false to protect and stand up for real survivors of abuse who ultimately are the ones harmed by fraud.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM ACCESS CONTEMPORARY MUSIC
The 20th Annual Sound of Silent Film Festival
Access Contemporary Music’s popular Sound of Silent Film Festival is a unique event featuring new short silent films in every conceivable genre screened with newly-composed musical scores performed live. This year is the 20th anniversary of the festival! 
Join us
 at the gorgeous Music Box Theater for this special event on April 2nd at 7:30 PM.
3.
A Trump executive order targets a Chicago law firm
 
President Donald Trump signed an executive order yesterday targeting a major Chicago-based law firm that previously employed Andrew Weissmann, who worked on special counsel Robert Mueller’s team examining suspected Russian interference in Trump’s 2016 election campaign.
As my colleague Kade Heather reports for the Chicago Sun-Times, the order aims to investigate Jenner & Block’s security clearances, government contracts and access to federal buildings. Trump alleges Jenner & Block “engages in obvious partisan representations to achieve political ends.”
Last week, a federal judge blocked parts of a similar executive order against a prominent firm in Seattle. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
4.
Tony’s Fresh Market workers have kicked off union voting
 
More than 2,000 workers across Tony’s 21 stores in Chicago and the suburbs have until tomorrow to decide if they want to join Local 881 United Food and Commercial Workers, my colleague Amy Yee reports for the Chicago Sun-Times.
The proposed bargaining unit could include about 2,400 Tony’s employees. Full- and part-time clerks, assistant managers and department managers are eligible.
Employees are demanding better pay, health insurance and workplace conditions. Results are expected Friday. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
Happy hour is out. In Chicago, sauna socializing is in.
 
Nate Daubert has a unique role in Chicago spa culture: He’s the city’s only certified “saunamaster,” WBEZ contributor Ximena N. Beltran Quan Kiu reports.
“People are looking for ways to reconnect to nature, especially since the pandemic really digitized our entire lives,” Daubert said. “There’s an increasing need for people to remove themselves from technology, and sauna is a really great way to do that, on top of the science and health benefits.” 
Research by the Mayo Clinic shows that the use of sauna offers health benefits like reducing the risk of vascular disease (such as high blood pressure); alleviating headaches, arthritis and the flu; and increasing skin health. [
WBEZ
]
Including Eastend, the sauna where Daubert works, here are 10 spots to try out to get through Chicago’s remaining chilly weather. [
WBEZ
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
NPR and PBS leaders answered lawmakers’ allegations of bias during a House subcommittee hearing today. [
NPR
]
The Atlantic released the entire Signal chat showing national security officials’ detailed attack plans against Houthis. [
AP
]
Hundreds of people in Gaza took part in the largest anti-Hamas protest since the war with Israel began. [
NPR
]
Here are the numbers to know for each of the 16 teams remaining in March Madness. [
AP
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
Preservationists see the correction of building code violations at the Walser House as a critical first step toward a Frank Lloyd Wright home being rescued and reused, my colleague Lee Bey reports.
Built in 1903 for printing executive Joseph Jacob Walser Jr., the stucco home came relatively early in Wright’s career. Its strong horizontal lines, overhanging eaves and bands of windows would later become trademarks of his larger and more celebrated Prairie School work.
Even with that history, the home has been in disrepair for decades. The nightmarish list of needed repairs includes rotting wood, cracked and failing exterior stucco, exposed structural elements, a deteriorating roof and chimney — and much more.
The neighborhood group Austin Coming Together and a coalition of architecture organizations hope the home can go to a nonprofit that can raise the millions needed to restore the house and convert it to public use. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
 
Tell me something good
 
I was just in India and saw the Taj Mahal, and it absolutely lived up to the hype as one of the most beautiful buildings in the world. That has me wondering, what’s something that left you in awe while traveling, whether it’s an iconic landmark or a unique experience?
Samantha writes:
“I know this sounds nuts. I have traveled the world, lived on three continents, and the one place that takes my breath away is Atwater Park just north of Milwaukee. Looking out from the top on a clear, sunny day you can see the sunken piers disappear into a Lake Michigan filled with blues and greens of all shades. Highly recommend stopping by for a quick moment of zen if you're ever passing through.”
Marty writes:
“My favorite site was Muir Woods in California. The majesty and beauty of that location inspires great reverence for the wonders of the natural world. I felt as if I were in a medieval cathedral with the awesome silence and spiritual connection one feels when walking through those woods. Seeing the natural growth and animals interact was truly inspiring. Made me feel both insignificant and empowering that I and others could experience this wondrous sight!”
And Sharon writes:
“Driving across the Gobi Desert, you can see 360 degree views. No roads, only vehicle tracks in the sand. Utterly quiet, no airplanes overhead. We spent nights with nomads in their gers (tents). As we drove away in the morning, they tossed goats’ milk after the van for good luck.”
Feel free to email me, and your response may be included in the newsletter this week.
Thanks for reading and have a nice night! I'll see you tomorrow.
— Bianca Cseke
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting. 
DONATE TODAY
©Chicago Public Media Inc 848 East Grand Ave, Navy Pier Chicago, IL 60611

subject: Celebrating a Milestone: CST is Now a Certified B Corp!
body:
Dear Clients and Friends,
Big News!
 
We are thrilled to announce that 
Culture Shift Team
 (CST) is now a Certified B Corporation! This achievement is not just a milestone—it’s a reaffirmation of our core mission to use business as a force for good.
Our Journey:
 Our journey began in September 2022 when we undertook the B Corp Assessment—a rigorous evaluation of our impact on our workers, customers, community, and environment. After 915 days of diligent effort and dedication, we achieved a score of 85.6, officially making us a B Corp just in time to celebrate B Corp Month!
What This Means:
 Achieving B Corp status means that CST meets the highest standards of verified social and environmental performance, public transparency, and legal accountability. We are committed to:
Social and Environmental Impact:
 Elevating our initiatives to create positive impacts both locally and globally. 
Transparency:
 Upholding an open and honest relationship with our stakeholders. 
Accountability:
 Ensuring we are accountable for our impacts on our employees, communities, and the environment. 
Thrilled to Join Global Leaders:
 As an advertising, marketing, and inclusive workplace culture firm, we are thrilled to join the global B Corp community alongside companies like Ben & Jerry's, Danone North America, Patagonia, TOMS, and Warby Parker. These companies have set benchmarks in their respective industries, and we are excited to contribute to this movement of responsible and sustainable business practices. 
Looking Ahead:
 We are excited to continue this journey, striving for improvement and making a lasting impact in every area of our business. 
Thank You:
 We would like to extend a heartfelt thank you to our team, clients, and partners who have been instrumental in this process. Your support fuels our continued commitment to define and embody the future of business excellence. 
Thank you for celebrating with us this new achievement!
Warm regards,
Marcela Gómez
CEO
Culture Shift Team, Inc.
marcela.gomez@cultureshiftteam.com
615-828-0987

subject: 🌍 Women in Communications: Redefining the Narrative!
body:
Your Weekly NYWICI Newsletter!
 
 
About
 
Membership
 
 
Last Chance to Register: Take Charge of Your Financial Future
Join NYWICI on 
Tuesday, April 1, 2025
, at 
12:00 PM EST
 for a dynamic webinar focused on building financial confidence and making informed money decisions.
Led by
 Judy Herbst, 
Executive Director of Savvy Ladies, and moderated by 
Jackie Hyland, 
Associate Director of Corporate Affairs at KPMG US, this session will explore essential financial topics, including budgeting, investing, and long-term wealth strategies. Gain practical insights and actionable advice to navigate financial challenges and secure your future.
No matter your financial stage, this conversation will equip you with the tools to take control and thrive.
Location
: Virtual (Zoom link provided upon registration)
Cost
: Free for NYWICI members | $20 for non-members
Register now to receive the Zoom link!
register here
 
 
 
A New Path Forward for Sustainability Communications is Almost Here!
Join us on 
Wednesday, April 2, 2025
, from 
4:00 – 7:00 PM
 at 
Idealist.org
 (389 Fifth Ave, NYC) for a thought-provoking discussion on the evolving landscape of sustainability communications.
As shifting policies and public sentiment create uncertainty around corporate sustainability and social impact initiatives, communicators must adapt their strategies to maintain trust and engagement. This event will explore how companies are responding—whether by reinforcing commitments, rebranding efforts, or stepping back entirely—and what these changes mean for the future of sustainability communications.
Featuring:
🔹 Moderator: 
Catherine Addo
, Social Impact Strategist & Founder, Impact Media
🔹 Panelists: 
Sara Adams 
(Chief Executives for Corporate Purpose),
 Emily Goodstein 
(Greater Good Strategy)
, Reed Handley 
(The Bliss Group)
Pricing: $25 for NYWICI members | $50 for non-members
register here
 
 
 
Leading with Style: A Fireside Chat with Rebecca Minkoff
﻿
Mark your calendars for 
April 22, 2025, 
from 
12:00 – 1:00 PM EST
 for an exclusive conversation with and Real Housewife of New York, 
Rebecca Minkoff
 as she shares insights from her book "
Fearless: The New Rules for Unlocking Creativity, Courage, and Success
."
In this session, Rebecca will dive deep into her journey from being an industry outsider to creating a global brand. She’ll reveal the bold and unconventional strategies that propelled her success, including how she turned self-doubt into confidence, navigated setbacks, and built an authentic, powerful network.
This fireside chat will be packed with real-world insights, practical advice, and Rebecca’s candid wisdom on unlocking creativity, courage, and success. Plus, don’t miss your chance to ask her questions directly during the live Q&A session.
Location
: Virtual (Zoom link provided upon registration)
Cost
: Free for NYWICI members | $20 for non-members
Spots are limited—register now to hear from one of fashion’s most fearless leaders!
register here
 
 
 
NYWICI 2025 Matrix Awards: Honoring Industry Luminaries Registration is Now Open!
This year’s Matrix theme, Leading Luminaries, celebrates women who are blazing trails and shaping the future. Our 2025 Matrix honorees are the luminaries lighting the way to success and influencing the industry and community. These women shine brightly, guiding others through times of darkness with resilience, perseverance, and a steadfast focus on their goals.
Luminaries inspire by example, lead with purpose, and contribute to the greater good. They sacrifice personal gain for collective progress and use their influence to make a meaningful impact. These women not only achieve great things—they leave a lasting legacy.
Join us in honoring these extraordinary leaders at the 2025 Matrix Awards on May 20, 2025, at the Ziegfeld Ballroom in NYC. This year’s honorees are:
Leslie Berland, EVP, Chief Marketing Officer, Verizon
Teneshia Jackson Warner, Founder & CEO, Egami Group
Dustee Jenkins, Chief Public Affairs Officer, Spotify
Lucy Kaylin, Editorial Director, Hearst Magazines
Nkechi Okoro Carroll, Writer, Showrunner, Producer
Kristen Welker, Moderator of Meet the Press
Bellamy Young, Actress and Activist
Let’s celebrate these powerful luminaries who embody the spirit of resilience, empowerment, and lasting impact!
register here
 
 
Congratulations to Mechelle Morgan, Our Volunteer of the Month!
 
What are some fun facts about you? 
The beach is my fav place to be, one of my favorite books is The Memo: What Women of Color Need to Know to Secure a Seat at the Table" by Minda Harts, and I’ve seen every episode of Law and Order SVU :) 
How has volunteering with NYWICI had an impact on you?
Impact of Volunteering with NYWICI: Volunteering with NYWICI has been a transformative experience. It’s allowed me to meet and learn from accomplished women in the industry, and it’s allowed me to strengthen my skills as a writer.
If you could encourage someone to volunteer with NYWICI, what would you tell them?
Encouraging Others to Volunteer: I would tell anyone considering volunteering with NYWICI that it’s one of the best ways to expand your network and sharpen your skills while giving back to a community that empowers women in communications.
 
 
Changemakers: Lesley Jane Seymour, CEO, CoveyClub.com
In this episode, Womenheard: Changemakers host Georgia Galanoudis reconnected with 
Lesley Jane Seymour, founder and CEO of CoveyClub.com
. Lesley first joined our NYWICI podcast in 2023 and she’s back with her trademark honesty and updates! The former Editor-in-Chief of Marie Claire, Lesley has been at the editorial helm of beloved and influential magazines: Vogue, Women’s Wear Daily, Harper’s Bazaar, Glamour, YM, Redbook, and More. She launched CoveyClub.com in 2017, a lifelong learning community empowering women ages 40+. Listen to this episode for insights on entrepreneurship and knowing when to make a change.
listen here
 
 
 
NYWICI Speaker Spotlight: Alyssa Bernstein
Looking for practical career advice from a seasoned communications pro? Read our latest 
blog
 featuring 
Alyssa Bernstein
, a communications leader at TelevisaUnivision with experience at ABC News, CBS, ViacomCBS/Paramount, and a speaker at our Women of AI event in January.
Alyssa shares her insights on staying relevant, the evolving role of communications professionals, and how to make a lasting impact within your organization. She also talks about the importance of community—shoutout to NYWICI—and how building authentic connections can help you grow in your career.
If you’re navigating your career journey or looking for inspiration, you don’t want to miss this conversation. Read the full blog now!
read here
 
 
 
Stay Inspired: Explore NYWICI’s Latest Blogs
Breaking into the Communications Industry: Tips for Emerging Professionals
 Breaking into the communications industry can feel overwhelming, but with the right approach, you can stand out. In this blog, I share essential tips for emerging professionals, from defining your professional identity and honing your skills to building a strong network. Whether you’re a recent graduate or shifting careers, these strategies will help you enter the field with confidence. Read the full blog now and get the insights you need to succeed in communications!
LEFT OUT OF HISTORY
 In honor of Women’s History Month, we’re revisiting a topic that’s long overdue—highlighting women who have been left out of history. From Angelyne, the original influencer, to Hedy Lamarr, the mother of Wi-Fi, these women revolutionized industries and left lasting legacies.
In this blog, we celebrate the lives of trailblazing women like Muriel Fox, Joan Ganz Cooney, and the ENIAC programmers—whose contributions to advertising, technology, activism, and education are often overlooked.
Read on to learn more about these incredible women who paved the way for so many of today’s innovations and movements.
Equal Pay Day: A Call for Change and Equity
 Equal Pay Day is more than just a statistic—it’s a call for action. For women of color, the gap between what we earn and what our white male counterparts earn is a stark reminder of the systemic inequality still present in the workforce. In honor of Equal Pay Day, I reflect on the powerful work of women like Minda Harts and Shonda Rhimes, who have paved the way for women of color to assert their value and fight for the pay we deserve.
This blog is a reminder that the fight for equal pay isn’t over, but with continued effort and voices like Minda’s and Shonda’s leading the charge, we will push for the change that’s long overdue. Read the full blog now!
read more here

subject: Fastest-Growing Firms: The Power of GSA and SBA
body:
Fastest-Growing Firms: The Power of GSA and SBA                                                     
Fastest-Growing Firms: The Power of GSA Schedule and SBA Certifications
 
Learn More
Fastest-Growing Firms: The Power of GSA and SBA
Each year, Washington Technology publishes its "Fast 50" list, featuring the fastest-growing firms in the Federal IT sector. 
Reviewing the 2023 "Fast 50" list is invaluable for gaining insights into effective practices in federal business development. The results underscore the importance of having an SBA Certification and a GSA Schedule for firms aiming to succeed in the federal marketplace.
Here are some impressive statistics:
Six of the 50 firms on our list—12%—are our valued clients.
Twenty out of fifty firms, or 40%, are 8(a) Certified, with 18 of those also holding a GSA Schedule.
Two firms, representing 4%, are VOSB Certified, and both are on the GSA Schedule.
Ten firms are SDVOSB Certified, comprising 20% of the list, and all of them have secured GSA Schedule contracts.
Eighteen out of fifty firms, or 36%, are WOSB Certified, with 16 of these in the GSA Schedule.
Twelve firms, representing 24%, hold EDWOSB Certification, and 10 of these are also on the GSA Schedule.
Five firms, or 10%, are HUBZone Certified, and all of them are on the GSA Schedule.
In total, 43 out of 50 firms—an impressive 86%—have secured a GSA Schedule Contract. 
The intersection of SBA Certifications with GSA Schedule status defines a strategic combination that significantly enhances growth opportunities within the federal marketplace. These certifications are not merely advantageous; they are essential for thriving in this competitive sector.
Below is a listing of the 50 firms on the Washington Technology 2023 Fast 50 list (we have included only their positions on the list, without the names; however, non-disclosure agreements preclude me from naming them).
The impressive statistics from the 2023 "Fast 50" list clearly illustrate the vital role that SBA Certifications and GSA Schedule participation play in achieving success within the federal marketplace. As evidenced by the firms on this list, these qualifications not only enhance credibility but also significantly boost growth potential in government contracting.
If you’re interested in discovering the certifications that align with your firm's marketing plans and can propel your success, we invite you to take advantage of our free initial phone consultation. Let’s connect and explore how we can help you seize these invaluable opportunities and set your company on the path to success in government contracting!

subject: Open House - Saturday 3/29 & Sunday 3/30 | 253 W Second St., OIB
body:
View in your browser
 
OPEN HOUSE
Saturday 3/29 & Sunday 3/30 from 12:00 to 2:00 PM
253 W Second Street, Ocean Isle Beach, NC
Hosted by Daniel Stitt | 980-722-5169
 
 
 
 
 
OPEN HOUSE – YOU’RE INVITED! 
Please join us for an exclusive Open House at 253 W Second Street, Ocean Isle Beach, NC.
📅 Saturday, 3/29 & Sunday, 3/30 
⏰ 12:00 PM – 2:00 PM 
💰 Offered at $1,375,000
Welcome to Coastal Luxury: 
Experience the perfect blend of coastal elegance and modern luxury at 253 W Second Street, a stunning custom-built home just moments from the shore. Designed with meticulous attention to detail by the homeowners in collaboration with an interior designer and builder, this partially furnished 1,952-square-foot retreat is a true island paradise.
Exceptional Design & Thoughtful Layout: 
This exquisite home boasts 4 bedrooms and 3 baths, offering ample space for relaxation and entertaining. The open and airy floor plan invites natural light, creating a warm and sophisticated ambiance. The main living area features LVP flooring for a perfect balance of durability and style, complemented by crown molding that extends throughout the home. Cozy up by the fireplace or immerse yourself in a premium entertainment experience with smart wiring, four built-in speakers, and pre-wiring for a surround sound system and center speaker (stereo equipment not included). A built-in TV antenna adds an extra layer of convenience.
Gourmet Kitchen & Elegant Primary Suite: 
Designed for both function and style, the kitchen is equipped with sleek cabinetry, a modern electric stove, and generous space for culinary creativity. The primary suite offers a peaceful retreat with elegant crown molding, a spacious walk-in closet, and high-end finishes. Additional conveniences include a dedicated laundry area with a stackable washer and dryer, as well as a tankless water heater for endless comfort.
Breathtaking Ocean Views & Upper-Level Sanctuary: 
The second floor is a true highlight, featuring a private balcony with stunning ocean views—the perfect setting for morning coffee or evening relaxation. This level also includes a cozy fireplace, a flexible den space, and a fourth bedroom with a spacious closet and private ensuite bathroom, making it ideal for guests or as a secondary retreat.
Don’t miss this opportunity to tour this exceptional home and experience its charm firsthand. We look forward to seeing you at the Open House!
For a private showing, contact Amy at 704-242-0446 to schedule your visit.

body:

TOP NEWS
 
Who will celebrate in the end? Our expert predictions are in!
 
See who the voters on our panel picked to win divisions, clinch Wild Cards, claim pennants and hoist the World Series trophy. There's just one more sleep before it all gets started on Thursday!

The major milestones within reach for star players in 2025
 
Sarah Langs looks at players with significant statistical benchmarks within reach -- and the likelihood each one will hit the mark this season.
 
Every team's great unknown ahead of Opening Day
 
We asked every MLB beat writer about their respective club's greatest unknown entering the season. Here's what they said.
 
Juan Soto, pitcher? It could have been, if not for this coach
 
Rafael Zapata looked at the 14-year-old star pitcher -- who couldn't hit and couldn't run -- and saw money in his bat.
 
How family, health and 'The Greatest' gave Murphy perspective

He's more than 'just a dude'
 
Blue Jays manager John Schneider sees himself as just a regular guy -- but he knows he's much more than that in the eyes of the fans. As he enters his third full season as skipper, he wouldn't want to be anywhere -- or anyone -- else.
 
Looking back at the best extra-innings moments of '24
 
With extra innings once again presented FREE on MLB.TV thanks to GEICO in 2025, let’s take a look back at some of the most memorable extra-inning games and moments from last season.

Mossier New(ish) Direction
A Letter to the Mossier community
Mossier
Mar 26
 
READ IN APP
 
Dear Partners and Friends,
Whew - what a year it has been already.  2020 opened up the DEI conversation in ways we couldn’t even imagine. It also ignited a stream of constant attacks on our shared values of equity, inclusion and fairness for all.  November’s election was the clearest signal yet that a new strategic direction is warranted. Our country is evolving, the DEI industry is evolving and Mossier is evolving too.
For starters, 
we’ve made the difficult decision to sunset our job seeker and recruiting programs including our job board, resume database and hiring events
. This decision was extremely difficult mostly because we don’t want to leave our Mossier job seeker community hanging. 
 
We know how hard it is to navigate the job search as an LGBTQ person.
  
Ultimately
, 
this decision was made for a variety of reasons:
The needs of our clients are evolving.  Between a slow down in hiring and a bullish Trump administration threatening to dismantle DEI, what we’re hearing from clients is they need more support navigating an ever-shifting legal environment, assessing reputational risk and improving the impact of their internal DEI programs.
It’s not what we are best at
. There are other players in the LGBTQ recruiting and career coaching space (click here to see our faves) who have made supporting LGBTQ job seekers their core work and we highly encourage you to check them out.
We want to dedicate all of our effort to helping workplaces get set-up so
 they can actually retain LGBTQ employees 
once they are hired. We’ve seen first hand, and research is indicating, that biased promotion processes, inconsistent hiring operations and feedback mechanisms and a lack of leadership buy-in is slowing down progress for LGBTQ employees.
Our mission will be the same moving forward. In short, Mossier will continue to enable employment equity for everyone LGBTQ through culture assessments, strategy development and training and coaching. We’ll be sharing more about our updated services soon so stay tuned.
We encourage all of our Mossier job seekers to check out these job seeker resources.  If you need support in finding your next employer, don’t hesitate to reach out to 
info@mossier.com
 and we will help connect you to the right people.
Challenges lie ahead for our shared vision of a more inclusive and healthy world where everyone can thrive at work but we are so grateful to be in that fight with you.
With love and gratitude,
Nick
Job Seeker Resources
Organizations supporting LGBTQ job seekers:
Twin Cities Pride
Out for Undergrad
Reaching Out MBA
Out in Tech

Career Coaches Supporting LGBTQ Job Seekers:
Alex Lahmeyer
: 
Alex is a queer and non-binary coach who helps LGBTQ+ professionals navigate key career moments. With a background in DEI and recruiting, Alex collaborates with clients to develop personalized strategies for finding fulfilling work that meets their needs. If you’re looking for support with a career pivot, job search, or navigating the workplace as an LGBTQ+ person, book a free consultation to explore working together.
Brandon Beaulieu
 at GESMN provides job search assistance for individuals through the Dislocated Worker program. We can assist eligible individuals who have been laid off with the following no cost services:
Career counseling and assessments to help determine your career path
Resume assistance, interview preparation and access to networking groups
Assistance with job searching across occupation and levels of experience
Funding and help with career certifications and training programs
Limited support services we can provide to help assist with financial need.
You can contact Brandon Beaulieu at bibeaulieu@gesmn.org or 651-382-1922 for more information.

subject: Anti-Racism Reading List March 2025
body:
10+ insightful articles to promote learning and action on anti-racism  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
March 26, 2025   |   
Read Online
Anti-Racism Reading List March 2025 
10+ insightful articles to promote learning and action on anti-racism 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello friends, 
There is a LOT in this month's reading list, from lessons from history, to changing our thinking, to surviving and thriving this moment in global history. And the Of Note section is getting longer. So, without further ado, feel free to dive in…
﻿
1. 
Reclaiming Knowledge: The Evolution of Decolonial Thought and the DIA Framework
 by Christian Ortiz
Christian Ortiz has been bringing it recently - I look forward to seeing his articles in my LinkedIn feed. What I like about this article isn't just the theme and approach but also the fact that he explicitly acknowledges that it's built on ancestral wisdom and that it's being released to the world as a shared piece of knowledge: 
“This framework is not meant to be static. It does not seek validation from colonial institutions but remains in dialogue with the communities it serves. It is a communal offering, designed to grow through continuous engagement with Black, Indigenous, and feminist knowledge keepers.”
2. 
When Education Erases: The Harm in Superficial Black History Lessons
 by Meghan Stewart
I felt the opening sentence to my core. Though there was some Caribbean flavour, my own education was largely very "English grammar school" in approach. As this author points out, we can and must do better: 
“I need our history to be honoured with the same depth and care as other histories. I need our stories to exist beyond civil rights struggles and adversity. I want my daughter to know that she comes from a lineage of artists, healers, visionaries, mathematicians, and philosophers. That she is more than resistance, she is also creativity, joy, and possibility.”
3. 
Maroon Leadership: A Blueprint for Workplace Resistance and Collective Strength
 by Janice Gassam Asare, Ph.D.
One thing I DID learn about in school was the resistance to enslavement by the Maroons of Jamaica, which is why this article caught my eye. It points the way to a model of resistance and community that's much needed in these times: 
“These communities thrived by leveraging collectivism, strategic adaptability, and ancestral wisdom. This leadership framework draws from the spirit of Sankofa, going back and reclaiming what is valuable from our past. It recognizes that beyond the trauma and oppression imposed on the African diaspora, there is also a rich inheritance of resistance, innovation, and self-determination.”
4. title
4. 
What is White Nationalism?
 by Arturo Dominguez
As the author points out, we need to understand it to fight it, so here's a primer: 
“Once referred to as “leaderless” movements – a decades-old misnomer – these hate groups and far-right extremists can no longer be referred to as such. While they have always had obvious leaders, legacy media often refers to those who commit hate crimes as “lone wolves” or refer to the broad amount of hate groups as leaderless. This is largely attributable to the fragmented nature of hate groups nationally. We can all see who their leaders are now.”
5. 
How White Co-Workers Can Derail Black Women's Careers
 by Monique Judge
Tall poppies, glass cliffs - whatever the syndrome Black women are often disproportionately affected, and it's their white co-workers who bear much of the responsibility: 
“Black women who begin their careers working around a higher percentage of white co-workers are more likely to leave their jobs and less likely to get promoted. This means that even when Black women are hired — and best believe, they have to go above and beyond to prove that they are “worthy” of being hired — they are not set up for success in the workplace in the same way that their white counterparts are.”
6. 
10 Books That Shaped Black History Over the Last Century
 by Kai Mora
I had a moment of joy as I typed this, because it's a compilation by an African writer on a Nigerian publication featuring Black literature. I always aim to include resources from around the globe and I'm delighted to include this here: 
“below is an attempt to map some of the most influential literary interventions made in Black history during the twentieth century. The books on this list not only shaped Black history over the last century, but also reflect the diversity yet unity with which Africans on the continent and in the diaspora saw themselves, their history, and thus, their purpose.”
7. 
A Path to Wellness for Black Women
 by David McQueen
The disparities experienced by Black women in healthcare systems are well know. Here, David McQueen draws some threads together to move towards leadership that can address these issues: 
“Black women working collectively to advocate for better healthcare policies and services is a must whether that is forming local wellness groups to encourage accountability and shared learning, or leveraging social media and online platforms to amplify issues and mobilise communities to demand change.”
Fact-based news without bias awaits. Make 1440 your choice today.
Overwhelmed by biased news? Cut through the clutter and get straight facts with your daily 1440 digest. From politics to sports, join millions who start their day informed. 
Sign up now!
8. 
Democracy is Crumbling. Is Anybody Doing Anything?
 by Sherrilyn Ifill
Things are moving so quickly that this article might feel a bit dated, but two points remain relevant. First, where the responsibility lies for the current mess in the US (and indeed, in the world). Second, that there is and continues to be resistance: 
“But this moment we find ourselves in is the result of the reckless voting of our fellow Americans in 2024, the failures of our media over decades, the critical political mistakes of our leaders, the short-sighted greed of the corporate community, and the longstanding lack of urgency about repairing the gaping cracks in our democratic infrastructure over far too many years. There is no magical way out.We are reaping what has been sown by many, many years of inattention to the eroding foundations of our democracy and we must face it.”
9. 
Throwback Thursday: Dealing With Racist Bone Disease
 by Michael Harriott
And now, a little bit of satire with a foundation in reality: 
“Perhaps the most disturbing part about the illness is that the bone-ified racists can never admit that they are infected. When asked, Osteowypiposis sufferers will offer bold assurances that they have not contracted the virus. However, all of the available research indicates that there has never been a case of a racist who was aware of their racism until it metastasized into its incurable, late-stage form known as the “Trumpian stage.”
10. 
How Black music record stores changed UK music forever
 by 2Funky Arts
To round out our main selection this month, a positive story about the influence of Black culture in the UK: 
“
It’s also clear how much camaraderie these record stores offered. These places were about more than buying records – they afforded the chance for people to learn about gigs, watch performances, hear about parties and get a music education.
”
﻿Of Note - Things Worth Highlighting
Learning for Good
 - a monthly newsletter which share useful resources 
Digital Green Book
 - trusted voices and credible resources for the Black community 
The Future of DEI
 virtual summit - convened by Erin Corine Johnson of the Reparations Race and Hola Magnolia 
DEI Support Hub
 for federal workers in the US 
The Racism Survival Spectrum
 by Dr Shungu H. M’gadzah 
Tech Safari
 - a guide to African tech 
As always, I'd love to know, what stood out to you from this month's reading list, and what's the next intentionally anti-racist action you'll take as a result. Feel free to comment below or reply to the email. 
Thanks for reading, 
Sharon

subject: REBOOT: Proximity Isn’t The Flex You Think It Is
body:
Stop using the “Black friend” defence  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
March 26, 2025   |   
Read Online
REBOOT: Proximity Isn’t The Flex You Think It Is 
Stop using the “Black friend” defence 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello friends,
It’s time for the monthly trawl through the archives. It’s a couple of years since this article on proximity was first published and it still rings true. I’ve updated it with some new links and a couple of relevant Instagram galleries, but otherwise, it’s pretty much as originally written. Check it out…
Proximity Isn’t The Flex You Think It Is
I know some white people may be offended by this but it needs to be said: proximity to a Black or Global Majority person doesn’t make you an expert on their experience. For sure, you have a ringside seat to many of the oppressions they face. And because you care about them, you can empathise with their pain but, and it’s an important but, you don’t have the same experience - viscerally - that they do. It’s another of those cases where you need to know what you don’t know. 
In the past, I’ve talked about the 
“Black friend defence”
 - the use of a Black person you happen to know as a way to undermine the validity of what the Black person in front of you is saying. There’s also the “
Black partner defence
” which is (you guessed it) the use of a Black person you’re married to or partnered with to undermine the validity of what the Black person in front of you is saying. 
It’s time for that to stop. Seriously, it’s another manifestation of 
white supremacy
. And I have to wonder if your Black friend or partner appreciates being used this way. 
our.moral.imperative
 
our.moral.imperative
  
Add a comment...
Thank you for being on the free list for Sharon’s Anti-Racism Newsletter. I can’t do this work without the support of readers like you. But most of all, I rely on those of you who upgrade to premium subscriptions. You can find pricing options here: 
Show me how I can support SARN 
Now, if you’re doing it with context, that’s one thing. I publish a whole newsletter and I have said stuff in here you can quote, but when you do that, remember that I am 
not a monolith
. I have had certain experiences around the globe that inform what I write and speak about, and how I do that. Many of those experiences give me things in common with Black people around the world; but some are unique to my own cultural background. If you have learned things on your journey that you believe reflect a collective view, you certainly can share those, but be mindful of the fact that you might not know it all. After all, who does? 
Instead of going straight for the Black friend defence, question 
your own motivations
 for using it. Are you doing it because your actual Black friend said something relevant to what you’re talking about? Or because you have a number of Black friends who share this opinion and it’s therefore a kind of collective expression? That might be ok. 
Or are you doing it because you’re looking for backup for something you’re not sure of yourself, and want to escape being challenged? If it’s the latter, then that’s a problem. 
evolvedteacher
 
evolvedteacher
  
Add a comment...
To wrap this up, there’s a world of difference between telling someone “I have a Black friend and all Black people feel this way” and saying “My friend x, who is Black, feels this way”. Context and nuance matter in this, as in everything. So, remember to pause the next time you’re thinking of using your 
proximity to Blackness
 or to a Global Majority person to take down someone else’s argument. Pause and figure out it if this is really the best approach for all concerned. Nine times out of 10 it isn’t. 
[2025 update: my challenge to you all is to notice when the temptation to use proximity as a a defence creeps in and then choose to do something different.]
Thanks for reading,
Sharon

subject: Register Now for Leading with Style: A Fireside Chat with Rebecca Minkoff - April 22
body:
Dear Monica,
Leading with Style:
 
A Fireside Chat with Rebecca Minkoff
Join us for an exclusive conversation with fashion industry pioneer, bestselling author and Real Housewife of New York,
 
Rebecca Minkoff
 
as she unpacks insights from her book "
Fearless: The New Rules for Unlocking Creativity, Courage, and Success
." 
Rebecca will share her journey from fashion outsider to global brand builder, revealing the unconventional strategies that propelled her success. Whether you’re an aspiring entrepreneur, creative professional, or just looking to up-level your career, this conversation will explore breaking through creative blocks and self-doubt, turning setbacks into comeback opportunities and building a powerful network authentically.
Get ready for an inspiring conversation filled with actionable takeaways, real-world examples, and Rebecca's signature straight-talking advice. Participants will have the opportunity to engage in a live Q&A session.
Register today!
Date:
 April 22, 2025, |
 12:00 - 1:00 pm EST
Location
:

‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌   ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  
How can Nextdoor help Language & Culture Worldwide ?
 
As your neighborhood social network, Nextdoor brings real customers to local businesses in neighborhoods around the world, including yours. Learn how a business account connects Language & Culture Worldwide with them — instantly: 
“How can I be sure I’m reaching people who live where I do business?” 
Everyone on Nextdoor is a verified neighbor, so the instant audience you unlock with your free page are real people who really live where your business is. 
“Word-of-mouth is the main way I grow my business now — can Nextdoor help with that?” 
Neighbors rank Nextdoor as the #1 place for local recommendations over other business directories. Here, they can Fave and recommend you, vote for you in the annual Neighborhood Faves, and you can stay in their feeds with free posts. 
“Can I use Nextdoor to reach customers beyond my neighborhood?” 
Once you sign up for your free page, you'll have access to Nextdoor Ads that can get your name out in a mile radius or any ZIPs you choose, starting at $3 a day. 
Visit the 
Help Center
 for answers to more questions. 
Claim your page
Source: Nextdoor Neighbor Survey, May 2023

subject: Your Board Invitation 📩  Join DeepXL's Advisory Board
body:
DeepXL is seeking professionals like you to join their advisory board - check out your invitation inside to get started! - 
 
You're invited!
 Join join the DeepXL Advisory Board on AdvisoryCloud today.
 
DeepXL
 Advisory Board
Upcoming Board Meeting in Q2 | 
Your Expertise is Requested
DeepXL
 is a pioneering artificial intelligence company on a mission to safeguard digital truth and foster a safer, more authentic online environment for all. DeepXL is currently seeking professionals with 
or without
 AI experience to give feedback on our ground-breaking new product.
 
Want to get involved as a board member and see behind the scenes?
Get started today
 
The ROI of Joining Boards
✓
 Get involved in interesting new companies
✓
 Add board work to your resume & social profiles 
✓
 Elite networking and introductions
✓
 Elevate your current and future earning potential 
✓
 Long-term career stimulation and opportunities
 
Explore boards today
 
 
But Am I Qualified?
Every professional has unique ideas and perspectives, whether you’re early in your career, already in the executive ranks, or starting to think about working a bit less. 
There are over 30 million businesses in the United States alone. For too long it's been hard for companies to build an advisory board and get feedback from a large and diverse group of professionals, but AdvisoryCloud has changed all of that - 
and we want you to be a part of it.
Joining boards gives you a behind-the-scenes look at exciting new businesses, exposes you to interesting new people, and can open doors of professional opportunity in a lot of different ways.
So take your shot 
- 
get started today for free.

subject: We go live in 1 hour :  Federal Employees: Ready to Pivot to the Private Sector? Join This Free Event! 7 PM
body:
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Monica
The federal landscape is shifting. Layoffs, restructuring, and uncertainty are becoming the norm. 
If you’re considering a move to the private sector—or even just exploring your options—you need a plan.
That’s why I’m hosting a 
free, high-impact webinar
:
The Federal Pivot: Your Power Move to the Private Sector
Tuesday, March 25, 7PM ET - 
 
Live Webinar
If you’ve 
built a successful career in government
 but aren’t sure how to translate that into private sector opportunities, 
this session is for you.
What You’ll Walk Away With:
✔ 
A clear understanding of where your skills fit in the private sector
—so you don’t waste time on the wrong roles.
✔ 
How to rewrite your resume & LinkedIn profile
—so recruiters instantly see your value.
✔ 
The #1 networking strategy
 for landing private sector roles (even if your entire career has been in government).
✔ 
How to ace interviews & negotiate your worth
—so you don’t get lowballed or overlooked.
✔ 
The 5 biggest mistakes federal employees make when transitioning
—and how to avoid them.
 
BONUS
: Every attendee gets The Federal Pivot Toolkit: The 5 Critical Shifts You Need to Make for Private Sector Success.
This isn’t just another career talk. It’s a 
strategic roadmap
 to ensure you transition with confidence, clarity, and 
the best possible opportunities.
Seats are limited, and this is information you can’t afford to miss.
 
Reserve your spot 
here
See you there!
Time to get SCRAPPY! 
 
Deborah T. Owens
Head Alley Cat
 
P.S Share this webinar with your friends and colleagues

 | Sent by Corporate Alley Cat 
641 S St. NW, Suite 300 • Washington, DC • 20001

subject: School board members oppose pension payment
body:
Plus, a new opera takes on our obsession with cults. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Tuesday - March 25, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Bianca Cseke
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! Here’s where you can celebrate 
Eid al-Fitr
 in the Chicago area next week. And here’s what else you need to know today.
  
1.
Mayor Brandon Johnson lacks the votes to compel CPS to make a city pension payment, giving him days to find the cash
 
Seven of 20 Board of Education members say they oppose reimbursing the city for a disputed pension payment, dooming the budget’s chances of passing, my colleagues Nader Issa, Sarah Karp and Fran Spielman report. 
“We cannot in good conscience make payments towards things for which we have no sustainable means of raising revenue,” the board members wrote in a letter first reported by Chalkbeat Chicago.
A postponed vote would have amended the CPS budget to include three additional costs: the pension payment, which also covers CPS staff who aren’t teachers; a CTU contract that’s nearing settlement; and a not-yet-settled agreement with the new principals union.
The mayor has pushed for CPS to pay all three expenses using what’s left of a record nearly $300 million tax-increment financing surplus, provided by his office, and other methods, such as short-term borrowing or debt restructuring. Johnson’s office said yesterday it would keep working with the board to find a solution and “continues to expect CPS” to make the pension payment. The mayor has not presented a Plan B.
If the city doesn’t get the money from CPS by March 31, Johnson will have three bad choices: close the books on 2024 in the red, find the $175 million elsewhere in the city budget or dip into reserves. [
Chicago Sun-Times/WBEZ
]
2.
Illinois returned nearly 1,500 acres of stolen land to the state’s first federally recognized tribe
 
Gov. JB Pritzker has signed a law to restore Shabbona State Park, about 1,500 acres in DeKalb County, to the Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation, my Sun-Times colleague Violet Miller reports.
The law’s passage attempts to correct what state lawmakers called a “historic injustice” from 175 years ago, when the U.S. government auctioned off nearly 1,300 acres of Prairie Band land while Chief Shab-eh-nay was visiting relatives in Kansas. Illinois established the state park after it purchased the land with federal grant funds between 1969 and 1978.
Prairie Band Chairman Joseph Rupnick, the fourth great-grandson of Chief Shab-eh-nay, said the move showed that “healing and reconciliation are possible.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM MUSIC OF THE BAROQUE
Mozart & His Mentors April 7
Mozart has inspired many music lovers. But who inspired him? Join 
Music of the Baroque
 April 7 at the Harris Theater as Jane Glover leads 
“Mozart and His Mentors,”
 featuring his 
Paris
 Symphony alongside works by Hasse and Mysliveček. Mozart’s Concerto No. 13 with pianist 
Imogen Cooper,
 whose mentor was the great Alfred Brendel, completes a delightful evening. 
Save $10 with promo code WBEZ10.
3.
Chicago’s upcoming Small Business Expo will offer free resources for entrepreneurs
 
The city will hold a free online conference for small businesses Thursday, during a time when government resources are in flux because of federal restructuring, Amy Yee reports for the Chicago Sun-Times.
The conference includes a webinar on local, state and federal government resources for small businesses and will feature speakers from Cook County Small Business Source, Illinois Department of Commerce & Economic Opportunity and U.S. Small Business Administration.
Another webinar will discuss small business funding in the local community, including grants, low-interest loans and microloans. Panelists include neighborhood business development centers such as Allies for Community Business, Women’s Business Development Center and Score. 
Attendees can register at 
Chicago.gov/BizExpo
. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
4.
‘Into the Woods,’ ‘Coronation’ and ‘Seven Guitars’ are among the 2025 Non-Equity Jeff Award winners
 
Kokandy Productions was honored with five Non-Equity Jeff Awards last night, leading the pack of award winners at the 51st annual celebration of the city’s Non-Equity live theater productions, my colleague Miriam Di Nunzio writes for the Chicago Sun-Times.
The company’s staging of 
Into the Woods
 was honored as best production (musical or revue), best ensemble (musical or revue), best direction (musical or revue), best musical director (musical/revue) and artistic specialization (orchestrations).
Meanwhile, the award for best production of a play went to City Lit Theater Company for its staging of August Wilson’s 
Seven Guitars
, which also netted the award for best performer in a supporting role (play) for Robert Howard.
You can see the full list of winners in the link. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
‘The Listeners’ casts a soprano from Chicago to lead its convention-shattering story
 
A charismatic cult leader, lurid affairs, weed and ample cursing: It may sound like the type of bingeable plot you’d find on Netflix or a podcast feed. But these are the makings of a buzzy new opera, 
The Listeners
, which will have its Chicago premiere this week, my colleague Courtney Kueppers reports.
At the center of it all is the leading lady, a complex 40-something teacher, wife and mother named Claire. In opera, that character too is a novelty.
“Every opera is based on some young ingénue or a male role who is heroic in some type of way,” said Nicole Heaston, the soprano from Chicago who plays Claire. “There are no roles written for middle-aged women.”
Until now, that is. In a lot of ways, 
The Listeners
 is a course correction for opera, a 400-year-old art form that tends to lean on the hits, mostly created centuries ago by white, male composers. [
WBEZ
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
Trump administration officials texted live attack plans to a group chat in a secure app that included a journalist. [
AP
]
United Airlines will raise fees for its lounges and rewards credit cards. [
CNBC
]
A progressive TikTokker has launched a bid to unseat 9th District Rep. Jan Schakowsky. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
For the second year in a row, Naperville was named America’s best city to live in. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
Asked about the new dance work 
ABORT
, Kierah/KIKI King does not mince words. 
“I was impregnated when I was 17 and didn’t know I was pregnant until really later on, so I ended up having a late-term abortion,” the dance and movement artist told WBEZ.
King brashly titled their work 
ABORT
, which premieres at Links Hall on Thursday, double-billed through the weekend with a solo theater piece called 
Praise Music Sonogram
. 
ABORT
, which runs under an hour, draws from club culture, with audio from the DJ Professor Wrecks. King said the work celebrates the sonic legacy of Black women in rock, as well as the urgency of reproductive justice. [
WBEZ
]
 
Tell me something good
 
I was just in India and saw the Taj Mahal, and it absolutely lived up to the hype as one of the most beautiful buildings in the world. That has me wondering, what’s something that left you in awe while traveling, whether it’s an iconic landmark or a unique experience?
Nancy writes:
“A landmark that left me in awe: you see pictures of the St. Louis Arch and it looks interesting. Standing below it you can't believe it's possible to go up in the little elevator (not for the claustrophobic!) and actually walk around at the top — I was amazed!”
Brian writes:
“The most amazing thing I’ve seen was the Northern Lights, on the banks of the Yukon River just outside of Whitehorse. The lights shimmered and dimmed, then exploded in all the colors, and this went on for nearly 3 hours. It was mid-September and by midnight when the show was over my feet were (literally) frozen to the ground.”
And Louise writes:
“Everytime I see the Grand Tetons I’m in awe. So majestic & beautiful but unfortunately due to global warming the mountains now have less, if no snow at all.”
Feel free to email me, and your response may be included in the newsletter this week.
Thanks for reading and have a nice night! I'll see you tomorrow.
— Bianca Cseke
The Rundown is reader-funded.

subject: Why Lawyers Are Standing Up To Big Law
body:
Plus: Are AI Agents Tools Or Workers? | A Potential U.S. Science Brain Drain | Work Group Chats Gone Wrong 
BECOME A MEMBER
 • 
Newsletters
 • 
MyForbes
President Donald Trump’s latest target? Big law firms. But their associates and other legal professionals are trying to fight back. 
Since he took office in January, Trump has signed a number of executive orders restricting access and government business with some of the biggest and most prestigious law firms in the country. The common thread: They all worked for clients that President Trump “disfavors,” including Hillary Clinton, George Soros and former special counsel Jack Smith. 
Such actions have stirred up concern, contempt and even panic amongst legal professionals. But it was President Trump’s second 
executive order
—one that removes the security clearance of Perkins Coie attorneys and requires federal contractors to disclose any business they retain with the law firm—that was the final straw for many in the field.
Take Rachel Cohen, a third-year finance associate at the Chicago offices of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom who, in a 
now-viral email and LinkedIn post
, put in her two-weeks notice and called out her employer for not standing up to the president. She’s one of over 1,500 signatories to a 
letter
 calling on big law leadership to join the American Bar Association in condemning Trump’s actions.  
Perkins Coie is one of the law firms taking action, and after hiring Williams & Connolly—known for aggressively fighting the federal government—to represent them in court, won a 
preliminary injunction
 on the executive order.   
But others aren’t. Shortly after Trump signed an executive order similarly restricting Paul Weiss, the global law firm announced it would stop all DEI programs and commit $40 million worth of pro-bono work to the Trump Administration. The executive order was then removed. Once again, legal professionals were not happy. 
But Trump has only increased his fight against some of the biggest law firms in the country since then. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sent a letter to 20 “big law” firms last week 
over their DEI policies.
 On Friday, the president 
instructed
 Attorney General Pam Bondi to “seek sanctions against attorneys and law firms who engage in frivolous, unreasonable, and vexatious litigation against the United States” or U.S. executive agencies. 
Where the profession goes from here is unclear, with associates ready but afraid to publicly speak up and firms facing seemingly “
existential threats”
 from these executive orders. And all of this is occurring in a year where law school applications are 
up 20%
. 
Maria Gracia Santillana Linares 
Careers Reporter
Follow me on 
Forbes.com
WORK SMARTER
Practical insights and advice from 
Forbes 
staff and contributors to help you succeed in your job, accelerate your career and lead smarter
Shut down 
office drama 
with four simple words: 
“Just the facts, please.”
Could 
burning bridges
 actually be the
 
right career move?
Tips and tricks on 
using ChatGPT
 
to improve your workflow. 
Q&A With Lattice CEO Sarah Franklin
"I’m not saying I’m more intelligent, but I’m much wiser," Mackey tells Forbes as he re-enters "start-up mode."
  
Lattice
Are AI Agents Tools Or Digital Workers?
Read Article
Last July, Lattice CEO Sarah Franklin received a flurry of online criticism after announcing on LinkedIn that the people management company would start creating performance review packages for “digital workers.” But as more companies releases AI agents, was she ahead of the curve? I spoke with Franklin about Lattice’s own AI products and how the conversation around AI workers has changed in the last eight months. Our conversation has been edited for length and clarity, and you can find a full version of it here. 
What has been the biggest shift in the HR and people space with the rise of AI?
We’re moving into this AI economy where it’s no longer just about data, it’s really about intelligence. It’s not about how we automate, it’s around autonomy. And in that frame, the most important thing is the question around trust. 
How do you build trust with a machine then?
It’s the same way we always have––with time, doing things well and showing up. I think a good analogy is the evolution of ATMs and tellers, especially with HR files. You think about money––that’s something you really wanna trust somebody with. The idea of going into a bank and depositing your money was something that required a different level of trust than for you to go to a metal box and have it handle your money. That took time to develop. It’s the same with AI. 
But what’s different is that AI adoption is happening fast, so we can’t afford mistakes. We can’t afford to lose trust at all. So we have to be transparent, we have to be accountable, and we have to continuously ask ourselves hard questions. Not just how can it be helpful, but how can it be hurtful, to avoid losing that trust. And that’s the same thing with AI is that we have to hold it to transparent accountability, especially the people that are implementing and deploying the AI in our business. 
It sounds like what you tried to do with the 
digital worker records last summer
. Why do you think it was so contentious at the time?
We’re really in a whole new era with a digital workforce. What’s very interesting is that we usually think of these shifts needing huge new technology to be developed that is going to be very complicated to roll out. The difference is this technology, AI, is not complicated to roll out and it’s quite simple to interact with. The big lift is making the mental shift and thinking, “oh, my colleague may be a person or it also may be an AI digital worker.” That is mind blowing! 
Last July, when we saw this coming, people weren’t ready for it then. And not to say they’re even ready for it now, but they’re understanding what is happening. There’s still a big lack of education for what a digital worker would be like, even with AI agents.
How are you defining AI agents?
AI agents can answer questions. Right now at Lattice, we’re really oriented towards being helpful and answering questions. And the next step is when it becomes autonomous. This is where the trust thing is really important. When agents start acting and talking and making decisions on your behalf, and you don’t know with certainty what the outcome is going to be, that requires a whole different level of trust. It requires a whole different level of accountability and transparency.
What does that trust and accountability look like in practice?
Well on a practical level, holding the tools accountable means very simply writing down what their job is and what they’re supposed to be doing. This is something that we haven’t had for decades––accountable software for what they’re supposed to be doing. They’re supposed to be saving us time and money, but it hasn’t really fulfilled that promise in the sense of making our lives easier. So the first thing we need to do is write it down. What do we expect the AI to do? Second thing we need to do is write down and know who is going to be in charge of managing the AI. Third, we need to regularly evaluate the performance of the AI, just as we do any piece of our business or work. So it’s not a complicated new thing, it’s what we do now, but we have to just start. Because we can’t lose control of the AI. We need to know who’s managing it so it’s working for us
. 
Sounds a lot like job descriptions and performance reviews! So ultimately, are AI agents tools or digital workers?
AI is a technology, it is not human. AI is not a person. It is getting very good at imitating and understanding, and being able to reason similarly to how a human can. I think of police officers that go to work with their dog––the K-9 units. They work together with an animal because the animal can sniff out certain things humans cannot. 
The future in my mind is that we will all be different and have different functions, but we need to learn how to collaborate together. We need to understand each other’s jobs, functions and hold each other accountable to our performance and be transparent about how we’re doing. So AI is not a human, but AI is an entity that we will work with, just like the police officers with their dogs.  
TOUCH BASE
 
Hegseth Says ‘Nobody Was Texting War Plans’ After Atlantic Editor Claims He Was Part Of Signal Chat
 
(Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)
 
News from the world of work
Work group chats gone wrong: 
The top national security officials of the United States were caught red-handed this week when the editor-in-chief of 
The Atlantic
 
revealed he’d been mistakenly added
 to an encrypted Signal chat (whose messages were set to disappear after a week) discussing plans to bomb Houthi rebels in Yemen. 
Defense secretary Pete Hegseth has denied
 the existence of such messages, despite the 
National Security Council saying
 the messages appeared to be an authentic communication chain and was reviewing the matter. 
DOGE cuts are not only impacting federal workers. 
Consulting firm Accenture warned investors last week 
that the 
cuts may affect the company’s sales and revenue
.
 
Revenue from the federal government accounted for 16% of the company’s Americas revenue in the most recent fiscal year. 
Talk about an over-extended work trip. NASA astronauts 
successfully returned to Earth
 last week after a 285-day stay at the International Space Station. Originally scheduled to return in June 2024,
 their voyage home was delayed due to technical and staffing issues.   
AI literacy, conflict mitigation, adaptability and public speaking
 are among 
LinkedIn’s top in-demand skills this year.
 
The report comes on the heels of an increasingly AI-focused job market. And with professionals entering the workforce today on pace to hold twice as many jobs over the course of their careers compared to workers just 15 years ago, being adaptable and knowing how to effectively use AI are becoming more important skills than ever. 
The U.S. is becoming a 
slightly better
 country to work in as a woman,
 but with no federally mandated parental leave policy, it’s still lagging behind, according to 
The Economist
’s annual 
glass-ceiling index.
 
Topping the list this year is Sweden, which dethroned Iceland, as nearly half of all managerial positions in the European country are filled by women.  
NUMBER TO NOTE
79%
That’s how many employees say they’ve been 
catfished
 into taking a job, according to a report by job search platform 
Monster
, meaning that the job’s description, responsibilities or work culture was misrepresented.

subject: Remote Work Is the New Labor Battlefield (Wise Decision Maker Guide 148)
body:
Wise Decision Maker Guide 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
Greetings Monica,
Remote work is reshaping labor relations, with unions securing its permanence through collective bargaining. The Alphabet Workers Union (AWU) set a tech industry precedent by negotiating remote roles and workplace protections for Google Help contractors. In the public sector, the American Federation of Government Employees (AFGE) secured telework rights for Social Security Administration staff until 2029, boosting productivity amid staffing shortages. Globally, unions are addressing surveillance, work-life balance, and career equity in remote work agreements. 
These efforts signal a shift toward modernized labor activism, ensuring flexibility and protections for employees while strengthening unions' relevance in a digital workforce.
To learn more, check out this 
blog
.

video
 based on the blog:

,

.
 
Your Testimonials
You and others who gain value from Disaster Avoidance Experts 
services
 and thought leadership occasionally share testimonials about your experience, such as the one below. You can read more testimonials 
here
.
 
“We had the pleasure of co-hosting a webinar that was presented by Dr. Gleb. This webinar, using hybrid work to improve retention and productivity while cutting costs, was an excellent experience. He presented his research in a thoughtful and engaging way. He engaged with his attendees. He also gave them the opportunity to ask questions and give feedback at the end of the webinar. As a result, 
the survey feedback that we received following Dr. Gleb's presentation was resoundingly positive
. If you have the opportunity to work with Dr. Gleb, whether as a presenter or consultant in your organization, I highly recommend it.”
Brandie Laughner
, 
President of the Virtual Chapter of the Labor and Employment Relations Association
Schedule a Free Consultation
 
What's Up With Me
I was recently asked to be an expert witness in the killing of Amaree’ya Henderson, a Black American, by police during a routine traffic stop in Kansas City, Kansas. The police acted aggressively and escalated the situation, Henderson tried to drive away, and was then shot and killed. I was asked to explain the anxiety of Black Americans in response to discrimination and aggression by police, as well as the emotional distress experienced by his girlfriend, who was in the car with him, and his mother, who was on Facetime on the phone during the stop. 
I read the report on the incident, and then watched the
 
body cam footage
 
of the police officer doing the shooting, and my response to the body cam footage was, to me, surprisingly strong. I was already outraged by the report, but the body cam took it to another level, from intellectual, rational outrage, to something much more visceral. It gave me much more appreciation for why body cam footage needs to be made public: a picture (or video) is truly worth a thousand words, and grabs hold of you in a way that words don’t. We need to do our utmost to provide police with better training and guidance, and to incentivize municipalities to do so through legal court cases that punish police excessive use of force when police mess up. And we need to get cities to deploy body cam footage widely and release it publicly, when the family of the victim allows, to address abuses. 
Would love to get your feedback on what you found most useful about this edition of the “Wise Decision Maker Guide” - simply reply to this email.
Decisively Yours,
Dr. Gleb
 
Dr. Gleb Tsipursky
CEO of Disaster Avoidance Experts
PS: Are we connected on LinkedIn? If not, 
please add me
.

Never Go With Your Gut: How Pioneering Leaders Make the Best Decisions and Avoid Business Disasters

(New Harbinger, 2020)

body:
Hello all,
I'm reaching out to give you the address for the game this Thursday at 5:00pm against U-High. We will be playing at IIT 
(
2967 S Michigan Ave, Chicago, IL 60616). The bus will be leaving DCP at 3:30pm. 
Best,
Coach Hinkamp
On Sun, Mar 23, 2025 at 12:47 PM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
I hope you've all thawed out after yesterday's double header! Thank you to those that were able to come out and support us in the cold! I thought it was a great start to the season! 
This week is busy with games Monday-Thursday and then again on Saturday. This week's game/practice schedule is as follows:
-Monday 3/24: Game 6:30pm vs St. Pat's @ Reed-Dunning (Bus leaves DCP at 4:00pm)
-Tuesday 3/25: Game 4:30pm @ Whitney Young (Bus leaves DCP at 3:00pm)
-Wednesday 3/26: Game 4:30pm @ Niles West (Bus leaves DCP at 3:00pm)
-Thursday 3/27: Game 5:00pm @ U-High (Bus departure time TBD, will let boys know ASAP)
-Friday 3/28: Practice 3:00pm - 5:00pm @ Kerry Wood Field (might have to shift time and location)
-Saturday 3/29: Game 12:00pm @ Schaumburg (Bud departure time TBD, will let boys know ASAP)
I will follow up with another email when I hear back from Coach Colon regarding Thursday's bus departure, Friday's practice time and location, and Saturday's bus departure. 
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp
On Thu, Mar 13, 2025 at 7:03 AM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
It was very nice meeting many of you last night! As promised, here is the updated email chain (hoping I've got it correct this time!). As a reminder, I will share the practice schedule for the rest of the week, as well as the week of Spring Break:
Thursday 3/13: No Practice (hoping the boys go to the basketball game)
Friday 3/14: Practice 5:30pm - 7:00pm @ Clark Park
Saturday 3/15: Practice 8:00am - 10:00am @ Kerry Wood Field
SPRING BREAK
Monday 3/17: No Practice
Tuesday 3/18: No Practice
Wednesday 3/19: No Practice
Thursday 3/20: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Friday 3/21: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Saturday 3/22: Games 10:00am / 12:00pm (Double Header) vs Taft @ Laramie Park (Skokie)
I will be sending another email today or tomorrow (whenever I'm able to get this information confirmed) regarding the practice times and locations for Thursday and Friday of Spring Break. 
Again, thank you all for everything you've done/will do for the boys and team this year! 
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp
