subject: Learn What the Future Holds for the 8(a) Program
body:
Learn What the Future Holds for the 8(a) Program                                                    
Learn What the Future Holds for the 8(a) Program
 
Learn What the Future Holds for the 8(a) Program
 
Learn More
 
Current 8(a) Conundrum
The new administration is making changes to how procurement is going to work moving forward. They have already made large cuts to DEI programs. One of the major fears disadvantaged businesses face is how these changes will affect the 8(a) program, and should they even bother to join?
Past 8(a) Environment
During the Biden administration a pledge was made that the administration would increase the amount of federal procurement from the 5% congressionally mandated goal to 15%. Let’s look at what the reality was for 8(a) spending levels in 2024.
RESULTS:
 Eligible non-discretionary federal business sales for 2024 were $637 billion. The 8(a)-program accounted for $37 billion of these dollars or 5.8% of eligible federal sales. Very strong results for the 8(a) program however a large gap remained between the prior 5% target and the 15% the Biden administration was wanting to achieve. But on a firm-by-firm basis this resulted in a very sizeable average sales figure of $6.4 million dollars.
Future of 8(a) Program
SBA Kelly Loeffler Day One Priorities:
https://www.sba.gov/article/2025/02/24/sba-administrator-loeffler-issues-memo-day-one-priorities
Contained in this memo is the following pertinent language as it relates to the 8(a) program:
13.Promoting fair competition by returning 8(a) contracting goals to statutory levels: 
The previous Administration increased the 8(a) federal contracting goal for Small Disadvantaged Businesses to an all-time high of 15%. This action unfairly tipped the scales against any small business that did not qualify as “disadvantaged,” negatively impacting many veteran-owned small businesses. As part of a broader effort to support competition and equal access to federal contracting for all small business owners, SBA has returned the 8(a) SDB contracting goal to its statutory level of 5%.
This would result in average sales per 8(a) firm of $5.4MM
This basically returns the 8(a) program to its 2023 numbers. However, what we are currently seeing in the marketplace is a reluctance for 8(a) firms to join the program because many fear the 8(a) program is going away and based upon the Loeffler Memo this should not be a concern.
Additionally, because of Covid 8(a) firms received an additional year in the 8(a) program. Therefore, even if the number of firms applying each year stays the same, and this is doubtful, the 5,800 figure is likely to decrease by 10% over the next few years. Less firms with the same federal spending with 8(a) firms will also increase the 8(a) per firm’s average sales.
Contrarian Thinking
We have interviewed federal buyers in the past that simply put rely on the 8(a) program’s sole source capabilities to make quick purchases. Without this ability many of the smaller procurements would take much longer and have a much higher administrative burden. Simply put, the federal government needs the 8(a) program to function efficiently. 
The old stock market saying “buy when the blood is in the streets” may hold true for the 8(a) program as it currently sits. Over the next six months we foresee things returning to normal with the 8(a) program and those firms that acted now will be well ahead of the game!
Mark Ryan & Todd Luttenegger
859-442-3300

subject: Payment Preferences In Education
body:
Survey reveals the views of consumers.
Do school payment systems impact the education experience? New research suggests they can.
The education payment ecosystem extends far beyond tuition. It can include paying for extracurriculars for high schoolers, cafeteria lunches for grade schoolers or room and board for undergrads. As a result of these myriad touchpoints, school payment systems have the ability to affect the student experience. 
To learn more 
about the evolving payment preferences in education, American Express and Forbes Insights asked consumers to evaluate their experience making education-related payments over the past six months. 
Here are five key findings:  
1. MULTISTEP PAYMENT PROCESSES CAN TURN OFF CONSUMERS
41% of consumers feel frustrated when multiple steps are involved in making an education-related online payment, 
and 21% said the process took too long.
2. NEARLY HALF REPORTED PAYMENT PROBLEMS
46% of consumers reported a range of issues when making their payment in the last six months, 
including 14% who said they failed to complete an online, email or text payment.
3. FRUSTRATION ALSO ARISES WHEN CREDIT CARDS AREN’T ACCEPTED
48% of consumers said they feel frustrated when credit card payment options are not offered.
4. PREFERRED PAYMENT METHODS MATTER TO CONSUMERS
86% of consumers said it’s important that their education provider offer the payment method they prefer,
 and 67% said they would set up recurring payments or autopay if given the option.
5. LIMITED PAYMENT OPTIONS MIGHT AFFECT STUDENT RETENTION 
Nearly 1 in 4 consumers would consider switching education providers, including camps and extracurricular activities, if they couldn’t use their preferred method. 
Institutions that fail to offer payment options risk more than delayed payments: They potentially risk losing students altogether.
WHAT THE DATA TELLS US
Education payment systems need to accommodate the payment preferences and varying needs of the students and parents who rely on them. Consumers most of all want a simple process when paying with the method they most prefer. 
  
Getty Images
Consumer Choice: The Case For Streamlined Payment Solutions In Non-Retail Industries
For perspective into all seven industries studied in the nationwide consumer survey conducted by American Express and Forbes Insights, read our complementary report.
Explore the Report
 
SURVEY METHODOLOGY
American Express and Forbes Insights asked 687 consumers to evaluate their preferences and pain points when making education-related payments over the past six months. The exploration was part of a larger, comprehensive survey of 2,507 U.S. based consumers across key non-retail industries.

subject: The most exciting storylines to watch in 2025
body:
Plus: Ohtani to resume pitching rehab
Tuesday, March 25
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS
 
Get your popcorn ready: Here are 2025's most scintillating storylines
 
A mystical unicorn returns to the mound. The game's purest hitter starts fresh crosstown. Up-and-comers break new ground, and some veteran stars were lost -- but now are found. Suffice to say, the 2025 season isn't short on intrigue.
 
Ohtani to resume pitching program with long-term view
Burnes at the back of rotation? Here's why

'Frustrated' McClanahan eager to return ... but timetable remains uncertain
Witt a 'perfect fit' for 1st Major League Play Ball Ambassador
Betts, battling illness, takes a turn for the better

How do Opening Day starters stack up? We've got 'em ranked
 
Eighteen of the 30 Opening Day starters received at least one vote from our panel, but only one can top the list.
 
The secret to doing damage as a hitter? It lies in the point of contact
 
The latest Statcast release on Baseball Savant highlights two areas of hitting that have been discussed basically forever, yet never really with accessible data: Where does a hitter stand, and where does he make contact?
 
Comparing the industry's 2025 Top 100 Prospects lists
 
Get a sense of the industry's consensus top prospects -- and most divisive youngsters -- with this analysis of Top 100 rankings.
 
Sarah Edwards becomes first woman to be on-field coach in Asian pro baseball
 
The first female coach in the Phillies system has also played softball for the Italian women's national team and baseball for the USA women's national team. Now she'll be embarking on another first.

Taste of Iceland is an annual event celebrating Icelandic culture across North America. With food tastings, film screenings, concerts, and more, attendees can experience a taste of Iceland closer to home.
 
Get a taste

Viewpoint
, a group photo exhibition exploring a different side of Iceland. It gathers a diverse range of work by a group of Icelandic artists, each offering their own unique perspective.
The images capture moments often overlooked: chasms in the landscape, desolate fields, mundane urban life, and striking juxtapositions of nature and human presence.
The exhibition is open from 12 - 5 PM and is open and free for all.

subject: Don't Miss this NYWICI Event! Corporate Social Responsibility and Communications, 04/02/2025
body:
Dear Monica,
Have you registered yet for NYWICI's latest in person event?
A New Path Forward for Sustainability Comms
Wednesday, April 2, 2025
4:00 – 7:00PM
 
Location:  
Idealist.org, 389 Fifth Ave, NYC
Over the past decade, sustainability has been recognized as a crucial part of a company’s operational model, significantly impacting ways of working, corporate reputation, and engagement with both internal and external stakeholders. However, recent abrupt changes in public policy, sentiment, and discourse have introduced tension and uncertainty regarding sustainability and other social impact initiatives, as well as the communications surrounding them.
Currently, companies and organizations are attempting to navigate these challenging conditions by adopting various strategies–from maintaining their commitments to simply rebranding or renaming their policies to fully abandoning initiatives–each presenting its own distinct advantages and disadvantages. During this unprecedented period, how should we, as communicators, adjust our approach to sustainability and social impact communications and marketing when fear and uncertainty are muddying the waters? What new challenges are anticipated from our customers, investors, and employees? And what lessons can we draw from these experiences for the future?
Moderator
Catherine Addo
, 
Social Impact Strategist • Impact Media Founder 
Featured Speakers
Sara Adams
, Chief Communications Officer, Chief Executives for Corporate Purpose
Emily Goodstein
,
 
Founder + CEO, Greater Good Strategy
Reed Handley
,
 Executive VP, The Bliss Group
Agenda:
4:00 - 4:50 pm: Welcome Drinks and Networking 
4:50 - 4:55 pm: Opening Remarks
4:55 - 5:45 pm: Panel Discussion 
  
5:45 - 6:10 pm: Audience Q&A 
 
6:10 - 7:00 pm: Networking 
Price:  $25/$50 member/nonmember 
Join the conversation, connect and network with fellow communicators.
Click here to register. 
I hope to see you there.
Best regards,
Donna-Jean
Donna-Jean Plante, CAE
Executive Director, New York Women in Communications (NYWICI)

subject: DePaul JV Baseball: Introducing Team Parents and Planning for the Season
body:
Hello all:
My name is Monica Marcel (mom to Ash, 2028) and our family is new to DePaul College Prep. It's great to be a part of this community and we are excited for the season.
Andrea Gosz (mom to Andrew, 2028) and I are JV Team Parents this season, and if any of you would like to join us in this role please reach out! 
Our understanding from Coach Hinkamp is that Team Parents' primary role is to help coordinate meals/snacks, etc. Coach asked us to stay away from greasy foods, to remember any dietary restrictions boys may have, and mentioned that meals/snacks are not something we have to do for every game. 
With that guidance in mind: we were thinking that Crustables, protein bars and Gatorades would be fine most days, with an occasional Jersey Mike's or Jimmy John's delivery thrown in; for example, on a day when the bus leaves school right at 3pm for a further away field, since kids won't have time to grab something.
Since both Andrea and I are new to what JV baseball parents at DCP might have done in years passed, we'd really appreciate hearing any particular traditions, expectations, or experiences you think we might build on or incorporate. 
To cover costs for the 20 boys on the roster and 30+ games on the schedule, we could: 
Use a SignUp Genius for each family to choose particular games to be individually responsible for
Collect funds upfront from all families, for Team Parents to then draw from to cover as many games as best we can
So to recap:
Please let us know if you'd like to join as Team Parent and/or if you have particular ideas for making the 2025 JV season special 
Please let us know if your child has any dietary restrictions. 
If you have a preference between 1 and 2 above for covering costs -- or if you have another ideas whatsoever -- please let us know that as well
We'll get to work on making our plan this week and get something out to you asap. 
Look for this same message on Game Changer, to ensure 'all our bases are covered' (pun fully intended!!!).
Thank you! And #GoRams
Monica and Andrea

subject: Chicago immigrants’ health care in jeopardy
body:
Plus, a new history of Lollapalooza. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Monday - March 24, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Bianca Cseke
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! It’s Monday, and I’m back after visiting five countries in two weeks. Here’s what you need to know today.
  
1.
Health coverage for Chicago-area immigrants is threatened in Gov. JB Pritzker’s budget proposal
 
Nearly 33,000 Illinoisans without legal status — including 22,000 in Cook County — could be left without health care if lawmakers approve a plan to eliminate a costly program that has covered thousands of people since COVID-19 hit, my colleagues Elvia Malagón and Mitchell Armentrout report.
The state’s Health Benefits for Immigrant Adults provides health insurance for immigrants between the ages of 42 to 64, but costs have ballooned while Illinois faces a massive overall budget shortfall. Pritzker’s office estimates cutting the benefits will save $330 million.
But a broad coalition of groups aims to get immigrant adult coverage back into the budget, saying fewer people with coverage means longer wait times for care. That, in turn, means higher costs and thin resources stretched thinner, according to Cyruss Winnett, chief public affairs officer of the Illinois Primary Health Care Association.
“Everybody needs to be clear-eyed about the implications this decision will have on our service capacity and our ability to meet the needs of our communities,” Winnett said. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
2.
Doctors and patients are battling long COVID five years on
 
Symptoms like dizziness, brain fog and extreme fatigue still plague about 1 in 5 U.S. adults who have had COVID-19, according to The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
As my colleague Araceli Gómez-Aldana reports, medical experts at Chicago’s Shirley Ryan AbilityLab hope their comprehensive approach can provide solace to the invisible toll long COVID takes on their patients.
Marie Saxon, a senior speech-language pathologist, and her team use what they call “pacing” or “symptom management.”
“We try to figure out what that means for each person,” Saxon said. “So, that might mean for someone, I can work on my spreadsheet for 90 minutes, but then I start making mistakes, I start getting a headache. So, we need to figure out what that break is and then how soon after can you return to that activity.” [
WBEZ
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM POLYMATH UNIVERSITY
Polymath University: Enroll in Summer or Fall Courses Now
Legacy higher education offers a business model from the 1950s and an educational model from the 1880s. We've built a new nonprofit university in Chicago from the ground up – Polymath University – that is interdisciplinary, apprenticeship based, and debt-free. We call it, "ROTC for the private sector" and we're launching our first Master's level courses this Summer.
Register for a Systems Thinking course this summer
Attend an info session
Follow us on LinkedIn
3.
Mayor Johnson accepted campaign contributions from a lawyer whose firm has pending lawsuits against City Hall
 
Chicago lawyer Antonio Romanucci has become a relatively well-known civil rights and personal injury attorney, handling high-profile lawsuits including the one that led to a $27 million settlement for the family of George Floyd.
As my colleague Robert Herguth writes for the Chicago Sun-Times, Romanucci & Blandin, LLC, represents clients in nine pending lawsuits against City Hall.
Even though the city’s Law Department often helps decide if and how to settle these legal cases, Johnson continues to accept campaign contributions from Romanucci and other employees of his law firm, records show.
While the mayor is not supposed to accept campaign donations from city contractors under municipal ethics rules, there’s no prohibition on taking campaign cash from lawyers. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
4.
Chicago’s piping plover monitors help the endangered birds feather the nest at Montrose Beach
 
As winter ends, piping plovers will soon return to their nesting grounds in Chicago, which means monitors are finishing their preparations and new members are being trained, Rafaela Jinich reports for the Chicago Sun-Times.
During nesting season, usually May until August, more than 100 volunteers take turns in two-hour shifts from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m., keeping an eye on the birds, ensuring their nesting sites remain undisturbed and engaging with the public.
“There’s something special about these birds. They’re so small, so vulnerable, and yet they travel incredible distances and return year after year,” said Eden Essex, who has been monitoring since plovers returned to Chicago in 2019. “Once you start watching them, you can’t help but care.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
A new book about Lollapalooza is an entertaining history of the rise of alternative rock
 
Lollapalooza: The Unscripted Story of Alternative Rock’s Wildest Festival
 includes hundreds of interviews with musicians, promoters and others, The Associated Press reports.
When Lollapalooza was introduced in 1991 as a traveling music festival, “it was as if a switch had been flipped,” authors Richard Bienstock and Tom Beaujour write. Conceived as a farewell tour for Jane’s Addiction, the festival introduced audiences to acts such as Pearl Jam, Rage Against the Machine, Smashing Pumpkins and Soundgarden.
The book also details the work that went into producing a traveling festival (an unusual concept at the time), Lollapalooza’s use of a second stage for additional acts to play and the village set up to introduce festivalgoers to political and cultural advocacy.
Perhaps most jarring in 2025: the $27.50 ticket price for the inaugural festival in 1991. [
AP
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
Concerns about espionage are rising as President Donald Trump and Elon Musk fire thousands of federal workers with inside knowledge of the government. [
AP
]
Genetic testing company 23andMe filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy, raising questions about where its troves of genomic data will end up. [
AP
]
Mia Love, the first Black woman elected to Congress as a Republican, has died at 49. [
KUER
]
Tokyo’s official cherry blossom spotters have confirmed the first blooms of the season. [
AP
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
It’s easy to overlook the Yukon, on the southwest corner of Clark and Van Buren streets, because the building is overshadowed by the Metropolitan Correctional Center, the triangle-shaped high-rise jail built in 1975.
But from one particular vantage point (two stories up, on the exit stairs from the elevated CTA stop at LaSalle and Van Buren), you can see its story unfold, WBEZ contributor Dennis Rodkin writes for 
Reset
.
The Yukon is a two-story structure built in 1898 by the Boston-based real estate investor who also put up the Rookery, the Monadnock and the Marquette in Chicago. The family that’s owned the Yukon for more than half a century put it up for sale. Now, the property taxes are delinquent and at least three tenants have vacated their spaces in recent months. [
WBEZ
]
 
Tell me something good
 
I was just in India and saw the Taj Mahal, and it absolutely lived up to the hype as one of the most beautiful buildings in the world. That has me wondering, what’s something that left you in awe while traveling, whether it’s an iconic landmark or a unique experience?
Feel free to email me, and your response may be included in the newsletter this week.
Thanks for reading and have a nice night! I'll see you tomorrow.
— Bianca Cseke
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting. 
DONATE TODAY
©Chicago Public Media Inc 848 East Grand Ave, Navy Pier Chicago, IL 60611
Unsubscribe from The Daily Rundown
 |

subject: - Why do I do what I do?
body:
Spoiler: It's corny. And authentic.‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­‌   ­
 
 
A little context about some big news...
Way, way back in high school when I got the “What do you want to be when you grow up?” question, I recall answering, “I don’t know yet but farther down the road I could see myself teaching.” All I really knew was that I wanted to make a difference in people’s lives. And a positive one at that.
 
I knew classroom teaching wasn’t my sweet spot, but I dabbled in it on three continents before I found my way to transformational training and facilitation for adults, and a few years later when I became MBTI and coaching certification Sparks of Change was born. I’ve long known I am not the one to lead the movement, but my role is to support and spark, if you will, others to be and do their best. And, in the past two years a new identity emerged as I became a trauma-informed coach and healer, developing myself into a somatic and spiritual leader.
As coach, facilitator, trainer, instructional designer and healer—my role is to help people get along just a little better. Corny factor acknowledged, this is my bit towards world peace. 
Psst:
­
Read the gory details of my journey summarized in pithy bullet points.
­
About Me
 
Last summer I started itching to figure out how to communicate the common thread to my roles and skills.  
Thus, with help from the amazing folks at 
Perspektiiv
, 
I am thrilled to launch the new Sparks of Change website!
­
Check it out now! 
 
­
I facilitate connection
 to yourself, to others and with Spirit.  
I take a holistic and inclusive approach to wellness, experiential learning and facilitation for individuals and groups interested in transformation and wellbeing. 
Promo code: CONNECTION
To celebrate and be of service to those who know me and those will be new,  I am gifting everyone a deep discount to come work with me. 
 
Use code CONNECTION for a 25% discount on any offering. Must be purchased by April 15, 2025 but you can schedule sessions for any time, they won't expire.
 
This is heart work, I offer a money back guarantee if you are not satisfied. 
 
Let's Connect Now
­
I would love to support and learn along with you, 
 
Joayne Nicole 
­
Sparks of Change
4509 Oakland Ave, 55407, Minneapolis

Kids Program Spotlights
 
Voice Classes for Kids
In Old Town School's kids voice classes, children explore meaningful, simple melodies of folk music traditions from around the world. Our approach values singing, active music making, and musical discovery as children build an extraordinary foundation for musical literacy and further musical study in vocal or instrumental music.

Fiddle Classes for Kids
The Kids Fiddle Program at Old Town School offers an engaging, fun-filled approach to learning fiddle. By combining elements of both fiddle and violin traditions, we create the perfect space for kids to explore music. Our unique kids fiddle classes draw from global folk traditions and the renowned Shinichi Suzuki method, ensuring students of all levels enjoy a joyful learning experience. PS - 
we have a dedicated fiddle summer camp too!

Dance Classes for Kids
Give your kiddo a whole new way to experience music in an Old Town School dance class! We've got offerings for all age ranges from 18 months to 12 years old, and our classes are perfect for children who have never danced before. Every teaching artist provides a supportive and collaborative space for young artists to express themselves. Dance education is for everybody and every body, so all ability levels are welcome!

subject: ONE MONTH AWAY: Seph Schlueter Counting My Blessings Tour in Palos Heights!
body:
Get your tickets today!
 
ONE MONTH AWAY!
Join Seph Schlueter on his first headline tour with special guest Jamie MacDonald, featuring songs from his debut EP, Counting My Blessings. Rooted in his journey of faith and shaped by years of worship leading, Seph’s music offers a simple but powerful message of hope. Don’t miss this opportunity to hear Seph live as he shares his journey, his songs, and his prayer for revival.
Thursday, April 24, 2025
Moraine Valley Church
Palos Heights, IL
BUY TICKETS
 
 
ABOUT SEPH SCHLUETER
For artist and songwriter Seph Schlueter, his debut single “Counting My Blessings” hitting No. 1 on Spotify Brazil’s Viral Playlist was beyond unexpected. It’s a story covered in God’s fingerprints, one Seph is all too happy to share. As a young high school graduate, Seph joined a missionary group/youth retreat in Ohio as a worship leader. “I gave my life to the Lord in high school,” Seph shares, “and made the decision to give Him my whole life. I joined Damascus to be a part of bringing revival to the Catholic church, for students and families to have a real encounter with Jesus.” As he grew in leadership at Damascus, Seph was also developing his songwriting skills. The more he wrote, the more his songs gained traction within the Damascus and Catholic community. Friends encouraged him to send his songs to record labels in Nashville. “I didn’t know anyone in the music industry or where to send my music. An artist I followed on Instagram made a post thanking a bunch of people at her label, so I wrote down all their names and sent my song to them as well as a bunch of artists I looked up to. That usually doesn’t work too well,” Seph jokes. For Seph, launching Counting My Blessings on the heels of a viral hit only adds to his prayer for these songs. “I hope this EP gives people a framework for Jesus. These songs are my loaves and my fish for the Lord. If He wants to multiply it, that’s great. Multiplication isn’t my job, faithfulness is. If no one on earth heard my songs but only heaven sang them, that would be enough.” 
BUY TICKETS
 
ABOUT JAMIE MACDONALD
Jamie MacDonald is living her dream as a signed artist with Capitol Christian Music Group, creating music that inspires and uplifts. With a soulful voice and raw, heartfelt lyrics, songs like “A Million Chances” and “Desperate” tell stories of redemption and hope, drawn from her own journey. That journey hasn’t been easy. Raised in Michigan in a chaotic home, Jamie faced loss, addiction, and heartbreak. A church camp as a pre-teen offered her a glimpse of hope, but she struggled for years, falling into addiction and losing her way. It wasn’t until she cried out to God in her darkest moment that her life began to turn around. Since then, Jamie has poured her faith and story into her music. Along the way, she worked in prison ministry, and found her authentic sound in Gospel-inspired melodies. Now back in Nashville—the city where she was born—Jamie’s music is a beacon of hope for anyone searching for their own second chance. 
BUY TICKETS
 
 
 
 
Important Ticket Info: 
There has been an increase in fraudulent and unlawful scams around concert ticket sales online. To ensure everyone has an official ticket to the event through proper channels, we recommend you purchase your tickets through the official ticketing outlet for your event. Any purchases through 3rd parties or 3rd party ticketing sites are not guaranteed by TPR. and limits your ability to receive up to date information for the event and any necessary assistance.

subject: New York Women in Communications Unveils 55th Annual Matrix Honorees
body:
An Exceptional Class of Leading Lumanaries Setting New Standards 
 
 
New York Women in Communications Unveils 55th Annual Matrix Honorees 
An Exceptional Class of Leading Lumanaries Setting New Standards 
 
New York Women in Communications
 (NYWICI), the premier organization for female communications professionals, is proud to announce the honorees for its 2025 Matrix Awards, which will take place on the evening of Tuesday, May 20, 2025, at the Ziegfeld Ballroom in Manhattan. This year’s theme, “Leading Luminaries,” celebrates and highlights the narratives shared by the honorees who lead by example, never lose sight of their goals, and illuminate a path forward for future generations. 
 
The 2025 NYWICI Matrix Honorees include: 
Leslie Berland, EVP, Chief Marketing Officer, Verizon 
Teneshia Jackson Warner, Founder and CEO of Egami Group 
Dustee Jenkins, Chief Public Affairs Officer, Spotify  
Lucy Kaylin, Editorial Director of Hearst Magazines 
Nkechi Okoro Carroll, Writer, Showrunner, Producer 
Kristen Welker, Moderator of NBC’s Meet the Press 
﻿
Bellamy Young, Actress and Advocate 
The Matrix Awards, established to recognize outstanding achievement and women who exemplify exceptional leadership, stands as NYWICI’s flagship event and primary fundraiser. 
The communications, media, and marketing industries are facing unprecedented challenges and change, and we must keep up with this acceleration. In times of rapid change, leadership is paramount. "We are proud to honor seven phenomenal women who are not only keeping up with the pace of change but are leading the change,” said NYWICI President Brandi Boatner. "This year’s recipients demonstrate excellence in leadership that defines the Matrix Awards. These women are redefining the landscape and are not just shaping the future but illuminating it with their brilliance, unwavering passion and dedication to their craft."
learn more
 
As New York City’s largest organization of professional women in the communications industry, NYWICI prioritizes cultivating the next generation of communications leaders. In addition to the Matrix honorees, NYWICI’s 2025 college scholarship recipients will be recognized at the event. To date, NYWICI has awarded more than $2 million in scholarship support nearly 400 young women pursuing communications-related degrees and careers. 
Now in its 55th year, the Matrix Awards have recognized and celebrated female leaders across the communications and the arts, 
including 
Kristen Chenoweth, Nina Garcia, Hoda Kotb, Gwen Stefani, Clarissa Ward, Judy Woodruff, Halle Berry, and Gloria Steinem. While honorees come from a variety of industries and backgrounds, all are leaders in their respective fields, resilient rulebreakers and champions of change for female empowerment.  
For more information on registration, donations, and sponsorship opportunities, please visit 
NYWICI.org
. 
  
  
  
  
 
 
 
 
New York Women in Communications | 
1660 International Drive, Suite 600
 | 
McLean, VA 22102 US

subject: 👀 The hidden message in your video background
body:
Your virtual presence sends signals—are they the right ones?
 
View this email in your browser
 
Your virtual presence sends signals -
are they the right ones?
 
Blurred? Branded? Revealing?
Your video background is saying more than you think.
In 2025, 
virtual presence
 is no longer optional - it’s a critical leadership skill.
And your video background?
It’s a subtle, but powerful, part of that presence.
💡 What the research says:
▪️ Neutral backgrounds can signal competence - but may feel cold.
▪️ Personalized backgrounds increase warmth and connection.
▪️ Warmth boosts perceptions of service quality - 
without hurting your credibility.
▪️ BUT: Avoid polarizing visuals (🕷️ 🐍) - they distract and can backfire.
 
No perfect setup? No problem.
▪️You don't need a magazine-worthy home office to build connection.
▪️A thoughtfully crafted 
virtual
 background can still reflect who you are—your values, interests, or personality.
👉 Try this: add a favorite quote or a favorite image to your virtual background to create a personal touch.
It’s not about perfection - it’s about being intentional.
𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗯𝗶𝗴 𝗽𝗶𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲.
Virtual leadership requires 
thoughtful digital presence.
 
Knowing how to influence, engage, and build relationships through a screen is a competitive advantage.
I’ve been leading distributed teams while working remotely for over 14 years.
I use my video background to humanize virtual interactions - family photos, travel momentos, artwork, and hobbies spark conversation and connection.
Your action step:
Take 2 minutes to audit your video background.
Ask yourself:
✔️ Does it reflect 
who I am
, not just 
what I do
?
✔️ What change could I make to show up in a way that builds both connection 
and
 credibility?
Ready to take your virtual presence further?
▪️Thousands have built their Personal Virtual Exposure and Influence Plan with us.
👉 
Join the waitlist
 for our next workshop and start building yours.
Have a great week!
Sacha Connor
CEO, Virtual Work Insider
P.S. 
 Want to learn more about using video as a tool of influence? 
Check out this article
. 
Join the Waitlist
 
Strengthening Connections and Visibility Across Distance
“The action plan I created during Virtual Work Insider’s 
Build Your Network and Exposure Across Distance
 workshop had an immediate and lasting impact.
Within a month, I had already deepened connections with senior leaders across time zones and expanded my local network. By organizing in-person meetups, I increased my visibility within the division and uncovered new career opportunities.
These strategies continue to boost my confidence, influence, and ability to navigate remote work effectively. The workshop provided a clear, actionable roadmap to grow my network and advance my career in a geographically distributed organization.”
Dixit Gandhi
TPM Business Consultant
TELUS Agriculture & Consumer Goods

Our Insider knowledge can help your organization build the skills, behaviors, and mindsets critical to being effective in a distributed, hybrid or remote work environment.

Leading Effective and Inclusive Hybrid & Remote Meetings

subject: Not Enough or Too Much? Working While Black
body:
Racism and Black women in the workplace  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
March 24, 2025   |   
Read Online
Not Enough or Too Much? Working While Black 
Racism and Black women in the workplace 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello friends, 
As a Black woman in corporate, or in any office job, you're always under scrutiny. Heck, as a Black woman existing and minding your own business, the same is true. 
Downgraded For Being Quiet
I learned that for the first time at a training day in England. I've told the story before, but here it is in a nutshell. I was quiet throughout the day, as the trainer wasn't telling me anything I didn't know - no point in taking up airtime when there were people who needed the input more, I thought. 
Having aced the tests when the training finished, I discovered that the trainer thought that my silence equated to ignorance rather than knowledge. In other words, I'd been under scrutiny, and he'd drawn the wrong conclusion. It was a lesson I wouldn't forget. 
It's one of the reasons why, even in the discomfort of my introversion (nothing wrong with being introverted but in my case it didn't lead to social adeptness) I constantly had to force myself to speak up and advocate for myself. Now it's easier than it would have been then, as I can use writing - for which I have a gift - as my main mode of communication. 
Not Enough or Too Much?
Returning to the work sphere, the criticisms of Black women usually fall into two camps: not enough or too much, with a side order of microaggressions and outright racism. You can keep your head down, be good at your job, and prop up the poor managers above you in the hierarchy, and you'll still hear that you lack leadership qualities, confidence, experience and those go-getter qualities that are often prized in men and despised in women. 
Because if you DO have any of those qualities, you'll suddenly be too full of yourself, too pushy, too confident (I got accused of this once because as a tall, long-legged woman, I strode through the corridors, even though inside I was quietly uncertain). And of course, in both cases, it can be said that you're not a team player. 
Thank you for being on the free list for Sharon’s Anti-Racism Newsletter. I can’t do this work without the support of readers like you. But most of all, I rely on those of you who upgrade to premium subscriptions. You can find pricing options here: 
Show me how I can support SARN 
From Pet to Threat
While some Black women are lucky enough to be in environments where they have mentors and advocates, many don't. Instead, by the time they get to their second job, they can see what's ahead with a dreadful inevitability. It's often the "
pet to threat
" syndrome (the term coined by Dr Kecia Thomas in 2013, which is still all too relevant today.) 
In fact, sometimes the "pet" period is pretty short. You may be welcomed into the company initially, but there'll likely be someone you report to and a close colleague who doesn't have your best interests at heart, is racist, or just hates you, and who will undermine you at every turn. 
Turn in the same level of performance as your white colleagues, and you'll be under-performing. Exceed their performance, and you'll need to be brought down a peg or two. Before you know it, you're on a performance improvement plan, and the only way to rescue your stalled progress internally is to get another job. Racism, discrimination and bias win again. 
Take Action
Anti-racism advocates, this phenomenon is visible, if you are paying attention. So pay attention. And, if the person affected is ok with it (do check if they want your support) you can call out inconsistencies in treatment, both directly and by starting conversations that make others aware too. You can advocate for them in rooms they're not in. And you can show up consistently so they know they have some support. Don't expect trust at first, but do what you know you have to do as an active anti-racist. 
P.S. This phenomenon doesn't just happen in the office: check out the news and see how many Black women in prominent positions have been driven over the glass cliff in the past year alone and how many ridiculously qualified Black women end up out of a job simply for saying what they saw - you'll get into double digits pretty fast. 
Thanks for reading. 
Sharon 
Additional Reading
REBOOT: Why Black Women Prioritise Education 
Without it, where would we be?
www.antiracismnewsletter.com/p/why-black-women-prioritise-education
The Triple Whammy of Being a Black Woman Introvert
All three can count against you in the workplace
www.antiracismnewsletter.com/p/black-woman-introvert
Time to Stop Tone Policing Black Women
Because speaking nicely doesn’t solve injustice
www.antiracismnewsletter.com/p/stop-tone-policing-black-women

subject: 1 thing we learned from each team this spring
body:
Plus: Will we see Max Muncy vs. Max Muncy?
Monday, March 24
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS
 
1 important thing we learned about each team this spring
 
As teams begin to break camp in preparation for Opening Day, our beat reporters came up with one thing we can glean from each club from Spring Training.
 
Skenes hears the noise -- he's just not listening
No. 7 overall prospect Campbell makes Sox roster (source)
Angels acquire righty Anderson from Braves for Suarez
Injuries: Mookie, McClanahan, Gunnar, Ranger
Strider's second outing 'wasn't as easy,' but Braves righty feeling good
Chourio's confidence at all-time high heading into season
Gardner family, Yankees mourn loss of Brett's 14-year-old son Miller
MORE TOP NEWS
 
MLB MORNING LINEUP PODCAST
 
 
 
PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!
 
MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
MLB's most interesting and extreme batting stances
Statcast's new data about where hitters are in the batter's box can tell us things like who stands closest to and farthest from the plate and even whose stance most resembles Ted Williams.
 
Max Muncy vs. Max Muncy?
 
A's prospect Max Muncy made the Opening Day roster, meaning he could match up against Dodgers star and former A's prospect Max Muncy when the teams meet in May.
 
What will Skenes do for an encore?
 
As Paul Skenes follows up his Rookie of the Year campaign for the Pirates, here is a ranking of how the 26 previous starting pitchers to win the honor fared in their sophomore seasons.
 
DC is central to Nationals' new look
 
The Nationals' new City Connect uniforms feature touches like a block letter “W” with an outline of the Capitol Dome inside of it and Washington, D.C.'s city grid on the jersey and underbill of the cap.
 
Opening Day Strikeout Contest
Compete to win tickets, a free MLB.TV subscription and a gift card to the MLB Shop in the 2025 Opening Day Strikeout Contest presented by Sage.
 
Red Sox vs. Sultanes de Monterrey
Catch the Red Sox in the opener of a two-game exhibition series against the Mexican League’s Monterrey Sultanes at Estadio Mobil Super in Mexico at 9 p.m. ET on MLB Network.

subject: Building the Future of Zionism through Education
body:
Fifth Edition of the World Zionist Village Newsletter
To view this email as a web page, go 
here.
 
CEO LETTER
Dear Friends and Supporters of Zionism,
In every generation, the torch of Zionism has burned brightly, illuminating a path for the Jewish people toward sovereignty, resilience, and unity. It was this vision that brought about the rebirth of Israel, the revival of Hebrew, and the remarkable flourishing of a people who had wandered for centuries without a homeland. Today, however, we stand at a crossroads. The very essence of Zionism is being questioned, misunderstood, and at times, even misrepresented. It is our duty to reclaim it, to reaffirm its relevance, and to reinvigorate its spirit.
READ MORE
Innovation
Building The Zionist Dream
Imagine some of the greatest minds in real estate—moguls, developers, and visionaries—gathered in a single room for six hours, meticulously analyzing the master plan of the most ambitious capital investment project in the Jewish world.
READ MORE
Education
Education Spotlight
Zionism is at the root of our collective history—it is also the lifeblood of our Jewish future. It is the unwavering belief in the right of the Jewish people to self-determination in their ancestral homeland, the connection to our shared past, and the commitment to building a thriving, innovative, and unified nation.
READ MORE
Impact
Donor Spotlight
This month, we proudly recognize Joe Wolfson as our Donor of the Month, honoring his unwavering dedication to Israel and Zionism. 
READ MORE
Village Talks & Conversations
"The World Zionist Village will be transformative. In 50-75 years from now our grandchildren and great-grandchildren are going to look back and thank us for what we did for the future of Zionism, with the vision we had years ago to make a dream become a reality." - Joe Wolfson

subject: Re: DCP JV Baseball Parent/Guardian Emails (Corrected)
body:
Hello all,
I hope you've all thawed out after yesterday's double header! Thank you to those that were able to come out and support us in the cold! I thought it was a great start to the season! 
This week is busy with games Monday-Thursday and then again on Saturday. This week's game/practice schedule is as follows:
-Monday 3/24: Game 6:30pm vs St. Pat's @ Reed-Dunning (Bus leaves DCP at 4:00pm)
-Tuesday 3/25: Game 4:30pm @ Whitney Young (Bus leaves DCP at 3:00pm)
-Wednesday 3/26: Game 4:30pm @ Niles West (Bus leaves DCP at 3:00pm)
-Thursday 3/27: Game 5:00pm @ U-High (Bus departure time TBD, will let boys know ASAP)
-Friday 3/28: Practice 3:00pm - 5:00pm @ Kerry Wood Field (might have to shift time and location)
-Saturday 3/29: Game 12:00pm @ Schaumburg (Bud departure time TBD, will let boys know ASAP)
I will follow up with another email when I hear back from Coach Colon regarding Thursday's bus departure, Friday's practice time and location, and Saturday's bus departure. 
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp
On Thu, Mar 13, 2025 at 7:03 AM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
It was very nice meeting many of you last night! As promised, here is the updated email chain (hoping I've got it correct this time!). As a reminder, I will share the practice schedule for the rest of the week, as well as the week of Spring Break:
Thursday 3/13: No Practice (hoping the boys go to the basketball game)
Friday 3/14: Practice 5:30pm - 7:00pm @ Clark Park
Saturday 3/15: Practice 8:00am - 10:00am @ Kerry Wood Field
SPRING BREAK
Monday 3/17: No Practice
Tuesday 3/18: No Practice
Wednesday 3/19: No Practice
Thursday 3/20: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Friday 3/21: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Saturday 3/22: Games 10:00am / 12:00pm (Double Header) vs Taft @ Laramie Park (Skokie)
I will be sending another email today or tomorrow (whenever I'm able to get this information confirmed) regarding the practice times and locations for Thursday and Friday of Spring Break. 
Again, thank you all for everything you've done/will do for the boys and team this year! 
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp
-- 
Zachary Hinkamp (He/Him), LPC

body:

Sunday, March 23
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS

MORE TOP NEWS

PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!
 
MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
1 fact about every team to make you sound smart
 
If you want to impress friends with your baseball knowledge, Sarah Langs has you covered with one interesting fact for each team heading into the 2025 season.
 
'That's some center-fielding'
Add multitasking to Jackson Merrill's list of skills after he made a smooth running catch while being interviewed during the Padres' win over the Reds.
 
An Opening Day to remember, 100 years later
 
We can only hope for an Opening Day as wild as in 1925, when Cleveland and St. Louis combined to score 35 runs, Babe Ruth was out with an infamous "bellyache" and more.
 
Escarra's crazy route reaches Majors
 
After driving for a ride share service and working as a substitute teacher while trying to work his way to the big leagues, J.C. Escarra's dream came true when he learned he will be on the Yankees' Opening Day roster.
 
Spring Training tripleheader
It’s Orioles vs. Braves at 1 p.m. ET (available in Orioles market), Brewers vs. Mariners at 4 (available in Brewers market) and Angels vs. Dodgers at 8, live on MLB Network.

subject: 🤖❤️‍🩹 Can a Robot Heal? Meet PARO.
body:
See the healing affects of this robotic baby seal at Robot Block Party April 4 and 5.‌ 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
 
 
Artifact Highlight: PARO the Healing Harp Seal … Robot?
Animals have been known to have calming effects on humans — there are plenty of animal-assisted therapies available to prove it. But not all settings, like hospitals and nursing homes, allow live animals. Thanks to PARO, however, the benefits of a furry friend can be accessible to all.  
PARO is a furry robot designed to mimic a baby harp seal. Sensor pads inside the robot read human touches and respond with life-like movements and sounds. Since its introduction to the public in 2001, this adorable companion has been shown to improve patients’ relaxation, motivation and socialization.
Griffin MSI currently has its own PARO in the Museum’s permanent collection, and it will be on display at 
Robot Block Party
 on Friday, April 4 and Saturday, April 5 from 9:30 a.m. to 2 p.m. The two-day event features interactive displays from local robotics groups and the chance to experience PARO’s healing powers firsthand.
See Details About Robot Block Party
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Griffin Museum of Science and Industry 
5700 S. DuSable Lake Shore Drive
Chicago, IL 60637
United States
 
 
 
 
© 2025 Kenneth C. Griffin Museum of Science and Industry. The Museum gratefully acknowledges the support of the Chicago Park District on behalf of the citizens of Chicago.

subject: 10 players who could be difference-makers
body:
Plus: Predicting the AL and NL stat leaders
Saturday, March 22
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS
 
15 Spring Training stat lines that matter
 
With domestic Opening Day less than a week away, let's try to pick out some of the players whose stellar springs will translate to stellar 2025 seasons.
 
Royals acquire OF Canha from Brewers (source)
O's reunite with veteran SP Kyle Gibson on 1-year deal
Top prospect Baldwin on Braves' Opening Day roster: 'No question he's ready for it'
Owning his voice, Vladdy stepping up for Blue Jays
Injury updates on Darvish, Suárez, Kirby and others
Baty earning big opportunity with Mets as torrid spring continues
Back as Rays' ace, McClanahan's fire never wavered
Skenes MLB debut patch card sells for $1.11M at auction
Tokyo Series a record-breaking international event for MLB
MORE TOP NEWS
 
MLB MORNING LINEUP PODCAST
 
 
 
PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!
 
MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
X-factors for 10 teams that missed playoffs in '24
 
Every season, new teams emerge as legitimate postseason threats after missing out the previous year. In fact, 2024 marked the third straight year with six new playoff teams. If things break right for these 10 teams, at least some could find themselves playing October baseball in 2025.
 
Experts predict 2025 AL, NL stat leaders
 
We polled 59 MLB.com experts for their picks on who will lead the American League and National League in six key categories: homers, batting average, stolen bases, ERA, strikeouts and saves.
 
Burger, wife Ashlyn form foundation for daughter on World Down Syndrome Day
 
March 21 is World Down Syndrome Day, and for the first time it has special meaning for Jake Burger and his family.
 
Unsatisfied by '24, Winn wants to be 'one of the faces' of MLB
 
Masyn Winn might have just one full MLB season under his belt, but he is brimming with confidence that he can be one of the game’s best all-around shortstops.
 
8 new Copa de la Diversión teams coming to MiLB in 2025
 
Check out the inspiration behind the Cencerros Increibles, Los Pingüinos, the Stockton Cheladas and more.
 
Spring Training doubleheader
 
It’s Blue Jays vs. Twins at 1 p.m. ET, followed by Reds vs. Padres at 4 (available in Reds market), live on MLB Network.

subject: Spring break ideas for procrastinators
body:
Plus the latest news from Chicago's NPR station.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
 Donate
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
Photo: Jamie Kelter Davis for WBEZ
WBEZ NEWS
10 delightful Chicago spring break ideas for procrastinators, oddballs and tourists alike
No plans? No problem. Our family-friendly guide helps you make the most of a city break — or a day trip — with these quirky outings.
READ MORE
WBEZ NEWS
 
Photo: Fabio Lovino/HBO
‘White Lotus’ actor Carrie Coon is not afraid to go to extremes
The Steppenwolf ensemble member, last seen on Chicago stages with the visceral Bug, on working with Mike White while juggling theater and TV.
READ MORE
 
Photo: Manuel Martinez/WBEZ
Five years since COVID, how Chicago works to improve the health of the city
Chicago has the largest life-expectancy gap in the country. As threats to federal funding loom, health experts hope they can still shrink that gap.
READ MORE
 
Photo: Jamie Kelter Davis for WBEZ
Beloved by chefs, Chicago’s rare tea mastermind Rod Markus makes his retail move
The Rare Tea Cellars founder is expanding his creative universe with a new venture in Lincoln Square.
READ MORE
 
Photo: Morgan Ciocca/Vocalo
New venue Bookclub revives former Elbo Room in “a leap of faith”
The former DIY venue went legitimate in January.
READ MORE
 
SPONSORED BY HARRIS THEATER
Twyla Tharp Dance: Diamond Jubilee
On April 10–12 at the Harris Theater, Twyla Tharp Dance celebrates 60 years of choreography with a program that spans decades of the iconic dance maker's illustrious career, featuring Chicago’s own Third Coast Percussion. 
The three performances
 will feature Oliver-nominated 
Diabelli
 and a dazzling new work, 
SLACKTIDE
.
 
UPCOMING EVENTS
 
WBEZ Present: An Evening with Roxane Gay & Sasha-Ann Simons
Date/Time: 
Wednesday, March 26 at 7:30 p.m.
Location:
 Athenaeum Center -  2936 N Southport Ave, Chicago, IL 60657
Join WBEZ for an unforgettable evening with New York Times best-selling author and feminist icon Roxane Gay on March 26. In conversation with WBEZ’s Reset host, Sasha-Ann Simons, Gay will discuss her latest work, 
The Portable Feminist Reader
—a deep dive into the history of American feminism through a multicultural lens, exploring intersectional issues like ecofeminism, disability, and Black feminism. 
Special Offer:
 Use code 
FRIEND
 at checkout for a 
Buy One, Get One
 book bundle! 
TICKETS
 
Making: Stories Without End Podcast Launch
Date/Time:
 Sunday, April 6 at 2 p.m.
Location:
 DuSabel Black History Museum - 740 E 56th PL , Chicago, IL 60657
Celebrate the latest season of the critically acclaimed WBEZ podcast, 
Making: Stories Without End
, with host Natalie Moore! Dive into the rich history of daytime television and explore the impact of Black representation in soap operas—from early radio dramas to modern-day storytelling. Join us for a podcast launch party and discussion ahead of the new season’s premiere! 
TICKETS
 
The Other Art Fair Chicago
Date/Time:
  March 27-30, Various Times
Location: 
Artifact Events - 4325 N Ravenswood Ave, Chicago, IL 60613
4 days. 115+ independent artists. Unlimited creativity. The Other Art Fair isn’t just about seeing art—it’s about experiencing it. Expect pieces that surprise at prices that don’t. Plus, interactive installations, portrait sessions with Anna Marie Tendler (booking required), live DJ sets, a flowing bar, local food vendors, and a few unexpected moments along the way.
TICKETS

An ongoing news experiment with coverage about Chicago, the surrounding region and its people

In bite-sized episodes every weekday, we’ll keep you informed and tickled and on Chicago’s news, culture and people.

subject: Your Invitation to the Ayuda Health Advisory Board
body:
Ayuda Health is seeking advisors from various backgrounds and expertise - view your invitation inside! - 
 
REMINDER: 
You're Invited to Join the Ayuda Health advisory board on AdvisoryCloud!
 
Ayuda Health
 Advisory Board
Now accepting new board members with various expertise
 
Upcoming Board Meeting in Q2 - Your advice is requested!
Ayuda Health
 is leading the charge in chronic disease management with smart, culturally-sensitive tech that inspires healthier lives and reduces hospitalizations. Their advisory board is currently seeking professionals with 
and without
 healthcare experience (growth, operations, strategy, and more) to give feedback on current goals and initiatives before Q2.
 
Want to become a board member, get involved, and see behind the scenes?
Join this advisory board
 
The ROI of Joining Boards
✓
 Get involved in interesting new companies
✓
 Add board work to your resume & social profiles 
✓
 Elite networking and introductions
✓
 Elevate your current and future earning potential 
✓
 Long-term career stimulation and opportunities
 
Start joining boards today
 
 
But Am I Qualified?
Every professional has unique ideas and perspectives, whether you’re early in your career, already in the executive ranks, or starting to think about working a bit less. 
There are over 30 million businesses in the United States alone. For too long it's been hard for companies to build an advisory board and get feedback from a large and diverse group of professionals, but AdvisoryCloud has changed all of that - 
and we want you to be a part of it.
Joining boards gives you a behind-the-scenes look at exciting new businesses, exposes you to interesting new people, and can open doors of professional opportunity in a lot of different ways.
So take your shot 
- 
start joining boards today.

subject: Fewer traffic stops, but more end in violence
body:
Plus, a local principal spins the Wheel of Fortune. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Friday - March 21, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Esther Bergdahl
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! If you’re looking to rescue an 
endangered historic movie house
, consider scouting out Portage Park. As for the rest of the news, here’s what you need to know today.
  
1.
Chicago cops have been making fewer traffic stops, but more are ending in violence
 
The fatal shooting of Dexter Reed one year ago today sent shockwaves through the city and led to promises of reform. Still, Chicago Police Department leaders have pushed officers to boost their numbers in recent years, leading to stops that put both cops and community members in danger. Last year, officers reported using force 787 times during traffic stops — the most since 2018, which was the first full year cops were subjected to tougher reporting requirements.
To get a better grasp of the factors that make some stops so volatile, my colleagues at the Sun-Times, alongside the Investigative Project on Race and Equity, analyzed use-of-force data, conducted interviews and reviewed court records and police disciplinary files. They found, among other things, that nearly 85% of those use-of-force incidents during traffic stops were concentrated in majority Black and Latino communities on the South Side and the West Side. Police officials declined interview requests.
“Any time the police get behind me, I cringe, you know, from the past trauma,” said Eric Wilkins, 54, who is Black. “You don’t know what’s going to happen. Today could be that day that I get killed.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
2.
CTA, Metra and Pace say they will have to cut services by 40% in 2026 if the state doesn't intervene
 
The agencies are staring down a $700 million-plus budget deficit in 2026, when federal COVID-19 pandemic grant money runs out. Severe cuts to transit would have ripple effects on the broader economy, my Sun-Times colleague David Struett reports. Nearly 3,000 transit workers could be laid off, and the Chicago area could lose $2.6 billion in gross domestic product due to increased congestion and job loss.
The CTA would be the first agency to run out of federal grants and reduce service in 2026, according to a report released today by the Regional Transportation Authority. Four of eight CTA rail lines would see suspended service on all or portions of the lines. More than 50 stations would close or drastically reduce service. Rail service would decline by anywhere from 10% to 25% on the rest of the rail network. Bus service would be hit just as hard: As many as 74 of CTA’s 127 bus lines would be eliminated, leaving a half-million riders without a nearby bus stop, according to the agency.
“CTA’s impact is going to be huge,” RTA Executive Director Leanne Redden said. “There’s cuts on [the] Metra and Pace side as well. Even beyond the transit riders, it affects employees. Workers won’t be able to get to their jobs. Traffic congestion is going to be even worse.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM POLYMATH UNIVERSITY
Polymath University: Enroll in Summer or Fall Courses Now
Legacy higher education offers a business model from the 1950s and an educational model from the 1880s. We've built a new nonprofit university in Chicago from the ground up – Polymath University – that is interdisciplinary, apprenticeship based, and debt-free. We call it, "ROTC for the private sector" and we're launching our first Master's level courses this Summer.
Register for a Systems Thinking course this summer
Attend an info session
Follow us on LinkedIn
3.
Supreme Court uses Patrick Daley Thompson case to further limit feds
 
The U.S. Supreme Court has unanimously sided with former Chicago Ald. Patrick Daley Thompson, finding that a law he’d been convicted under outlaws false statements but not misleading ones, as his attorneys have long argued.
A jury found Thompson guilty in February 2022 of two counts of lying to regulators and five counts of filing false income tax returns. The conviction ended his tenure as the 11th Ward’s representative on the Chicago City Council. Thompson has already served four months in prison, and his appeal revolved only around claims that he made false statements to regulators.
The question Thompson raised at the Supreme Court, writes my Sun-Times colleague Jon Seidel, basically amounted to “When is a lie a lie?” Chief Justice John Roberts used the case to continue the high court’s trend of putting restraints on federal prosecutors.
“In casual conversation, people use many overlapping words to describe shady statements: false, misleading, dishonest, deceptive, literally true, and more,” Roberts wrote. “Only one of those words appears in the statute. [The law] does not criminalize statements that are misleading but true.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
4.
Immigration crackdowns are leading to reports of ICE agents near Chicago Public Schools, emails show
 
Students, educators and staff in Chicago schools have been on edge since the Trump administration promised mass detentions and expulsions of immigrants. In January, Hamline Elementary School in Back of the Yards became the site of panic amid rumors about the presence of Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers nearby.
The Chicago Tribune reports that even if ICE agents are not yet a common sight near local schools, the fear they inspire — particularly in plainclothes — has profoundly disrupted the day-to-day lives of Chicago students.
“The teachers in the classroom are under enormous stress, because they’re trying to teach a class, they’re trying to get the kids ready to take their exams,” said Patricia Gandara, an education professor and co-director of the Civil Rights Project at the University of California, Los Angeles. “[But] kids may be crying. They’ve got their heads down. They can’t cooperate.” [
Chicago Tribune
]
5.
Lincoln Park HS students say their principal “could have won a lot more” on 'Wheel of Fortune'
 
Lincoln Park High School Principal Eric Steinmiller deleted the first two emails he got from 
Wheel of Fortune
 because he thought they were spam. Being on the long-running game show had never been on his radar, he told my colleague Anna Savchenko. The third email convinced him to hop on a flight to Los Angeles.
The 
Wheel of Fortune
 episode with Steinmiller aired last night. To celebrate the occasion, he organized a watch party at his North Side high school, with some two dozen students, parents and teachers in attendance. Sitting in the auditorium, he laughed as he watched himself struggle to guess the right letters onscreen, while his opponents scored big by figuring out unexpected phrases like “photo finish your vegetables.”
Steinmiller said he was focused at the time on getting momentum on his wheel spins, which he practiced ahead of filming. “Maybe I was too focused on getting a good spin,” he said, which is why “it kept landing on ‘bankrupt.’ ” [
WBEZ
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
Tourists from ally nations, including in Europe, are warning each other not to travel to the United States after multiple long ICE lock-ups. [
AP
]
Chicago postal workers join their colleagues nationwide to protest the Trump administration’s likely attempts to dismantle and privatize the U.S. Postal Service, which is mandated in the Constitution. [
Block Club Chicago
]
Indiana’s Department of Natural Resources has reported mass deaths of sandhill cranes from bird flu, an alarming first. [
WBEZ
]
Scientists may have unlocked some insights into why we can’t remember being babies. [
NPR
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
For more than a decade, Roxane Gay has been one of the most influential voices in modern feminism. Her writing challenges traditional feminist narratives, making space for nuance and imperfection in ways that have reshaped contemporary discourse.
Gay’s new book, 
The Portable Feminist Reader
, curates a sweeping collection of feminist thought. It comes at a precarious moment, when the Trump administration seeks to erase words like “feminism” and “woman” from federal documents and progress on reproductive rights and LGBTQ+ protections is being rolled back. Gay, who will join WBEZ Reset host Sasha-Ann Simons for a conversation in Chicago on March 26, spoke with WBEZ contributor Elly Fishman about the process of building a feminist reader for our era.
“Writing is not something that can single-handedly save the world, but it can be a call to action,” Gay said. “It can remind us where we’ve been and what is at stake. Some of these essays offer practical ways to organize and mobilize, and that’s part of what makes books powerful.” [
WBEZ
]
 
Tell me something good
 
The Cubs were just in Tokyo and the Music Box Theatre is running a series on 
baseball films
. That has me wondering: What’s your favorite sports movie?
Jeff writes:
"My favorite sports movie is 'Hoosiers.' It helps I’m from Indiana (I live in Ravenswood now) and I was in the film due to being in the right time at the right place with high school basketball and acting/music background."
Bill writes:
"'Eight Men Out' is the best. Part of Chicago's history. Dennis Bingham's portrayal of the first base ump is realistic and mesmerizing."
Ken writes:
"'Bull Durham.' Crash's speech on what he believes is worth it alone."
Susie writes:
“One of the first movies I remember seeing was the Knute Rockne story [ed: '
Knute Rockne, All American']
 with Pat O’Brien and the famous Ronald Reagan as 'the Gipper.' I really enjoyed it as a youngster.”
Paul writes:
“Favorite sports movie? 'Breaking Away.' One of the best coming of age movies and a film every cyclist should see. The race- Yes, the Little 500 is real and pretty much how the movie depicts it- is a fun event to travel for and have a great weekend in Bloomington Indiana at IU.”
Matt writes:
“At the risk of sounding like a middle schooler, one of my favorite filmmakers is a YouTuber. Jon Bois makes heartfelt, hilarious and highly detailed documentaries about under-explored subjects that catch his fancy, including multi-part series on woebegone franchises like the Atlanta Falcons, Seattle Mariners and Minnesota Vikings. My favorite of his docs is 'The Bob Emergency,' a tongue-in-cheek analysis of the numerical rise and fall of athletes with the name Bob that somehow becomes an incredibly moving portrait of several undersung sports figures in the 20th Century (named Bob, of course).”
Thanks for reading — it has been such a pleasure writing for you these past two weeks! Have an excellent weekend, and Bianca will be back Monday.
— Esther Bergdahl
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting. 
DONATE TODAY

Unsubscribe from The Daily Rundown
 |

subject: Reinvent. Reintroduce. Reclaim Your Brilliance—Join Our March 27 Community Call!
body:
​
​
​
Hi there,
We’re living through times that are asking more of us as leaders. 
More resilience, more agility, more courage to pivot
 when the path ahead feels unclear. For women in leadership, this moment calls for something even deeper: 
The boldness to reinvent ourselves, to reintroduce our brilliance, and to reclaim our space in rooms where decisions are made.
That’s why I’m thrilled to invite you to the 
March Community Call
, where I’ll be joined by the incredible 
Dr. Yvette Burton
 for a candid, actionable conversation about navigating through change.
If you caught my recent conversation with Yvette on 
The Will to Change
 podcast, you already know the depth and wisdom she brings. We talked about her own reinvention journey and pivoting from academia and leadership into cybersecurity. She shares what it really takes to lead with agility and courage in uncertain times. If you haven’t listened yet, I highly recommend it! You can find the episode 
here
.
This upcoming community call will build on that conversation and go even deeper. Together, Yvette and I will explore how women leaders are embracing bold pivots, owning their brilliance, and reintroducing themselves in powerful ways.
Join us for the March Community Call!!!
​
 
Date:
 Wednesday, March 27
Time:
 12:00 PM ET | 9:00 AM PT
​
Guest Speaker:
 Dr. Yvette Burton
Register Here
This isn’t just another leadership talk. It’s a space to get real about what it takes to navigate 
career pivots
, 
own your brilliance
, and 
lead with confidence
, especially in unpredictable times.
Yvette brings her decades of experience as an executive, academic, and leader. Plus, her own powerful reinvention as she pivoted into cybersecurity. Together, we’ll explore:
How to recognize when it’s time to pivot or deepen where you are
Practical strategies to reintroduce yourself and your expertise to your network
Ways to overcome imposter syndrome and build unshakable confidence
How to translate your skills and lived experience into new opportunities
Why agility, intuition, and authenticity are key leadership traits right now
Whether you’re contemplating a career shift, returning to the workforce, or ready to claim a bigger seat at the table, this conversation will offer insights and next steps to help you move forward with clarity, courage, and community.
Looking Ahead: Mentorship That Moves Us Forward
Next month, I’m excited to launch something new that’s been in the works. A Mentee/Mentor Training Series designed to support leaders at every stage of their journey. Whether you’re a mentor ready to guide with more purpose and impact, or a mentee seeking the right relationships to help you grow, these sessions will offer practical strategies, inclusive frameworks, and real-world guidance.
I’ll be sharing more details during our March 27 Community Call, so those in attendance will be the first to hear about it and receive the invitation to join me.
If you’re already feeling curious, or you know this is exactly what you need right now, 
reply to this email or reach out to my team.
 We’ll make sure you’re on the list to get the first invite when registration opens for these Mentee/Mentor Trainings.
Because when we invest in mentorship, we invest in each other, and in the future we’re shaping together.
Stay Connected
Don’t miss new episodes of 
The Will to Change
 
​
Read my latest reflections on 
Substack 
​
​
In solidarity,
​
Jennifer Brown
CEO & Founder, 
Jennifer Brown Speaks
​
Author, 
Inclusion
, 
How to Be an Inclusive Leader
, and 
Beyond Diversity
​
Host, 
The Will To Change
 Podcast
​
Unsubscribe
 | 
Update your profile
 | 113 Cherry St #92768, Seattle, WA 98104-2205

Substack

,

, and

Travel With Us on An Unforgettable Mission
donate

plant
   
travel
Coming Home Mission
July 6 - 13, 2025
As evacuated communities affected by the war are returning to their homes, we return home too – to Israel.
We invite you to embark on a
 
life-changing
 
journey that will feed your soul - one of resilience, hope, and unity. Together, we are not just rebuilding; we are restoring homes, mending hearts, and uplifting spirits.
This is our moment to feel the power of community, lift each other up, and be part of something bigger. 
Come home with us, come home to them
. Your presence makes a difference.

subject: Your Expertise Available at Upcoming Board Meetings?
body:
Monica, while reviewing upcoming board meetings for Q2 on AdvisoryCloud, I'm more convinced than ever that your 
high-level business
 expertise & professional experience is a huge missing piece on many of these companies' advisory boards.
 
  
Let's get you set up as an advisor (free) and match you to a couple new board roles ASAP.
 
  
My team will also create an executive profile for you, and help you choose a custom project-based rate for any additional advisory work or services you're interested in providing to others who come across your profile.
 
  
With over 200 open board roles exclusively available on AdvisoryCloud, I think this is the perfect way to jumpstart a whole new professional path for yourself as an advisor in your unique area of expertise. 
All the best,
Chris
 
 
Chris Beaver

subject: Meet the marketing visionaries shaping a new era of leadership
body:
Plus, insights from our 2025 New Era of Leadership judges.
 
 
LEADING THROUGH DISRUPTIONS
 
Meet the Marketing Visionaries Shaping a New Era of Leadership
 
e.l.f Beauty CMO Kory Marchisotto and TikTok Global Head of Business Marketing Sofia Hernandez talk the keys to innovative brand-building in 2025.
 
Read More
 
 
 
 
PATH TO THE C-SUITE
 
How This Chief Revenue Officer Got Her CEO to Train Her for the Top Job
 
2024 New Era of Leadership Award winner and 2025 judge Jacquelyn Cameron on the value of voicing your ambition, her plans for becoming a CEO, and her key strategies for growing Axios event revenue by 60%.
 
 
READ MORE
 
 
EQUALITY ACROSS THE GENDER SPECTRUM
 
Less Than 20% of Wikipedia’s Biographies Are About Women — This CCO Wants to Change That
 
Anusha Alikhan — a 2024 New Era of Leadership Award winner and 2025 judge — is increasing the number of diverse stories told on one of the world’s top 10 most-visited websites.
 
READ MORE
 
 
 
 
 
For the women redefining business as usual.
 
As the most powerful network of executive women, we know good leadership when we see it. This Women’s History Month, Chief is bringing back The New Era of Leadership Awards. Nominate an exceptional executive you know by Monday, March 31 and help honor the women who are shaping the future of business.
 
NOMINATE AN EXECUTIVE
 
 
 
Top Shelf
25 Famous Women Leaders on Power
THE CUT
Women Founders and Execs Talk Acts of 'Micro-Feminism' at Work — and Why They Matter
BUSINESS INSIDER
The Best Leaders Aren’t Decisive. They’re Ambivalent

Bold Moves
Michele Chase Kashap
was hired as Vice President, Head of Global Commercial Operations at Gilead Sciences

received a Congressional Leadership Award in honor of Women’s History Month

was hired as Vice President, Head of Delivery Risk at Genpact

received an Excellence in Healthcare Award at the Healthcare 2.0 Conference

was named a 2025 92NY Women inPower Fellow

was hired as Vice President, Marketing at Crunchbase

joined the board of NESsT

launched Endeavor Studios

launched Paragon Sports Marketing

subject: Catchers Camp Announcement
body:
Have issue viewing this email? 
Click here
Hello Parents (& Catchers),
If you haven't already heard, I'll be down in
 Chicago/Mokena, IL,
 for another catchers only camp in April!
I don't know when or if I'll make my way back up to the Milwaukee area so I thought I'd let you know when I was going to be close.  I promise I'll make it worth the road trip and I would love to work with each of your catchers again!
Check out the info below and click the "More Details & Register Now" button if you're ready to get signed up now.  
CHICAGO (MOKENA), IL SPRING CATCHERS CAMP DETAILS
:
April 26-27, 2025 (Saturday & Sunday)
from 9:00am-1:30pm Daily
Baseball & Softball Catchers age 10-16
Cost: 
$499 per catcher 
(ONLY 2 SPOTS LEFT!)
D-BAT Mokena
9950 West 190th St,
Mokena, IL 60448
 
(
MAP
)
This will be another 
"Big 3" Skills camp
 and we will cover in detail, stances and set ups, receiving, blocking and throwing.
MORE DETAILS AND REGISTER NOW! 
Please let me know if you have any questions and I hope to get to work with your catcher again.
Sincerely,
Todd Coburn
The Catching Guy
thecatchingguy.com
 
 
 
 
 
 
Gamer Baseball LLC
PO Box 18083
Reno, NV 89511
United States
Unsubscribe from our newsletter
REFUND POLICY
: 
 
If we have to cancel the camp for any reason, you will be given a full refund.  If you have to cancel camp for any reason, you will be given a camp credit that is good for one year.

Sorry folks, I had the wrong day, games start tomorrow. We have 9 more squares so if anyone wants more or knows someone who would like to play, let me know and we can fill in the empty ones and reissue the sheet.

On Mar 19, 2025, at 5:39 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
 
 
Hello All,
 
Just under the wire here.  I had some late editions so my apologies for getting this out late.  
 
Rules are one winner per game, $100 payout per game.  Last numbers of each team's final score is the winning square.  Left to right (x-axis) is the higher seeded team and top to bottom (y-axis) is the lower seeded team. 
 
This may require some further explanation so let me know and I'll be happy to go over it.  Thank you again to all and good luck to all.
 
Mike

Thank you all again for another nice push yesterday.  We currently need 38 more squares sold.  Please continue to reach out to friends and family.  I am keeping it open as long as I can which means I will close it and send out the sheet around 5 pm EST Tuesday.  If we don't hit the 100 mark, we will eliminate the early games to compensate.  Hope we dont have to do that so let's get to 100.
 
Thank you again to all
Mike
