Good Afternoon Everyone,
 
We are getting closer to our goal of 100 squares with 46 left.  Very much appreciate everyone who has contributed up to this point.  We still have plenty of opportunities to jump in as there are 46 squares left.  Please reach out to friends and family.  
 
Thank you again to all
Mike
 
On Mar 14, 2025, at 1:53 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
 
 
I am going to work very hard to keep this at the top of everyone's inbox. I apologize in advance for the amount of emails I plan on sending out.  We are wrapping up the fundraising so we need one final big push. We have until Monday night to fill this sheet out.  I started by purchasing 3 myself.  97 more.  The brackets are fun but the odds of winning anything at all are relatively low.  With the squares, your odds of winning are significantly higher and much more realistic than football squares.  3 days, please pass along to friends or family that would like to join in supporting the baseball program.
 
Thank you
Mike
 
On Mar 14, 2025, at 12:07 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
 
 
Good Evening Everyone,
 
Just want to say thank you again for the great support shown during the fundraising and the First Pitch Event.  We are now reaching the end of the fundraising season as we enter the baseball season.  As you are likely aware, there are other groups at DePaul doing March Madness brackets. I know it puts more pressure on families to financially engage and we try to avoid it.  Regardless, we're gonna open our final fundraiser and try something a little different.  Rather than doing the traditional bracket, we are going to do squares. This is very simple, buy your squares and win based on the final score of each game.  Remember, there are 67 games when including the play in games.  That means you literally have 67 chances to win.  With each game fetching a $100 prize, you could win up to $6700.  Let's make this the biggest fundraising event yet.  Send it out to friends and families.  Let's make sure we sell this one out  We're going $100 per square.  Payment cam be made with Zelle to 
rogs1@mac.com
.
 
Let me know if you have any questions.
 
Mike

subject: Batter up ⚾ Play for Opening Day is back!
body:
Come celebrate the start of the 2025 season.
 
 
Mar 21, 2025
 
View Online
 
 
Step up to the plate for a chance to win one million dollars!
Celebrate Cubs baseball returning to the Friendly Confines for the 2025 season! The Play for Opening Day batting practice event returns to Wrigley Field Friday, March 28, where 100 lucky fans will have the opportunity to take swings from home plate for the chance to win prizes!
Want to play? Head to Gallagher Way from 8-9 a.m. CT March 28, to receive a scratch-off card. If your card is one of the 100 lucky winners, you'll get three chances to hit a target in the ballpark to win prizes, including the grand prize of one million dollars! All 100 fans who participate, regardless of whether they hit a target, will receive a pair of tickets to a 2025 regular season home game which must be redeemed by April 11, 2025. 
More Info
 
NO PURCHASE NECESSARY TO ENTER OR WIN.
 The entry window for the "Play for Opening Day" Batting Practice Fan promotion ("Promotion") begins at 8:00 a.m. Central Daylight Time ("CDT") on March 28, 2025, and ends at 9:00 a.m. CDT on March 28, 2025. Open to legal residents of the United States including its commonwealths, territories and possessions, excluding Florida, New York and Rhode Island, and Canada (excluding the Province of Quebec) who are twenty-one (21) years of age or older at the time of Promotion and physically located within fifty (50) miles of Gallagher Way during the entry window. Current or former professional baseball or softball players, current baseball or softball coaches and current collegiate or high school baseball or softball players or coaches, members of the media, employees or family members of Sponsor, the other MLB Entities, Anheuser-Busch, LLC, Everest Indemnity Insurance Company and all companies associated with the Promotion are not eligible to participate in the Promotion or win a Prize. TRAVEL NOT INCLUDED. One Hundred (100) participants will be randomly selected for an opportunity to receive a maximum of three (3) pitches to hit a designated target. Odds of being selected to participate depend on the number of eligible entries received. Enter in-person only. Limit one (1) entry per person. Void in Florida, New York, Rhode Island, the Province of Quebec, and where prohibited. Restrictions apply; see Official Rules at 
https://www.mlb.com/cubs/fans/play-for-opening-day
. Sponsored by Chicago Cubs Baseball Club, LLC. 
© 2025 MLB Advanced Media, L.P. MLB trademarks and copyrights are used with permission of Major League Baseball. 
Visit MLB.com
. Any other marks used herein are trademarks of their respective owners. 
Please review our 
Privacy Policy
. 
You (
monica@lcwmail.com
) received this message because you registered to receive commercial email messages or purchased a ticket from 
cubs.com
. 
Please add 
info@marketing.mlbemail.com
 to your address book to ensure our messages reach your inbox. If you no longer wish to receive commercial email messages from 
cubs.com
, please 
unsubscribe
 or log in and 
manage your email subscriptions
.

cubs.com
, c/o MLB Advanced Media, L.P., 1271 Ave​nue of the Americas, New Yo​rk, NY 10020.

subject: Chambray—our new soft, airy woven
9 BOLD predictions for 2025
body:
Plus: Jays confident they can keep Vladdy
Friday, March 21
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS
 
9 outlandish (but feasible!) predictions for 2025
 
An entirely new American League playoff field? A certain speedster stealing 80 bases? These are just a couple of the wild feats MLB.com's Anthony Castrovince wouldn't be shocked to see this season.
 
Which ranked prospects are still vying for Opening Day spots?
Mark Shapiro on Vlad Jr.: 'I think we're going to extend him'
Padres phenom outfielder ready to build on exceptional rookie campaign
Soto brothers play in same game for first time in Mets-Nats rivalry
Back atop Braves' lineup, Profar poised to hit leadoff on Opening Day
Henderson, O's ready for reloaded AL East: 'Best division in baseball'
State of Reds' 'pen: Ashcraft's in, but is Díaz out?
MLB.TV offering stacked slate of FREE baseball as camp winds down
MORE TOP NEWS
 
MLB MORNING LINEUP PODCAST
 
 
 
PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!
 
MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
The Coors Conundrum: How can Colorado win consistently at altitude?
 
In Denver's one-of-a-kind baseball setting, one thing is certain: the altitude problem is a Rubik's Cube at the intersection of physics, physiology, psychology and sport. And it’s far more layered in its complexity than many realize.
 
What is a slugger really thinking about at the plate?
 
Go inside the mind of an MLB star in the biggest at-bat of his life as Pete Alonso takes you pitch by pitch through his confrontation with Devin Williams in last year's NL Wild Card Series.
 
Willi's technicolor dream ... gloves?
 
Willi Castro plays just about everywhere for the Twins and has a glove for every position -- and a color for just about every occasion.
 
Grubbs makes history as Astros' 1st woman strength and conditioning coach
 
Stephanie Mock Grubbs bounces around Astros camp each morning with boundless energy. That might be the first thing you notice, but her knowledge and passion for her craft is what’s impressed her new team the most.
 
'It's just different': Halos responding well to new rule
 
Manager Ron Washington instituted a ban on cell phone use in the clubhouse, leaving it to veterans like Mike Trout to enforce the rule. The players say it's made the team closer.
 
Rylee Pay blazing trail as Triple-A broadcaster
 
For the first time in 26 years, the Tacoma Rainiers will have a new voice on the radio airwaves.
 
Spring Training tripleheader
 
It’s Twins vs. Phillies at 1 p.m. ET (available in Twins market), Yankees vs. Tigers at 6 (available in Yankees market) and D-backs vs. Brewers at 9 (available in D-backs market).

body:
Uvionix is still seeking advisors with expertise like yours before their next board meeting - 
 
You're invited!
 Immediately join the Uvionix Advisory Board on AdvisoryCloud.
 
Uvionix Corporation
 Advisory Board
Logistics & Robotics | Now seeking new board members
Uvionix
 is taking logistics airborne
 using AI-driven drones to deliver flawless inventory control and unshakable supply chain dominance. This advisory board is currently seeking professionals 
without
 necessary AI / Robotics experience to give high-level, high-impact feedback on current goals and initiatives.
 
Want to get involved and see behind the scenes?
Join this advisory board today
 
The ROI of Joining Boards
✓
 Get involved in interesting new companies
✓
 Add board work to your resume & social profiles 
✓
 Elite networking and introductions
✓
 Elevate your current and future earning potential 
✓
 Long-term career stimulation and opportunities
 
Start joining boards today
 
 
But Am I Qualified?
Every professional has unique ideas and perspectives, whether you’re early in your career, already in the executive ranks, or starting to think about working a bit less. 
There are over 30 million businesses in the United States alone. For too long it's been hard for companies to build an advisory board and get feedback from a large and diverse group of professionals, but AdvisoryCloud has changed all of that - 
and we want you to be a part of it.
Joining boards gives you a behind-the-scenes look at exciting new businesses, exposes you to interesting new people, and can open doors of professional opportunity in a lot of different ways.
So take your shot 
- 
start joining boards today.

subject: A Message from the CEO
body:
Monthly News from Russell F. Robinson
To view this email as a web page, go 
here.
 
Monthly News from Russell F. Robinson
 
Donate
 
News
 
Plant
 
Travel
 
Welcome to The Robinson Report, our exclusive monthly newsletter from me to 
you
. Each edition is dedicated to sharing the pivotal updates and breaking news that define our work — a mission driven by your unwavering commitment to our land and people of Israel and Zionist engagement.
 
My Latest (and Emotional Rollercoaster) Visit to Israel
I just returned from another extraordinary and emotional visit to our homeland. Yes, there is still an underlying feeling of pain – an emotion I share with the people of the north and south. However, my heart is overflowing with inspiration, profound hope, and immense pride in our shared philanthropic achievements. Every moment reaffirmed the incredible impact Jewish National Fund-USA is making, thanks to the vision and generosity of 
you
, our partners (donors).
Read More
 
Can I Let You In On A Secret?
We are winning! Not just on the battlefield but in our schools, our synagogues, and in our philanthropic impact for our land and people of Israel. If the last few months had a theme at Jewish National Fund-USA, it would be unstoppable resilience and momentum. 
Read More
 
Planning for our World Zionist Village
This week, our 
World Zionist Village
 team and I met with one of Israel’s most prominent architects, Erez Ella, of HQ Architects to review our Master Plan. After an extensive global search, Ezra’s firm was chosen to design our World Zionist Village and bring to life this visionary concept. Over several days at JNF House, we dreamed, imagined, and challenged conventions on what a global hub for Zionists everywhere should look and feel like. 
Read More
 
A Special Book for Evacuated Children
I want to share a heartwarming message from the families of children who were displaced by the war. Since October 7, 2023, Israeli children have been forced to flee their homes, schools, and communities, facing disruption, anxiety, and trauma. To support these children, we worked with Israeli creators to publish a children’s book called "Cami Is Missing Home"—a heartfelt story that addresses the feelings of loss and adaptation faced by young evacuees. Suitable for children ages 5-8. 
Read More
 
Our Impact - As seen in the Hollywood Reporter
Our commitment to supporting Israel's arts and entertainment sectors and sharing the truth about our homeland is exemplified through impactful projects like the documentary 
October 8
, made possible with our philanthropic support. This film, directed by Wendy Sachs (a proud alum of our 
Alexander Muss High School
 in Israel) and executive produced by Emmy and SAG award-winning actress, Debra Messing, delves into the surge of antisemitism on college campuses, social media, and our streets following the October 7, 2023, Hamas attack on Israel. 
Read More
 
Shabbat for Israel
Wow! We’re now expecting 712 (and counting) homes and congregations from across the country to either host or attend a Shabbat for Israel Friday night dinner on May 2, 2025, coinciding with Yom Ha’atzmaut—Israel’s Independence Day. This is an incredible opportunity to bring the beauty of Israel and Shabbat into your home in a way that’s meaningful for you. 
Read More
 
Exclusive:
Global Conference for Israel First Speaker Confirmed
Can you believe that our 
Global Conference for Israel, taking place in Hollywood, Florida, October 23-26
, is expected to sell out months in advance? With 1,597 proud Zionists registered, I want you to be a part of this extraordinary gathering of solidarity, purpose, and impact for our land and people of Israel. 
Read More
 
Do You Know a High School Student Looking to Excel Academically?
Our 
Alexander Muss High School in Israel
 is bursting at the seams, with hundreds of high school teenagers from across the US now on our wonderful amenity-rich campus (featuring dormitories, recreation facilities, a dining hall, synagogue, classrooms, a podcast studio, and more). While they may come for the opportunity to make friends, have fun, and taste a little “independence,” you, as parents, know they are entering a world of academic excellence.
Read More
 
Israeli Volunteer Firefighters Say Thank You!
It is a testament to our impact that we receive countless thank-you letters every week from the beneficiaries of our work. I was especially moved to receive the letter (see landing page) from firefighters in northern Israel, who, through our philanthropic support, were able to acquire specialized equipment designed for combating forest and open-area fires.
Read More
 
Thank you for all you do for the land and people of Israel. Please do reach out with comments, ideas, and suggestions. Email me at 
ceo@jnf.org
.
Am Yisrael Chai – The People of Israel Live!
Russell F. Robinson
Chief Executive Officer, Jewish National Fund-USA
JEWISH NATIONAL FUND-USA builds a strong,
vibrant future for the land and people of Israel through
bold initiatives and Zionist education.

subject: Why Racial Inclusion Still Matters
body:
View in browser
 
 
 
READ THE FULL ARTICLE
 
Hi Monica,
Today marks the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination — a reminder that conversations about race are not only necessary but vital for creating fairer workplaces and communities.
 
Race shapes our environments in both subtle and significant ways, yet many feel uncomfortable addressing it directly. Ignoring these dynamics doesn’t erase them. In fact, when organisations embrace racial inclusion, they see better decision-making, greater innovation, and stronger connections.
 
The question isn’t whether we should talk about race. It’s how we do it in a way that leads to understanding, fairness, and progress.
A racially inclusive, equitable world is a meritocracy.

subject: Teachers union, school district close to a deal
body:
Plus, a look at three Bears stadium proposals. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Thursday - March 20, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Esther Bergdahl
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! Take a minute to 
savor scenes
 from a Lombard cafe where patrons socialize through the night during Ramadan. As for the rest of the news, here’s what you need to know today.
  
1.
CTU contract deal in sight, delaying pivotal CPS budget vote
 
Chicago Public Schools officials and Chicago Teachers Union leaders were close to a contract agreement today as all parties appeared exasperated by protracted negotiations that have dragged on for almost a year.
The day after a tense meeting at City Hall in which Mayor Brandon Johnson tried to broker a compromise, the school district returned to the bargaining table with new proposals on additional planning time for teachers and extra pay for veteran educators, sources close to negotiations told WBEZ and the Chicago Sun-Times. The two sides also continued discussing the frequency of evaluations for some teachers, the third and final outstanding issue.
The progress came as the Board of Education postponed a crucial vote on a proposed late-year amendment to the CPS budget that would have reimbursed City Hall for a long-disputed pension payment as well as funded a CTU agreement. At the start of the board’s monthly meeting, board President Sean Harden announced the amendment was withdrawn from the agenda because CPS and CTU were “extremely, extremely close” to a deal.
“This morning they met and considerable progress has been made,” Harden said. “I’m very pleased about that.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
2.
City ordered to speed up installation of crosswalk signals to assist visually impaired pedestrians
 
Just 3% of Chicago’s crosswalks accommodate visually impaired pedestrians and a federal judge has ordered the city to speed up installation for the rest of Chicago’s 2,800 intersections.
U.S. District Judge LaShona Hunt’s proposed remedial order is aimed at resolving a lawsuit filed nearly five years ago by the American Council of the Blind of Metropolitan Chicago. The lawsuit accused the city of violating Title II of the Americans for Disabilities Act by failing to equip signalized street intersections with accessible pedestrian signals. The judge’s order mandates the city to install the devices “at a minimum of approximately 71% of signalized intersections” by Dec. 31, 2035, and five additional years to hit the 100% mark.
“As our populations age — as we see more and more Chicagoans with disabilities — this can’t continue to be a marginal investment,” Ald. Daniel La Spata, 1st Ward, told my Sun-Times colleague Fran Spielman. “This has to be something we take seriously as a city.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM SPLOOT VETERINARY CARE
Sploot: Redefining Vet Visits, One Tail Wag at a Time
Sploot is more than a vet—it’s a new kind of pet care. With same-day appointments, drop-offs, urgent care, and stress-free wellness, we make high-quality veterinary care easy and accessible 365 days a year. Our warm, modern clinics and tech-powered accessibility bring primary and urgent care together—all under one woof. Experience the future of vet care—find a Sploot near you today!
$
349
 $249 SplootPack
 
TM
 Memberships
Vaccines for life raffle
Veterinary Tele-triage
Book a $29 wellness appointment today
Follow us on Instagram
3.
Michael Madigan to be sentenced in June, federal judge says
 
Former Illinois House Speaker Michael J. Madigan is scheduled to be sentenced June 13, four months after his historic conviction for a bribery conspiracy and other crimes, my Sun-Times colleague Jon Seidel reports. In February, a jury found Madigan guilty of a nearly decadelong bribery conspiracy involving ComEd.
Jurors also convicted him of a plot to install former 25th Ward Ald. Danny Solis on a state board in exchange for Solis’ help securing private business for Madigan’s law firm. However, they couldn’t agree whether to find Madigan guilty of a broad racketeering conspiracy, in which he was accused of turning his political empire into a criminal enterprise.
U.S. District Judge John Blakey confirmed he also intends to hold a forfeiture hearing on June 9 that could result in a financial judgment against Madigan, who was the longest-serving state House leader in the United States. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
4.
Comparing 3 Bears stadium proposals in Arlington Heights, Bronzeville and the lakefront
 
After decades at Soldier Field, the Bears have their sights set on a new stadium that brings their facilities and capacity into the 21st century. The only question is where they’ll be able to build it.
With only eight years left on the Bears’ Soldier Field lease, the NFL team has started to entertain proposals that would keep it near the lakefront or even send it to the northwest suburbs, where the franchise currently owns the property of the now-closed Arlington Park racetrack.
The Bears and public officials have not come to terms yet on any stadium deal, but developers and the team are pushing bold (and expensive) ideas. All of them involve moving the Bears into a world-class stadium with a dome. My colleagues at the Sun-Times have sized up the pros and cons of the three most prominent proposals — Arlington Heights, the museum campus lakefront and the former Michael Reese hospital site in Bronzeville. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
‘Lakshmi’ could be the next surprising romantic comedy set in Chicago
 
Puja, a Chicago-area actress, writer and director, is working to develop a new romantic comedy that she feels will speak to her fellow Gen Xers, especially immigrants aging in the U.S.
 Lakshmi
 focuses on falling in love later in life; Puja dreamed up the story after wondering about widowhood. The script made it to the quarterfinals of a prestigious screenwriting competition and has attracted the interest of prolific Indian actress Neena Gupta for the lead role.
The story begins when 60-year-old Lakshmi, recently widowed and living in Chicago, finds a surprise romance with fun, spiritual and chaotic Tom. Jim Carrey has been floated for Lakshmi’s newfound love, while Bollywood star Aamir Khan could play a supporting role, Puja told Block Club Chicago.
“If you had an arranged marriage and then you, like, stumble into first love at 60 years old, that’s hilarious and a lot,” she said. “I feel like it’s enough to just navigate falling in love when you’re young … and then there’s this other idea [that] it’s never too late.” [
Block Club Chicago
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
Coyote vs. Acme
, a completed Looney Tunes film with a big-name cast that Warner Bros. shelved for tax incentives in 2023, may soon see the light of day. [
Variety
]
New evidence from astronomers may upend our understanding of dark matter — and Einstein’s model of the universe. [
New York Times
]
President Donald Trump signed an executive order eliminating the Department of Education, an action only permitted with Congressional approval. [
AP
]
A promising experimental treatment for certain forms of hereditary Alzheimer’s disease faces danger from the Trump administration’s cuts to research funding. [
AP
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
If you’re a fan of artists like Vampire Weekend, Fall Out Boy or Jenny Lewis, chances are that you’ve heard Greta Morgan’s music live. Morgan’s band The Hush Sound toured with Fall Out Boy while Morgan was still a suburban Illinois high schooler in the mid-aughts. She went on to create a number of projects, from solo band Springtime Carnivore to a punk cover album with LA rocker Katy Goodman.
The multi-instrumentalist-slash-vocalist joined Vampire Weekend as a touring member in 2018, even joining for the band’s Lollapalooza set that year. But Morgan’s voice — her livelihood — would soon be altered by COVID-19. Five years ago this month, the Oak Brook–raised singer contracted the virus, which she believes happened during a festival in Okeechobee, Florida, where she performed with Vampire Weekend.
In her forthcoming memoir 
The Lost Voice
, Morgan chronicles how the disease left her voice impaired. “The top half of my range became inaccessible,” she said, “and I began to feel like a stranger in my own body as well.” Now a participant in the Mayo Clinic’s long COVID treatment program, Morgan is still navigating all of the ways that COVID has shaped her art and life writ large. [
WBEZ
]
 
Tell me something good
 
The Cubs are in Tokyo and the Music Box Theatre is running a series on 
baseball films
. That has me wondering: What’s your favorite sports movie?
 
Bill writes:
"Favorite Baseball Movie: ‘Bang the Drum Slowly,’ a 1973 gem starring Robert De Niro pre-Travis Bickle and an equally youthful Michael Moriarty. Funny, sad, tragic and even a bit loopy, it’s a classic from one of Hollywood's best periods. I love this movie, but I don't think I know a soul who has seen it. A pity."
 
Paul writes:
“‘A League of Their Own!’ An all-star cast, memorable dialogue (“There’s no crying in baseball!”), and a fact-based story that even has an Illinois connection (the Rockford Peaches) - what more could you ask for?”
 
Alison writes:
“A League of Their Own is undoubtedly the best sports movie ever. Then the miniseries with Abbi Jacobson and D'Arcy Carden that came out a few years ago was even better!”
Feel free to email me, and your response may be included in the newsletter this week.
Thanks for reading — have a great evening! I'll see you tomorrow.
— Esther Bergdahl
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting. 
DONATE TODAY

subject: Re: March Madness Pool
body:
All,
Higher seed (number on top) is the lower number, lower seed(number on the side) is the higher number.  Using Wisconsin and Montana as an example, Larry Liss would win with the 5 and 6 square.  
I know this is rather complicated and I apologize for doing a poor job of explaining.  Hopefully this helps.
Mike
Sent from my iPhone
On Mar 19, 2025, at 7:52 PM, Kristy Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
﻿And we did it. We have sold all 100.  Thank you again to everyone for your contributions.  Let the games begin. 
Sent from my iPhone
On Mar 19, 2025, at 6:42 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
﻿
Sorry folks, I had the wrong day, games start tomorrow. We have 9 more squares so if anyone wants more or knows someone who would like to play, let me know and we can fill in the empty ones and reissue the sheet.
Thanks
Mike
On Mar 19, 2025, at 5:39 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Hello All,
Just under the wire here.  I had some late editions so my apologies for getting this out late.  
Rules are one winner per game, $100 payout per game.  Last numbers of each team's final score is the winning square.  Left to right (x-axis) is the higher seeded team and top to bottom (y-axis) is the lower seeded team. 
This may require some further explanation so let me know and I'll be happy to go over it.  Thank you again to all and good luck to all.
Mike
On Mar 17, 2025, at 7:50 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Thank you all again for another nice push yesterday.  We currently need 38 more squares sold.  Please continue to reach out to friends and family.  I am keeping it open as long as I can which means I will close it and send out the sheet around 5 pm EST Tuesday.  If we don't hit the 100 mark, we will eliminate the early games to compensate.  Hope we dont have to do that so let's get to 100.
Thank you again to all
Mike
On Mar 16, 2025, at 2:35 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Afternoon Everyone,
We are getting closer to our goal of 100 squares with 46 left.  Very much appreciate everyone who has contributed up to this point.  We still have plenty of opportunities to jump in as there are 46 squares left.  Please reach out to friends and family.  
Thank you again to all
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 1:53 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
I am going to work very hard to keep this at the top of everyone's inbox. I apologize in advance for the amount of emails I plan on sending out.  We are wrapping up the fundraising so we need one final big push. We have until Monday night to fill this sheet out.  I started by purchasing 3 myself.  97 more.  The brackets are fun but the odds of winning anything at all are relatively low.  With the squares, your odds of winning are significantly higher and much more realistic than football squares.  3 days, please pass along to friends or family that would like to join in supporting the baseball program.
Thank you
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 12:07 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Evening Everyone,
Just want to say thank you again for the great support shown during the fundraising and the First Pitch Event.  We are now reaching the end of the fundraising season as we enter the baseball season.  As you are likely aware, there are other groups at DePaul doing March Madness brackets. I know it puts more pressure on families to financially engage and we try to avoid it.  Regardless, we're gonna open our final fundraiser and try something a little different.  Rather than doing the traditional bracket, we are going to do squares. This is very simple, buy your squares and win based on the final score of each game.  Remember, there are 67 games when including the play in games.  That means you literally have 67 chances to win.  With each game fetching a $100 prize, you could win up to $6700.  Let's make this the biggest fundraising event yet.  Send it out to friends and families.  Let's make sure we sell this one out  We're going $100 per square.  Payment cam be made with Zelle to 
rogs1@mac.com
.
Let me know if you have any questions.
Mike
<March Madness Squares.pdf>

subject: Tariffs spark a rush of car sales
body:
Plus, funding cuts to Illinois Humanities. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Friday - April 4, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Bianca Cseke
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! It’s Friday and, nine games into the season, the 
Cubs
 finally play at Wrigley Field. Here’s what else you need to know today.
  
1.
Car buyers are rushing to lock in deals before President Donald Trump’s tariffs raise prices
 
Chicago-area dealerships say they’ve seen an increase in sales and foot traffic as the new taxes on cars assembled outside the U.S. kick in, Bob Chiarito reports for the Chicago Sun-Times.
The tariffs will also apply to imported auto parts starting May 3, which will add to the cost of cars made in the U.S., as well as auto repairs. The tariffs were part of a much larger move declaring taxes on imports from all countries.
Car prices affected by tariffs will vary widely based on the automaker and the model, but the Budget Lab at Yale University estimated “a loss of purchasing power of $3,800 per household on average.”
For now, people like Katie Lopez, a 48-year-old social worker from Mount Greenwood, are on a mission to buy a car before any tariffs cause potential price increases.
Dealers across the Chicago area have been preparing the last couple of months by increasing their inventory, and car sales teams have been using the threat of tariffs to spur customers into action — with some telling the Sun-Times they’ve recently experienced record sales. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
2.
A gun turned over to Chicago police wound up in the hands of a teenager
 
The Chicago Police Department has used gun buybacks to get thousands of guns off the street, but at least two of them have resurfaced at crime scenes, Casey Toner, Tom Schuba and Peter Nickeas report for the Chicago Sun-Times and the Illinois Answers Project.
A December 2023 gun buyback event was marked by excitement, confusion and ultimately chaos after one cop inventorying the weapons at a police station noticed a Glock handgun was missing. In an office full of cops assigned to inventory the guns and keep them secure, someone had walked off with the weapon.
Police say they found the stolen gun nearly a year later after chasing down a 16-year-old boy who had allegedly been pulling on car door handles in South Shore, about five miles from where the buyback event took place.
The lost weapon’s journey mirrored an earlier event in which a gun turned in by a Cook County judge disappeared from another buyback in Chicago — only to resurface at a fatal police shooting in Cicero, as the Better Government Association and Chicago Sun-Times reported in 2017.
Both cases raise questions about the integrity and logistics of Chicago’s gun buybacks, which are a key element of the police department’s community policing and public relations efforts. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM GREATER CHICAGO FOOD DEPOSITORY
Helping Our Neighbors
More Chicagoans than ever are struggling to put food on the table. 1 in 5 local households faces hunger. Proposed federal cuts to critical hunger-relief programs will make the situation worse. But you can make a difference for our neighbors. 
Gifts to the Food Depository
 are now matched to provide 2x immediate relief for families, older adults and veterans reeling from economic challenges.
3.
Families are turning to the Illinois Attorney General to help bring back surgeries for transgender youth
 
About two months ago, Lurie Children’s Hospital and Northwestern Memorial Hospital, stopped providing gender care surgeries for people younger than 19 after an executive order from President Donald Trump threatened to cut federal funding.
After the order, Raoul and 14 other attorneys general vowed to protect access to gender-affirming care. But this week, Raoul said it would be hard to make a case Lurie and Northwestern are violating state law, my colleague Kristen Schorsch reports.
In recent weeks dozens of families and advocates have written to Raoul’s office asking him to enforce the Illinois Human Rights Act and demand hospitals keep providing treatment, according to documents WBEZ obtained under the Illinois Freedom of Information Act.
Many families have told WBEZ they feel betrayed and disappointed by the hospitals’ actions, and they fear what other gender-affirming care the hospitals may stop next. [
WBEZ
]
4.
Nine years after the FBI knocked on his door, the feds are moving to toss the charges against former Ald. Danny Solis
 
The request, part of a deal Solis struck with the feds in 2018, brings his case to a stunning but long-expected conclusion and signals the end of an era at the Dirksen Federal Courthouse, my colleague Jon Seidel writes for the Chicago Sun-Times.
Though he’s been labeled a “massive tax cheat” and a “malignant tumor,” he’s also been described as a “walking microphone” and one of the “most significant” undercover government moles Chicago has seen in decades. Prosecutors say he delivered “extraordinary” cooperation that helped them snare two of the city’s most powerful politicians.
Now, Solis appears to be square with the federal government. Barring a surprise twist, he’ll walk away with his freedom, criminal record and pension intact. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
Illinois Humanities faces an abrupt $1 million funding cut
 
The Trump administration’s cuts to the National Endowment for the Humanities could have a trickle down effect on museums, history programs and Chicago’s popular humanities festival, my colleague Mike Davis reports for WBEZ.
Among the list of Illinois organizations that received federal humanities funding in the past three years are the Adler Planetarium, the Newberry Library, the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library, the Art Institute of Chicago, several colleges and universities and even the city’s newest cultural institution, the 
National Museum for Public Housing
, which formally opened today.  
The cuts are significant because they come midyear, when projects have been started with the promised funding, said Gabrielle Lyon, executive director of Illinois Humanities. She said she’ll be watching closely to see whether the federal government will actually be allowed to pull the grant at all. [
WBEZ
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
The job market remained healthy last month — but tariffs could upend things. [
NPR
]
Severe weather killed at least seven people across the Midwest and South, and more storms are expected this weekend. [
AP
]
Canadians are canceling trips to Chicago over Trump, sparking worries ahead of the summer tourist season. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
Cook County’s prescribed burn program, which was once banned, has grown into one of the largest in the country. [
Block Club Chicago
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
Baby fever has spread throughout Brookfield Zoo.
Some of the spring babies expected include Humboldt penguin chicks, a nyala antelope calf, a western gray kangaroo joey and Lake Titicaca frogs, according to the zoo.
Brookfield Zoo has led efforts in a conservation program at Punta San Juan for nearly 20 years. Researchers estimate the wild population of the penguins to be under 24,000 and about 30 live in a colony at the zoo.
The penguins will be on display beginning in June, zoo officials said in a statement. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
 
Tell me something good
 
What’s the best book you’ve read recently? I finally have some room on my library hold list, and I always feel like staying in for weeks after getting back from long trips.
Susan writes:
“
Wildwood 
by Elinor Florence is one I would definitely read again. A beautifully written story of Molly, a young single mom, down on her luck, who inherits a house & farm in Canada from a great-aunt. It details her life with her non-verbal child in the Canadian backcountry-wilderness, her struggles to overcome her situation and survive her first Canadian winter. And a love story, too.”
Karen writes:
“
Frozen River
 is the story of a famous midwife in the 1700s, how she grew as a woman and a midwife in a community that gave all advantages to the men. It’s also a mystery based on her diary.”
And Lisa writes:
“
The Small and the Mighty
 by Sharon McMahon is such a fascinating and inspirational book. It really highlights the amazing ripple effects of people doing what they can with what they have and where they are at. These are stories from American history, but they reminded me that there are always important ways to make a difference in the world.”
Thanks for all the responses this week! Now to decide what to add first to my library hold list.
Thanks for reading and have a nice weekend! I'll see you on Monday.
— Bianca Cseke
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting. 
DONATE TODAY
©Chicago Public Media Inc 848 East Grand Ave, Navy Pier Chicago, IL 60611

subject: Reimagining Culturally Resilient Initiatives Through the Power of Questions
body:
Register Now for Our April 9th Webinar! ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Reimagining Culturally Resilient Initiatives Through the Power of Questions
 
 
 
 
April 9, 2025 @ 11:30AM ET
 
 
 
 
 
Questions drive innovation, and this webinar invites SIETAR USA members to explore how thoughtful inquiry shaped the adaptation of the Barnga intercultural communication simulation and the creation of the Culturally Resilient Card Deck. Consider the questions that fueled their creative processes—How can we recreate cultural immersion online? What tools enable resilience and understanding in diverse contexts? —as they transformed traditional methods into dynamic virtual experiences. Questioning plays a central role as participants learn how asking questions can uncover new possibilities and create meaningful, culturally rich learning environments. This session offers actionable insights emphasizing the importance of flexibility, cultural awareness, and creative design in fostering meaningful learning experiences that resonate across cultural and digital divides. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
MEMBER REGISTRATION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NON-MEMBER REGISTRATION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
PRESENTERS:
 
Presenters
 
Dr. Terra Gargano serves as the Director of Faculty Development and Academic Affairs in the School of Education at Johns Hopkins University. Throughout her twenty-five-year career in higher education, she managed dozens of institutional collaborations worldwide, conducted workshops for faculty at domestic and international organizations, and learned alongside her students in the US and over a dozen countries. She taught English in Japan, serving as the Assistant Dean for Semester at Sea before joining the faculty at American University as the Program Director and Faculty Advisor for Online Programs in the School, with students logging into classes from over 15 time zones. She is a fierce Skee-Ball competitor and enjoys a good campfire story.  
Dr. Ed Timke, assistant professor in the Department of Advertising + PR at Michigan State University, is an expert in intercultural and global studies of media, with a focus on disability. He taught intercultural communication at American University’s School of International Service and held faculty positions at Duke University and the University of California, Berkeley. Through the International Student Exchange Programs, Ed taught English in a French high school and collaborated on international research projects. Living with a lifelong hearing disability, he advocates for accessibility and inclusion. When not spoiling six cats or trying to get home to the forests of the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, Ed enjoys “just one more coffee" and indulging his ultimate vice: The Golden Girls.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent by SIETAR USA 
4880 Lower Roswell Rd, Suite 165 • Marietta , GA • 30068

body:
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Monica,
Let’s be real—
federal jobs aren’t as “safe” as they used to be.
 Budget cuts, downsizing, and restructuring are happening 
at every level.
The real question is: 
Are you ready for what’s next?
Inside The Federal Pivot Webinar, you’ll learn:
 
How to translate your federal experience
 so hiring managers actually 
understand
 your value.
 
The biggest mistakes
 federal employees make when applying to the private sector.
 
How to rewrite your resume & LinkedIn profile
 to stand out—immediately.
 
The salary negotiation strategy
 that ensures you 
never
 get lowballed.
BONUS:
 Show up live & get 
The Federal Pivot Toolkit
—your step-by-step guide to making the transition the 
right 
way.
Tuesday, March 25, 7PM ET
Opportunities go to those who take action.
 Are you ready?
Register here
. 
Let's get SCRAPPY!
 
Deborah T. Owens
Head Alley Cat
 
PS - Share this webinar with your friends and colleagues!
 
 
 
 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent by Corporate Alley Cat 
641 S St. NW, Suite 300 • Washington, DC • 20001

subject: Culture Shift Team Invites you to Download the Free Guide on the Current Landscape of Corporate DEI Commitment
body:
Dear Monica, 
As the business environment evolves amid increasing social and political challenges, the commitment to Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) becomes more critical than ever. While some high-profile companies like Meta, John Deere, and Walmart have reevaluated their DEI efforts, it's important to recognize that the core values of DEI remain indispensable, especially for globally focused organizations. 
CST’s Latest Resource:
 We've released a primer on "The Current Landscape of Corporate DEI Commitment" that sheds light on how major corporations are navigating these changes. Despite some companies scaling back, an overwhelming majority of Fortune 500 companies remain steadfast in their commitment, driven by the tangible benefits DEI brings to talent management, employee engagement, and bottom-line profitability. 
Why This Guide? Our comprehensive guide is designed to help you understand:
Rebranding DEI: A Strategy or a Retreat?
 Explore why some companies are rebranding their DEI initiatives and the implications of such changes. 
Short-Term Gains vs. Long-Term Consequences:
 Analyze the immediate benefits and potential lasting impacts of scaling back DEI efforts. 
The Role of Corporate Leadership in Shaping DEI:
 Discover how leadership decisions influence the direction and effectiveness of DEI strategies. 
The Internal Effect of Disengagement:
 Understand how reducing commitment to DEI can affect employee morale and corporate culture. 
2025 Recommended Approach to Organizational Inclusion:
 Learn about the forward-thinking strategies to foster a more inclusive organizational environment. 
Download Your Free Guide: Embrace a strategic, integrated approach to safeguard and promote your corporate values and competitiveness in a global business environment. Click below to access our free guide and start enhancing your DEI commitment today.
Download the Corporate DEI Commitment Guide
CST is a leading consultancy specializing in Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) strategies that foster inclusive and equitable environments within organizations. At CST, we understand that true change comes from thoughtfully designed strategies that address systemic inequities head-on. Our services range from comprehensive DEI assessments and customized training programs to strategic planning and implementation that ensure sustainable cultural transformation. 
We work closely with each client to create environments where diverse talents are valued, and inclusive practices are woven into the fabric of everyday business operations. Our goal is to empower organizations to not only meet but exceed their DEI objectives, driving innovation and enhancing corporate reputation by truly embracing the power of diversity. 
Warm regards,
Robert Lawrence Wilson
robert.wilson@cultureshiftteam.com
Chief Strategy Officer
Inclusive Workplace Culture Expert
Culture Shift Team, Inc.
https://www.cultureshiftteam.com

subject: Make sure you file a tax return
body:
Here's what you need to know about filing your taxes. 
View in browser
 
 
Your Taxes and Help with Marketplace Costs
Monica
 
Remember: 
If you haven’t already filed your taxes, now’s the time to do so.
 
According to our records, you enrolled in a Marketplace health plan for 2024 and got help with your premium costs. You must file a federal income tax return for 2024 using information from the Form 1095-A we mailed to you. This is true even if you don’t normally have to file. To get an electronic copy of your Form 1095-A, log into 
HealthCare.gov
, select your 
2024
 application, then select “Tax forms.”
 
Your 2024 tax return is how you’ll compare the amount of financial help you received and the actual amount you qualify for in 2024 based on your final income. If there’s a difference, it might affect the size of your refund or how much you owe on your tax return.
 
 
Important:
 File your income tax return by the 
April 15, 2025 deadline
 using the information on Form 1095-A we provided by mail or online. If you don’t do this, you might lose your help with premium costs in the future.
 
 The
 
HealthCare.gov
 Team
 
P.S.
 Many people with Marketplace coverage can get free help with filling out their taxes. This may include free access to tax software programs, or free in-person help. For more information, visit 
IRS.gov/freefile
 or
 IRS.gov/VITA
.
This message is paid for by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. It was created and distributed by the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. You're receiving this message because you signed up for email updates from the HealthCare.gov Team. You can 
update your preferences
,

 or

 until the next Open Enrollment period, or

 to stop receiving messages from the HealthCare.gov Team. Please contact support@subscriptions.cms.hhs.gov if you have questions or problems with your subscriptions.

subject: Unlock Federal Success: GSA Schedule = Your Storefront
body:
Unlock Federal Success: GSA Schedule = Your Storefront                                              
Unlock Federal Success: GSA Schedule = Your Storefront
LEARN MORE
Unlock Federal Success: GSA Schedule = Your Storefront
Discover how a GSA Schedule can become your federal storefront and unlock new opportunities for working with the government. This week, we'll explore the significance of having a GSA Schedule and why it's crucial for businesses seeking to do work with the federal government.
B-to-B and B-to-G Sales Channels: Similarities and Differences
While business-to-business (B-to-B) and business-to-government (B-to-G) sales channels share some commonalities, they also have distinct differences. As businesses scale, their purchasing processes often resemble those of government entities, with bureaucratic structures and complex procurement procedures. For small businesses, navigating these complexities can be daunting. That's where GSA Schedules come in, providing a streamlined storefront to facilitate federal government contracting.
Federal Government Structure for Making Purchases
Sam.gov
Think of a SAM.gov profile like having a phone number that's constantly being bombarded with cold calls. You wouldn't respond to every inquiry, would you? Similarly, a SAM.gov profile can be a necessary step, but it's not an effective way to stand out or attract meaningful business opportunities. In today's competitive market, having a robust online presence is crucial for attracting and engaging with potential clients.
GSA Schedule
Obtaining a GSA Schedule elevates your company to the mid-tier of federal procurement, giving you a prime storefront. After investing time and effort into demonstrating your reliability, capabilities, and competitive pricing, you're now positioned to play a significant role in the federal government's procurement landscape. A GSA Schedule is a crucial stepping stone for federal contracting, allowing you to participate in the government's buying process.
Specific GWACs and IDIQ Contracts
Your GSA Schedule is generating revenue and attracting new clients. As your business grows, it's essential to expand your capacity to meet the demands of larger accounts. To take your business to the next level, consider targeting larger government-wide contracts, such as GWACs or IDIQs. These contracts streamline the procurement process, reducing competition and increasing your chances of securing lucrative federal contracts.
Teaming, Joint Ventures, being Acquired
Elite federal contractors have built a network of relationships with other trusted vendors, fostering a reputation that often precedes lucrative opportunities. These connections can lead to prime access to coveted contracts, sometimes before the position is even publicly advertised.
While it may take time to reach the highest levels of federal contracting, such as GWACs and IDIQs, or even joint ventures, obtaining a GSA Schedule can quickly establish your firm in the federal market. With a GSA Schedule, you can gain a foothold in just a few months and lay the foundation for future growth. If your firm is looking to make a strong entry into federal contracting, a GSA Schedule is a great place to start.
Obtaining a GSA Schedule is a critical step in establishing your firm as a trusted and reliable partner in the federal contracting landscape. By having a prime storefront, you'll be well-positioned to capitalize on new opportunities and grow your business. If you're ready to take your company to the next level, we're here to help. Our experts can guide you through the process of obtaining a GSA Schedule and provide valuable insights on how to navigate the complexities of federal contracting. Don't wait - give us a call today to schedule a consultation and start unlocking the doors to new opportunities in federal contracting.
Emily Hatchel
859-360-0909
www.advancegsa.com
 
Questions?
 Contact us today 1-859-360-0909
Advance GSA
10500 Norbotten Dr
Florence Kentucky 41042
United States

subject: 12 players with opportunities after injuries
body:
Plus: GOAT doing goat yoga?
Thursday, March 20
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS
 
Which teams are leveling up? Let's sort 2025 contenders into 9 tiers
 
This isn't about ranking clubs 1-30, but it's more about expectations and feelings, about where each team is in a broad sense -- and where they’re going this season.
 
deGrom finds he has more to work on after 2nd spring start
Espada confirms Altuve will be Astros' primary left fielder
Suárez's back injury could force Walker into Phillies' rotation
Mayer lining up to start at 2B for Sox? 'I'm always ready for anything'
Díaz's velo is down from his peak. Does it matter?
Elias: Playoff-hungry O's in a 'different mode' after rebuild success
Young Pirates righty Jones (right elbow discomfort) done pitching this spring
MORE TOP NEWS

MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
Injuries could open opportunities for these 12 players
 
For teams hampered by spring injuries, unproven players will have a chance to fill the void left by key contributors.
 
Who's up for some GOAT yoga?
 
The newest Mariners digital short features their newest Hall of Famer -- and literal goats.
 
Astros shoot for the moon, landing on new City Connect unis
 
Houston introduced its City Connect 2.0 uniforms, which keep with the space theme but feature a few changes and a new color scheme: "I love them. I think they look clean," Jeremy Peña said.
 
The Prince who was promised? Another Fielder making mark
 
Jadyn Fielder has true baseball pedigree, and as a Brewers Minor Leaguer he is part of an organization he grew up in. But the 20-year-old is out to show he's a different player from his dad and grandpa.
 
The top 11 moments from Spring Breakout
 
Instead of abbreviated seven-inning contests like in 2024, this year's prospect showcases lasted a full nine frames. That meant more at-bats, more filthy pitches and most importantly, more eye-popping moments. MLB Pipeline picks the best.
 
Chatting Practice: Elly De La Cruz
 
Reds shortstop Elly De La Cruz fielded questions from fans on Chatting Practice Powered by Zoom Events.
 
 
Spring Training tripleheader
 
It’s Phillies vs. Braves at 1 p.m. ET (available in Phillies market), Angels vs. White Sox at 4 (available in White Sox market) and Rangers vs. Padres at 9 (available in Rangers market), live on MLB Network.

EXPLORE ALL BENEFITS

Stays & Cars
 
 
 
 
 
Email Preferences
  |  
Privacy Policy
 
Business Card POID: K93G:9993
Terms and Conditions
Additional 
Rates and Fees
 Apply
1.
 
You can earn 110,000 bonus miles after you make  $12,000 or more (the "Threshold Amount") in eligible purchases on your Delta SkyMiles
® 
Reserve Business American Express Card within your first 6 months of Card Membership starting from the date that your account is opened. Miles will be credited to your account 8-12 weeks after you reach the Threshold Amount. Bonus Miles may appear on your account in more than one deposit. To receive the 110,000 bonus miles, your Card account must not be canceled or past due at the time of fulfillment. Eligible purchases can be made by the Basic Card Member and any Additional Card Members on a single Card account. Eligible purchases are purchases for goods and services minus returns and other credits. Eligible purchases to meet the spend requirement do NOT include fees or interest charges, cash advances, purchases of traveler's checks, purchases or reloading of prepaid cards, purchases of gift cards, person-to-person payments, or purchases of any cash equivalents. Additional Card Members on your account are not eligible for their own offer. In rare instances, your period to spend $12,000 may be shorter than 6 months if there is a delay in receiving your Card. Also, purchases may fall outside of the 6 month period in some cases, such as a delay in merchants submitting transactions to us or if the purchase date differs from the date you made the transaction. (For example, if you buy goods online, the purchase date may be the date the goods are shipped). This offer is not transferable. If your application is not received by 04/02/2025, we will not process your application even if we later receive your application. American Express reserves the right to modify or revoke offer at any time.  ​
If you have a history of cancelling or downgrading American Express Card accounts within your first year and you cancel or downgrade your new Card account within your first year, we may not credit, we may freeze, or we may take away the bonus miles from your account. If we determine that you have engaged in abuse, misuse, or gaming in connection with this offer in any way or that you intend to do so, including if you return purchases you made to meet the Threshold Amount, we may not credit, we may freeze, or we may take away the bonus miles from your account. We may also cancel any accounts you have with us.​
2.
 
Expanded Buying Power
The portion of your account balance that is above your credit limit is due in full each month as part of your minimum payment due. You will not incur interest charges on the portion of your account balance that is above your credit limit so long as you pay the entire minimum payment due by the closing date of the billing period in which it is due. If you do not, then the penalty rate will apply to your entire balance, including any amount above the credit limit. Some Delta SkyMiles Reserve Business American Express Card Members who opened their accounts prior to 2/1/24 may not have the Expanded Buying Power feature on their accounts. Please call the number on the back of your card to confirm.
3.
 
Miles on Eligible Purchases
1x Mile on eligible purchases:
 Basic Card Members will earn 1 mile for each dollar of eligible purchases charged on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account.
1.5x Miles on U.S. Shipping:
 Basic Card Members will earn 0.5 additional miles (for a total of 1.5 miles) for each dollar of eligible purchases on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account charged at merchants in the U.S. for shipping services. To earn additional miles for shipping, eligible purchases must be made at courier, postal, and freight shippers located in the U.S. Basic Card Members will not earn additional miles for shipping costs added to retail purchases or moving services.
 
1.5x Miles on Transit:
 Basic Card Members will earn 0.5 additional miles (for a total of 1.5 miles) for each dollar of eligible transit purchases on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account. Eligible transit purchases include purchases with train, taxicab, ride share service, ferry, toll, parking, bus, and subway merchants. Purchases of airfare, car rental and cruises are not considered eligible transit purchases.
 
1.5x Miles at U.S. Office Supply Stores:
 Basic Card Members will earn 0.5 additional miles (for a total of 1.5 miles) for each dollar of eligible purchases on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account at office supply stores located in the U.S. Office supply stores are in the business of selling a range of office supplies, including items like: paper, notebooks, office equipment, and office furniture. Office supplies purchased at other retail stores will not earn additional miles.
 
1.5x Miles on purchases after spending $150,000:
 If in any calendar year eligible purchases made on the Delta SkyMiles
® 
Reserve Business Card total more than $150,000, Basic Card Members will earn 0.5 additional miles (for a total of 1.5 miles) on eligible purchases on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account made after the $150,000 threshold is reached through the end of the same calendar year. Only one accelerator will apply even if a purchase qualifies for multiple mileage categories. If an eligible purchase qualifies for a category that has a higher mileage accelerator, only the higher accelerator will apply instead of the one-half mile per dollar. For example, if you make a Delta purchase after reaching the $150,000 threshold, the Basic Card Member will earn two additional miles per dollar instead of an additional one-half mile per dollar for that Delta purchase. The close of the calendar year is December 31st without regard to the time of the year that the account is opened. This means that for the first year of Card Membership, the Card Account’s time period to reach the $150,000 threshold may be less than twelve months.
3x Miles on Delta Purchases:
 Basic Card Members will earn 2 additional miles (for a total of 3 miles) on each dollar of eligible purchases on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account charged directly with Delta where Delta is the merchant of record, such as purchases via 
delta.com
, the Fly Delta app, phone reservations, or ticket counters, for upgrades, miles, seat selection, Delta Sky Club
® 
membership, and in-flight purchases of food and beverages on Delta-operated flights (“Delta Purchases”). Delta Purchases do not include in-flight purchases where Delta is not the merchant of record, such as in-flight wireless internet access and charitable contributions. Delta Purchases do not include Delta Gift Cards and purchases made at 
deltashop.com
 and/or the Delta Flight Museum. Delta Purchases include Delta Vacations
® 
packages but not other all-inclusive packages. Delta Purchases include new Delta Stays prepaid hotel or vacation rental bookings on the Delta Stays platform (
delta.com/stays
). Delta Purchases include purchases of qualifying Delta, Delta Connection
®
 carrier and Delta Shuttle
® 
flights taken with the purchase of a fare that is eligible for SkyMiles mileage credit. For purposes of this Card benefit, “Delta Purchases” also includes Delta Basic Economy fares, notwithstanding that these fares do not earn SkyMiles mileage credit for travel. Full SkyMiles program terms: 
delta.com/memberguide 
. Additional miles earned for Delta flight purchases made with the Card will be based on the total ticket price, including base fare, carrier-imposed surcharges and government-imposed taxes and fees.
Eligible purchases are purchases for goods and services minus returns and other credits. Eligible purchases do NOT include fees or interest charges, cash advances, purchases of travelers checks, purchases of gift cards, person-to-person transactions, purchases or reloading of prepaid cards, or purchases of other cash equivalents. Miles will be posted to the Basic Card Member’s Delta SkyMiles account 8 to 12 weeks after the end of each month. To be eligible to receive miles, the Card Account must not be canceled or past due at the time of fulfillment.
Merchants are assigned codes based on what they primarily sell. We group certain merchant codes into categories that are eligible for additional miles. A purchase with a merchant will not receive additional miles if the merchant’s code is not included in a reward category. Basic Card Members may not receive additional miles if we receive inaccurate information or are otherwise unable to identify the purchase as eligible for a reward category. For example, Basic Card Members may not receive additional miles when: a merchant uses a third-party to sell their products or services; or a merchant uses a third-party to process or submit the transaction to us (e.g., using mobile or wireless card readers); or Card Members choose to make a purchase using a third-party payment account or make a purchase using a mobile or digital wallet.
For questions about additional miles on a purchase, call the number on the back of your Card. Please visit 
americanexpress.com/rewards-info
 for more information about rewards.
General: 
All SkyMiles program rules apply. To review the rules, please visit 
Membership Guide & Program Rules 
. Prices and rules are subject to change without notice. Delta, SkyMiles, and the Delta logo are registered service marks of Delta Air Lines, Inc. Delta is not responsible for goods or services offered by any companies participating in miles promotions. Partner offers subject to the terms and conditions of each individual offer. See individual offers for details. Partners subject to change. Offers void where prohibited by law. Other restrictions may apply.
Comment or Complaint?
 
Unsubscribe
 
This email advertisement was sent to: 
monica@lcwmail.com
 
© 2025 American Express National Bank.
© 2025 Delta Air Lines, Inc. All rights reserved.
Delta Blvd. P.O. Box 20706 • Atlanta, GA 30320-6001

22nd March 2025, in Gurga
on!

Experience how Lumina Spark uncovers inter- and intra-personal dynamics 
Explore its applications in executive coaching, leadership development, and talent optimization through experiential activities.

subject: Re: March Madness Pool
body:
As I mentioned, we are now sold out of squares.  Please see the updated sheet and good luck to all.
Mike
On Mar 19, 2025, at 6:52 PM, Kristy Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
And we did it. We have sold all 100.  Thank you again to everyone for your contributions.  Let the games begin. 
Sent from my iPhone
On Mar 19, 2025, at 6:42 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
﻿
Sorry folks, I had the wrong day, games start tomorrow. We have 9 more squares so if anyone wants more or knows someone who would like to play, let me know and we can fill in the empty ones and reissue the sheet.
Thanks
Mike
On Mar 19, 2025, at 5:39 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Hello All,
Just under the wire here.  I had some late editions so my apologies for getting this out late.  
Rules are one winner per game, $100 payout per game.  Last numbers of each team's final score is the winning square.  Left to right (x-axis) is the higher seeded team and top to bottom (y-axis) is the lower seeded team. 
This may require some further explanation so let me know and I'll be happy to go over it.  Thank you again to all and good luck to all.
Mike
On Mar 17, 2025, at 7:50 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Thank you all again for another nice push yesterday.  We currently need 38 more squares sold.  Please continue to reach out to friends and family.  I am keeping it open as long as I can which means I will close it and send out the sheet around 5 pm EST Tuesday.  If we don't hit the 100 mark, we will eliminate the early games to compensate.  Hope we dont have to do that so let's get to 100.
Thank you again to all
Mike
On Mar 16, 2025, at 2:35 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Afternoon Everyone,
We are getting closer to our goal of 100 squares with 46 left.  Very much appreciate everyone who has contributed up to this point.  We still have plenty of opportunities to jump in as there are 46 squares left.  Please reach out to friends and family.  
Thank you again to all
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 1:53 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
I am going to work very hard to keep this at the top of everyone's inbox. I apologize in advance for the amount of emails I plan on sending out.  We are wrapping up the fundraising so we need one final big push. We have until Monday night to fill this sheet out.  I started by purchasing 3 myself.  97 more.  The brackets are fun but the odds of winning anything at all are relatively low.  With the squares, your odds of winning are significantly higher and much more realistic than football squares.  3 days, please pass along to friends or family that would like to join in supporting the baseball program.
Thank you
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 12:07 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Evening Everyone,
Just want to say thank you again for the great support shown during the fundraising and the First Pitch Event.  We are now reaching the end of the fundraising season as we enter the baseball season.  As you are likely aware, there are other groups at DePaul doing March Madness brackets. I know it puts more pressure on families to financially engage and we try to avoid it.  Regardless, we're gonna open our final fundraiser and try something a little different.  Rather than doing the traditional bracket, we are going to do squares. This is very simple, buy your squares and win based on the final score of each game.  Remember, there are 67 games when including the play in games.  That means you literally have 67 chances to win.  With each game fetching a $100 prize, you could win up to $6700.  Let's make this the biggest fundraising event yet.  Send it out to friends and families.  Let's make sure we sell this one out  We're going $100 per square.  Payment cam be made with Zelle to 
rogs1@mac.com
.
Let me know if you have any questions.
Mike
<March Madness Squares.pdf>

subject: Try Xfinity Mobile for a year
body:
Included with your Xfinity Internet service.
 
 
Get an Unlimited 5G mobile line 
INCLUDED for a year
 
With your internet, when you switch to Xfinity Mobile.
Claim your line
 
Offer ends 6/21. Xfinity Internet 300 Mbps or above required. Reduced speeds after 30 GB of usage/line. 
Details & restrictions
Save up to $300
 on a new smartwatch with Xfinity Rewards
When you switch to Xfinity Mobile as an Xfinity Rewards member. Not enrolled? It's free to join and easy to enjoy.
Explore rewards
 
Ends 4/14. Xfinity Internet and Xfinity Mobile required. Each smartwatch will be charged an additional $10 monthly smartwatch line fee. 
Details & restrictions
 
 
INTRODUCING XFINITY SPORTS & NEWS TV
Save $150/year over YouTube TV
It's finally college basketball season! Watch all your favorite teams throughout March as they battle each bracket.
Score the ultimate sports experience for an all-in price of $70/mo. Plus, enjoy Peacock Premium at no extra cost (currently $7.99/mo).
Add today
 
Savings compares Xfinity Sports & News TV ($70/mo) to YouTube TV ($82.99/mo) and Hulu Live TV ($82.99/mo).
 
 
ONLY WITH XFINITY
Stay connected even when the unexpected happens with Storm–Ready WiFi
No matter what storm life brings, Storm-Ready WiFi will keep you online during network and power outages with unlimited cellular data and up to four hours of Battery Backup.
Add today
 
Restrictions apply. Only available in areas within range of applicable 4G LTE cellular signal. Requires Xfinity Internet with compatible Gateway. Fully charged Xfinity Battery Backup will provide up to 4 hours of power. Device runs on cellular 4G LTE (data plans not affected).
During power outages, Internet will be reduced to speeds up to 30 Mbps download/7 Mbps upload. Actual speeds will vary and are not guaranteed. See pricing and other information for details.
 
 
Want to shop the latest devices in-person? Visit your local Xfinity Store.
Schedule appointment 
Xfinity app
xfinity.com
Ask Xfinity
 
 
 
 
View online
 
|
Unsubscribe
|
Privacy Policy
THIS EMAIL IS AN ADVERTISEMENT
You are receiving this email because you’ve requested to receive emails with information about Comcast products and services.
If you do not wish to receive emails like this in the future, please 
click here
 to unsubscribe.
Please do not reply to this email, it is not monitored. If you'd like to contact us, please visit our website 
here
.
Xfinity Mobile
 requires residential post pay Xfinity Internet. Line limitations may apply. Equip., intl. and roaming charges, taxes and fees, including reg. recovery fees, and other charges extra, and subj. to change. $25/mo. charge applies if Xfinity TV, Internet or Voice post pay services not maintained. Pricing subject to change. During times of network congestion, your cellular data speeds may be slower temporarily. After monthly data use threshold for a line is exceeded, speeds are reduced until the billing cycle ends. A minimum $20.00 charge applies per month, per account for By the Gig lines, regardless of data usage. Charges apply to each GB or partial GB of shared data. No rollover data. For Xfinity Mobile Broadband Disclosures visit: 
www.xfinity.com/mobile/policies/broadband-disclosures
.
Actual speeds vary and not guaranteed. For factors affecting speed visit 
www.xfinity.com/networkmanagement
.
Unlimited 5G mobile line included:
 Offer ends 6/21/25. Restrictions apply. Not available in all areas. New Xfinity Mobile customers only. Requires residential post-pay 300 Mbps internet or above. Offer limited to the value of one Unlimited line applied via 12 monthly bill credits. After 12 months, or if Internet service is canceled or downgraded, regular mobile rates apply.
Xfinity Rewards:
 To be eligible to enroll in the Xfinity Rewards Program you must be a current Xfinity post-pay TV or Internet, or Wireline Voice residential customer with a current and active Xfinity account in good-standing. Comcast employees who receive Xfinity courtesy services are not eligible to participate in the Program with respect to the address at which they receive Xfinity courtesy services. Visit 
xfinity.com/rewards
 for more information.
Up to $300 off eligible smartwatch:
 Offer ends 4/14/25. Limited to Xfinity members with Xfinity Mobile and account in good standing. $300 off for Diamond and Platinum tier Xfinity Rewards members, $150 off for Gold and Silver tier Xfinity Rewards members. Xfinity Mobile requires Xfinity Internet. Must first redeem reward on Xfinity Rewards dashboard, then enter offer code during checkout to receive advertised discount. Requires purchase and activation of new, eligible smartwatch device while supplies last, a 24-month Device Agreement, and activation of new Xfinity Mobile line within 30 days of device purchase date. When smartwatch is paired to compatible phone, data usage counts towards phone plan data allowance. Additional $10 monthly smartwatch fee applies. Pricing subject to change. Additional taxes and fees apply. Applicable taxes for the full smartwatch amount are charged when smartwatch is shipped (or when smartwatch is fulfilled in a Xfinity retail store) and are in addition to the monthly charge. Device credits applied monthly to your account over 24 months so long as Device Agreement is in effect. If line is canceled, voluntarily or involuntarily or device payments are accelerated, balance of credits associated with device payment are forfeited. One unique code per Xfinity Rewards member account/household. Code is valid for use in a maximum of five transactions. Not valid with prior purchases, returns or exchanges. Back orders are eligible. Out of stock devices are not eligible. Cannot be combined with other device offers.
Xfinity Sports & News TV:
 Restrictions apply. Not available in all areas. Limited to Sports & News TV. $70/mo price requires Xfinity Internet. Paperless Billing and Automatic Payments with bank account required, otherwise monthly service charge automatically increases by $10 (or $8 if enrolling with credit or debit card information). Discount will appear on statement within 45 days of enrollment. Equipment, installation, taxes and fees, and other applicable charges extra. Pricing subject to change. Service limited to a single outlet. May not be combined with other offers. TV: Not all programming available in all areas. Limited Basic service subscription required to receive other levels of service. On Demand selections subject to charge indicated at time of purchase. 30-Day Money-Back Guarantee applies to one month’s recurring service and standard installation charges up to $500. Actual channel line-up may vary.
Storm-Ready WiFi:
 Restrictions apply. Not available in all areas. Requires Xfinity Internet with compatible Xfinity Gateway, and within range of 4G LTE cellular signal. Included Xfinity battery req’d. Fully charged Xfinity battery provides up to 4hrs of power. During outages, Internet reduced to speeds up to 30/7 Mbps. Actual speeds vary and are not guaranteed. Taxes and fees extra and subject to change. Storm-Ready WiFi may not be compatible with all changes in the network. For details, please visit 
www.xfinity.com/learn/internet-service/stormready
.
Pricing & Other Information:
 Restrictions apply. Only available in areas within range of applicable 4G LTE cellular signal. Limited to Xfinity Internet customers with a compatible Xfinity Gateway. Storm-Ready WiFi device requires Xfinity Battery Backup, included in price. Taxes and fees extra and subject to change. Fully charged Xfinity Battery Backup will provide up to 4 hours of power to the Xfinity Storm-Ready WiFi device. Device runs on cellular 4G LTE (data plans not affected). During outages, Internet will be reduced to speeds up to 30 Mbps download/7 Mbps upload. Actual speeds will vary and are not guaranteed and may be impacted by a variety of environmental and other factors, including network congestion. Xfinity does not guarantee that 4G LTE will be available in all locations or that a connection will be obtainable. Assumes average power outage of two hours, excluding major events (U.S. Energy Information Administration). In times of congestion, your data may be temporarily slower than other traffic. Storm-Ready WiFi may not be compatible with all changes in the network.
