subject: Re: March Madness Pool
body:
Hello All,
Just under the wire here.  I had some late editions so my apologies for getting this out late.  
Rules are one winner per game, $100 payout per game.  Last numbers of each team's final score is the winning square.  Left to right (x-axis) is the higher seeded team and top to bottom (y-axis) is the lower seeded team. 
This may require some further explanation so let me know and I'll be happy to go over it.  Thank you again to all and good luck to all.
Mike
On Mar 17, 2025, at 7:50 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Thank you all again for another nice push yesterday.  We currently need 38 more squares sold.  Please continue to reach out to friends and family.  I am keeping it open as long as I can which means I will close it and send out the sheet around 5 pm EST Tuesday.  If we don't hit the 100 mark, we will eliminate the early games to compensate.  Hope we dont have to do that so let's get to 100.
Thank you again to all
Mike
On Mar 16, 2025, at 2:35 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Afternoon Everyone,
We are getting closer to our goal of 100 squares with 46 left.  Very much appreciate everyone who has contributed up to this point.  We still have plenty of opportunities to jump in as there are 46 squares left.  Please reach out to friends and family.  
Thank you again to all
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 1:53 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
I am going to work very hard to keep this at the top of everyone's inbox. I apologize in advance for the amount of emails I plan on sending out.  We are wrapping up the fundraising so we need one final big push. We have until Monday night to fill this sheet out.  I started by purchasing 3 myself.  97 more.  The brackets are fun but the odds of winning anything at all are relatively low.  With the squares, your odds of winning are significantly higher and much more realistic than football squares.  3 days, please pass along to friends or family that would like to join in supporting the baseball program.
Thank you
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 12:07 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Evening Everyone,
Just want to say thank you again for the great support shown during the fundraising and the First Pitch Event.  We are now reaching the end of the fundraising season as we enter the baseball season.  As you are likely aware, there are other groups at DePaul doing March Madness brackets. I know it puts more pressure on families to financially engage and we try to avoid it.  Regardless, we're gonna open our final fundraiser and try something a little different.  Rather than doing the traditional bracket, we are going to do squares. This is very simple, buy your squares and win based on the final score of each game.  Remember, there are 67 games when including the play in games.  That means you literally have 67 chances to win.  With each game fetching a $100 prize, you could win up to $6700.  Let's make this the biggest fundraising event yet.  Send it out to friends and families.  Let's make sure we sell this one out  We're going $100 per square.  Payment cam be made with Zelle to 
rogs1@mac.com
.
Let me know if you have any questions.
Mike

Coach Hinkamp

Hello all,

We will practice on both days from 9-11am in the DCP football stadium. Resources & Outside Links
 
Letter from the Principal
 
Dear NCA Families,
As we move through March, I want to take a moment to express my gratitude for the generosity and dedication of our school community. There is so much to celebrate this week!
Minds That Think
This week, we are celebrating National Reading Week! Some of our 3rd - 6th graders are leading the way by sharing their favorite books in our morning meetings. It has been wonderful to see their excitement for reading and to hear the stories that have inspired them. To wrap up our week, Wildcat Buddies will meet on Friday afternoon for a special reading session together. It’s always a joy to see our older and younger students bond over a good book!
Hearts That Love
Last night, we gathered at St. Gertrude Church as our 8th graders received the Sacrament of Confirmation. It was a beautiful and sacred evening, marking an important step in their faith journey. Please join me in praying for these young men and women—that they may fully embrace the gifts of the Holy Spirit and become true disciples of Jesus in all they do.
Hands That Serve
A heartfelt thank you to everyone who contributed to making The Soirée a spectacular success! Our annual fundraising gala netted an incredible $90,000, which will go a long way in supporting our school’s mission and tuition assistance . A special shout-out to the Soirée Committee, whose months of dedication and hard work made this event not only a successful fundraiser but also a memorable evening of community and celebration. Your commitment to serving something bigger than yourselves is an inspiring example for us all.
Also, a reminder that we have an early release on Friday as we head into our much-anticipated Spring Break! We hope you enjoy the time with family and return refreshed and ready for the last stretch of the school year.
Thank you, as always, for your support, faith, and commitment to Northside Catholic Academy. Wishing you all a restful and joyful Spring Break!
Blessings,
Terese Black

The coveted Van Winkle Special Reserve Bourbon (12 yr) is at stake! If you missed the sign up at the Soiree, now's your chance!
We're making some adjustments, and will have a 32-team bracket that will start with Saturday's games...which means better odds to win! Each entry will be assigned a random team that will participate in the NCAA national championship bracket. If your team wins the championship, you win the bottle!
Don't get assigned a top seed? No worries--there's still a chance to win! If you're assigned the team that pulls off the biggest upset (based on seeding in tournament), OR the team that suffers the biggest blowout (team that loses by largest margin at any point in the tournament), you'll win a bottle of bourbon worth $50+.
Sign up to enter here:

NO limit

subject: Closing Chicago’s life expectancy gap after COVID
body:
Plus, spring break plans for procrastinators. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Wednesday - March 19, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Esther Bergdahl
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! Yes, some 
gnarly weather
 is coming, but so is 
Chicagohenge
. As for the rest of the news, here’s what you need to know today.
  
1.
Five years since COVID, how Chicago works to improve the health of the city
 
Whether a person has access to healthy meals, a job and stable housing all contribute to their physical and mental health — and ultimately, how long they can expect to live. In Chicago, it’s vastly unequal depending on where you live and what you look like.
There’s a 25-year life expectancy gap between the Loop and West Garfield Park, public health data shows. In fact, researchers in 2019 found that Chicago had the largest life-expectancy gap across neighborhoods of any big city in America.
Since the COVID-19 pandemic, in some cases, the gap has swelled, my colleague Kristen Schorsch reports. Five years later, public health officials and community leaders are working to make sure the trust they built and the lessons they learned during the pandemic to help people become healthier aren’t lost — with fewer resources and a federal government that has targeted Chicago for everything from gun violence to immigration.
“People are really scared right now,” said Daisy Gabriel, who distributes healthy foods to low-income seniors with the nonprofit Beyond Hunger. “[C]lients know even if we have to purchase the eggs and it’s going to cost us $4 a unit, we’re going to make sure you’re getting the items that you depend on and look forward to each month.” [
WBEZ
]
2.
With a critical CPS budget vote looming, a long-awaited memo is released on ways to fill CPS’ deficit
 
The memo, by the Baker Tilly Advisory Group, walks through all the ways Chicago Public Schools could find money to cover all expenses, particularly those associated with a pension fund that includes thousands of CPS employees.
My colleagues Sarah Karp, Fran Spielman and Nader Issa report that the memo dismisses the idea of cutting costs this year, noting that the school year will be over in a few months. Given the timing, the memo states, “it would be difficult to generate sufficient savings to cover both the current budget shortfall and other Board obligations.”
Meanwhile, Mayor Brandon Johnson has likened himself to a parent trying to evict an adult child from the basement — only in this scenario, the overgrown kid is Chicago Public Schools and the parent is the city of Chicago.
The Chicago Board of Education “is going to be an independent body,” Johnson said at a press conference yesterday. “I don’t want to sound like my dad, but at some point, they’re gonna have to move out. That’s what this is. It’s a relationship that we have to disentangle.”
​​
Finding money for the pension payment has been a source of high drama since last summer. The city covered the payment for 100 years, but in 2021, former Mayor Lori Lightfoot began demanding that the school district pitch in. [
WBEZ
]
MEMBERS FUND WBEZ CHICAGO
Support WBEZ — and live your ‘White Lotus’ dreams!
Your donation today
 not only supports WBEZ’s mission of delivering high-quality, fact-based journalism to our Chicago community, it also enters you to win a 
five-night stay for four at a resort in Phuket, Thailand
!
Ensure a strong future for WBEZ and The Rundown with a gift today — 
a donation of any amount adds your name into the drawing
.
Don’t hesitate! 
Entry to win this giveaway ends at 7 p.m. TONIGHT
.
3.
Federal complaints lodged against Deerfield for accommodating trans students
 
Parent Nicole Georgas told Deerfield District 109 School Board members at a meeting last week that officials at Shepard Middle School were “allowing biological males to access girls’ locker rooms.” She said the practice “sets a dangerous precedent” and runs afoul of a February executive order signed by President Donald Trump.
In a statement, Deerfield Public Schools District 109 said that no student is required to change in front of others in the locker room and added that the school’s policies align with state law.
“They just want to exclude a child based on the fact that they’re transgender,” Asher McMaher, executive director of Trans Upfront Illinois, told my colleague Michael Puente. “It really does not have anything to do with changing. This whole thing is a mission for exclusion.”
A federal complaint has also been lodged against Chicago Public Schools and the state board of education for allegedly “forcing students” to share bathrooms and locker rooms with transgender classmates. [
WBEZ
]
4.
WBEZ and 12 other public media stations are under investigation by FCC
 
Public broadcasting stations are prohibited from running commercials. However, they are permitted to air corporate underwriting spots, which are supposed to be nonpromotional announcements that acknowledge their financial support.
WBEZ is among more than a dozen public media stations being investigated by the Federal Communications Commission for its underwriting practices, reports contributor Bob Chiarito for the Sun-Times — an inquiry which may jeopardize federal money on which the station relies.
The station received an estimated $1.47 million, or about 4.6% of its total operating revenue, from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, according to its financial statements for the 2024 fiscal year. The CPB is a private nonprofit created by Congress to help support public broadcasting. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
The investigation comes at a time when WBEZ’s parent company is battling financial hardship. Thirty employees of the Chicago Sun-Times — around 1 in 5 on its payroll — have agreed to resign under buyout terms offered by the paper’s nonprofit ownership in hopes of stanching persistent financial deficits. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
10 delightful Chicago spring break ideas for procrastinators, oddballs and tourists alike
 
Spring break for Chicago Public Schools is just around the corner, but sometimes life happens and plans just don’t. That doesn’t mean anyone should feel bummed about a staycation in Chicago, as WBEZ contributor Lauren Viera so delightfully proves.
She highlights places to seek out a new-to-you park or micromuseum, revisit a stunning architectural spectacle or swap your doomscrolling for a visit to the Doomsday Clock.
Adventures don’t have to be big to make a splash; consider visiting the city’s smallest park, just 20 square feet on IIT’s campus, celebrating iconic architect Ludwig Mies van der Rohe. If you love to squirm, pop into Lincoln Park’s International Museum of Surgical Science or (
my admitted favorite
) the Insect Asylum in Avondale.
I don’t want to spoil the rest of the list, but even if you’ve got spring break plans outside the city, these fabulous finds are happy to see you all year long. [
WBEZ
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
The sole grandson of former President John F. Kennedy condemned the spectacle around the Trump administration's much-touted release of thousands of files related to the assassination. [
People
]
The parliament in Hungary, a nation loudly admired by American right-wing figures, has banned displays of LGBTQ+ pride, including the Budapest Pride Parade. [
DW
]
Lawyers for the Internal Revenue Service pleaded with Trump administration officials not to justify mass-firing probationary employees with “performance” complaints, pointing out that contradictory evidence within the IRS would show the move was fraudulent. [
ProPublica
]
Nearly 500 researchers into artificial intelligence believe the bubble is about to burst. [
Futurism
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
Twenty-seven years ago, master tea-blender Rod Markus started Rare Tea Cellar, his Ravenswood laboratory stocked with unusual and hard-to-find ingredients.
The more he tasted, the more he learned that tea is as terroir-driven and complex as wine. Black and green teas grown on specific mountains in China and Sri Lanka deliver deeply nuanced and rich flavor bouquets. Certain parcels of Darjeeling exhibit sweet, muscatel grape–like notes, while shade-grown Japanese teas deliver unmatched umami. He discovered the almost haunting pine and honey qualities of hand-picked Emperor’s Ceylon Platinum white tea from the highest mountaintops of Sri Lanka’s Dimbula region.
Now, Markus’ Rare Tea Cellars is moving into retail at specialty grocer Piccadilly Market, which just opened in Lincoln Square. His trove of freeze-dried earthly delights, infused oils, spices, vinegars, caviar, chili pastes and aged soy sauces continue to supercharge the imaginations of chefs and bartenders at more than 1,800 high-end restaurants, bars and hotels across the U.S. and beyond.
But Markus’ first love will always be tea, which is why WBEZ contributor Maggie Hennessy sought him out “to help me up my own sad tea game.” [
WBEZ
]
 
Tell me something good
 
The Cubs were in Tokyo and the Music Box Theatre just ran a series on 
baseball films
. That has me wondering: What’s your favorite sports movie?
Lisa writes:
"Does ‘The Big Lebowski’ count? I love that movie, and there is bowling…."
Cindy writes:
"Favorite sports movie: ‘Harvard Beats Yale 29-29,’ hands down. The documentary includes clips from the famous 1968 game, as well as interviews with players 40 years later. Woven in are glimpses of 1968: the Vietnam war, Doonesbury, Meryl Streep and more, interspersed with the unbelievable game and the players who clearly still feel the joy and agony all those years later."
David writes:
"The 2022 documentary ‘It Ain't Over’ -- about legendary Yankees’ catcher Yogi Berra. A star who is woefully overlooked and not getting the recognition he deserved. A runner up -- ‘Cool Runnings,’ 1993 movie loosely based on the debut of the Jamaican national bobsleigh team at the 1988 Winter Olympics. Just the idea brings a smile."
Feel free to email me, and your response may be included in the newsletter this week.
Thanks for reading — have a great evening! I'll see you tomorrow.
— Esther Bergdahl
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting.

subject: Re: DCP JV Baseball Parent/Guardian Emails (Corrected)
body:
Hello all,
I hope your week has been going well! I'm reaching out because we are going to adjust our practice location for tomorrow morning. We will not be practicing from 9:00am - 11:00am at Gordon. Friday's practice will still be from 9:00am - 11:00am in the DePaul Prep football stadium. Finally, Saturday's double header against Taft will be at 10:00am and approximately 12:00pm (weather permitting! fingers crossed). I will make sure to remind the boys of this in our team GroupMe as well.
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp
On Fri, Mar 14, 2025 at 1:33 PM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
I hope you're all doing well and ready for Spring Break! I'm reaching out to let you know that I have just confirmed our practice times and location for next week's practices on Thursday and Friday. We will practice on both days from 9-11am in the DCP football stadium. Also, on Saturday for our Double Header against Taft at Laramie Park at 10:00am/12:00pm, we are asking the players to meet us at the field, as we will not have a bus to take us there. 
Best,
Coach Hinkamp
On Thu, Mar 13, 2025 at 7:03 AM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
It was very nice meeting many of you last night! As promised, here is the updated email chain (hoping I've got it correct this time!). As a reminder, I will share the practice schedule for the rest of the week, as well as the week of Spring Break:
Thursday 3/13: No Practice (hoping the boys go to the basketball game)
Friday 3/14: Practice 5:30pm - 7:00pm @ Clark Park
Saturday 3/15: Practice 8:00am - 10:00am @ Kerry Wood Field
SPRING BREAK
Monday 3/17: No Practice
Tuesday 3/18: No Practice
Wednesday 3/19: No Practice
Thursday 3/20: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Friday 3/21: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Saturday 3/22: Games 10:00am / 12:00pm (Double Header) vs Taft @ Laramie Park (Skokie)
I will be sending another email today or tomorrow (whenever I'm able to get this information confirmed) regarding the practice times and locations for Thursday and Friday of Spring Break. 
Again, thank you all for everything you've done/will do for the boys and team this year! 
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp
-- 
Zachary Hinkamp (He/Him), LPC

subject: Translation time capsule
body:
Celebrating 20 years of connecting worlds through language 
View this email in your browser.
 
Translation time capsule
Two decades of evolution. One constant mission.
 When we opened our doors 20 years ago, our office looked quite different. Files were stored on CD, books and paperwork lined our shelves, a boombox provided the tunes, and a fax machine hummed in the corner. Like the physical tools we used, language itself has transformed dramatically over these two decades.
Phrases have faded from use, slang has ridden its own roller coaster, emojis have woven themselves into our daily communication tapestry, and new technologies have integrated into the very fabric of how we express ourselves across cultures and borders.
 
Yet through all these changes, one thing remains constant: 
the fundamental human need to connect through language
.
 
20 years of connecting worlds
For two decades, we've been honored to serve as the bridge between languages, cultures, and ideas for our clients and their audiences. What began as a workplace language training company has grown into a human-powered, tech-driven global language partner offering:
Translation:
 Culturally nuanced translation that captures not just words, but meaning and intention across 75+ languages
Multilingual research moderation:
 Bilingual moderators who bring depth and cultural understanding to focus groups and in-depth interviews
Transcription:
 Fast, accurate transcriptions that preserve every nuance
Transcreation:
 Creative adaptation that ensures your marketing message resonates authentically in every market
Multimedia localization:
 Subtitling and voiceover to connect with multilingual audiences worldwide
Each service represents a different way we help you forge authentic connections with your global audience—ensuring that language barriers never stand in the way of understanding.
Let's chat about your next project!
 
 
Connect with us in person!
We're celebrating our milestone anniversary by connecting face-to-face with our community at these upcoming events:
Co-sponsoring Women in Research (WIRe) at Quirk's
 — April 1: Join us in supporting this vital organization that champions women's voices in our industry.
 
Exhibiting at Quirk's Chicago
 — April 2-3: Stop by our booth to celebrate with us and learn how our language solutions can enhance your market research initiatives.
Speaking and exhibiting at AAPOR
 
 — May 14-16: Jill Bishop will be joining the Multicultural, Multilingual, and Multinational Research panel to present “Behind the curtain: How translation agencies are leveraging AI for survey localization and transcriptions."
 
The connections we've made
We're proud to have built relationships with organizations working across the globe:
But our most meaningful connections have always been with the people—researchers, marketers, and business leaders who trust us to carry their message across languages with precision and cultural sensitivity.
At Multilingual Connections, we understand that language isn't just about words—it's about creating authentic human connections that transcend borders. Here's to 20 more years of bringing people together through the power of language!
 
What our clients say:
 
Do you have a project that requires a nuanced understanding of language?
 Tap into the expertise of 
our team
 so you have the confidence the rich stories you need to tell won't be lost in translation! 
Let’s chat
!
See the 75+ languages we work in
 
Request a quote
 
 
Multilingual Connections is a language and culture consultancy that helps you create connections across the globe. Our global team of linguistic and cultural experts provide translation, localization, transcreation, transcription, subtitling, voiceover, bilingual research moderation, and interpretation services in over 75 languages. We leverage the best of technology while never losing sight of the value and nuance that humans bring to each project. We’re Chicago-based and proudly woman-owned.
 
 
Copyright ©2025 Multilingual Connections, All rights reserved.
 
Multilingual Connections | 
805 Greenwood St, Evanston, IL 60201 
Prefer not to hear from us? Just click 
here
.

subject: Last Chance! Register Now for IDC's Signature Train-the-Trainer Experience
body:
The SPRING25 Special Ends on Mar. 20th!
 
AMBP-L
™
Refresher Course
Readiness Workshop
s
AAL™ Program
 
How is Diversity Work Evolving?
IDC's programs have focused on research-based initiatives, global best practices, and strategies that work for more than a decade. While you may have recently discovered that there is a more effective way to achieve inclusive excellence, we could have saved you some time...
Here's a few of the latest realizations that are already reflected in IDC's signature programs:
Diversity Training should focus on skills, not controversial topics (when prior training 
has not 
been provided) or general information (when prior training 
has
 been provided).
Diversity Recruiting should not concentrate on representation goals, but prioritize objective, fair, and holistic end-to-end talent management practices.
Professional standards are required for both organizations and Inclusive Excellence practitioners.
Global and local business risks must be evaluated holistically (e.g., legal, reputational, financial, cultural, operational, etc.) and balanced with sustainability goals.
Diversity is a competitive advantage that must be validated with a strong business case (i.e., making money, saving money, achieving organizational goals).
Diversity, accessibility, and technology are the future. Organizations must prepare for a workplace and marketplace that builds on this 3-pronged approach.
Diversity efforts must go beyond EEO categories, towards intersectional identities. Community expertise and collaboration should trump lived experiences alone.
The mass adoption of AI technology must integrate trust, accuracy, security, fairness, and ethical leadership. Guardrails must be used to prevent AI bias, as well as ensure that misinformation and online harassment are not normalized.
Don't fall behind; the Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accesibility landscape is evolving at lightening speed. Get credentials, become a member, collaborate with your peers, and continue your professional development journey with IDC!
 
Hurry-- This Special Ends on Thurs., Mar. 20th and Will Not be Extended!
 
 
Join us for IDC's Signature Train-the-Trainer Program on Mar. 26-27
 
 
Last Chance! IDC's $174 Membership Special ends 3/20. Use Promo Code: SPRING25 now
 
 
 
 
www.diversitycertification.org

subject: 🚀 Soaring Beyond Limits: Women Driving Change in Communications!
body:
Your Weekly NYWICI Newsletter!
 
 
About
 
Membership
 
 
Take Charge of Your Financial Future
﻿
Join us on
 Tuesday, April 1, 2025
, at 
12:00 PM EST 
for a dynamic webinar focused on building financial confidence and making informed money decisions.
Led by Judy Herbst, Executive Director of Savvy Ladies, and moderated by Jackie Hyland, Associate Director of Corporate Affairs at KPMG US, this session will explore essential financial topics, including budgeting, investing, and long-term wealth strategies. Gain practical insights and actionable advice to navigate financial challenges and secure your future.
No matter your financial stage, this conversation will equip you with the tools to take control and thrive.
Free for NYWICI members | $20 for non-members
Register now to receive the Zoom link!
register here
 
 
 
Navigate the Future of Sustainability Communications!
Join us on 
Tuesday, April 2, 2025
, for an insightful discussion on the evolving landscape of sustainability communications. Over the past decade, sustainability has become a core pillar of corporate strategy, shaping operations, reputation, and stakeholder engagement. Yet, with shifting public policy, changing sentiment, and increasing uncertainty, organizations are facing new challenges in how they communicate their social impact initiatives.
From companies doubling down on commitments to others rebranding or even abandoning efforts altogether, the landscape is rapidly changing. As communicators, how do we adapt our approach to sustainability messaging in a time of heightened scrutiny? What do customers, investors, and employees expect now—and how can we prepare for the future?
Featured Speakers:
Catherine Addo, Social Impact Strategist • Impact Media Founder 
Emily Goodstein, Founder + CEO, Greater Good Strategy
Reed Handley, Executive VP, The Bliss Group
Danielle Holly, Executive Lead, Ellen MacArthur Foundation
Don’t miss this timely conversation on the challenges, strategies, and opportunities in sustainability communications.
register here
 
 
 
Leading with Style: A Fireside Chat with Rebecca Minkoff
﻿
Join us on 
April 22, 2025, from 12:00 – 1:00 PM EST
 for an exclusive conversation with fashion powerhouse, bestselling author, and Real Housewife of New York, 
Rebecca Minkoff
 as she shares insights from her book "
Fearless: The New Rules for Unlocking Creativity, Courage, and Success
."
Go behind the scenes of Rebecca’s journey from industry outsider to global brand visionary. She’ll reveal the unconventional strategies that fueled her success, including overcoming self-doubt, transforming setbacks into opportunities, and building an authentic, high-impact network.
Expect a dynamic discussion filled with real-world lessons, practical advice, and Rebecca’s signature no-nonsense wisdom. Plus, a live Q&A session gives you the chance to ask your own questions.
Location: Virtual (Zoom link provided upon registration)
Free for NYWICI members | $20 for non-members
Don’t miss this opportunity to learn from one of fashion’s most fearless leaders! Register now to secure your spot.
register here

Save the date! On 
May 20, 2025
, the prestigious Matrix Awards return to celebrate the extraordinary women who are shaping the future of communications. This unforgettable evening will honor the visionaries, leaders, and innovators whose contributions continue to inspire and transform the industry.
Stay tuned for more details as we prepare to recognize this year’s honorees. Stay tuned for more details as we prepare to announce this year's honorees.
 
 
Changemakers: Leah Meranus, CEO, North America, dentsu X
In this episode of NYWICI's Womenheard Podcast: Changemakers host Georgia Galanoudis speaks with Leah Meranus, CEO, North America of dentsu X – a global media agency within dentsu, known for its unique ability to defy convention to deliver meaningful outcomes for leading brands. She leads over 1,000 people – no small task!
Listen to this episode for tips on maximizing your decision-making power and how to avoid listening to a “focus group of one”.
listen here
 
 
 
A Woman's World: Investment is Impact
Happy Women’s History Month! In this month’s message, our President, Brandi Boatner, celebrates your resilience and growth, highlighting the power of women in shaping the future. She encourages you to continue investing in yourself, with exciting upcoming events including a financial empowerment webinar, a fireside chat with Rebecca Minkoff, and the 55th annual Matrix Awards.
Read Brandi’s full message and discover how to invest in your personal and professional development today!
read here
 
 
 
Stay Inspired: Explore NYWICI’s Latest Blogs
Five Tips: Thriving in a Hybrid Work Environment
 The hybrid work experiment is still evolving, and companies continue to refine their approach to balance in-office and remote collaboration. Even if your current setup seems set, chances are hybrid work will remain part of your professional life in some capacity. So, how can you make the most of this model? From maximizing in-person interactions to fostering stronger virtual connections, these five simple yet effective strategies will help you and your team thrive in a hybrid environment. Read on to discover how small changes can lead to a more productive and enjoyable work experience!
Networking 101: Building Connections in the Communications Industry
 Networking can often feel intimidating, but it’s an essential skill for career growth, no matter where you are in your professional journey. As a NYWICI member, you’re already part of an invaluable community of women in communications – now it’s time to leverage that network and build meaningful relationships. In this post, we dive into key strategies that go beyond small talk, including tips on strengthening your personal brand, finding the right connections, and deepening your professional relationships. Ready to transform your networking approach? Read more to start building relationships that matter!

subject: Achieving Success with HUBZone Federal Contracts
body:
Achieving Success with HUBZone Federal Contracts                                                    
Achieving Success with HUBZone Federal Contracts
 
Achieving Success with HUBZone Federal Contracts
Read More
 
The Historically Underutilized Business Zone (HUBZone) program, administered by the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA), is a federal initiative aimed at revitalizing economically distressed communities. Through this program, the federal government seeks to allocate at least 3% of its contracting dollars to HUBZone-certified small businesses each year, providing significant opportunities for these companies to compete for and secure federal contracts. This article examines the recent growth trends in HUBZone spending across various industries from 2021 to 2023, highlighting the sectors that have seen the most growth and outlining the benefits of the HUBZone program for small businesses.
How the HUBZone Program Benefits Small Businesses
The HUBZone program is designed to foster economic development and create jobs by providing small businesses in designated areas with preferential access to federal contracts. Key benefits include:
Restricted Competition:
 For certain contracts, competition is limited exclusively to HUBZone-certified businesses, giving these companies an edge in winning federal projects.
Price Evaluation Preference:
 HUBZone-certified businesses enjoy a 10% price evaluation preference in open contract competitions, allowing them to be more competitive when bidding against larger companies.
Eligibility for Multiple Programs:
 In addition to competing for HUBZone set-aside contracts, certified businesses can also qualify for other socio-economic programs (such as 8(a) or Woman-Owned Small Business programs), expanding their contracting opportunities.
This structured support not only increases federal investment in underutilized areas but also enables small businesses to build a sustainable base of government contracts, promoting long-term growth and community development.
A review of the top industries by HUBZone dollars spent over the past three years reveals significant growth, especially in construction and technology-related sectors. The following industries stand out for their substantial increase in funding:
Commercial and Institutional Building Construction (NAICS 236220)
Growth:
 $1.05 billion (from $2.31 billion in 2021 to $3.37 billion in 2023)
Insight: The largest growth in HUBZone spending has been in commercial and institutional building construction, reflecting the federal government’s commitment to infrastructure development in underutilized areas. This increase likely includes investments in public facilities, schools, and community buildings, which not only improves infrastructure but also creates jobs and boosts local economies.
Other Computer Related Services (NAICS 541519)
Growth: 
$604 million (from $1.62 billion in 2021 to $2.23 billion in 2023)
Insight: The second-largest growth occurred in computer-related services, which includes a range of IT support and digital transformation services. This trend highlights the increasing federal demand for technology solutions to modernize government operations, particularly in areas such as cybersecurity, cloud computing, and data management.
Computer Systems Design Services (NAICS 541512)
Growth:
 $246 million (from $809 million in 2021 to $1.06 billion in 2023)
Insight: As the third-largest growth sector, computer systems design services also saw significant funding increases, underlining the federal push towards comprehensive digital infrastructure. These services are essential for developing customized software solutions, which are critical in making government processes more efficient and accessible.
The HUBZone program is more than just a contracting opportunity; it is a catalyst for economic transformation in America’s underserved communities. With over $3.3 billion allocated to the top industry—commercial and institutional building construction—in 2023 alone, the program is making a real difference by investing in both physical infrastructure and digital modernization. For small businesses in HUBZone-designated areas, this initiative provides a competitive advantage, increased visibility, and the chance to grow by contributing to impactful federal projects.
If federal contracting is part of your marketing plan, EZ8A can help guide you through the HUBZone eligibility process. Navigating certification requirements can be complex, but our expertise in federal contracting can simplify the journey, helping you position your business for success in the HUBZone program. Call us today to learn how we can support your growth and open new doors to government contracting opportunities.
Emily Hatchel
859-442-3300
www.ez8a.com

10500 Norbotten Dr
Florence Kentucky 41042
United States

subject: Re: March Madness Pool
body:
Good Morning Everyone,
We did not reach our goal of 100 squares which is why the square sheet did not go out yesterday.  We still have 16 squares left and I will leave it open until 4 EST today.  We will start with the 6:40 EST game tonight.  Payouts for this week will go out early next week.  When the sheet comes out, please review for accuracy and let me know if you see any discrepancies.
Thank you again to all.
Mike
On Mar 17, 2025, at 7:50 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Thank you all again for another nice push yesterday.  We currently need 38 more squares sold.  Please continue to reach out to friends and family.  I am keeping it open as long as I can which means I will close it and send out the sheet around 5 pm EST Tuesday.  If we don't hit the 100 mark, we will eliminate the early games to compensate.  Hope we dont have to do that so let's get to 100.
Thank you again to all
Mike
On Mar 16, 2025, at 2:35 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Afternoon Everyone,
We are getting closer to our goal of 100 squares with 46 left.  Very much appreciate everyone who has contributed up to this point.  We still have plenty of opportunities to jump in as there are 46 squares left.  Please reach out to friends and family.  
Thank you again to all
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 1:53 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
I am going to work very hard to keep this at the top of everyone's inbox. I apologize in advance for the amount of emails I plan on sending out.  We are wrapping up the fundraising so we need one final big push. We have until Monday night to fill this sheet out.  I started by purchasing 3 myself.  97 more.  The brackets are fun but the odds of winning anything at all are relatively low.  With the squares, your odds of winning are significantly higher and much more realistic than football squares.  3 days, please pass along to friends or family that would like to join in supporting the baseball program.
Thank you
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 12:07 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Evening Everyone,
Just want to say thank you again for the great support shown during the fundraising and the First Pitch Event.  We are now reaching the end of the fundraising season as we enter the baseball season.  As you are likely aware, there are other groups at DePaul doing March Madness brackets. I know it puts more pressure on families to financially engage and we try to avoid it.  Regardless, we're gonna open our final fundraiser and try something a little different.  Rather than doing the traditional bracket, we are going to do squares. This is very simple, buy your squares and win based on the final score of each game.  Remember, there are 67 games when including the play in games.  That means you literally have 67 chances to win.  With each game fetching a $100 prize, you could win up to $6700.  Let's make this the biggest fundraising event yet.  Send it out to friends and families.  Let's make sure we sell this one out  We're going $100 per square.  Payment cam be made with Zelle to 
rogs1@mac.com
.
Let me know if you have any questions.
Mike

subject: 🏅 Gold medal care: Dr. Monica Rho’s impact in STE(A)M
body:
Meet the U.S. Women’s Soccer Team doctor shaping sports medicine right here in Chicago. 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
 
 
Women’s History Month spotlight: Dr. Monica Rho
Dr. Monica Rho is not only the director of women's sports medicine at the Shirley Ryan AbilityLab and an associate professor at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine right here in Chicago, but she is also the head physician for the U.S. Women’s National Soccer Team. In fact, she was with the team in Paris at the 2024 Summer Olympics when they won the gold medal.  
Her career pathway highlights one of the many ways that anyone can combine multiple interests into an exciting and fulfilling career in STE(A)M. In Dr. Rho’s case, a passion for medicine and sports allows her to travel the world helping athletes stay healthy while performing at an elite level.
"As a sports medicine physiatrist (a doctor of physical medicine and rehabilitation), I enjoy taking care of patients to help them achieve the highest level of their own abilities. Having the opportunity to do this with the greatest female athletes on the planet is a dream come true." — Dr. Monica Rho
Dr. Rho is one of more than 100 present-day women in STE(A)M featured in Griffin MSI’s 
Women in Science
 pop-up exhibit and in the digital Rotunda Experience throughout March.
See more from the Women in Science exhibit
 
Girls in STEM programs are made possible by Ann M. Drake.
Photo credit: IF/THEN

subject: Meet Writer & Publisher Delvin Howell (Part 2)
body:
And learn about his vision for Black and Caribbean storytelling  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
March 19, 2025   |   
Read Online
Meet Writer & Publisher Delvin Howell (Part 2) 
And learn about his vision for Black and Caribbean storytelling 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello friends, 
Welcome to part two of the interview with Barbadian writer and publisher Delvin Howell. In 
part one
, Delvin talked about how he became a writer, and his choice to move beyond struggle stories and show Barbadian protagonists as heroes and more. Ready to dive in?
Delvin, what response have you had to your writing?
The response has been positive. People are often surprised at the approaches I take to certain ideas. Whether it is the reimagining of Bajan (Barbadian) folklore characters in a fantasy setting, the intricate fight scenes that I weave using them, or the novel approach to things that should not work on paper, it is always exciting for the audience. 
I’m especially happy with my prose, being smooth to read but also poetic or visceral when it needs to be. I admit I wasn’t comfortable with my writing for quite some time. Despite the accolades I received when I first started, I always consider myself a student of the form. With my progress having tangible results to the reader, I am excited to see my style evolve as I continue learning and improving. 
You've set up your own publishing imprint. Why did you make that choice, and were there any challenges and notable successes along the way?
Beyond Publishing Caribbean was formed due to our established relationship as comic creators in Barbados. It made more sense to pool our resources and come under one banner as opposed to try to operate separately. This allowed us to reach a larger audience and have more of an impact when it came to our roster of titles. 
We also had more control of the stories we want to tell. Not beholden to established brands and labels, we could focus on the ideas that we were passionate about and the execution of said stories. 
[Editor's note: a great point, which is why I advocate for 
self-publishing
.]
As for prose, it seemed natural to expand to different products and mediums as the publisher grew. There was also the added landscape of traditional publishing when it came to fantasy novels and Caribbean novels at the time. There is an established presentation when it came to those genres and it clashed with the way I wanted the 
Offset 
novels to look. To coincide with the comic series, I opted to add illustrations to capture key moments in the story in cinematic ways throughout the book. This was something that was not explored in the traditional space, and it is still limited to this day, at least in the Western hemisphere. 
The biggest challenge right now is distribution. We have natural limitations being in the Caribbean when it comes to shipping and it is limiting how quickly we can scale. We have adjusted our business models to suit, but it is still a tall task in expanding our reach. 
As for successes, Beyond Publishing has released 11 titles across multiple genres such as fantasy, science fiction, crime drama, horror and adventure. We have won several awards from the Caribbean Advertising Federation in publication, illustration and book design, along with collaborations with the National Cultural Foundation, U.S. Embassy and with international publishers such as Wise Acre Comics and Megascope Books (an imprint of Abrams Publishing). 
We are currently working on a project with UNESCO through their Creative Caribbean grant initiative that seeks to encourage financial literacy and entrepreneurship in readers. The comic series called Loose Change is seeking to launch in August 2025, and I am excited to share this one with the world. 
Enjoyed this interview? You can 
buy me a coffee
 or 
upgrade to a paid subscription
 to support the work of creating this newsletter.
﻿
What's your view on the importance of Black stories in general, and Caribbean stories in particular?
Stories from the African diaspora about the Black experience are still largely unexplored. At the base level, I prefer to see stories that come from the source cultures rather than appropriated by someone else. I make an effort to check out any books, comics, films etc from unique regions when I have a chance because I believe they have a more authentic point of view that wouldn’t be reached from the outside. 
In the speculative fiction space, Black creators have been making strides whether there are based in the U.S or U.K or coming from African countries themselves. While this is fantastic, I believe the Caribbean has much to add to that conversation. Our unique history, character and setting allows for massive narrative opportunities. Especially, since the Caribbean is a melting pot of sorts for various other cultures. 
If you could wave a magic wand, what future would you create for Caribbean writers?
I would like to see established industries around the literary medium in the Caribbean. Despite the strides made from organisations such as Bocas Lit Fest, Frank Collymore Endowment and many others, I still think we should have more tangible environments to encourage creators to publish their work. 
For example, it is difficult to find professional editors, literary agents and book designers within the Caribbean market. I am sure they exist but there is no 
Writer’s Digest
 for the Caribbean that a new author can use to shop or improve their manuscript. Regional printing presses also do not have a print-on-demand model which can force new writers into massive print runs that will be a challenge to sell. 
There is also a certain look and feel people have for Caribbean stories in the literary space. It is often rustic or abstract in their presentation, with grass-roots narratives. Some of these books are favourites of mine. However, I do think there is room to present the Caribbean in cinematic ways without sacrificing our identity to do so. It is my hope that through my series, as it grows more readers and upcoming authors would begin to reimagine the Caribbean in a different light. 
I know that for comics and even animation/film, Caribbean storytellers have been trying to shift towards this trend. There is hope for the future, for sure. 
Daily News for Curious Minds
Be the smartest person in the room by reading 1440! Dive into 1440, where 4 million Americans find their daily, fact-based news fix. We navigate through 100+ sources to deliver a comprehensive roundup from every corner of the internet – politics, global events, business, and culture, all in a quick, 5-minute newsletter. It's completely free and devoid of bias or political influence, ensuring you get the facts straight. Subscribe to 1440 today. 
Sign up now!
Since this is an anti-racism newsletter, I'd love to know: In relation to racism, what is your vision for the future?
This may be a controversial take, but I believe that the best way to tackle racism is to create empathy without guilting people who look like our oppressors. I have seen many stories that are combative against certain groups, and I understand why and the need for this. I even enjoy those type of stories from time to time. But they can have an alienating effect. I would like people to see people as human beings. The colour of our skin or our background does not diminish the human experience that we have, and stories are a powerful vehicle to show that human experience. 
The best-case scenario is that people see the African Diaspora as being cool, without wanting to gentrify it (for lack of a better term). I have seen this in Hip Hop culture which is the most dominant in music right now. Despite it not being limited to the African-American demographic anymore, it is still a cultural leader in that space, without keeping out anyone else who may not be in that demographic. People look up to Kendrick Lamar, Kanye West, etc., across the world without insisting that rappers' music to be repurposed through a rapper of another “race”. I would like stories to happen the same way and I believe we are nearly there as the world opens up its access to global content. 
Thank you, Delvin. Folx, if you want to see something new from the Caribbean, please feel free to connect with Delvin on the 
Offset Serie
s and 
Beyond Publishing Caribbean
 websites, and on Instagram at 
@offsetcomic
, 
@beyondpublishingcaribbean
 and 
@loosechangecomic
.
Thanks for reading,
Sharon
﻿

subject: Join NYWICI: Corporate Social Responsibility and Communications, 04/02/2025
body:
Dear Monica,
Have you registered yet for NYWICI's latest in person event?
A New Path Forward for Sustainability Comms
Wednesday, April 2, 2025
4:00 – 7:00PM
 
Location:  
Idealist.org, 389 Fifth Ave, NYC
Over the past decade, sustainability has been recognized as a crucial part of a company’s operational model, significantly impacting ways of working, corporate reputation, and engagement with both internal and external stakeholders. However, recent abrupt changes in public policy, sentiment, and discourse have introduced tension and uncertainty regarding sustainability and other social impact initiatives, as well as the communications surrounding them.
Currently, companies and organizations are attempting to navigate these challenging conditions by adopting various strategies–from maintaining their commitments to simply rebranding or renaming their policies to fully abandoning initiatives–each presenting its own distinct advantages and disadvantages. During this unprecedented period, how should we, as communicators, adjust our approach to sustainability and social impact communications and marketing when fear and uncertainty are muddying the waters? What new challenges are anticipated from our customers, investors, and employees? And what lessons can we draw from these experiences for the future?
Featured Speakers
Catherine Addo
, 
Social Impact Strategist • Impact Media Founder 
Emily Goodstein
,
 
Founder + CEO, Greater Good Strategy
Reed Handley
,
 
Executive VP, The Bliss Group
Danielle Holly
, Executive Lead, Ellen MacArthur Foundation
Agenda:
4:00 - 4:50 pm: Welcome Drinks and Networking 
4:50 - 4:55 pm: Opening Remarks
4:55 - 5:45 pm: Panel Discussion 
  
5:45 - 6:10 pm: Audience Q&A 
 
6:10 - 7:00 pm: Networking 
Price:  $25/$50 member/nonmember 
Join the conversation, connect and network with fellow communicators.
Click here to register. 
I hope to see you there.
Best regards,
Donna-Jean
Donna-Jean Plante, CAE
Executive Director, New York Women in Communications (NYWICI)
(571) 685-8011
Donna-Jean.Plante@nywici.org

unsubscribe
 
at any time.
New York Women in Communications
1660 International Drive, Suite 600
McLean, VA 22102

info@nywici.org
  |  Phone: 212.251.7255

subject: Federal Employees: Ready to Pivot to the Private Sector? Join This Free Event!
body:

View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Monica
The federal landscape is shifting. Layoffs, restructuring, and uncertainty are becoming the norm. 
If you’re considering a move to the private sector—or even just exploring your options—you need a plan.
That’s why I’m hosting a 
free, high-impact webinar
:
The Federal Pivot: Your Power Move to the Private Sector
Tuesday, March 25, 7PM ET - 
 
Live Webinar
If you’ve 
built a successful career in government
 but aren’t sure how to translate that into private sector opportunities, 
this session is for you.
What You’ll Walk Away With:
✔ 
A clear understanding of where your skills fit in the private sector
—so you don’t waste time on the wrong roles.
✔ 
How to rewrite your resume & LinkedIn profile
—so recruiters instantly see your value.
✔ 
The #1 networking strategy
 for landing private sector roles (even if your entire career has been in government).
✔ 
How to ace interviews & negotiate your worth
—so you don’t get lowballed or overlooked.
✔ 
The 5 biggest mistakes federal employees make when transitioning
—and how to avoid them.
 
BONUS
: Every attendee gets The Federal Pivot Toolkit: The 5 Critical Shifts You Need to Make for Private Sector Success.
This isn’t just another career talk. It’s a 
strategic roadmap
 to ensure you transition with confidence, clarity, and 
the best possible opportunities.
Seats are limited, and this is information you can’t afford to miss.
 
Reserve your spot 
here
See you there!
Time to get SCRAPPY! 
 
Deborah T. Owens
Head Alley Cat
 
P.S Share this webinar with your friends and colleagues

subject: Rethinking the Language of DEI
body:
Bridging Divides Without Compromising Values  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
View in browser
 
 March 18, 2025
DEI has become undoubtedly one of the most polarized topics in today's workplace. While some attribute the backlash to misinformation, what if the real issue is how we—DEI advocates—have framed and communicated these concepts? Our team has recently written about this challenge, not to assign blame but to foster understanding. How did we get here, and how can we do better? Whether you champion DEI initiatives or have doubts, we invite you to read, listen, and share your perspective.
 
 
– Team Aleria
DEI Backlash: 
Pros
 and 
Cons
Stories focused on the anti-DEI backlash, and efforts to put a stop to the nonsense!
 
Quantifying DEI
Exploring the tangible aspects of DEI and current efforts to quantify it
 
DEI Resources
Useful tools and information to support your DEI efforts
 
The Complexity of DEI
Unintended consequences and ripple effects of DEI
 
Golden Nuggets,
 Silver Linings
Unexpected bits of good news... when we can find them.
Congratulations to Louis Chesney, whose consulting work on the film 
Magnetospher
 has contributed to its selection as one of fourteen feature films to be screened at the 
ReelAbilities Film Festival New York
—the world's largest festival dedicated to showcasing films that celebrate the stories and talents of people with disabilities.
We're also pleased to see 
female influencers bridging the gap 
between traditional media in a male-dominated sport and a growing online fan base of women. And, of course, kudos to the 
nine companies leading the way
 with policies that break down barriers to workforce participation—and are seeing the results!
 
 
Aleria Happenings
The latest from the Aleria Team
Missed these conversations? Listen here:
🎙️
The Chris Voss Show Podcast
: 
“Measuring Inclusion: Higher profits and happier people, without guesswork or backlash”
🎙️
The State of Work Today Podcast
: 
"
The Real Business Case for Inclusion: Measuring What Matters"
🎙️
The Future Talent Council interview
: 
“Measuring What Matters: A New Approach to DEI"
 — a written version of the interview is 
also available, download it 
here
.
 
Embrace a new approach to DEI! Find out how focusing on inclusion leads to greater, sustainable diversity while driving superior performance for 
any
 organization, creating alignment instead of backlash. 
Visit our website
 for additional information, 
send us an email
 to learn more, or use the button below to schedule a call with Aleria's Founder and Chief Scientist, Paolo Gaudiano, who can provide more details and answer any questions about how measuring inclusion can give your organization a competitive advantage.
Book a call with Paolo
 
 
Mark Your Calendars
DEI-related events, applications and opportunities. Submit relevant events to 
info@aleria.tech
On March 27, 2025 at 11am US/ET, join this expert-led session, where leaders from KPMG, Legal & General Investment Management, and Lloyds will share proven strategies for creating workplaces that celebrate neurodiversity - driving innovation, boosting productivity, and cultivating a culture of belonging. 
Free registration
.
On April 3, 2025 at 12pm US/ET, join Charter and Understood for "Neurodiversity and the Future of Business," a discussion of the workplace designs, team dynamics, and leadership approaches to maximize the strengths of neurodivergent workers. The presentation includes case studies and resources that you can use in your own organization. 
Free registration
.
On April 3-9, 2025, join the 17th Annual ReelAbilities Film Festival: New York. This amazing festival, which spans multiple venues and virtual showings, reframes disability and celebrates inclusion and accessibility through film. 
Get your tickets today
!
On Thursday, April 10 at 11:00 am US/ET join our Chief Scientist Paolo Gaudiano for a FREE webinar on 
Rethinking DEI: Addressing Common Misconceptions. 
Paolo we'll dive into the misconceptions surrounding diversity and inclusion, address concerns about meritocracy, and explore practical ways to approach DEI while staying compliant with current policies. 
Free Registration
.
 
Spread the love!
If you enjoy the Aleria newsletter, forward it to a friend or colleague!
If you received this newsletter from a loving friend or colleague :-), use the button below to reach our newsletter subscription page.

subject: Funding freeze hits tree-planting project
body:
Plus, Lollapalooza announces its 2025 lineup. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Tuesday - March 18, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Esther Bergdahl
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! The World Wildlife Fund announced that populations of the iconic but endangered Eastern monarch butterfly 
almost doubled
 last year. As for the rest of the news, here’s what you need to know today.
  
SUPPORT THE RUNDOWN: 
You could win a 5-night trip to Thailand!
 
DONATE
1.
A Chicago church won’t be planting fruit trees this spring as climate funds remain frozen
 
As cities like Chicago grapple with rising global temperatures, improving the urban canopy — the layer of collective tree cover in a city — isn’t just about beautifying the neighborhood. Trees help reduce air pollution and are increasingly among the most cost-effective ways to mitigate the impacts of climate change, reports my colleague Juanpablo Ramirez-Franco.
Local environmental nonprofit Faith in Place had plans in January to give out grants, funded by the Biden administration’s Inflation Reduction Act, to 58 faith-based organizations across the Midwest. These would pay for tree planting in low-income communities and create urban forestry jobs to maintain them.
The Stone Temple Baptist Church in North Lawndale was ready to plant fruit trees in its community garden, providing the majority-Black community with seasonal access to pears, peaches, apples and plums.
Then, on his first day in office, President Donald Trump signed his “Unleashing American Energy” executive order, which abruptly froze those payments. Faith in Place has laid off five employees after breaking the news to its partner organizations.
“It’s really upsetting that the government’s not keeping their end of the bargain,” Faith in Place’s Rev. Brian Sauder said. “We’ve kept our commitment, and they aren’t keeping their commitment to us.” [
WBEZ
]
2.
Stricter rules around truck pollution would prevent 500 deaths a year in the Chicago area, study shows
 
Environmental scientists at Northwestern University are asking Chicago to look west for inspiration — all the way to California, where strict emissions regulations on trucks used for overland shipping have greatly reduced deaths and illnesses related to pollution. This study, reports the Chicago Tribune, projects that majority Black and Latino neighborhoods would see the greatest improvement in health outcomes, including hundreds fewer cases of childhood asthma.
The Illinois Pollution Control Board is currently considering a proposal to adopt California’s Clean Trucks rule, which requires manufacturers of medium and heavy-duty trucks to increase their production and sales of zero-emission vehicles. However, under the Trump administration, the Environmental Protection Agency is seeking exemptions for Clean Trucks rules and similar state initiatives that exceed federal requirements. [
Chicago Tribune
]
In December, my Sun-Times colleague Brett Chase looked into Mayor Brandon Johnson’s commitment to Chicago’s environmental issues and how shakeups at City Hall affect residents in neighborhoods like Little Village and McKinley Park. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM GREATER CHICAGO FOOD DEPOSITORY
Visits to Chicago food pantries on the rise
Household visits to Chicago food pantries and grocery programs have increased by 57% since 2020. And while the need keeps growing, hunger relief programs are under federal threat. As caring neighbors, you are the hope that ignites change. 
Gifts to the Food Depository
 are now matched for 2x the impact to provide meals and build solutions to end hunger.
3.
The Chicago Teachers Union accuses CPS of fostering disruption and chaos in not agreeing to key compromises
 
The Chicago Board of Education is set to vote on a contentious budget amendment to set aside money for the teacher’s contract, as well as a controversial pension payment. There’s some concern among the partly appointed, partly elected board that approving the budget amendment before the teachers’ contract is landed could leave the school district without enough money to pay for this year’s contract costs.
The school district and the union have been bargaining since last April, and both sides say they are close to a deal, writes my colleague Sarah Karp. But after CPS quickly rejected a proposal to reinstate 30 minutes of teacher planning time — a major remaining sticking point — the two sides are trading accusations of sabotage.
Sources say the union is now “barreling toward an escalated conflict instead of the stability of a landed contract.” The CTU has completed the legal process and can take a vote at any time that would give 10 days notice of a strike. [
WBEZ
]
4.
Sabrina Carpenter, Olivia Rodrigo and Tyler, the Creator to headline Lollapalooza 2025 in Chicago
 
Set your reminders or get in touch with your ticket guy: Lolla turns 21 this year and passes go on sale Thursday. Four-day general admission, July 31 to Aug. 3 at Grant Park, starts at $385.
Headliner Olivia Rodrigo is making her Lollapalooza debut, while returning stars and new favorites include A$AP Rocky, Gracie Abrams, the Jack Antonoff-led band Bleachers, K-pop girl group TWICE, country singer Luke Combs and rising multi-instrumentalist Mk.gee.
Chicago talent also made its way onto the lineup, including R&B singer-songwriter Ravyn Lenae, who had one of WBEZ’s favorite albums of 2024; Djo, the music alias for actor Joe Keery of 
Stranger Things
 and “End of Beginning” fame; and the Chicago Youth Symphony Orchestra.
Lollapalooza is the largest of the summer’s Chicago music extravaganzas — a summer marking the first festival season without Pitchfork, which announced it would not return to Chicago in 2025. [
WBEZ
]
5.
New venue Bookclub revives former Elbo Room in “a leap of faith”
 
The DIY concept of Bookclub was born out of necessity in summer 2021. As lockdown restrictions began to lift, K.O. Weakley — who makes music under the name TYGKO — was eager to return to the stage. But less than a week before he planned to perform at KIP Studios in Logan Square, the location was served a cease and desist order.
“We knew we needed a place to play; we knew other people needed a place to play; we knew that we needed a live context for the music that we had been making,” Weakley told my Vocalo colleague Nudia Hernandez. “That was the main push behind even opening a DIY spot.”
In September, Weakley and co-founder Cam Stacey announced they had bought the Elbo Room, the famed venue which put its building up for sale and closed in 2019 after 30 years in Lake View. Bookclub opened at the end of January with live music and daytime, dog-friendly bar hours. [
Vocalo
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
The ceasefire in Gaza ended after Israel accused Hamas of stalling on hostage releases and launched air strikes, killing hundreds. [
ABC News
]
Because of changes stemming from the Trump administration’s excising of diversity, equity and inclusion measures, the federal government no longer explicitly prohibits contractors from segregating facilities based on protected identities. [
NPR
]
Scientists report National Institutes of Health officials are urging them not to reference mRNA vaccines, a promising field that has implications for cancer treatments, in grant applications. [
KFF Health News
]
A suburban man is bringing back an annual passion project: selling heritage tomato plants and donating to organizations that supply food pantries. [
Block Club Chicago
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
When 
Purpose
 premiered at Chicago’s Steppenwolf Theatre last spring, it was a big deal. Even before preview performances, there were whispers that the family drama, written by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins (
Appropriate
), would go to New York.
But the production’s Broadway premiere over the weekend illustrates Chicago’s keen ability to incubate shows that rouse even the center of the theater world. If the Chicago production was really good, writes my colleague Mike Davis, the Broadway show reaches another level.
Audiences locked onto parallels between the Jasper family on stage — a father entrenched in the civil rights movement, his son juggling a political career and a prison sentence — and the family of Rev. Jesse Jackson in Chicago. But underneath the politics were relatable themes that easily connected with audiences. Both Jasper children struggle with their mental health, and Jacobs-Jenkins carefully portrays the generational differences in a Black family in understanding and addressing issues of mental health and sexuality.
Then there’s Tony-nominated actress LaTanya Richardson Jackson (
A Raisin in the Sun
) — and wife of actor Samuel L. Jackson — who plays Claudine Jasper, the matriarch. [
WBEZ
]
 
Tell me something good
 
The Cubs are in Tokyo and the Music Box Theatre is just concluding a series on 
baseball films
. That has me wondering: What’s your favorite sports movie?
Erika writes:
“Ok - you said 
sports
, not just baseball... so I hope this is ok!
But anytime I hear ‘favorite sports movie,’ I immediately think of my favorite sports documentary, which is actually just one of my favorite movies of all time: the 1994 documentary, 
Hoop Dreams
. I have loved it since I first saw it MANY years ago as a twenty-something year-old. I was struck by how captivating it was and how the filmmaking pulled me into the stories of the Gates and Agee families so much so that I felt like I knew them.
I clearly remember Siskel and Ebert championing this film on At the Movies back in 1994 (what Chicago area movie-loving kid didn't watch that syndicated show every single week since they were born?), and everything they said about 
Hoop Dreams
 held to be true. Many years later, I've now been lucky to be able to teach this film as part of an English elective course for high school students, and my passion for the film, the families' stories, and for teaching only grows stronger with each viewing. I've met Arthur Agee a few times; he even generously spoke to one of my classes last semester after we studied and wrote about the film.
As Ebert once said, ‘...movies are like a machine that generates empathy.’ 
Hoop Dreams
 generates that and so much more. We are all kinder, more understanding people after watching it. I'm so grateful to the families who opened up their lives and trusted the filmmakers - and so grateful to the filmmakers, Steve James, Peter Gilbert, and Frederick Marx, who proved to be talented and caring storytellers worthy of their trust.
Thank you for reading if you made it this far. I never pass up an opportunity to share a few words (or a paragraph) about 
HOOP DREAMS
!”
Feel free to email me, and your response may be included in the newsletter this week.
Thanks for reading — have a great evening! I'll see you tomorrow.
— Esther Bergdahl
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting. 
DONATE TODAY
©Chicago Public Media Inc 848 East Grand Ave, Navy Pier Chicago, IL 60611
Unsubscribe from The Daily Rundown
 |

subject: Slack Spies And Corporate Espionage Allegations
body:
Plus: AI Is The New Gender Gap Front In Tech | Law School Admissions Get More Competitive | Nurses Push Back on AI Patient Care
BECOME A MEMBER
 • 
Newsletters
 • 
MyForbes
It’s 2025 and corporate espionage is no longer done by sneaking contracts out of office buildings or installing malware on your competitors’ computers. Now, Slack messages are the new target.
At least that’s what work management platform Rippling has accused its main competitor—global payroll company Deel—of going after in a corporate espionage 
lawsuit filed on Monday
. Rippling says that Deel hired a “spy” employee to steal Rippling data, including sales tactics, product pricing and customer retention strategies. 
According to the suit, Rippling’s “spy” employee shared intel on Deel’s own customers who discussed switching to Rippling.  
Rippling also alleges that the “spy” took employee contact information from Rippling colleagues and passed it on to Deel, which then sent WhatsApp messages to certain employees and offered them jobs at the competitor. 
The smoking gun moment came when Rippling’s general counsel sent a letter to Deel’s senior leadership that mentioned a “honeypot” Slack channel set up specifically to catch the employee. Lo and behold, the “spy” employee searched and accessed the Slack channel shortly after the letter was sent. 
Bad blood has been brewing between the two companies since Rippling banned former employees who now work at competitors, including Deel and Workday, from its 
tender offer stock sale in June. 
And while their products––payroll systems and work management tools––can be quite boring for those not working in people management, the details of the lawsuit certainly aren’t. If anything, it’s a reminder that your employer can monitor not only what you send on Slack, but also what channels you preview and your searches. 
Happy reading, and hope you have a lovely week!
Maria Gracia Santillana Linares 
Careers Reporter
Follow me on 
Forbes.com
WORK SMARTER
Practical insights and advice from Forbes staff and contributors to help you succeed in your job, accelerate your career and lead smarter.
Why 
midday power naps 
can 
increase your productivity and strengthen your memory
.
From interviews to business deals, 
questions are essential to any type of job
. Here are 
three ways to ask better ones. 
Deliver negative feedback in person
, and more tips on 
how to give constructive criticism. 
You were the better candidate
 but someone else got the job. 
Now what?
DEEP DIVE
Only 29% of women say they have AI skills, according to a new Randstad report. It's only exacerbating gender discrepancies in tech. 
  
Getty
AI Upskilling Is The New Gender Gap In Tech 
Read Report
In the already male-dominated tech world, a new 
report
 by staffing firm Randstad shows the staggering gap in AI skills between men and women.
We’ve all seen the ads for 
“AI skills” classes
. From prompt engineering 101 to managing AI agents, learning how to best use artificial intelligence at your job is currently a major focus of corporate development programs.
But not everyone is benefitting from such opportunities equally. A new report by global staffing firm
 
Randstad found
 that while 71% of men report having AI skills, only 29% of women can say the same.
Equitable access to resources and skilling opportunities is key to the global talent scarcity, Randstad CEO Sander van’t Noordende wrote in the report. “When it comes to AI, demand continues to grow at an unprecedented rate, and so does the AI equity gap it is creating,” he adds. This is especially true in the tech industry, where women 
make up only about 25% of roles.
 Whether it be in more formal LLM training or simple advice on how to effectively prompt generative AI to create a customized deck, access to AI training is quickly mirroring already-existing gender gaps. 
“Technology scales so fast, it scales what already is,” says Sree Menon, a partner at venture capital firm FalconX and founder of EmpowerHer.ai.
But here’s the caveat: The gender discrepancy comes from employees reporting using employer-provided AI. That’s not to say that there isn’t an actual gap between men and women in AI usage, but is it possible that women are under-reporting their own use of the technology?
Says Menon: “I have seen women take a lot more pride in their work, and take it more personally, than men do. So when it comes to using AI, that may be an admission that I actually used help.” 
Indeed, a 2024 report by Microsoft and LinkedIn found similar results: Workers are 
reluctant to share with their bosses
 that they’re using AI at work, even when it’s sanctioned by their employers. Ethan Mollick, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania’s Wharton School who studies AI, told 
Forbes
 at the time that employees “know if they tell [their bosses] about it, then maybe [they’re] not so impressed by all the amazing work they’re doing. Everyone is trying to not show that they’ve automated their work.” 
TOUCH BASE
 
Rand Larsen has spent the past year living in a camper van, traveling the country to help small business owners connect and navigate entrepreneurship.
 
Brandon Kochkodin
 
News from the world of work 
Owning a small business can be a lonely affair, especially for those pursuing entrepreneurship through acquisition, a practice that has gained traction but remains rare in the broader small business world. 
One influencer is creating a community to help business owners stay sane,
 
Forbes’ 
Brandon Kochkodin 
reports
. 
It’s getting harder to get into law school.
 Applications are up 20.2% from last year, according to the
 
Law School Admissions Council
, while open seats remain relatively the same. Law school applications rise during recessions, according to the 
Wall Street Journal
, or when the job market is tough, as in 2021. But this year could also be experiencing a “Trump bump,” as applicants follow high-profile legal battles. 
President Trump
 
revoked 19 executive orders
 signed by former President Biden
 last week, including actions establishing a 
$17.75 minimum wage
 for federal contractors, mandating apprenticeship programs, and what the Trump Administration called a “directive to prioritize union-driven policies that imposed unnecessary regulations on industries.”
The Trump Administration
 continues to lay off employees as part of the president’s effort to downsize the federal government. 
Last week, the Department of Education said it would 
cut about 50% of its workforce
. But it’s not certain that these employees will remain out of work, as a federal appeals court on Monday upheld a ruling ordering several agencies to 
rehire
 their laid-off employees. 
AI nurses are facing growing pushback from their human counterparts,
 reports the 
AP
. As companies increasingly hire AI chatbots to supposedly aid nurses with paperwork and help address a worker shortage, nursing unions say that these programs are instead generating false alarms and dangerous advice. 
Forbes
 released its tenth annual
 
Best Management Consulting Firms list
 today, a ranking of the best firms across 16 different industries and 17 different functional areas. 
Topping the list was Deloitte
, which received the most recommendations from both clients and other consulting partners. 
NUMBER TO NOTE
86%
That’s how many teenagers said it is extremely or very important for them 
to have a job or career they enjoy when they’re an adult
, more than the percentage who said the same about getting married or having children in a recent Pew Research Center survey.  
 
VIDEO
What You Need to Know About Trump’s Student Loan Forgiveness
Watch Video
QUIZ

A.
Finding cockroaches on floors and bugs out of faucets
B.
Working from a supply closet due to lack of space
C.
Using a personal hotspot to access government data
D.
Leaking ceilings
