subject: Smart Strategies for Gen AI in Law Firms (Wise Decision Maker Guide 147)
body:
Wise Decision Maker Guide 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
Greetings Monica,
Generative AI offers law firms opportunities to improve efficiency and client service, but ethical risks must be carefully managed. For example, several recent cases resulted in fines for lawyers who provided fictitious citations that were obtained through Gen AI. In response, the American Bar Association issued Formal Opinion 512, reinforcing that ethical obligations under the ABA Model Rules of Professional Conduct remain critical when using Gen AI. Lawyers must ensure accuracy, safeguard client confidentiality, communicate AI use transparently, and uphold reasonable billing practices. 
Law firms that want to take advantage of AI’s potential must prioritize training, clear policies, and human verification.
To learn more, check out this
 
blog
.
Read Blog
 
Prefer video to text? See this 
video
 based on the blog:
If you prefer audio, listen to this 
podcast
 based on the blog:
Make Your Voice Heard
Vote in this 
LinkedIn poll
 to contribute to the conversation. I will use the responses to inform my articles in 
Harvard Business Review
, 
Fortune
, and 
Entrepreneur
.
Your Testimonials
You and others who gain value from Disaster Avoidance Experts 
services
 and thought leadership occasionally share testimonials about your experience, such as the one below. You can read more testimonials 
here
.
“I wanted to thank you for speaking recently at our Spring 2024 National Legal Malpractice Conference. We really enjoyed having you and hearing you discuss proximity bias. It was really a worthwhile event and conversation for our panel who really didn't know a great deal about it or a lot of the implications related to it. We 
really appreciated all the energy and obvious underlying knowledge that you have related to the topic.
 All of our panelists really enjoyed hearing from you, our guests enjoyed hearing from you, and we look forward to working with you again.”
‌
Jay Reyes
, 
Chief Counsel at the American Bar Association
Schedule a Free Consultation
 
What's Up With Me
My wife and business partner, Agnes Vishnevkin, and Iwere making our plans to travel from our hometown of Columbus, Ohio, to visit my parents for my mom’s 75th birthday in New York City. At the same time, she’s been struggling with a period of back pain for the past two months. Her condition fluctuated, but it was worse again in the days leading up to the trip, so I suggested she should skip the trip. She was quite reluctant to do so, because she was concerned that my mother would be upset. I was surprised how hard it was to convince her to agree to stay home.
This is the kind of situation where she and I differ: I tend to think people will understand and forgive, while she is more worried about others’ judgments. Maybe sometimes I underestimate how judgmental people might be, but in this case I think I was right. Sometimes, we need to reduce our concerns about other people’s opinions and focus on our own self-care. Now, that doesn’t mean being a jerk, there has to be a balance, but in this case the balance to me was clearly toward self-care. 
What do you think should be the balance between self-care and consideration of other people’s feelings?
 
Would love to get your feedback on what you found most useful about this edition of the “Wise Decision Maker Guide” - simply reply to this email.
Decisively Yours,
Dr. Gleb
Dr. Gleb Tsipursky
CEO of Disaster Avoidance Experts

subject: Reminder: Learn how to use logic to defeat unconscious bias
body:
Did you know that logic is a powerful tool for defeating bias?
 
 
 
"Overcoming Bias: A Guide to Skilled Skepticism"
 
Don’t you love being right? I sure do. I think that’s one reason most of us are afflicted with what’s called “confirmation bias” – the pesky habit of noticing only the evidence that proves our previously held beliefs correct. In other words, we see what we expect to see.
 
This is where our biases – our inflexible beliefs about categories of people – trick us into jumping to the wrong conclusions. Once we get it into our heads that members of particular groups “all” – because they are members of that group – share a particular characteristic, our brain just can’t resist proving that bias right.
 
Take for example what can happen when we encounter a new team member who uses a wheelchair. Unfortunately, there is a tendency for some of us who are fully-abled to reflexively assume that a person in that situation will require extra help to perform their duties. 
 
That assumption – that bias – in turn means that we fastidiously notice every time he or she does, in fact, ask for help and – conveniently for the confirmation we are seeking – we fail to spot the more numerous times when that same person is utterly self-sufficient.
 
Noticing only that which makes us feel right may be tempting, but it sure is a bad idea if we are to see the people around us for who they really are and what they have to bring to the workplace.
 
So, here’s a thought: What if we adopt and practice a far-more productive habit? Namely the habit of "skilled skepticism". What if, every time we make an assumption about what someone is like, we pause to weaken that conclusion by dissecting its logic? Specifically, we ask ourselves these two questions:
 
Have I ever encountered someone who uses a wheelchair whose need for extra help interfered with my performance in some way?
 
This brings us to the reality that, sure, some people who use wheelchairs do require extra help. That’s real. It’s not, however, “all” as our confirmation bias tricks us into believing. And this brings us to the demonic nature of bias. 
 
When we have even one experience with a member of a group that negatively impacts us in some way -- in this case “interferes with performance"-- the brain seeks to protect us from repeating that experience by erroneously teaching us that all members of the group in question are equally apt to put us at that disadvantage. 
 
Sadly experiences like this can cause a bias to be born. By recalling that experience and recognizing that it is an 
isolated
 incident, it brings the event into perspective and, thereby, weakens its impact on our thinking. 
 
How many people who use wheelchairs do I 
actually know
 who are constantly asking for help?
 
 
The key phrase here is “actually know.” This doesn’t mean saw depicted on the web or heard a rumor about. It means having had significant ongoing contact with a situation in which help was regularly sought. The answer is overwhelmingly apt to be very few if any. That answer -- that insight -- has the power to cut through your bias, to weaken it, and allow the rational brain to take over. 
 
Skilled scientism – it works. You’ll be surprised at what you will learn – not only about your colleagues – but about yourself as well.

CLIENTS AND TESTIMONIALS
 
CONTACT US TODAY!

Virtual Presentations
 on How to Defeat Unconscious Bias

Whatever is best for you, let’s work together to get results.

Client Comments About Sondra's Programs:
“Sondra’s unique ability to engage the audience and involve them in the process made us feel as if we were in the same room with her.” Janice Bowman, Former President, Association of Diversity Councils.
“For 90 minutes, Sondra kept the participants engaged. She told amusing anecdotes, employed industry-specific examples, and took an involving approach that got her message across.” Cindy Levernois, Former Director, Healthcare Association of New York State

What Readers Have to Say: 
"
Simplicity at its finest. We all have those moments of truth when we recognize a bias in our thinking. Sondra’s book gives us a refreshingly practical way to call bias out and change our behavior to defeat it.” Grace Figueredo, Vice President, Workplace Culture, Chief Diversity & Inclusion Officer, Aetna, Inc.
“A gentle yet effective model for encouraging well-intentioned people to become more mindful, thoughtful, and deliberate in their interactions.” Eileen Shanahan, Assistant Professor, Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine
“This is a quick, easy read that delivers on its promise – providing a means for uncovering and dealing with buried attitudes that might be interfering with your ability to make good decisions, treat people with respect, and form fruitful relationships. Dr. Thiederman’s handbook is full of helpful, practical advice on identifying and reducing the harmful effects of unintended bias.” Leslie Aguilar, Author, OUCH! That Stereotype Hurts

body:

TOP NEWS
 
All the best moments from the Tokyo Series opener
 
The 2025 MLB season got off to a jubilant start in Tokyo, where Pokémon-themed festivities set the stage for a duel between Japan-born starters Yoshinobu Yamamoto and Shota Imanaga before Shohei Ohtani helped the Dodgers pull away for a victory.
 
Ohtani ignites LA, keys winning rally in Tokyo Series opener
Imanaga bests Ohtani in 'made for TV' Tokyo matchup
Freeman (left rib discomfort) scratched from Tokyo Series opener
Strider fans 5 straight in perfect first start back after surgery

Pokémon key to celebration of Japanese icons
If Tuesday’s Tokyo Series opener between the Dodgers and the Cubs was a one-of-a-kind ballgame, the pregame ceremony needed to be just as momentous. With a bow to Pokémon, it was just that.
 
Japan's baseball passion on full display
 
A popup with an entire floor dedicated to Shohei Ohtani memorabilia and an MLB collaboration with Demon Slayer on a short anime-style film featuring Dodgers and Cubs stars are among the examples of how this week's series has taken Japan by storm. 
 
Is this the secret to Ohtani's all-fields power?
 
Almost as impressive as how many homers Shohei Ohtani hits is WHERE he hits them. His power to all fields might be unmatched, and where he makes contact in the zone tells us a lot. 
 
The 2025 All-Spring Breakout Teams
 
Here are all the exciting young prospects who stood out the most during the second annual Spring Breakout showcase this past weekend.

subject: Top Tips for Getting Your Firm 8(a) Certified
body:
Top Tips for Getting Your Firm 8(a) Certified                                                       
Top Tips for Getting Your Firm 8(a) Certified
 
Top Tips for Getting 
﻿
Your Firm 8(a) Certified
Learn More
Obtaining 8(a) Certification is a rigorous and detailed process, often involving thousands of pages of documentation. With a 75% rejection rate, it is critical to understand the key requirements and strategies for success. Here’s a concise guide to navigating the process effectively:
Key Requirements for 8(a) Certification
Social Disadvantage
Owners must demonstrate social disadvantage, often tied to minority status.
U.S. citizens with 100% minority heritage qualify automatically; others with at least 25% heritage must provide a detailed narrative.
Eligible groups include Native Americans (with tribal cards), Hispanics (including those of Iberian descent), and individuals from the Middle East or North Africa (with documented discrimination narratives).
Tips:
Native Alaskans and Hawaiians are presumed eligible but often overlook their status.
Ownership of 51% or more by the disadvantaged individual(s) is mandatory.
Economic Disadvantage
Owners cannot earn more than $400 thousand annually on average (past 3 years).
Net worth must not exceed $850 thousand, excluding the primary residence, business assets, and retirement accounts.
Total assets must not exceed $6.5 million, excluding retirement accounts.
Tips:
Retained earnings reinvested into the firm or taxes paid on such earnings do not count towards the income cap.
To reduce net worth, consider paying down the mortgage on your primary residence.
Fully disclose all assets to avoid denial due to discrepancies found in the SBA credit check.
﻿
Potential for Success
The firm must demonstrate financial viability, including profitability, a positive net worth, and at least two years in business (or meet criteria for a two-year waiver).
Not more than 70% of the firm’s revenue should come from a single source, evaluated on a rolling 12-month basis.
Tips:
Only the 51% owner must work full-time for the business.
A two-year waiver is possible with at least $150,000 in revenue and one profitable tax return.
The 70% revenue rule is waived for firms with a two-year waiver.
Control of the Firm
The disadvantaged owner must manage daily operations, lead strategic planning, and typically be the highest-paid individual.
The firm should not share employees or office space with other entities that could indicate control issues.
Tips:
Limit revenue from past employers to no more than 25%.
Justify any instance where the owner is not the highest-paid employee.
Good Moral Character
Owners must be free of unresolved ethical issues.
Taxes must be current, or a payment plan must be in place.
All criminal offenses, regardless of age, must be disclosed.
Tips:
Offenses over 5–7 years old are often forgiven, but nondisclosure is never tolerated.
The SBA conducts an FBI background check on all applicants.
Every year, 500–600 firms achieve 8(a) Certification, opening the door to unparalleled opportunities in federal contracting. While the process is demanding, careful preparation and adherence to SBA requirements can set your firm up for success.
For further assistance or questions about 8(a) Certification, feel free to contact us.
Mark Ryan & Todd Luttenegger

subject: Payment Preferences In Healthcare
body:
Survey reveals the views of consumers.
A healthcare provider’s payment system can directly influence patient satisfaction and loyalty. Here’s why, according to new research. 
Catalyzed by post-pandemic shifts across the healthcare industry, providers have worked to innovate their payment systems. Consumers interact with these systems whenever they make a payment at a doctor’s office, hospital or for any healthcare service not covered by insurance. Are healthcare payment options meeting patient expectations? 
To learn more
 about evolving payment preferences in healthcare, American Express and Forbes Insights asked consumers to evaluate their experiences making healthcare payments over the past six months. 
Here are five key findings: 
1. HAVING CHOICE OF PAYMENT METHOD IS IMPORTANT
87% of consumers said it’s important for their healthcare provider to offer their preferred payment method, 
and 24% said they would consider switching to a different healthcare provider if they couldn’t pay with their preferred payment method. 
2. THE MAJORITY PREFER TO PAY BY CREDIT CARD …
54% of consumers prefer to pay for healthcare expenses by credit card,
 the most popular option by far.
3. … AND THEY ARE LIKELY TO BECOME FRUSTRATED WHEN THEY CAN’T
48% of consumers said they feel frustrated when credit card payment options are not offered 
when paying healthcare expenses.
4. OFFERING DIGITAL METHODS MAY IMPROVE CONSUMER SATISFACTION
33% of consumers experience frustration when modern payment solutions are not offered, 
indicating they would like the option to pay using a digital wallet or mobile payment system.
5. DIGITAL REMINDERS ARE MOST POPULAR BUT SOME CONSUMERS PREFER PAPER
68% of consumers prefer an email notification when their healthcare payment is due, 
and 54% would like a text notification. Nearly half would still like a mailed statement.
WHAT THE DATA TELLS US
The survey shows that consumers want convenience, and they expect choice when making a healthcare payment. When they have a choice, the majority prefer to pay with a credit card. 
  
Getty Images
Consumer Choice: The Case For Streamlined Payment Solutions In Non-Retail Industries
For perspective into all seven industries studied in the nationwide consumer survey conducted by American Express and Forbes Insights, read our complementary report.
Explore the Report
 
SURVEY METHODOLOGY
American Express and Forbes Insights asked 680 consumers to evaluate their preferences and pain points when making healthcare-related payments over the past six months. The exploration was part of a larger, comprehensive survey of 2,507 U.S. based consumers across key non-retail industries.

subject: Tesla owners are being targeted in Chicago
body:
Plus, Carrie Coon on Steppenwolf and ‘The White Lotus.’ Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Monday - March 17, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Esther Bergdahl
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! Today, we’ll see more than 12 hours of sunlight for the first time 
since September
. As for the rest of the news, here’s what you need to know today.
  
Let WBEZ take you to the symphony! 
Support The Rundown & you could win. 
DONATE
1.
Amid backlash against Elon Musk and DOGE, Tesla owners say they’re caught in the middle
 
Across the country, authorities have reported vandalism against Tesla vehicles and dealerships. The Chicago area hasn’t been immune to the backlash: Vandals tagged a new Tesla dealership in Buffalo Grove over the weekend and a Tesla showroom in the Gold Coast has been the site of protests calling for people to ditch their vehicles.
Individual Tesla owners are also facing outrage from all sides, reports my colleague Emmanuel Camarillo at the Sun-Times. “I think you should be able to separate personal property from that,” one driver said. “The people who own the property have nothing to do with what [CEO Elon Musk] did, and most of us bought the car before Elon went rogue.”
Eddie Zipperstein, owner of Richard’s Body shop in Albany Park, said his store had serviced four vandalized Teslas in the last couple of months. The vandalism to those cars included damage from eggs and one case in which a Tesla was rammed from behind.
Zipperstein owns a Cybertruck and has seen people’s frustrations when he’s on the street. “I get the finger like literally once a day, and it’s not because I drive like an idiot,” he said. He hopes people realize that “a car is not a political statement.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
2.
CTA slow zones are growing, and that means longer commutes for ‘L’ riders
 
The Chicago Tribune reports that slow zones, wherein trains that normally travel up to 55 mph stutter and crawl between 35 and 15 mph, have more than doubled since 2020.
Five years ago, CTA riders might encounter slow zones over 13% of the rail system, but today that number stands at 30%. All train lines suffer from slow zones, but the Forest Park branch of the Blue Line is particularly burdened, with 77% of its route slowed down. Major portions of the Green Line, the Brown Line and downtown strips of the Red Line also performed poorly.
The CTA points to still-diminished ridership and funding since the COVID-19 pandemic, leaving riders still caught between a rock and a slow spot. [
Chicago Tribune
]

Disclaimers
1 Mode Mobile recently received their ticker reservation with Nasdaq ($MODE), indicating an intent to IPO in the next 24 months. An intent to IPO is no guarantee that an actual IPO will occur.
2 The rankings are based on submitted applications and public company database research, with winners selected based on their fiscal-year revenue growth percentage over a three-year period.
3 A minimum investment of $1,950 is required to receive bonus shares. 100% bonus shares are offered on investments of $9,950+.
3.
Robbery of $30,000 necklace incited the brawl and shootout at O'Hare
 
A $30,000 gold necklace caused a wild shoot-out where nearly 60 shots were fired and a self-proclaimed rapper was wounded last week at O’Hare Airport, according to police reports, writes my colleague Mohammad Samra at the Sun-Times..
Passengers from a Spirit Airlines flight from Houston made their way down an escalator to baggage claim around 12:55 a.m. Wednesday; one of them, a 27-year-old South Side man, spotted the 25-year-old rapper and followed him.
The 27-year-old, carrying a backpack that contained the white gold necklace and $1,000, noticed half a dozen or more males exit a van outside and walk toward the lower level where he was heading, according to a police report and sources.
Once downstairs, the 27-year-old was attacked by several masked males and he was hit in the head and chest area after a quarrel, apparently over the backpack. Soon, “[m]ultiple male offenders began to open fire at each other,’’ according to the police report, which showed evidence technicians recovered 57 shell casings. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
4.
Cindy Pritzker, beloved family matriarch and philanthropist, dies at 101
 
Marian “Cindy” Friend Pritzker was the matriarch of one of Chicago’s most powerful families. She was the wife of the man behind the Hyatt Hotel dynasty, aunt of Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker and a philanthropist who championed the city’s public libraries and architecture.
Pritzker also liked to have a good time. She enjoyed the occasional glass of wine and cigarette. She held the family record for swearing. At age 80, she got her ears pierced for the first time. A decade later, she got her first tattoo. She headed the Chicago Public Library Board and, with her husband, co-founded the Pritzker Architecture Prize. Andy Warhol even painted her portrait, which now hangs in the Chicago Athletic Association hotel’s rooftop lounge that carries her name.
Pritzker died Saturday, according to a family representative, report my colleagues Kaitlin Washburn and Michael Sneed at the Sun-Times. She was 101 years old. A statement from her family did not disclose how or where she died. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
Peggy Montes helped establish Chicago's Women's History Month — and still is a 'lady in motion'
 
It’s easier for Montes to name the Chicago institutions she does not have a relationship with, whether as a philanthropist, trustee, awardee or founder, reports my Sun-Times colleague Mariah Rush.
The Bronzeville native is chairwoman emerita at DuSable Museum, member of the Black Creativity Program at the Griffin Museum of Science and Industry and co-founder of the Leadership Advisory Council at the Art Institute of Chicago, to name a few.
Beside the arsenal of awards and accomplishments is a woman well aware of her mark on Chicago’s cultural and political history, and she has more goals on her to-do list.
Montes says she knows why so many social and political powerhouses have sought her help: “I am intelligent, I have wisdom, I’m beautiful and I’m going to do what is right.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
A new study finds that excessive heat can age you as much as smoking. [
NPR
]
Republicans in Congress holding town halls and constituent meetings are facing a torrent of confrontational voters scared about possible cuts to Social Security. [
AP
]
In Little Village, Rodeo Farm is working to restore Illinois prairie with native plants. [
Block Club Chicago
]
Sun-Times reporter Maddie Lee follows the Cubs to Japan for the Tokyo Series against defending World Series champions Los Angeles Dodgers. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
Actor Carrie Coon has appeared in TV series such as 
The Leftovers, Fargo 
and
 The Gilded Age
, as well as movies such as 
Gone Girl
. But here in Chicago, she is perhaps best known as an ensemble member of Steppenwolf Theatre, alongside her husband, the actor and writer Tracy Letts.
Currently, Coon stars in the third season of Mike White’s award-winning HBO anthology 
The White Lotus
. Her character belongs in a trio of middle-aged women who take a girls’ trip to Thailand. While they are ostensibly vacationing, each character’s secrets lurk under an otherwise placid surface. It’s the type of layered, complex character that has attracted Coon throughout her career.
“We’re all living in this world where we’re performing self on social media,” she told my colleague Mike Davis. “It’s absolutely absurd, and everyone’s feeling lonely and everyone’s feeling left out, and everyone’s pretending they’re not. And if you ask any one of these women who is the most judged, left out or lonely, they would each say themselves. It’s just that Laurie happens to be portraying it in the story more thoroughly.” [
WBEZ
]
 
Tell me something good
 
The Cubs are in Tokyo and the Music Box Theatre is running a series on 
baseball films
. That has me wondering: What’s your favorite sports movie?
Feel free to email me, and your response may be included in the newsletter this week.
Thanks for reading — have a great evening! I'll see you tomorrow.
— Esther Bergdahl
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting.

1 player from every team making the biggest impression
From up-and-coming young players to newly acquired stars to veterans seeking to rebound, here is one player at each Spring Training camp who has turned some heads.
 
'Just to be clear, I will be pitching'
 
Joey Gallo has put up some prodigious strikeout totals while slugging 208 career home runs, and now he is going to try to rack up some K's from the mound.
 
Shaw is no stranger to Tokyo
 
Cubs prospect Matt Shaw is slated to make his MLB debut during the Tokyo Series, but it won't be a completely unfamiliar experience. He played at Tokyo Dome only four months ago in the Premier12 tournament.
 
Baseball's best, according to the players
 
We surveyed more than 100 players on everything from the best player in the game to who should host a podcast. Here are all of the final results.

subject: Boost employee engagement? Yes, please
body:
Exclusive invitation to our Diversity Reboot Summit
Hi Monica,
 
Since you grabbed our report, Supporting Neurodiversity in the workplace — you already know that embracing Neurodiversity can give you a vast competitive edge across quality improvement, innovative capabilities, and employee engagement. 
 
Speaking of engagement… 
employees feel more disconnected from employers than ever before
. And they’re feeling it most when it comes to:
Communication of expectations
Connection to the company mission
Growth opportunities
Feeling cared about at work
 
Is it really as bleak as it sounds? If so, a bigger question remains.
 
What can I do to increase employee engagement?
 
For starters, consider attending an upcoming PowerToFly Summit. Our summit series is the 
largest conference series of its kind today
, calling on subject matter experts from all over the world to share insights, move the needle on critical issues, and unite work communities.
 
Save my spot
 
As your partner and ally, we’re excited to take this journey with you. Please feel free to reply to this email or 
use this link
 to schedule a 15-minute chat with us today.
 
Best,
 
Sienna Brown
VP of Growth
 
PowerToFly, 228 Park Avenue South, Suite 75391, New York, NY 10003, United States

subject: Building Anti-Racist Habits
body:
Why it's important and how to do it  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
March 17, 2025   |   
Read Online
Building Anti-Racist Habits 
Why it's important and how to do it - including my personal anti-racism habit stack 
 
 
 
 
 
Here’s a special sneak preview of an article going to paid subscribers. If you’d like to read it all, please consider 
upgrading your subscription.
Hello friends, 
One of the things that came up in the SHHARE anti-racism membership community a couple months ago was the question of how to build and sustain anti-racist habits. In other words, while everyone's heart is in the right place, sometimes things slip through the cracks, and people don't feel like they're living up to their values. 
In response to this, I put together a live learning session on the topic, centred around the productivity practice of habit stacking. In my previous career as a freelance writer, I wrote about habit stacking for 
OnePageCRM
: 
“take a few of the small changes you want to make and combine them into a single routine that helps you achieve them. Once you get used to doing the first task, all the others will fall into place as a matter of course.”
Why did I think habit stacking was useful for anti-racism? Because small actions, repeated regularly, can add up to lasting change. 
Getting Started With Anti-Racism Habit Stacking
Many of you will have started with one small action, which might be as simple as following a Black or Global Majority activist or creator and reading, learning from, commenting on or amplifying their work. I'm guessing that's how many of you found me. But imagine the power when you start daisy-chaining multiple actions together, to create daily, weekly and monthly anti-racism habit stacks. 
In the session, I looked at habits: 
to support an anti-racism mindset 
to create a foundation for learning and taking action 
to spot and deal with racism both in the workplace, and in social and family settings 
for reflection and self-awareness 
for going further once you get beyond the initial phase of habit building. 
And I shared this sample habit stack for anti-racism: 
Daily:
 Reflective practice morning and evening; amplify a Black creator or activist; identify and learn from a new source and reflect on your learning; add to your list of new sources 
Weekly/Monthly
: Support a Black-owned business (regular donation or one-off); volunteer in a Black-owned business; advocate for an anti-racism cause; track your progress 
Regularly
: Accountability check-ins; seek support from the group; speak up; interrupt racism; self-care 
My Personal Habit Stack
Since I believe in applying what you learn, the week after the learning session there was another task for the community: to create and share their own starter habit stack. And since I'm part of the community, I created and shared my own. 
Subscribe to SARN Supporter to read the rest.
Become a paying subscriber of SARN Supporter to get access to this post and other subscriber-only content.

subject: Re: March Madness Pool
body:
Thank you all again for another nice push yesterday.  We currently need 38 more squares sold.  Please continue to reach out to friends and family.  I am keeping it open as long as I can which means I will close it and send out the sheet around 5 pm EST Tuesday.  If we don't hit the 100 mark, we will eliminate the early games to compensate.  Hope we dont have to do that so let's get to 100.
Thank you again to all
Mike
On Mar 16, 2025, at 2:35 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Afternoon Everyone,
We are getting closer to our goal of 100 squares with 46 left.  Very much appreciate everyone who has contributed up to this point.  We still have plenty of opportunities to jump in as there are 46 squares left.  Please reach out to friends and family.  
Thank you again to all
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 1:53 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
I am going to work very hard to keep this at the top of everyone's inbox. I apologize in advance for the amount of emails I plan on sending out.  We are wrapping up the fundraising so we need one final big push. We have until Monday night to fill this sheet out.  I started by purchasing 3 myself.  97 more.  The brackets are fun but the odds of winning anything at all are relatively low.  With the squares, your odds of winning are significantly higher and much more realistic than football squares.  3 days, please pass along to friends or family that would like to join in supporting the baseball program.
Thank you
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 12:07 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Evening Everyone,
Just want to say thank you again for the great support shown during the fundraising and the First Pitch Event.  We are now reaching the end of the fundraising season as we enter the baseball season.  As you are likely aware, there are other groups at DePaul doing March Madness brackets. I know it puts more pressure on families to financially engage and we try to avoid it.  Regardless, we're gonna open our final fundraiser and try something a little different.  Rather than doing the traditional bracket, we are going to do squares. This is very simple, buy your squares and win based on the final score of each game.  Remember, there are 67 games when including the play in games.  That means you literally have 67 chances to win.  With each game fetching a $100 prize, you could win up to $6700.  Let's make this the biggest fundraising event yet.  Send it out to friends and families.  Let's make sure we sell this one out  We're going $100 per square.  Payment cam be made with Zelle to 
rogs1@mac.com
.
Let me know if you have any questions.
Mike

subject: Empowering Small Businesses Through AI Survey
body:
Message Preheader Content 
Having trouble viewing this email?
View this email in a web browser
.
 
Dear WIPP Community, 
  
We’re inviting you to participate in a brief survey designed exclusively for small business owners like you. WIPP and our partners want to better understand the challenges you face using artificial intelligence (AI), the tools you need, and how AI can make a real difference in your business.
  
Your perspective is critical, and we’re listening.
  
Please take the time to share your thoughts and help create tools that truly work for you and your business.
  
Your responses will be completely confidential. At the end of the survey, you will have the option to provide contact information to receive a copy of the findings. 
  
Questions? Email 
survey@reimaginemainstreet.org
.
Click to fill out the survey.

subject: Re: March Madness Pool
body:
Good Afternoon Everyone,
We are getting closer to our goal of 100 squares with 46 left.  Very much appreciate everyone who has contributed up to this point.  We still have plenty of opportunities to jump in as there are 46 squares left.  Please reach out to friends and family.  
Thank you again to all
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 1:53 PM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
I am going to work very hard to keep this at the top of everyone's inbox. I apologize in advance for the amount of emails I plan on sending out.  We are wrapping up the fundraising so we need one final big push. We have until Monday night to fill this sheet out.  I started by purchasing 3 myself.  97 more.  The brackets are fun but the odds of winning anything at all are relatively low.  With the squares, your odds of winning are significantly higher and much more realistic than football squares.  3 days, please pass along to friends or family that would like to join in supporting the baseball program.
Thank you
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 12:07 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Evening Everyone,
Just want to say thank you again for the great support shown during the fundraising and the First Pitch Event.  We are now reaching the end of the fundraising season as we enter the baseball season.  As you are likely aware, there are other groups at DePaul doing March Madness brackets. I know it puts more pressure on families to financially engage and we try to avoid it.  Regardless, we're gonna open our final fundraiser and try something a little different.  Rather than doing the traditional bracket, we are going to do squares. This is very simple, buy your squares and win based on the final score of each game.  Remember, there are 67 games when including the play in games.  That means you literally have 67 chances to win.  With each game fetching a $100 prize, you could win up to $6700.  Let's make this the biggest fundraising event yet.  Send it out to friends and families.  Let's make sure we sell this one out  We're going $100 per square.  Payment cam be made with Zelle to 
rogs1@mac.com
.
Let me know if you have any questions.
Mike

subject: Book your spring escape in New York City with our member breakfast discount.
body:
Make InterContinental New York Times Square your home base for everything the city has to offer.
 
 
 
Plan Your NYC Escape
 
Spring marks the return of the MLB season for you to cheer for New York City’s beloved teams: the New York Yankees and the New York Mets as they kick off their home openers. Coming up as well, the Easter Parade, The Bonnet Festival, The New York Auto Show, along with the debut of new Broadway shows. 
With so many exciting events happening, there are plenty of reasons to plan a getaway to New York City. Take advantage of our Member Exclusive Offer and enjoy savings with our Breakfast Member Discount. For added flexibility, you can rebook or cancel your reservation at no charge up to two days before your stay. 
Reserve our member offer by clicking the booking link below.
 
BOOK NOW 
 
 
 
Big Apple Breakfast
For your next visit, explore our exciting new breakfast buffet selection at the Stinger. Enjoy a hot station with freshly prepared dishes, including fluffy scrambled eggs, crispy bacon, and daily grill specials. The cold bar features smoked salmon, charcuterie, fresh vegetables, seasonal fruit, yogurt, pastries, NYC bagels, cereals, and chilled beverages. 
Choose from a Continental or Full American breakfast, complete with New York specials.
 
BREAKFAST MENU
 
Jazz Evenings
with Russ Nolan Jazz Trio
We are excited to announce new performance dates for the Russ Nolan Jazz Trio at The Stinger Cocktail Bar & Kitchen! Join us for unforgettable evenings of Latin and Modern Jazz on Tuesday, March 18, April 1, and April 15, from 5:30 PM to 8:00 PM.
 
Now On Broadway!
SMASH, the new musical based on the hit TV show, makes its long-awaited Broadway debut at the Imperial Theatre, with opening night set for April 10. Get your tickets now!
SMASHBROADWAY.COM 
InterContinental New York Times Square 
300 W 44th St, New York, NY 10036 
1 (866) 875-1978 
www.interconny.com

subject: MLB's best player? Well, we asked the players
body:
Plus: Last 4 Spring Breakout games today
Sunday, March 16
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS
 
How 150 years of baseball history led to Tokyo Series
 
As Tokyo prepares to host an epic opening series featuring several of MLB's top Japanese stars, it's worth going all the way back to 1872 to trace the path that led us to this point.
 
Sasaki a symbol of hope for people of Japan
Another first for Skenes -- an Opening Day start
'I love the country': Roberts' journey comes full circle in return to Japan
Spring Breakout highlights and results; final 4 games today
Gunnar (intercostal) eyes return by Opening Day: 'That's my plan'
Devers, Abreu debuts make Red Sox lineup whole again
Sale pays homage to Tiant with first pitch: 'One of my favorite people'
Bradfield dedicates Spring Breakout performance to late friend
MORE TOP NEWS
 
MLB MORNING LINEUP PODCAST
 
 
 
PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!
 
MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
MLB players say the best player in baseball is ...
In our survey of over one hundred players, they overwhelmingly chose Shohei Ohtani as the best player in baseball but had plenty to say about Bobby Witt Jr., Aaron Judge and others.
 
World Series foes reunited at Giants camp
 
Two of Pablo Sandoval's three homers in 2012 World Series Game 1 came off Justin Verlander. Now that Sandoval is a guest instructor for the Giants and Verlander has joined the club, has it been awkward? "I don't bring it up," Sandoval said.
 
From Whole Foods to the big leagues?
 
After spending the past two offseasons stocking shelves at a Whole Foods near his Nashville-area home, Mets catcher Hayden Senger has a realistic chance at cracking the Major Leagues.
 
The brief, frigid history of Cubs-Dodgers openers
 
You need to go all the way back to a 33-degree day at Wrigley Field in 1963 for the last time the Dodgers and Cubs faced off on Opening Day.
 
Moving back to take a step forward
 
With Statcast's new data on where hitters stand in the batter's box, we can look at changes Pete Crow-Armstrong has made at the plate that have paid dividends so far in Spring Training.
 
Gold stars: Award winners to wear special logo
 
Last year's MVPs, Cy Young winners and Rookies of the Year will wear gold MLB logos on the backs of their jerseys that will be incorporated into special Topps cards.

subject: MercyMe will be in Milwaukee, WI NEXT WEEK!
body:
Get your tickets today!
 
ONLY ONE WEEK AWAY🎉
 
MercyMe is coming to your area with Zach Williams and special guest Sam Wesley NEXT WEEK! You don't want to miss this unforgettable night full of worship and encouragement!
Saturday, March 22, 2025
Miller High Life
Milwaukee, WI
TICKETS!
 
 
ABOUT MERCYME
It continues to be a landmark time for the multi-platinum selling, GRAMMY® nominated, multiple American Music Award, Billboard Music Award and Dove Award winners MercyMe. They were named Billboard’s Top Christian Artist of the 2010 decade, and in 2020 received their eighth American Music Award nomination. A major motion picture based on the life of frontman Bart Millard who wrote the mega-hit song “I Can Only Imagine” after the loss of his father, opened at a remarkable No. 3 at the box office on Mar. 16, 2018 (Lionsgate, Roadside Attractions). Since their debut in 2001, the band has sold more than 9 million units in CD, single and DVD sales, garnered more than 49 No. 1 multi-format radio singles, and had four consecutive mainstream radio hits. MercyMe made history in 2014 as “I Can Only Imagine” surpassed 2 million digital downloads, making it the first song in Christian music to go platinum and double-platinum in the digital domain. The song has now gone 5x platinum. In 2009, Billboard named MercyMe’s “Word Of God Speak” the No. 1 Song of The Decade and the group the No. 1 Artist of the Decade in both the Christian Songs and Christian AC Songs categories, recognizing them as one of the industry’s most notable talents.  
Don't wait! Get your tickets today!
TICKETS!
 
 
 
 
Important Ticket Info: 
There has been an increase in fraudulent and unlawful scams around concert ticket sales online. To ensure everyone has an official ticket to the event through proper channels, we recommend you purchase your tickets through the official ticketing outlet for your event. subject: Ohtani electrifies Tokyo Dome with booming HR
body:
Plus: Senga unleashes 64 mph 'Miracle Ball'
Saturday, March 15
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS
 
Where Power Rankings stand heading into the 2025 season
 
With our first regular-season games in Tokyo just days away, the No. 1 team should not come as much of a surprise as we rank all 30 clubs going into Opening Day.
 
Ohtani electrifies Tokyo Dome with booming homer
Switch-pitcher Cijntje deals from both sides in Spring Breakout
Pair of exciting pitching matchups slated for Tokyo Series
Cardinals' young fireballer draws ... Kershaw comps?
Converted reliever Holmes gets Mets' Opening Day start
At age 19, top prospect Walcott mature beyond his years
'Just an honor': Rodón receives Opening Day nod for Yankees
MORE TOP NEWS
 
MLB MORNING LINEUP PODCAST
 
 
 
PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!
 
MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
Who is the best pitcher in baseball? Here's what players said
In our survey of more than one hundred players, the picks for the best pitcher in baseball included the reigning Cy Young Award winners and last season's top NL Rookie.
 
How Imanaga reinvented himself in MLB
 
Shortly after Shota Imanaga reported to Cubs Spring Training last year, he made changes to his pitching style that helped him dominate in his first taste of the Major Leagues.
 
'Ghost Fork,' meet 'Miracle Ball'
 
After Kodai Senga got an awkward swing out of a looping 63.5 mph curveball, he dubbed the pitch "The Miracle Ball," but would not commit to it becoming a regular part of his repertoire.
 
Pearl of a trophy for Padres-Mariners winner
 
Interleague games between the Padres and Mariners have informally been known as The Vedder Cup for years, and now the season series winner will get a trophy featuring a guitar provided by Eddie Vedder himself.
 
Spring Breakout live on MLB Network 
Matchups between every team’s top prospects continue as the Twins face the Blue Jays at 1 p.m. ET, the Yankees meet the Orioles at 4 and the Angels take on the Cubs at 9.
 
Cubs vs. Yomiuri Giants
The Cubs get ready for the Tokyo Series with an exhibition game against the Yomiuri Giants, live Sunday at 6 a.m. ET on MLB Network.

subject: Inside the fossil hunt 80 miles south of Chicago
body:
Plus the latest news from Chicago's NPR station.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
 Donate
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members 
 
Photo: Manuel Martinez/WBEZ
WBEZ NEWS
Digging for the monsters of Illinois’ Mazon Creek
From batch sales of unopened rocks on eBay to discreet phone calls to higher-dollar patrons, Illinois’ commercial fossil trade is alive and well.
READ MORE
WBEZ NEWS
 
Photo: Andrew Meriwether for WBEZ
Why is there a cemetery at O’Hare Airport?
A little over 300 people found their final home at Resthaven Cemetery, which has been there since before the Civil War.
READ MORE
 
Photo: Manuel Martinez/WBEZ
In 2025, Chicago theater maven Jackie Taylor is breaking her own rules
The CEO of Black Ensemble Theater is disrupting her traditional formula with a new autobiographical musical — and a planned expansion in Uptown.
READ MORE
 
Photo: Esther Yoon-Ji Kang/WBEZ
Chicago etiquette luncheon builds confidence while covering bread-buttering, fork usage
As part of a mentorship program, young girls of color are taught the dos and don’ts of dining to help ease their way into any space.
READ MORE
 
Photo: K’Von Jackson for WBEZ
What’s That Building? The Gerber Building and former Uptown Station
A structure that used to house the now–Wilson Red Line stop could soon be a grocery store owned and operated by customers.
READ MORE
 
MEMBERS FUND WBEZ CHICAGO
 
WBEZ is sending a listener to Mexico!
If you already need a vacation from 2025, WBEZ has just the remedy. Your donation today not only supports your local NPR station and this newsletter, it also 
enters you to win a 4-night stay for two in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico!
A gift of any amount adds your name not only into this drawing, but also into 
one more trip giveaway that we’ll be announcing soon
. 
Support WBEZ today and enter to win!
 
UPCOMING EVENTS
 
WBEZ Present: An Evening with Roxane Gay & Sasha-Ann Simons
Date/Time: 
Wednesday, March 26 at 7:30 p.m.
Location:
 Athenaeum Center -  2936 N Southport Ave, Chicago, IL 60657
WBEZ invites you in conversation with New York Times best-selling author and feminist icon Roxane Gay at the Athenaeum Center for Thought & Culture on March 26. Gay will discuss her newest title, 
The Portable Feminist Reader
, with the host of WBEZ’s Reset, Sasha-Ann Simons.
The Portable Feminist Reader
 dives into the history of American feminism as Gay considers multicultural perspectives and intersectional issues like ecofeminism, feminism, disability, and Black feminism. Each ticket comes with a signed copy of 
The Portable Feminist Reader
.  
Use code “BOOKCLUB” for 20% off at checkout. 
TICKETS
 
Chicago Foundation for Women Impact Awards
Date/Time:
 March 20 at 5 p.m.
Location: 
Harold Washington Library - 400 S State St, Chicago, IL 60605
Celebrate bold organizations and changemakers working tirelessly to ensure women, girls, and gender-expansive individuals have the support they need to succeed. Join the Chicago Foundation for Women to commemorate the organizations 40th Anniversary and Women’s History Month, honor the Founding Mothers who ignited a movement and the trailblazers who continue to expand its reach through the Founders’ Fund. Don’t miss this opportunity to celebrate the extraordinary organizations and leaders driving change.
TICKETS
 
The Other Art Fair Chicago
Date/Time:
  March 27-30, Various Times
Location: 
Artifact Events - 4325 N Ravenswood Ave, Chicago, IL 60613
4 days. 115+ independent artists. Unlimited creativity. The Other Art Fair isn’t just about seeing art—it’s about experiencing it. Expect pieces that surprise at prices that don’t. Plus, interactive installations, portrait sessions with Anna Marie Tendler (booking required), live DJ sets, a flowing bar, local food vendors, and a few unexpected moments along the way.
TICKETS

subject: Re: March Madness Pool
body:
Good Evening Everyone,
What a great push early on.  28 squares off the table today with 3 more days to go until the sheet is live.  That means an average of 24 a day, which we beat today. We had grandparents, 2024 families as well as some 2028 families signing up.  Everyone is joining in. Push it to friends, family and colleagues.  All are welcome to join.  67 chances to win. 
Thank you again
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 12:07 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Evening Everyone,
Just want to say thank you again for the great support shown during the fundraising and the First Pitch Event.  We are now reaching the end of the fundraising season as we enter the baseball season.  As you are likely aware, there are other groups at DePaul doing March Madness brackets. I know it puts more pressure on families to financially engage and we try to avoid it.  Regardless, we're gonna open our final fundraiser and try something a little different.  Rather than doing the traditional bracket, we are going to do squares. This is very simple, buy your squares and win based on the final score of each game.  Remember, there are 67 games when including the play in games.  That means you literally have 67 chances to win.  With each game fetching a $100 prize, you could win up to $6700.  Let's make this the biggest fundraising event yet.  Send it out to friends and families.  Let's make sure we sell this one out  We're going $100 per square.  Payment cam be made with Zelle to 
rogs1@mac.com
.
Let me know if you have any questions.
Mike

subject: Only 6% of Chicago shootings lead to arrests
body:
Plus, this year’s viral St. Patrick’s Day stunt. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Friday - March 14, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Esther Bergdahl
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! Warmer temperatures have arrived, but so has the potential for 
major storms
 this weekend. As for the rest of the news, here’s what you need to know today.
  
1.
Slim odds of an arrest when someone is shot and wounded in Chicago
 
More than 19,000 people have been wounded by gunfire in the city since 2018, but the chance of anyone being charged with the shooting is about 6%. Last year alone, there were 2,300 nonfatal shootings and police made arrests in just 141 of them, my colleagues Andy Grimm and Tom Schuba report for the Sun-Times.
Law enforcement has also expressed deep frustration with the process. “Even if you wanted to run down every case like [it was] a murder, there’s just no time to do it,” one retired detective said. “And you’re not going to get approved for any overtime unless it’s a case that’s been in the news.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
Cynthia Green lost two sons to gun violence. A third was left paralyzed. She thinks she knows when detectives are doing their jobs. “I do think it makes a difference who you are or who they think you are and if they think it is worth it,” she says. “And that’s not how it should be.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
2.
Immigration agents arrested a U.S. citizen and created warrants after an arrest, lawyers say in court
 
Chicago attorneys with the National Immigrant Justice Center and the ACLU of Illinois have accused the federal government of violating immigration law and the constitutional rights of at least 22 people who were arrested and detained in the Midwest as part of President Donald Trump’s crackdown on immigration. Two people are still in custody, 19 were released on bond and one has already been deported, the lawyers said.
Attorneys are asking for the immediate release of people still detained, bond reimbursements, weekly reports on immigration arrests, and additional training and discipline of federal agents involved in the arrests, my colleague Adriana Cardona-Maguigad writes at the Sun-Times.
These actions may violate the Nava Settlement, a 2018 class-action lawsuit filed in response to unlawful arrests by ICE agents who used traffic stops and other tactics to make arrests without a warrant. Under the agreement, ICE officials can conduct a warrantless arrest if they believe an individual is likely to escape, but they must provide evidence.
“No one disputes that ICE has authority to do immigration enforcement in the U.S., in Chicago, anywhere in the U.S.,” said Mark Fleming of the National Immigrant Justice Center’s federal litigation project. “But they only have authority to do it under the laws that Congress have passed or are part of the legal limitations of the U.S. Constitution.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
MEMBERS FUND WBEZ CHICAGO
Experience some of Chicago's best dining!
Want to go on a tasting adventure of Chicago’s culinary gems across Hyde Park, The Loop, Lincoln Park, Logan Square and Pilsen? When you 
support WBEZ
, you can win a $500 dining package to 
Virtue
, 
The Berghoff
, 
Medi
, 
Lardon
, and 
HaiSous
! Donate TONIGHT by 7 p.m. for your chance to 
experience our city’s rich culinary scene while supporting independent journalism
.
3.
Trump takes aim at Chicago again — this time with a federal task force on antisemitism
 
A new Federal Task Force to Combat Antisemitism, led by U.S. Attorney General Pam Bondi, notified Mayor Brandon Johnson and his counterparts in New York, Boston and Los Angeles yesterday that it wanted to meet soon to discuss their responses to incidents of antisemitism over the last two years, my colleagues Fran Spielman and Tina Sfondeles report. A representative for Gov. J.B. Pritzker called out a pattern of obsession with Illinois in general and Chicago in particular by the Trump administration.
“If the Department of Justice was actually interested in combating antisemitism, they would expand their scope beyond just a politicized effort in a few select blue cities and states,” spokesman Alex Gough said. “Protesting, even if it’s something you disagree with, is a critical part of the protections under the First Amendment and in no instance should we allow the federal government to infringe upon that right.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
More than 50 universities are currently under federal investigation for alleged racial discrimination, including against white and Asian students, as part of the Trump administration’s campaign against diversity, equity and inclusion efforts. [
AP
]
4.
Some CTA buses to start giving out tickets for blocking bike and bus lanes
 
Transit and biking advocates had long spoken out in favor of designated lanes to share city streets with cars, while decrying drivers’ intrusions in those lanes. This summer, the Chicago Transit Authority plans to deploy ticket-writing cameras on some of its buses as part of the city’s bike and bus lane enforcement pilot, writes my Sun-Times colleague David Struett.
The CTA board this week approved a $315,852 contract with Hayden AI for the cameras and technology. The city’s Transportation Department has said the cameras will be fixed to buses using Dearborn, Madison and Washington streets and Chicago Avenue. Cameras added to six CTA buses will begin issuing warnings and tickets in July or August, according to a CTA spokesperson. The exact date will be determined after a 60-day testing period begins in May or June.
The potential violations include $90 fines for parking in a bus lane, $250 fines for bike path obstructions, $50 tickets for parking in expired meters outside of the central business district and $140 tickets for personal vehicles parked in commercial loading zones. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
Chicago pubs prep for St. Patrick’s Day ‘splitting the G’ TikTok trend
 
Guinness, the centuries-old malted barley stout synonymous with Irish pub culture, may not have the edge of other viral beverages, but this St. Patrick’s Day is the beer’s time to shine on social media. Drinkers dedicated to “splitting the G” film themselves attempting to swig enough on their first chug to line up the foam with the middle of the “G” on a Guinness-branded glass, writes my colleague Katie Anthony at the Sun-Times.
Chris Wise, 27, has made it his mission to “split the G” at every bar in Chicago — and has chronicled his attempts on TikTok. “What works for me, when it works, is three big gulps,” he said. “You gotta go in the mindset of, ‘I’m gonna get it.”
In Avondale, at a pub which boasts a “Best Pint in America” award, Chief O’Neill’s bar manager Anluan McKinney said they expect to go through 50 or more kegs of Guinness on parade day alone. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer drew fire from fellow Democrats after supporting a Republican budget plan that averts a partial government shutdown. [
ABC News
]
Hamas indicated willingness to release five American hostages after 524 days, including 21-year-old New Jersey native Edan Alexander and four who have been killed in Gaza. [
Times of Israel
]
When the Chicago River is dyed green tomorrow to celebrate St. Patrick’s Day, scientists will be ready to study how it affects wildlife in and near the water. [
Chicago Tribune
]
The beavers spotted along the Chicago River finally have names, after a round of voting: mom Ida Beav Wells and kits Chewy Garcia and Plumpton Sinclair. [
Block Club Chicago
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
Organizers have revived a citywide celebration of composer J.S. Bach, starting with a daylong festival and a Union Station pop-up.
The first Bach in the City concert, “Bach and the Venetians,” happens March 21 at St. Vincent de Paul in Lincoln Park. The organizers hope that event — and an earlier performance that day at Union Station for commuters — will spur Bach events that dot Chicago’s music scene throughout the year and the city.
“I’m 72, and I am on fire for this as much as I was when I was 21,” said organist and conductor Richard Webster, the music director of 98% of Bach Weeks, the previous incarnation of the fest which ran for five decades. “I need this musical outlet. I don’t want to shrivel up. I love what I do, and I still have a passion and energy for it.” [
WBEZ
]
 
Tell me something good
 
Chicago expects temperatures exceeding 70 degrees by the end of the week. How are you planning to embrace milder climes and more hours of daylight?
Ann writes:
“My garden is enjoying the warmth. Snowdrops have quickly popped up and bloomed, both in the garden and in the lawn. The small early crocuses are up and forming buds. I’m looking forward to glory of the snow, scillas, and early daffodils.”
Sandra writes:
“How will I embrace the spring thaw? Finally getting out of hibernation mode; going for walks by the lake and taking my new electric bike out for some joy rides!” 
Thanks for reading — have a wonderful weekend! I'll see you on Monday. Until then!
— Esther Bergdahl
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting. 
DONATE TODAY

 |

subject: Re: March Madness Pool
body:
I am going to work very hard to keep this at the top of everyone's inbox. I apologize in advance for the amount of emails I plan on sending out.  We are wrapping up the fundraising so we need one final big push. We have until Monday night to fill this sheet out.  I started by purchasing 3 myself.  97 more.  The brackets are fun but the odds of winning anything at all are relatively low.  With the squares, your odds of winning are significantly higher and much more realistic than football squares.  3 days, please pass along to friends or family that would like to join in supporting the baseball program.
Thank you
Mike
On Mar 14, 2025, at 12:07 AM, Michael Rog <rogs1@mac.com> wrote:
Good Evening Everyone,
Just want to say thank you again for the great support shown during the fundraising and the First Pitch Event.  We are now reaching the end of the fundraising season as we enter the baseball season.  As you are likely aware, there are other groups at DePaul doing March Madness brackets. I know it puts more pressure on families to financially engage and we try to avoid it.  Regardless, we're gonna open our final fundraiser and try something a little different.  Rather than doing the traditional bracket, we are going to do squares. This is very simple, buy your squares and win based on the final score of each game.  Remember, there are 67 games when including the play in games.  That means you literally have 67 chances to win.  With each game fetching a $100 prize, you could win up to $6700.  Let's make this the biggest fundraising event yet.  Send it out to friends and families.  Let's make sure we sell this one out  We're going $100 per square.  Payment cam be made with Zelle to 
rogs1@mac.com
.
Let me know if you have any questions.
Mike

subject: Re: DCP JV Baseball Parent/Guardian Emails (Corrected)
body:
Hello all,
I hope you're all doing well and ready for Spring Break! I'm reaching out to let you know that I have just confirmed our practice times and location for next week's practices on Thursday and Friday. We will practice on both days from 9-11am in the DCP football stadium. Also, on Saturday for our Double Header against Taft at Laramie Park at 10:00am/12:00pm, we are asking the players to meet us at the field, as we will not have a bus to take us there. 
Best,
Coach Hinkamp
On Thu, Mar 13, 2025 at 7:03 AM Zachary Hinkamp <
zhinkamp@depaulprep.org
> wrote:
Hello all,
It was very nice meeting many of you last night! As promised, here is the updated email chain (hoping I've got it correct this time!). As a reminder, I will share the practice schedule for the rest of the week, as well as the week of Spring Break:
Thursday 3/13: No Practice (hoping the boys go to the basketball game)
Friday 3/14: Practice 5:30pm - 7:00pm @ Clark Park
Saturday 3/15: Practice 8:00am - 10:00am @ Kerry Wood Field
SPRING BREAK
Monday 3/17: No Practice
Tuesday 3/18: No Practice
Wednesday 3/19: No Practice
Thursday 3/20: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Friday 3/21: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Saturday 3/22: Games 10:00am / 12:00pm (Double Header) vs Taft @ Laramie Park (Skokie)
I will be sending another email today or tomorrow (whenever I'm able to get this information confirmed) regarding the practice times and locations for Thursday and Friday of Spring Break. 
Again, thank you all for everything you've done/will do for the boys and team this year! 
GO RAMS!
Coach Hinkamp
-- 
Zachary Hinkamp (He/Him), LPC

subject: ⏰Our "Let's Talk Throwing" Workshop Starts Soon!
body:
View in browser
 
SHOP SWAG
ONLINE PROGRAMS
CAMPS & EVENTS
DON'T MISS OUR EXCLUSIVE
"LET'S TALK THROWING" VIRTUAL WORKSHOP
REGISTER NOW!
 
Ever feel like runners are stealing at will, ANTHONY?
I've got the perfect solution to shut down the running game, and it won't break the bank.
Just $20.
That's all it takes to transform your throwing game in our 
"Let's Talk Throwing: Drop Your Pop" Virtual Workshop
 next week.
🔥 What You'll Learn:
Lightning-quick release techniques to cut your pop time
Step-by-step footwork options for clean throws every time
Proper mechanics to boost accuracy and velocity
The exact muscles used in throwing and how to strengthen them
The aggressive mindset that elite throwing catchers possess
Perfect for catchers who want to:
✅ Start with the fundamentals of throwing
✅ Decrease their release time significantly
✅ Improve velocity and accuracy on throws
✅ Become a game-changing defensive force
THE DETAILS 
March 19th & 20th (Wednesday & Thursday)
10:00am -11:30am PST each day
I'm going to break down and demonstrate EASY-to-follow processes to help you throw runners out more consistently.
This is the same system that's helped hundreds of catchers at all levels dramatically improve their caught stealing percentage.
Although throwing isn't the most important responsibility we have as catchers, being a good throwing catcher can be a game changer & give you the edge against your competitors that sets you apart from the rest.
DON'T MISS OUT!
⬇️⬇️⬇️
GRAB YOUR SPOT HERE
 
▶️ The 2-day clinic will take place via Zoom and an email will be sent with the recording for you to be able to view it for 24 hours after the live.
🎯 If you can't make it live, don't worry... there's an option to grab access to the replay videos available when you grab your ticket.
‼️If you are in the 
Catch with Confidence Academy
 DO NOT 
sign up for this workshop. All members get access to all the workshops for free! Reply to this email if you need the code to grab your spot for free.
See you there!
Todd Coburn
The Catching Guy
thecatchingguy.com
 
Gamer Baseball LLC, PO Box 18083, Reno, NV 89511, United States
Unsubscribe

Bill Himmelstein Honored by Chicago Titan100!
Bill Himmelstein, Founder & CEO of the Tenant Advisory Group, takes a moment to extend his humble gratitude to the Chicago Titan100 organization for recognizing him as a 2025 Chicago Titan. This honor has led to many new connections, perspectives, and community opportunities that he's excited to continue to foster and explore.
Watch Video Here
 
Entrepreneur Spotlight
Amy Ratnow
ALR Connections - staffingwomen.com
ALR Connections brings authenticity and passion to helping women find jobs where their skills can shine. They assist individuals in pivoting, reinventing, and re-establishing themselves in the current workplace by building personal relationships, highlighting transferable skills, and developing a community of professional support.
ALR Connections' mission is to create meaningful work-life balance for everyone. They are committed to finding the perfect match for both candidates and clients, ensuring that every placement aligns with personal and professional goals. Join them in reshaping the future of work with personalized staffing solutions that make a difference.
Featured Nonprofit
Bobby E. Wright Comprehensive Behavioral Health Center
The Bobby E. Wright Comprehensive Behavioral Health Center (BEWCBHC) is a non-profit organization dedicated to providing quality mental health care, addiction treatment, and developmental disability services for over 51 years. Located on Chicago's Westside, BEWCBHC serves the communities of Garfield Park, Austin, North Lawndale, and surrounding areas. The center offers a holistic, evidence-based approach to behavioral health, focusing on positive mental health in the home, workplace, and community. 
BEWCBHC provides a wide range of services, including residential programs, supported employment, developmental training, crisis care, substance use treatment, and psychiatric services. The center's mission is to improve the quality of life for Chicago's Westside residents by delivering culturally sensitive, high-quality services to children, adolescents, and adults. BEWCBHC remains committed to Dr. Bobby E. Wright's philosophy of commitment, accountability, and excellence in service to the community
Featured Resume
Becky Getz
Becky Getz is a customer-first, enterprise-wide leader and growth driver with proven agility across a breadth of functions and industries. She has an unwavering commitment to crafting exceptional and valuable customer experiences cross-functionally and in complex organizations. Becky's track record is characterized by driving growth, building organizations (ranging from $30M to $30B in revenue), driving global reach and impact, and leveraging technology to achieve customer-centric results. 
Becky has served as a Fortune 2 executive, with diverse functional experience across marketing/brand (including data and insights), customer experience, digital transformation and operations with p&l leadership. She has board experience spanning PE- backed/private, non-profit and industry associations. And she has global industry breadth across technology, financial services, travel, health care, retail, and marketing/brand/design agencies. She is currently looking for her next leadership/CEO role. 
Resume
 
Featured Property
2nd Floor Virtual Tour
 
5th Floor Virtual Tour
 
Office Space Available
 
Retail Space Available
 
Custom 
Office 
Designs
If you’ve been paying attention, you already know that there is plenty of office space available right now and that the leverage is high on the side of the tenant to lock in a good deal with great concessions.
You also already know that operating a fully remote place of business is leading to less productivity and a waning or nonexistent company culture.
The main question I am hearing these days is:
How do we intentionally design our space to make our people want to come back into the office and be together again?
Fortunately, we have recently partnered with a design firm focused on commute-worthy workplaces created to encourage your team members to get back to the office. We would love the chance to sit down together to discuss a process that can help you navigate the ideal design for your individual business
Please respond if you are interested in setting up some time to chat about designing a space that will motivate your team to want to come back.
TAG Broker Challenge
TAG asks you to participate in the Broker Challenge
Read Our Reviews!
 
What are your current broker’s clients saying about
 them
?
Odds are, if they are like almost every broker in Chicago, absolutely nothing! I’ve always found it amazing how every broker says they are the best yet if you actually look into what their clients are saying, it’s eerily silent.
The top three largest cre firms have a combined total of 0 client testimonials on their website and 0 reviews on Google.
Many other cre firms don’t have any while a few have 3-5. While TAG is exponentially smaller than the 3 biggest firms and has been around a fraction of the combined time as these firms, Tenant Advisory Group has over 
120+ client testimonials
 on our website!
That’s over 
1,800% more
 rave reviews representing nearly 1/3 of the clients we have worked with! We also have 
100 all five-star reviews on Google
.
My broker challenge is if you are working with or have worked with a broker other than TAG in the past, look them up on the company’s website and see how many client testimonials they have.
If TAG doesn’t have 
1,000%
 more, we will send you a bottle of the best BBQ sauce in America!
According to our clients, TAG is the best cre firm in Chicago. Nearly 1/3 of our clients think so highly of the work we do for them that they express it in the form of a testimonial. You can see those client testimonials attached or on our website by clicking

. We’d like the opportunity to prove to you we are the best brokers.
Please reach out to schedule a call to learn more about why we have so many exceptional client reviews and why TAG will get you a better deal than any other broker.

Finding your perfect office space has never been easier. Click below to start personally curating your property listings to find the space that fits your office needs.
PROPERTY LISTINGS
 
TAG is Hiring Commercial
Real Estate Brokers!
Tenant Advisory Group is hiring experienced commercial real estate brokers to service clients brought in by a proven rainmaker. We handle the relationship/sales side and need brokers who can be given clients and know how to close.
The ideal candidate has the following qualifications:
Five to ten years of brokerage experience (more is a plus!)
Knows the Chicagoland commercial real estate market well (suburbs and/or city)
Knows Office and Industrial property types well
Knows at least one of the following: leasing brokerage, tenant representation,
buyer's brokerage, investment sales brokerage.
If you know of anyone, we are always happy to talk to great people!
Need 
An Expert?
At Tenant Advisory Group, we are more than just commercial brokers, we are business advisors that quarterback the entire real estate process. In addition to bringing, you our intimate knowledge of negotiations and the real estate process, we have also worked tirelessly to find the top performers in every sector of the commercial real estate space. Tenant Advisory Group has spent years vetting quite literally thousands of professionals in the above service professions and our partners have proven themselves to be valuable resources to our clients. Let's Connect!

body:

Friday, March 14

TOP NEWS
 
Ranking the top 10 pitching staffs in baseball
 
The way pitchers are utilized has changed, so instead of looking at starters and relievers separately, let's look at the entire assembly of arms a given team has and project how equipped that club is to thrive this season.
 
Dodgers' star Japanese trio ready for Tokyo Series spotlight
Cubs' trip to Tokyo for clash with Dodgers already a memorable experience
Boston's Big 3 prospects go yard in Spring Breakout
Spring Breakout continues with 6 games today

MORE TOP NEWS

PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!

STAFF PICKS
 
Who is the best defender in baseball? Let's ask the players
 
The two infielders – who happened to be traded for one another in a blockbuster deal ahead of the 2021 season – sit tied atop our latest poll thanks to their slick gloves.
 
Which teams have changed the most heading into ’25?
 
So many teams have made moves toward contending in 2025. But which clubs have done the most? We look at 10 teams with contending hopes who experienced plenty of roster turnover this offseason.

Six MLB.com beat reporters look at a Rule 5 pick on their teams who have a chance to make an impact this season.
 
Globe-trotting sports fanatics make Tokyo their next stop
 
David Carter and George Ross have been best friends since middle school, and they've made it their mission to see the world through famous sporting events before they turn 75.
 
Live Spring Breakout Games

The Dodgers get ready for the Tokyo Series with an exhibition game against the Yomiuri Giants, live Saturday at 6 a.m. ET on MLB Network.

subject: We see you, we thank you ❤️
body:
More intel on recruiting, retaining, and elevating neurodivergent professionals
Hi Monica,
Thank you for downloading our guide, Supporting Neurodiversity in the workplace. Whether you’re neurodivergent yourself or hoping to empower teammates at work, we genuinely hope you found it helpful.
 
Given that at least 
15-20% of the global population is considered neurodivergent
 
(with other estimates putting that figure as high as 30%), leaders must take on an all-embracing philosophy that celebrates and honors people as individuals.
 
And that begets the question:
 
 
What else can I do to boost my inclusion efforts and continue leveraging the talents of neurodivergent employees?
 
 
 
I’m glad you asked 😀 We’ve created a comprehensive guide on recruiting, retaining, and elevating neurodivergent talent, complete with 21 action items you can apply to support neurodivergent professionals at your company. And we want to share it with you today:
 
Download Guide
 
 
We’re here to support you in your journey to build a more inclusive workplace. Just reply to this email if you’d like more resources or info, including a 
chat with our team
.
 
Best,
 
Sienna Brown
VP of Growth

subject: March Madness Pool
body:
Good Evening Everyone,
Just want to say thank you again for the great support shown during the fundraising and the First Pitch Event.  We are now reaching the end of the fundraising season as we enter the baseball season.  As you are likely aware, there are other groups at DePaul doing March Madness brackets. I know it puts more pressure on families to financially engage and we try to avoid it.  Regardless, we're gonna open our final fundraiser and try something a little different.  Rather than doing the traditional bracket, we are going to do squares. This is very simple, buy your squares and win based on the final score of each game.  Remember, there are 67 games when including the play in games.  That means you literally have 67 chances to win.  With each game fetching a $100 prize, you could win up to $6700.  Let's make this the biggest fundraising event yet.  Send it out to friends and families.  Let's make sure we sell this one out  We're going $100 per square.  Payment cam be made with Zelle to 
rogs1@mac.com
.
Let me know if you have any questions.
Mike

subject: WATCH NOW: Build confidence in how your brand transcends language and cultural barriers.
body:
Improve your brand's communication strategy with tips from these experts. 
View this email in your browser.
 
Business happens in languages we don't know and cultures we don't understand. We need the confidence that we are getting more than just the words right – we want to be relevant, connect more deeply, and make every interaction count. 
 
Kristian Alomá from Threadline Research joined our own Carlos Hevia to discuss the intricacies at play when working across the globe. 
 
Watch our webinar replay to hear powerful stories and expert tips to:
- avoid alienating your audience
- focus multilingual projects on meaning over words
- keep the human at the center of every engagement
Watch the Webinar
 
This webinar is your opportunity to improve brand communication strategy to make meaningful connections. 
 
Questions? Just 
reach out!
