subject: Trump slashes local environmental programs
body:
Plus, the colorful cast of a fossil-hunting community. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Thursday - March 13, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Esther Bergdahl
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! Although I'm not a queen, I want to wish everyone a 
happy Purim
, which starts tonight. As for the rest of the news, here’s what you need to know today. 
  
RELAX & RECHARGE: 
Your support of WBEZ could win you a luxury spa day. 
DONATE
1.
Trump slashes environmental programs in Chicago that protect poor communities
 
Environmental justice, 
born in Chicago
 decades ago, recognizes how poorer communities often experience more air, water and ground pollution than more affluent areas. Environmental justice programs at the Environmental Protection Agency have since zeroed in on drinking water protections, as well as hazardous waste and other problems.
However, President Donald Trump this week ordered closures of EPA offices that help low-income communities overwhelmed with pollution, writes my colleague Brett Chase at the Sun-Times. It’s unclear how many positions will be cut in Chicago, but union officials estimate it may affect 20 to 30 of the roughly 1,000 EPA regional employees.
The order was one of dozens aimed at rescinding health and environmental protections. Related actions this week included a rollback of air pollution safeguards for coal-fired power plants, a planned review of fine-particle pollution rules begun under former President Joe Biden and elimination of requirements aimed at curbing global warming. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
Yesterday, EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin announced plans to target more than two dozen rules and policies in what the agency called the “most consequential day of deregulation in U.S. history.” Zeldin lauded his agency’s upcoming moves as a “dagger straight into the heart of the climate change religion.” [
NPR
]
2.
Illinois eyes taxing drivers by the mile — rather than by the gallon of gas
 
Illinoisans pay the second-highest motor fuel tax in the country after California. That tax helps pay for road, bridge and public transit improvements throughout the state. These days, reports my Sun-Times colleague George Wiebe, vehicles require less gas — or no gas at all — so funding for infrastructure has taken a hit.
“If you were to say to someone with an electric vehicle, ‘Do you think you should pay to maintain the roads and bridges that you’re driving on?’ I think most people would say yes,” said Marc Poulos, executive director of Operating Engineers Local 150, which strongly supports the proposed legislation.
With a mileage-based system, drivers could expect to pay three to four cents per mile. That would come on top of any tolls already being paid, similar to the gas tax. Oregon and Utah have already implemented similar programs, and five states including Pennsylvania and California have begun pilot or exploratory efforts, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM GRIFFIN MUSEUM OF SCIENCE AND INDUSTRY
The Black Creativity Juried Art Exhibition
For 50 years, the Griffin Museum of Science and Industry has hosted the nation's premier exhibition of African American art. The Black Creativity Juried Art Exhibition features over 100 works from professional and emerging Black artists from across the U.S., highlighting African American achievement in art, science, and technology. Now open through April 27. For more details, visit 
MSIChicago.org.
3.
Northwestern faculty and students say efforts to appease Trump chill free speech
 
Concerned students and faculty say they understand the threats the Trump administration is putting on the Evanston school, but they tell my colleague Lisa Kurian Philip that a new anti-bias training includes commentary characterizing criticism of Israel as antisemitic.
In one of the most contentious parts of the video, which students are required to watch, the presenter suggests comments made by critics of Israel are as problematic as those made by David Duke, the infamous leader of the Ku Klux Klan.
Northwestern is the target of multiple federal investigations. Federal officials say the university has failed to protect Jewish students. The stakes were magnified late last week when the White House announced $400 million in cuts to Columbia University over similar allegations. University spokesperson Jon Yates said the new antisemitism training video was meant to help the campus community understand how it feels for Jewish students to hear certain words and experience certain actions.
“I look at these trainings not as an end point, but I hope that they'll be a starting point to enabling … a more broad and a more thoughtful conversation about these issues in all quarters of the university,” said Michael Simon, who directs the Jewish campus organization Hillel. [
WBEZ
]
4.
South Side pastor takes action on ‘egg crisis’ by giving away 40,000 eggs
 
As 
egg prices soar
 due to bird flu, many Chicagoans have had trouble finding eggs at grocery stores or are not able to afford eggs at current prices — which are nearly 60% more expensive than last year. The U.S. Department of Agriculture expects egg prices to rise 41% this year over last year’s average of $3.17 per dozen.
The Rev. Charlie Dates, head pastor at Progressive Baptist Church in Bridgeport and Salem Baptist Church in Pullman, organized both churches to buy eggs from wholesale distributor Sysco. On Saturday, volunteers will distribute eggs at locations across the South Side between noon and 2 p.m. Each person who shows up will receive a carton of eggs, and Dates said he hopes to have enough eggs to pass out to nearly 3,000 families.
“We have a unique opportunity to do what the church has always done, and that is to care for marginalized people,” he told my Sun-Times colleague Cindy Hernandez. “So, we’re not going to wait for [President Trump] to fix it.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
Inside the fossil hunt: Digging for the monsters of Illinois’ Mazon Creek
 
Field Museum “super volunteer” Jack Wittry has done as much as anyone to link the Field’s distinguished scientists with a colorful group of characters: earnest fossil nerds, buyers and sellers, suspicious hoarders, wealthy dilettantes and scrappy collectors who test the outer bounds of legality.
WBEZ contributor Zachary Nauth introduces us to some of them, searching for the love of the chase, for science, for money and for reasons unknown. Their work has made the Field’s collection of 123 plant species and 330 animal species from Mazon Creek, about 80 miles southwest of Chicago, world-famous.
Wittry’s biggest score for the Field was the largest collection of high-quality Mazon Creek fossils in the world, held by Thomas Testa, who lived in nearby Carbon Hill. It had been appraised at close to $100,000, Wittry said, but the Field could never persuade a conspiratorial Testa to donate his haul.
Then, out of the blue in 2015, Wittry got a text message: “You’ve got 24 hours to come get them.” [
WBEZ
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
A mechanical titanium heart kept one Australian man alive for more than 100 days while he waited on a transplant, a breakthrough stopgap against donor shortages. [
CNN
]
Thanks primarily to immigration, the Chicago-Naperville-Elgin metropolitan area grew by nearly 71,000 people last year. [
Chicago Tribune
]
The oldest face in Western Europe belongs to a human ancestor found in Spain, where it lived more than 1 million years ago. [
The Guardian
]
The Oasis reunion tour, scheduled to launch this summer, will be turned into a film by the creator of 
Peaky Blinders
. [
Variety
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
For a certain kind of kid, memorizing as many decimal points of the mathematical constant pi is a titanic feat. However soon you trail off after 3.14, as my Sun-Times colleague Rafaela Jinich reminds us, the world’s favorite irrational number has inspired celebrations since Pi Day became a thing in 1988.
The first celebration took place in San Francisco at 1:59 p.m., featuring fruit pies and a tea urn set up by physicist Larry Shaw and his wife. Over the years, the event grew to include a “Pi Shrine,” a circular parade and a ritual of walking around the shrine 3.14 times while singing “Happy Birthday” to Albert Einstein — whose birthday also falls on March 14. Even the U.S. House of Representatives got in on the action, formally recognizing Pi Day in 2009.
Whether you’re in it for the math or just the munchies, some of Chicago’s restaurants and bakeries will serve up π-inspired deals on Friday, March 14. But since Pi Day is essentially the Super Bowl for pie businesses, some skip the discounts and instead roll out more flavors, knowing demand will be high. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
 
Tell me something good
 
Chicago expects to see temperatures approaching 70 degrees by the end of the week. How are you planning to embrace milder climes and more hours of daylight?
Paula writes:
"Play pickleball outdoors!"
Feel free to email me, and your response may be included in the newsletter this week.
Thanks for reading — have a great evening! I'll see you tomorrow.
— Esther Bergdahl

subject: March Newsletter
body:
You don't want to miss this.
 
 
Greetings. As I have recently returned from a month teaching in our MBA program in Bahrain, I had some time for reflection while I was between class sessions. This trip was a tremendous experience for me as I was pushed outside my comfort zone traveling to the Persian Gulf for the first time. Once there, I realized how friendly everyone was and it was so great to discover our similarities and respect our differences. One common theme was our discussion about discovering what you are passionate about in your career and in starting a business. Almost every entrepreneur we profile from Branson to Oprah to Jobs talk about how important passion is to being successful in business and in life! When you spend time doing what you love, what you’re uniquely gifted to do, all sense of time disappears. The old saying is to find a job you love and you will never work another day in your life. Now I realize that many of our graduating seniors have to “pay their dues” for a while to cover their expenses and get started in their career. We all had jobs that we did not really like, but the key is to keep an eye on what you are really passionate about. It is about finding your WHY in your career. Simon Sinek has a great Ted Talk on the Power of Why that defines us. The caution is that when you find a job you are good at, you might get comfortable and keep doing it to pay the bills, but it does not really fulfill your passion. People hesitate pursuing their true passion because it represents change, what am I giving up. Fear of the unknown, sadness of letting go and change can be scary. Is it better to just stay comfortable and be miserable? One thing to think about is if you only had 5 years to live, what really matters and how could you move toward your true passion. We wish you all a great journey to find your true passion!
CEC Executive Director
Bruce Leech
 
 
News Stories & Highlights 
 
 
EFBC Webinar With George Karavattuveetil 
On February 11th, students had the opportunity to engage in an exclusive discussion on career ownership and personal growth, hosted by the Entrepreneur & Family Business Council and the Coleman Entrepreneurship Center. This event featured George Karavattuveetil, President and Founder of Psyched, who shared invaluable insights on how to take control of what is yours.
Throughout the discussion, George guided attendees through key strategies to help them identify their goals, build self-discipline, cultivate confidence, and effectively communicate their needs. He emphasized the importance of leveraging personal strengths and taking intentional steps toward career success.
Students left the event feeling empowered and equipped with practical tools to seize new opportunities and navigate their professional journeys with confidence. This discussion served as a reminder that success starts with self-awareness, discipline, and the courage to take action.
A huge thank you to EFBC, and George Karavattuveetil for making this event possible! Stay tuned for the EFBC: Women Trailblazers Webinar on March 20th!
 
Womens Month Spotlight - Mariel Mudrik 
At the Coleman Entrepreneurship Center, we love seeing student entrepreneurs thrive, and Mariel Mudrik, co-founder of DePhi Media, is no exception. As a frequent user of CEC resources, Mariel has embraced every opportunity to grow her business while balancing the challenges of being a student entrepreneur.
DePhi Media, a video production company that “dares to be different,” specializes in infusing projects with experimental storytelling and editing techniques, breaking away from the industry norm. 
Mariel and her team started DePhi after recognizing
 how difficult it was for businesses to market their products effectively. By helping business owners feel seen, DePhi creates content that leaves a tangible impact. “The most rewarding part is reading reviews and seeing real change in the businesses we work with,” Mariel shares. However, time management has been one of the biggest challenges, juggling work, business operations, class, homework, and other commitments. Luckily, having a strong co-founder has helped her balance the workload.
Mariel recently competed in the Big East Pitch Competition, an experience that reinforced a key lesson: "Entrepreneurship is a hard journey, but you don’t have to do it alone." The competition exposed her to a larger network of people willing to help, emphasizing the importance of seeking out resources and connections. At the CEC, she’s taken full advantage of networking events, and workshops, which helped her build DePhi’s identity and visibility. “The Coleman Center provides opportunities for everyone, you get as much out of it as you put in,” she says.
As DePhi grows, Mariel envisions future collaborations with Chicago-based artists and brands, such as working with local musicians on visually compelling music videos or partnering with Chicago-based businesses and creative studios for commercial projects. She’s also focused on expanding DePhi’s social media presence and eventually building out a studio.
﻿
To connect with Mariel and learn more about DePhi, visit 
dephimedia.com
, 
reach out via 
LinkedIn
, or email her at 
mariel@dephimedia.com
.
 
 
 
Meet Mia Thomas, Our New Student Assistant!
We’re thrilled to welcome Mia Thomas to the Coleman Entrepreneurship Center as our newest student assistant! With her enthusiasm, creativity, and passion for community building, we know she’ll make a great impact on the center. We’re excited to see how she contributes to our programs, connects with students, and brings fresh ideas to the team. Get to know Mia in her own words: 
"Hi! I’m Mia Thomas and I am happy to announce that I am joining the CEC as a student assistant! I can’t wait to work with the team, help the center, and learn more entrepreneurship. I am currently a sophomore studying Management and am interested in exploring minors in Non-Profit Management, Event Planning, and Entrepreneurship. I grew up in Des Plaines, IL and have always loved all things Chicago, so DePaul was such an easy choice. I’m excited to meet everyone who stops by the center and would love to talk about all things Cubs, movies/TV shows, and any crafting hobbies (especially sewing and embroidery). Hopefully, see you soon!"
 
 
Social Impact Incubator Has Kicked Off! 
We’re excited to welcome the newest Startup Innovation Incubator (SII) cohort as they begin their entrepreneurial journey. Through mentorship, resources, and hands-on experiences, these students will develop their ventures and gain valuable insights along the way. We look forward to seeing their progress and sharing updates on their journey in the coming months. Stay tuned for more.
 
Upcoming Events, Deadlines, & Media
 
 
EFBC X CEC Woman Trailblazers Webinar
March 20th | 5:00 - 7:00 PM
Join us for an exclusive discussion in partnership with the Entrepreneur & Family Business Council, where Kelly Deady, Tina Meckaroski, and Laura Gale talk to us about their personal experiences and professional careers. This event aims to inspire by drawing out the panelists’ unique experiences, lessons learned, and practical advice. 
RSVP
 
 
 
Startup 101
April 17th | 4:30 - 6:00 PM
Join Bruce Leech, Executive Director of the CEC, as he shares key insights on launching and growing a business. Learn best practices, real-world strategies, and how the CEC can support your startup journey!
RSVP
 
 
 
Purpose Pitch 
May 22th | 5:00 - 7:30 PM
Join us at the Student Innovation Expo to support DePaul student entrepreneurs as they pitch their business ideas! This interactive competition lets attendees give feedback and ask questions while students compete for scholarships.
RSVP
 
 
 
﻿
New Podcast Episode: Gretchen Shuler
Look out for the latest episode of The Windy Napkin featuring Gretchen Shuler, a DePaul student entrepreneur and founder of ReBrewed! Learn how her sustainable coffee company is making a social impact and connecting the community through business.
Coming Soon
 
 
 
New Blog Post: 
Why Start-up Experience Matters for Today’s Students
 
In our latest blog post, we explore Dr. James Bort’s research on how start-up employees shape entrepreneurial opportunities. Through the Coleman Entrepreneurship Center’s internship program, students gain hands-on experience, taking on impactful roles that go beyond traditional internships. Tune in to see how our interns are driving real change and shaping their careers in the start-up world.

subject: [Global Leadership Associates] Self-Advocacy at Work: How to Play Big
body:
I've seen so many people break free from this, and I want to spill the tea on how they did it.
 
View this email in your browser
 
 
Hello friends,
In a world often dominated by challenging headlines, I'm thrilled to share some uplifting news that has rekindled my spirit!
My dear friend Zunaira Munir, the brilliant Executive Director of Blue Ocean Student Entrepreneurs Corporation, invited me to judge the 2025 Blue Ocean Student Entrepreneurs Competition. This extraordinary event stands as the world's largest virtual entrepreneurship competition for high school students globally.
The competition is powered by Blue Ocean Student Entrepreneurs Corp, a non-profit organization that was founded by a visionary high school student. Their mission is to prepare and empower high school students for the exciting world of entrepreneurship.
The young participants showcase their innovative ideas through 5-minute video pitches—and the numbers from 2025 are absolutely staggering: 12,784 students from 163 countries and territories participated, representing over 6,000 schools and 48 US states. 
 
I must confess, when I volunteered as a judge, I wasn't quite prepared for what awaited me. These video pitches completely blew me away! The students demonstrated remarkable creativity, exceptional articulation, and impressive resourcefulness. They tackled real-world challenges across diverse fields—healthcare, travel, environmental issues, education, sustainability, and so much more.
This volunteer experience has infused me with renewed energy and boundless hope for our future. The wisdom and innovation of these young minds prove that we adults have so much to learn from the next generation of leaders!
Together, they're creating a better world—one brilliant idea at a time!
✨ Isn't that something worth celebrating? ✨
Warmly, 
Maya 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Self-Advocacy at work: How to Play Big
 
So, I've been thinking about something that came up in a lot of my coaching sessions lately, and I just had to share it with you. You know that awful feeling when you're stuck in your career? Like, you're watching everyone else zoom past while you're just... there? 
Watch the Video Here
 
The Basic Human Need Some Companies Fail to Meet
Mutual respect can help you build an engaged, committed workforce. Here are four ways to build it.
By Maya Hu-Chan
 
One of my clients, let’s call her “Sarah,” recently walked away from the best job she’s ever had.
Sarah was a senior manager for a global company. She had been with the company for six years. She moved across the country for the opportunity and, for five years, loved the job. Her boss gave her complete autonomy, checking in regularly but trusting her to run the show. She did the same with her team. She was one of the highest-performing executives in the company, and her team was one of the most high-performing, too.
Everything changed when the company reorganized and moved her boss to a different department. Sarah’s new boss was an external hire with a background in a completely different field. He micromanaged Sarah, not trusting her decades of experience. He often went over her head to deliver directives directly to her team and would often change many of her decisions without her knowledge. If she objected, he would assert his authority by responding with, 
“I’m your superior.”
 At one point, Sarah developed a new digital marketing initiative, and her boss presented it to the CEO, taking all the credit. 
Read the Entire Article Here
 
Featured Articles
 
The Hidden Workplace Dynamic That Is Killing Your Company’s Inclusion
 
If your team has insiders and outsiders, you aren’t cultivating a truly inclusive environment.
Read More...
 
Alibaba’s Success Started With Just 1 Sentence
 
To have an innovative mindset, you must think globally — but that means more than you might think.
Read More...
Book Maya
 
Saving Face: How to Preserve Dignity ﻿
and Build Trust
 
'Saving face' is a universal concept that enables one to connect with people, break down barriers, and build trust & long-term relationships.
Organizations now need to attract, retain, and motivate teams and employees across distance, time zones, and cultural differences. Building authentic and lasting human relations may be the most important calling for leaders in this century.
This book illustrates how we can honor face to create positive first impressions, avoid causing others to lose face, and, most importantly, help others save face to build trust and lasting relationships inside and outside the workplace.
 
Available on Amazon!

mayahuchan@thegloballead.com

Maya is an internationally recognized keynote speaker, Best Selling author, and Master Certified Executive Coach. She specializes in global leadership, cross-cultural management, diversity, equity, and inclusion. Ranked Top Leadership Coaches of 2021 & 2022, Top 8 Global Solutions Thinkers by Thinkers50, World Top 30 Leadership Gurus, and Top 100 Thought Leaders in Management & Leadership, Maya has worked with Global Fortune 500 companies, non-profits, and public sectors worldwide.  
Maya is the founder and president of Global Leadership Associates, a global consultancy that partners with organizations to build leadership capabilities and enable profound growth and change. Her latest book “Saving Face: How to Preserve Dignity and Build Trust” is Amazon's #1 best seller (Berrett-Koehler 2020). subject: In Case You Missed It #56: The rise in remote work and its impact on productivity and more
body:
ICYMI 
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
Greetings Monica,
To help you filter the signal from the noise, I curated the most valuable articles I came across recently in case you missed them.
“
The rise in remote work since the pandemic and its impact on productivity
” (BLS.gov)
Summary
The COVID-19 pandemic sparked a dramatic increase in remote work, with many industries adopting work-from-home arrangements. By 2021, remote work participation had surged, especially in professional, scientific, and technical services, as well as information and finance industries. The rise in remote work contributed positively to Total Factor Productivity (TFP) growth across 61 private-sector industries, particularly through reduced nonlabor costs, such as office space expenses.
From 2019 to 2022, the increase in remote work was linked to a 1.1 percentage-point rise in industry-level productivity, with companies benefiting from lower turnover and operational efficiencies. However, productivity gains were not passed to employees through higher compensation. Instead, workers reaped indirect benefits, such as reduced commuting time and expenses. Despite these advantages, industries varied in their ability to balance output and labor input. For most high-productivity sectors, output growth outpaced labor input increases, indicating efficient use of remote work.
Dr. Gleb’s Take
This study confirms that remote work isn’t just a convenience—it’s a powerful driver of productivity and cost-efficiency. Businesses that adapt to remote or hybrid models are gaining a competitive edge, leveraging reduced office space and operational costs while enhancing employee retention.
However, the failure to share these productivity gains with employees reflects shortsighted leadership. Workers saved time and money on commuting, but organizations missed an opportunity to strengthen loyalty by sharing financial benefits to support workers being more productive and comfortable in their home offices. I always advise my clients to invest into employee home offices, such as good tech, ergonomic furniture, and fast internet, which is a win-win for employees and companies alike. 
The data is clear: remote work is not a temporary pandemic solution but a sustainable model for the future of work. Leaders who embrace and optimize this shift will outperform competitors who cling to outdated, office-centric paradigms.
“
Baby boomers say they don’t need to retire now that they can work from home—and they’ve got side hustles on top of their 9-to-5’s
” (Fortune)
Summary
Remote and hybrid work have reshaped retirement plans for baby boomers, allowing them to extend their careers while enjoying better work-life balance. A survey by Smart Energy GB found that nearly 70% of those over 60 are working in hybrid roles, while others work remotely full-time. Without the stress of commuting, many baby boomers are energized to take on side hustles, with tutoring being the most popular choice.
The flexibility of remote work has enabled 25% of surveyed boomers to explore new hobbies they had planned for retirement, such as gardening, yoga, and walking. This dual approach to career and leisure has left 66% feeling less stressed, 94% reporting a renewed zest for life, and 90% expressing satisfaction with their careers.
Globally, the trend of “unretiring” is growing. In the U.K., 14% of baby boomers and late Gen Xers have returned to work, with an additional 4% considering it. In the U.S., the share of workers aged 65 and older has nearly doubled since the 1980s, with 20% of that age group now employed. Many older workers cite financial concerns as a key reason for staying in or returning to the workforce.
Dr. Gleb’s Take
This is a striking testament to the transformative power of remote work. Baby boomers have cracked the code to achieving both financial security and personal fulfillment in their later years. By eliminating the daily grind of commuting, remote work has given them the flexibility to maintain their income while pursuing hobbies and even side gigs.
Employers should take note: offering hybrid or fully remote roles is not just a perk—it’s a retention strategy for experienced, highly skilled workers. Boomers bring decades of expertise, and their willingness to stay in the workforce longer is a massive asset to businesses willing to adapt to their needs.
The "unretiring" trend also highlights a cultural shift. Work is no longer seen as a binary choice between career and retirement. Instead, flexible models enable older workers to blend income, passion projects, and personal growth. Companies that fail to embrace this model risk losing out on a wealth of institutional knowledge and leadership from seasoned a multigenerational workforce. 
"
Matt Yglesias Considered As The Nietzschean Superman
" (Astral Codex Ten)
Summary
This piece explores Nietzsche's concepts of "master morality" and "slave morality," contrasting their historical roots and societal impacts. Master morality celebrates strength, achievement, and individual excellence, while slave morality emphasizes humility, equality, and harm reduction. The article critiques both frameworks, noting that slave morality often manifests as an obsession with diminishing oneself or others to avoid judgment, while master morality can devolve into arrogance and disregard for communal well-being.
Through diverse examples—from Puritans and Soviet propaganda to Ayn Rand and modern liberalism—the essay navigates attempts to reconcile these moralities. Figures like Ayn Rand and Richard Hanania represent different approaches to integrating Nietzschean ideas into modern frameworks. The author concludes by endorsing a "spiral of values," where altruism and ambition coexist in a dynamic balance to glorify civilization and improve human happiness.
Dr. Gleb’s Take
This essay is a masterful exploration of moral frameworks, and gets at a key point: the dichotomy of master and slave morality is too simplistic for the complexity of modern life. Both approaches contain dangerous extremes—unchecked master morality fosters exploitation and harm, while uncritical slave morality stifles innovation and achievement.
The path forward isn’t in choosing one over the other or crafting tenuous compromises like “liberal democracy.” It’s in embracing 
adaptive morality
: a system where individuals and societies balance personal excellence with collective good. This means rewarding ambition when it uplifts others and challenging humility when it becomes performative or self-defeating.
Nietzsche’s Superman isn’t a literal figure—it’s a call to evolve past outdated binaries. We need a vision that values strength as a tool for service and humility as a path to growth. That’s how you build a world where ambition thrives without crushing the vulnerable.
What did you think of my take on these articles? Look forward to hearing from you, simply reply to this email with your thoughts.
Decisively yours,
Dr. Gleb
Dr. Gleb Tsipursky
CEO of Disaster Avoidance Experts
Let's Connect!

Intentional Insights
, an educational 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, and its

subject: Success in Federal Contracts for Women-Owned Businesses: 8(a) & GSA Schedule Benefits
body:
Success in Federal Contracts for Women-Owned Businesses: 8(a) & GSA Schedule Benefits               
Success in Federal Contracts for Women-Owned Businesses: 8(a) & GSA Schedule Benefits
 
Success in Federal Contracts for Women-Owned Businesses:
﻿
8(a) & GSA Schedule Benefits
 
Learn More
 
Women-Owned small businesses (WOSBs) continue to make significant strides in the business world, with over 12 million WOSBs operating in the United States. Despite this growth, these businesses still encounter challenges in accessing government contracting opportunities. Fortunately, two key programs can help level the playing field: the 8(a) Business Development Program and the GSA Schedule.
The 8(a) Certification: Expanding Opportunities for Women-Owned Businesses
The 8(a) program provides a crucial pathway for socially and economically disadvantaged businesses, including women-owned businesses, to secure federal contracts. While many assume this program is limited to minority-owned businesses, the reality is that Caucasian women-owned businesses can also qualify if they meet the eligibility requirements.
Eligibility Criteria for 8(a) Certification:
*Must be a small business
*Must not have previously participated in the 8(a) program
*Must be at least 51% owned and controlled by U.S. citizens who are socially and economically disadvantaged
*Must meet specific financial criteria:
Personal net worth of $850 thousand or less
Adjusted gross income of $400 thousand or less
Total assets valued at $6.5 million or less
*Must demonstrate good character and have been in business for at least two years
*Must submit a social disadvantage narrative that provides documented evidence of discrimination or bias that has impacted business growth
Many Caucasian women-owned businesses mistakenly believe they are ineligible, but the SBA's 'preponderance of evidence' standard has made it easier for qualified applicants to gain certification. If you meet these criteria, the 8(a) program can provide invaluable access to government contracting opportunities.
The GSA Schedule: A Key Advantage for WOSBs
The GSA Schedule is another powerful tool for WOSBs seeking to expand their footprint in the federal marketplace. By obtaining a GSA Schedule Contract, women-owned businesses gain direct access to government buyers and streamlined contracting opportunities.
GSA has been instrumental in supporting WOSBs, working to remove barriers and promote greater access to federal procurement opportunities. The federal government has long set a goal of awarding at least 5% of federal contracting dollars to WOSBs, particularly in industries where they are underrepresented.
Why the GSA Schedule is Beneficial for WOSBs:
Provides a streamlined process for federal contracting
Enhances credibility and visibility with government buyers
Helps businesses compete more effectively for federal contracts
Offers long-term revenue potential through repeat business with government agencies
For the 14th consecutive year, GSA has earned an 'A+' rating from the SBA on its Small Business Procurement Scorecard, demonstrating its commitment to fostering the growth of small and disadvantaged businesses.
How 8(a) Certification and GSA Schedules Work Together
Women-owned businesses that obtain both 8(a) certification and a GSA Schedule gain a significant competitive advantage. The 8(a) certification allows businesses to pursue set-aside contracts, while the GSA Schedule makes the procurement process more efficient, increasing accessibility to federal agencies.
Take the Next Step Toward Federal Contracting Success
If you're a woman-owned business looking to maximize your federal contracting potential, now is the time to act!
Explore your eligibility for 8(a) certification and leverage the benefits it offers.
Get a GSA Schedule Contract to streamline your access to federal buyers.
Partner with experts who can guide you through the certification and procurement process.
Don't miss out on these valuable opportunities. Contact us today to learn how we can help you navigate the federal marketplace and secure the resources needed to grow your business
Emily Hatchel
859-360-0909
www.advancegsa.com
Advance GSA
10500 Norbotten Dr
Florence Kentucky 41042
United States

It was very nice meeting many of you last night! As promised, here is the updated email chain (hoping I've got it correct this time!). As a reminder, I will share the practice schedule for the rest of the week, as well as the week of Spring Break:
Thursday 3/13: No Practice (hoping the boys go to the basketball game)
Friday 3/14: Practice 5:30pm - 7:00pm @ Clark Park
Saturday 3/15: Practice 8:00am - 10:00am @ Kerry Wood Field
SPRING BREAK
Monday 3/17: No Practice
Tuesday 3/18: No Practice
Wednesday 3/19: No Practice
Thursday 3/20: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Friday 3/21: Practice (Time/Location TBD - will communicate when confirmed)
Saturday 3/22: Games 10:00am / 12:00pm (Double Header) vs Taft @ Laramie Park (Skokie)
I will be sending another email today or tomorrow (whenever I'm able to get this information confirmed) regarding the practice times and locations for Thursday and Friday of Spring Break. 
Again, thank you all for everything you've done/will do for the boys and team this year!

Terms and Conditions

 Apply
1.
 
You can earn 110,000 bonus miles after you make  $12,000 or more (the "Threshold Amount") in eligible purchases on your Delta SkyMiles
® 
Reserve Business American Express Card within your first 6 months of Card Membership starting from the date that your account is opened. Miles will be credited to your account 8-12 weeks after you reach the Threshold Amount. Bonus Miles may appear on your account in more than one deposit. To receive the 110,000 bonus miles, your Card account must not be canceled or past due at the time of fulfillment. Eligible purchases can be made by the Basic Card Member and any Additional Card Members on a single Card account. Eligible purchases are purchases for goods and services minus returns and other credits. Eligible purchases to meet the spend requirement do NOT include fees or interest charges, cash advances, purchases of traveler's checks, purchases or reloading of prepaid cards, purchases of gift cards, person-to-person payments, or purchases of any cash equivalents. Additional Card Members on your account are not eligible for their own offer. In rare instances, your period to spend $12,000 may be shorter than 6 months if there is a delay in receiving your Card. Also, purchases may fall outside of the 6 month period in some cases, such as a delay in merchants submitting transactions to us or if the purchase date differs from the date you made the transaction. (For example, if you buy goods online, the purchase date may be the date the goods are shipped). This offer is not transferable. If your application is not received by 04/02/2025, we will not process your application even if we later receive your application. American Express reserves the right to modify or revoke offer at any time.  ​
If you have a history of cancelling or downgrading American Express Card accounts within your first year and you cancel or downgrade your new Card account within your first year, we may not credit, we may freeze, or we may take away the bonus miles from your account. If we determine that you have engaged in abuse, misuse, or gaming in connection with this offer in any way or that you intend to do so, including if you return purchases you made to meet the Threshold Amount, we may not credit, we may freeze, or we may take away the bonus miles from your account. We may also cancel any accounts you have with us.​
2.
 
Employee Card
In order to use the Employee Card to make purchases, you or your employee will need to provide the employee’s Residential Address, Social Security Number, and Date of Birth when confirming the Employee Card. If this information is not provided within 60 days of Card issuance, your Employee Card will be canceled.
3.
 
Miles on Eligible Purchases
1x Mile on eligible purchases:
 Basic Card Members will earn 1 mile for each dollar of eligible purchases charged on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account.
1.5x Miles on U.S. Shipping:
 Basic Card Members will earn 0.5 additional miles (for a total of 1.5 miles) for each dollar of eligible purchases on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account charged at merchants in the U.S. for shipping services. To earn additional miles for shipping, eligible purchases must be made at courier, postal, and freight shippers located in the U.S. Basic Card Members will not earn additional miles for shipping costs added to retail purchases or moving services.
 
1.5x Miles on Transit:
 Basic Card Members will earn 0.5 additional miles (for a total of 1.5 miles) for each dollar of eligible transit purchases on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account. Eligible transit purchases include purchases with train, taxicab, ride share service, ferry, toll, parking, bus, and subway merchants. Purchases of airfare, car rental and cruises are not considered eligible transit purchases.
 
1.5x Miles at U.S. Office Supply Stores:
 Basic Card Members will earn 0.5 additional miles (for a total of 1.5 miles) for each dollar of eligible purchases on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account at office supply stores located in the U.S. Office supply stores are in the business of selling a range of office supplies, including items like: paper, notebooks, office equipment, and office furniture. Office supplies purchased at other retail stores will not earn additional miles.
 
1.5x Miles on purchases after spending $150,000:
 If in any calendar year eligible purchases made on the Delta SkyMiles
® 
Reserve Business Card total more than $150,000, Basic Card Members will earn 0.5 additional miles (for a total of 1.5 miles) on eligible purchases on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account made after the $150,000 threshold is reached through the end of the same calendar year. Only one accelerator will apply even if a purchase qualifies for multiple mileage categories. If an eligible purchase qualifies for a category that has a higher mileage accelerator, only the higher accelerator will apply instead of the one-half mile per dollar. For example, if you make a Delta purchase after reaching the $150,000 threshold, the Basic Card Member will earn two additional miles per dollar instead of an additional one-half mile per dollar for that Delta purchase. The close of the calendar year is December 31st without regard to the time of the year that the account is opened. This means that for the first year of Card Membership, the Card Account’s time period to reach the $150,000 threshold may be less than twelve months.
3x Miles on Delta Purchases:
 Basic Card Members will earn 2 additional miles (for a total of 3 miles) on each dollar of eligible purchases on their Card or any Additional Cards on the Card Account charged directly with Delta where Delta is the merchant of record, such as purchases via 
delta.com
, the Fly Delta app, phone reservations, or ticket counters, for upgrades, miles, seat selection, Delta Sky Club
® 
membership, and in-flight purchases of food and beverages on Delta-operated flights (“Delta Purchases”). Delta Purchases do not include in-flight purchases where Delta is not the merchant of record, such as in-flight wireless internet access and charitable contributions. Delta Purchases do not include Delta Gift Cards and purchases made at 
deltashop.com
 and/or the Delta Flight Museum. Delta Purchases include Delta Vacations
® 
packages but not other all-inclusive packages. Delta Purchases include new Delta Stays prepaid hotel or vacation rental bookings on the Delta Stays platform (
delta.com/stays
). Delta Purchases include purchases of qualifying Delta, Delta Connection
®
 carrier and Delta Shuttle
® 
flights taken with the purchase of a fare that is eligible for SkyMiles mileage credit. For purposes of this Card benefit, “Delta Purchases” also includes Delta Basic Economy fares, notwithstanding that these fares do not earn SkyMiles mileage credit for travel. Full SkyMiles program terms: 
delta.com/memberguide 
. Additional miles earned for Delta flight purchases made with the Card will be based on the total ticket price, including base fare, carrier-imposed surcharges and government-imposed taxes and fees.
Eligible purchases are purchases for goods and services minus returns and other credits. Eligible purchases do NOT include fees or interest charges, cash advances, purchases of travelers checks, purchases of gift cards, person-to-person transactions, purchases or reloading of prepaid cards, or purchases of other cash equivalents. Miles will be posted to the Basic Card Member’s Delta SkyMiles account 8 to 12 weeks after the end of each month. To be eligible to receive miles, the Card Account must not be canceled or past due at the time of fulfillment.
Merchants are assigned codes based on what they primarily sell. We group certain merchant codes into categories that are eligible for additional miles. A purchase with a merchant will not receive additional miles if the merchant’s code is not included in a reward category. Basic Card Members may not receive additional miles if we receive inaccurate information or are otherwise unable to identify the purchase as eligible for a reward category. For example, Basic Card Members may not receive additional miles when: a merchant uses a third-party to sell their products or services; or a merchant uses a third-party to process or submit the transaction to us (e.g., using mobile or wireless card readers); or Card Members choose to make a purchase using a third-party payment account or make a purchase using a mobile or digital wallet.
For questions about additional miles on a purchase, call the number on the back of your Card. Please visit 
americanexpress.com/rewards-info
 for more information about rewards.
General: 
All SkyMiles program rules apply. To review the rules, please visit 
Membership Guide & Program Rules 
. Prices and rules are subject to change without notice. Delta, SkyMiles, and the Delta logo are registered service marks of Delta Air Lines, Inc. Delta is not responsible for goods or services offered by any companies participating in miles promotions. Partner offers subject to the terms and conditions of each individual offer. See individual offers for details. Partners subject to change. Offers void where prohibited by law. Other restrictions may apply.

Letter from the Principal
 
Dear Northside Catholic Academy Families,
I hope you are enjoying the sunshine and taste of spring as we move further into March. Our students are certainly enjoying the weather!  I want to take a moment to share a brief snapshot of some recent happenings around our campus:
Minds that think…
We jumped into Trimester 3 this week with some great projects all around the school across grades. At the middle school, the 7th graders are prepping for their Mock Trials next week and the 6th graders are planning their Medieval Feast while the 8th graders created Spanish books with their 2nd grade buddies. 7th and 8th graders are hard at work on their science fair projects and our 8th graders are also working diligently each day on their production of a “Midsummer Night’s Dream,” memorizing lines, blocking scenes, and creating the set design. Our 4th graders are researching historical figures to bring to life at our annual Wax Museum. Mark your calendars for the 8th grade play on April 2 and the  Science Fair, Art Fair and Wax Museum on April 24!
Hearts that love…and hands that serve
Soirée Success – Thank You!
What an incredible evening we had at this year’s Soirée! It was a fantastic celebration of our community, all while raising essential funds for tuition assistance. The NCA community at large showered their love and offered their service to make this event happen. A huge thank you to everyone who attended, participated in our raffle, and placed bids in our online auction. Most of all, thank you to our Soiree committee who took on a monumental task of planning this event,  and to all the volunteers who helped the evening run smoothly. We are still finalizing the numbers and will share the impact of your generosity soon!
Love and prayers for our Eighth Graders
This Friday is a nerve- wracking day for many of our eighth graders as they receive their selective enrollment and choice high school admissions decisions. Additionally, next Tuesday, many of them will be Confirmed in the Catholic Church. They have a lot on their plates on top of their intense academics. Let’s keep these Wildcats in our prayers as they take these next steps in their journeys!
Thank you for your continued support and partnership in making NCA a place of faith, learning, and service.
Terese

subject: The fallout from Department of Ed cuts
body:
Plus, Steppenwolf’s lineup for its 50th anniversary season. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
Wednesday - March 12, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Esther Bergdahl
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! No matter what your area code, Chicago has something fun for you to do on 
312 Day
. As for the rest of the news, here’s what you need to know today.
  
SUPPORT THE RUNDOWN TODAY: 
You could win a 6-night stay in Ireland! 
DONATE
1.
How chaos at the Education Department impacts Illinois schools
 
The federal Department of Education announced last night more than 1,300 layoffs as part of a plan to reduce staffing by 50% through layoffs, buyouts and terminations.
The $79 billion agency, which employed 4,100 people when President Donald Trump was inaugurated, oversees federal financial aid for college students and offers oversight of special education services and civil rights laws that could be at risk.
The Trump administration’s proposal to dismantle the Education Department would play out differently locally and statewide. If, for instance, federal education funding is reduced — by Congress or by other means — Illinois and Chicago schools wouldn’t lose the majority of their education revenue, but they would be hurt. Most school funding in Illinois comes from local property taxes and the state. This school year, federal funding makes up about 16% of the $8.4 billion Chicago Public Schools operating budget.
However, federal funding also concerns higher education, in itself a major economic driver in communities nationwide, my colleagues Nader Issa and Lisa Kurian Philip report.
“It’s going to potentially put an end to my research career, and we won’t be able to develop these new therapies for diabetic wounds,” said one UIC professor of newly decimated federal research grants. “It’s the worst situation that I’ve encountered in my 25-year career.” [
WBEZ
]
2.
Federal officials drop a plan to expand a lakeside dump on the Southeast Side
 
The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is responsible for making sure the bottom of the Calumet River — a major waterway for commercial shipping in and out of Chicago — is deep enough to allow boats to easily navigate the water.
The dredged sediment from the bottom, contaminated by pollution, has been stored for decades just north of Calumet Park along Lake Michigan, my colleague Brett Chase reports for the Sun-Times. After sustained community opposition and a lawsuit, the Army Corps has set aside longstanding plans to expand an underwater landfill known as a “confined disposal facility” in favor of a “sustainable and feasible alternative.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
Meanwhile, the Chicago Tribune reports Chicago still ranks in the top 10 most polluted major cities in the U.S., even as we dropped from 2nd place to 7th in 2024. [
Chicago Tribune
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM COLUMBIA COLLEGE CHICAGO
Columbia College Chicago Celebrates 135 Years
As Columbia marks its 135th year, it celebrates a legacy rich in creativity, innovation, and resilience and its enduring commitment to shaping the arts, media, technology, and business. As we honor our past, we look forward to continuing our tradition of nurturing creative minds and shaping what’s next in the years to come. Learn more at 
colum.edu.
3.
Final phase of Kennedy Expressway construction expected to begin next week
 
Outbound lanes will be reduced and reversible lanes become permanently outbound until the fall, writes my colleague Dave Struett at the Sun-Times. Drivers should expect “significant delays” when the work begins on Tuesday, weather permitting, the Illinois Department of Transportation said in a news release.
Closures will begin this week to set up the work zone. Drivers should expect overnight ramp and lane closures from Ohio Street and Montrose Avenue between 9 p.m. and 5 a.m.
Construction is expected to be completed “around Thanksgiving,” the Transportation Department said. Improvements to the reversible lanes were completed last year. The inbound Kennedy was revamped in 2023. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
4.
Chicago Ukrainians fear deportations as Trump considers revoking legal status
 
Like many of the 40,000-plus Ukrainians who have arrived in Chicago since Russia invaded their homeland, 37-year-old Inha Ruda and her family entered the U.S. on a temporary humanitarian parole status that President Donald Trump is considering revoking.
Others could lose their legal status even sooner — perhaps as early as May — if Trump shuts down temporary protections issued by former President Joe Biden that have allowed 240,000 Ukrainians fleeing the war to come to the U.S.
“It’s hard to imagine how we’ve started step by step, getting documents, finding jobs, everything new. We finally have safety, schools, everything good, and then somebody makes a decision that everything stops and now you have to go,” she said. “It’s difficult.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
Steppenwolf's ‘slate of rock stars’ on tap for theater company’s 50th anniversary season
 
The anniversary season includes the world premiere of 
Windfall
 (April 9–May 31, 2026), penned by ensemble member Tarell Alvin McCraney (an Academy Award winner for 
Moonlight
, the film adaptation of his play 
In Moonlight Black Boys Look Blue
).
Other highlights include works by heavyweights Suzan-Lori Parks, Mia Chung and ensemble member Rajiv Joseph. The season’s concluding flourish is Peter Shaffer’s 
Amadeus
 (Nov. 6, 2025–Jan. 4, 2026), the Tony and Academy Award–winning fictional account of the rivalry between composers Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and Antonio Salieri.
“Chicago has really been here for the repeated relationships with our ensemble members,” co-artistic director Audrey Francis told my colleague Mike Davis. “They have this investment in our artistic journey and our evolution, and they have let us grow as artists and change. Every time we get on stage, they give us the opportunity to reinvent not only who we are but what we’re capable of.” [
WBEZ
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
The European Union has joined Canada in imposing tariffs on American goods, including bourbon, beef, jeans and motorcycles. [
AP
]
When one Congressman misgendered a fellow committee member during a hearing yesterday, transgender Delaware Rep. Sarah McBride responded in kind, saying, “Thank you, Madam Chair.” [
Texas Tribune
]
Elections in Greenland reacted to Trump’s vocal designs on the Arctic nation, rocketing the independence-minded Demokraatit party into power. [
The Guardian
]
The Transportation Security Administration stopped a would-be passenger at Newark International Airport last week: a 5-inch red-eared slider turtle stashed inside a man’s pants. [
TSA
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
From the air above O’Hare International Airport, Resthaven Cemetery looks like an island in a sea of beige. The view is barely less odd from the ground: about an acre and a half of land, one side surrounded by a low chain-link fence, the other by shrubby trees that block the runway directly adjacent. Across from the cemetery is a soulless gray and white Fedex Shipping facility filled with docked semitrucks.
“It’s kind of unique, standing in the middle of O’Hare Field, listening to airplanes,” says Resthaven caretaker Mike Moruzzi. “It gives [the cemetery] some character. It’s an ambiance.”
In many ways, Resthaven is a microcosm of the village of Bensenville’s long history of being slowly eaten by development. It’s a tale of what is sacrificed in the name of progress and the tension between the rights of a suburb and the city. It also evokes a contentious piece of local history which dates back decades before the Civil War. [
WBEZ
]
 
Tell me something good
 
Chicago expects to see temperatures approaching 70 degrees by the end of the week. How are you planning to embrace milder climes and more hours of daylight?
Paul writes:
"Milder temperatures? I’ll actually go to work - wait for it - without a jacket!!!"
Feel free to email me, and your response may be included in the newsletter this week.
Thanks for reading — have a great evening! I'll see you tomorrow.
— Esther Bergdahl
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting. 
DONATE TODAY
©Chicago Public Media Inc 848 East Grand Ave, Navy Pier Chicago, IL 60611

subject: Meeting Tonight + Hats for Sale
body:
Hello everyone, 
Excited to see many of you tonight at the parent meeting. Reminder, 6p start for the athletic orientation by Coach Mahoney (AD), but if you already attended a sports meeting this year, you do not need to arrive until 6:30p when we begin the Baseball portion of the meeting. We will be in the west dining hall. 
Also, game hats will be available for sale at $35 a hat, cash only.
Thanks and see you tonight!
-- 
Sam Colon 
Assistant Athletic Director
Head Varsity Baseball Coach

 3333 N. Rockwell St. | Chicago, IL 60618

subject: How to Pivot Towards a New Reality
body:
Understand Which Skills You Will Need for the Future
 
Membership
CDP® and CDE®
AAL™ Program
Refresher Course
 
 
The Weather is Changing & the Business Climate is Quickly Evolving. It's Time to Pivot.
Fear is beginning to ripple across the U.S., and in other nations that have traditionally supported American businesses, citizens, and tourists. When people are fearful or worried, they change behaviors. Understand how these changes will affect your organization. For example:
More Federal government workers are applying for unemployment. Because States were unprepared for a massive influx in traffic, there could be delays in processing requests. This will drive up competition for jobs as well as cause financial hardships for new recruits. Is your system designed to handle increased activity? Will Algorithmic bias screen out applicants? How long is your recruitment cycle? Are unnecessary delays built into the process?
Since some nonprofits were impacted by budget changes in Washington, they may not have the capacity to serve as many people as they did previously. What are your requirements and expectations for corporate giving and reporting?
Impending social security cuts, as well as fluctuations in the stock market, will impact 401K/403B plans, as well as those who were planning to retire this year or are currently retired. Do you have a plan to engage older workers?
Some small businesses are no longer operating because they lost their federal government contracts, boycotts are in play, and tariffs are about to kick in. What is your plan for diversifying the supply chain?
Add in the potential for a measles outbreak, climate emergency, or other disasters, there is a possibility that work-from-home becomes a necessity again. Have your policies been updated since the COVID work-from-home experience?
Layoff's are hitting some industries worse than others. If you needed to pivot to another field, what are your transferrable skills?
Some people still believe that cuts to Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility justify any economic hardships, but the reality is that the world is a little more complex than the hate that one person has for another individual or group.
The reality is that today's professionals must be prepared for anything. Make sure you are in the right network, and you have up-to-date skills. 
Become a member of IDC for $174 using the Promo Code: SPRING25 at 
www.diversitycertification.org 
 
 
 
Register Today!
 
Diversity Training is Still Needed-- Join us!
Research has shown that Diversity Training allows organizations to proactively pivot, as well as avoid potential problems during times of transition. From harassment education to team building between the generations, utilize Diversity training to keep morale high, improve skills, and ensure compliance. 
Register now
 for the Mar. 26-27 Train-the-Trainer experience.
 
Diversity is the Future. Reskill wi
th CDP® or CDE® C
redentials Now
 
 
 
 
 
Acquire Skills for the Future. Enroll Now in:
 
 
 
 
 
www.diversitycertification.org

7230 Arbuckle Cmns
 Ste 134﻿ | 
Brownsburg, IN 46112 US

subject: Thank you for attending Beyond The DEI Headlines: Actionable Insights
body:
Thank you for attending Beyond
 the DEI Headlines: Actionable Insights
. The feedback was overwhelmingly positive. Here's what one 
attendee
 had to say, "The event was powerful and insightful."
Click to hear Karen Brown's opening remarks and read key points below.
 
Impact of Executive Orders on DEI:
 The president’s executive orders and other actions are significantly affecting diversity, equity, inclusion (DEI), equal opportunity (EEO), and affirmative action (AA) work. efforts. These changes are reshaping the approach organizations take toward this work.
Mixed Responses from Executives:
 While many CEOs, board members, and DEI leaders remain committed, some are re-evaluating their efforts, with a significant number scaling back or canceling programs due to concerns over compliance, government actions, and legal risks.
Survey Findings:
 A recent
 survey
 of C-suite executives found that a growing number (53%) expect anti-DEI policies from the White House to lead them to roll back their DEI programs. Additionally, 55% are increasingly concerned about DEI-related lawsuits and government enforcement. Many executives, especially at federal contractors and public companies, are considering reducing or removing DEI-related language from public communications like websites and proxy statements due to mounting regulatory pressures.
 
Click to hear Paulette Brown's remarks and read key points below. 
Impact of Executive Orders:
 Paulette emphasizes the significant impact of recent executive orders on diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives, likening it to chaos and confusion. Despite some orders aiming to restrict this work, they have not overturned existing laws, such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964. She emphasized that diversity, equity, and inclusion are not illegal.
Legal Risks and Compliance:
 She stresses that diversity, equity, and inclusion work must not violate any existing laws, and although there is fear of potential legal repercussions, many lawsuits challenging these orders have been filed, some resulting in temporary injunctions. Organizations should consult legal counsel to understand their potential liabilities.
Business Decision:
 Paulette notes that organizations are taking preemptive measures out of fear, which may not be necessary. She argues that stepping away from DEI is not a good business decision, citing the example of 
Target's
 
decreased profits. These companies also risk alienating a broad base of customers and supporters.
Community and Collaboration:
 Paulette encourages building a community and fostering collaborations to navigate the challenges posed by executive orders. Nonprofit organizations are encouraged to seek out resources such as the 
Funders for Justice
, 
Democracy Forward
, and the 
National Council of Nonprofits
 to navigate challenges related to DEI programs and government funding.
The Importance of Courage and Collaboration:
 She advocates for maintaining courage in the face of fear and working together to continue this work. Building collaborative communities and ensuring internal alignment within organizations is key to successfully navigating current challenges and fulfilling legal obligations while promoting equity.
 
Click to hear Hugo Balta's remarks and read key points below. 
Historical Context:
 Hugo provides a historical context of diversity, equity, and inclusion work, emphasizing their development in response to address systemic inequalities in workplaces, education, and society. Their goals include promoting representation, dismantling barriers, fostering inclusive environments, and improving collaboration and innovation through diverse perspectives.
Misalignment:
 He notes that despite good intentions, many corporations struggle with effective implementation. He shares the misalignment between corporate values and actions, the issue of tokenism, the lack of accountability and clear metrics, and resistance from leadership or employees, which all hinder the success of DEI initiatives. 
Weaponization of DEI:
 Hugo explains how diversity, equity, and inclusion have been weaponized because they are incorrectly positioned as problems rather than opportunities. He offers that the current administration’s policies aimed at curtailing diversity training and promoting a merit-based approach are oversimplifying the issue and a misunderstanding of the need for equity. Hugo argues that merit-based hiring and diversity, equity, and inclusion can coexist. He highlights the legal challenges and public advocacy campaigns in response to the current administration's stance. 
The Importance of Framing DEI as Opportunity:
 He stresses that diversity, equity, and inclusion should be viewed as an opportunity to improve and create inclusive environments, not just a problem to solve. Mis-framing it as a problem leads to ineffective actions while recognizing it as an opportunity fosters more genuine and collaborative solutions. 
The Ongoing Fight for DEI:
 Hugo encourages individuals and organizations to continue pushing forward. It's crucial to stay courageous, foster alliances, and advocate for diversity, equity, and inclusion as foundational elements in creating systems that benefit everyone equitably.
 
Click to hear Peter Cunningham's remarks and read key points below. 
Peter states that with clients, he starts by focusing on values, then facts, followed by multi-dimensionality.
Shared Values:
 
He denotes the importance of starting diversity, equity, and inclusion conversations in the context of the company’s shared values. These could be profits, inclusion, safety from harassment, creative problem-solving, environmentalism, and inclusion.
Concrete Facts:
 He advocates for using concrete facts in diversity, equity, and inclusion discussions to avoid fruitless debates.
Multidimensional Approach:
 Peter highlights the multidimensional nature of diversity, equity, and inclusion, including veterans, race, gender, age, disabilities, and more. Successful diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives should aim to create a "bigger tent" that includes as many people as possible, ensuring broad engagement.
Case for DEI: 
He offers the importance of being clear about the case for diversity, equity, and inclusion, which could be linked to customer value, employee morale, creative problem-solving, or business competitiveness. 
Communication Strategy:
 Peter stresses the following important points when developing a communication strategy:
 
Framing diversity, equity, and inclusion discussions in a way that avoids extremism and judgment. 
Recognize the dynamic cultural environment and tailor your approach to different audiences. 
Frame the conversation to emphasize inclusion as a business and morale-boosting strategy rather than as a politically charged issue. 
Specifically
 for DEI, there’s a ripe opportunity for the DEI community to take ownership of the messaging on fairness and merit-based hiring because it cuts both ways.
It’s prudent to have a one-minute elevator speech. His example:
The 60-Second Case for DEI
 "Whether you work in business, government, the non-profit world or academia, your work is shaped by values—yours, your co-workers, your employers. Most of us want a safe workplace that is free of harassment. Most of us want a diverse workplace. Most of us want an efficient, effective workplace. And we all believe that we should hire the very best people possible to do the job. No one wants to work with low-performers. No one wants to hire them.
Acting on those values and goals, our organization is making sure that we are not – either intentionally or unintentionally – tilting the playing field in any one direction that could undermine us. Too many people of one gender or race or faith or viewpoint, or too few people with differing views and different skills, will undermine our larger goals, whether that be profits in the case of a private company, or impact in the case of a non-profit, or service in the case of a public agency. Diversity helps advance our values and goals. It challenges our thinking. Surveys show that diverse workplaces appeal to customers and the public, they boost morale, there is less turnover, and better bottom-line results. To paraphrase the Godfather Michael Corleone, “DEI isn’t just personal. It’s business.” 
Click to hear Jennifer Brown's closing remarks and read key points below. 
The Need for a 1.0 Conversation:
 
We've
 been having a 3.0 conversation and there's a call for a return to a foundational, less extreme conversation about diversity, equity, and inclusion. After the high-energy moments of the last few years, it's time to slow down, reassess, and revisit the basics to ensure that the conversation is digestible and effective for everyone involved.
Be Strategic and Cautious:
 As organizations navigate the evolving landscape, it’s essential to avoid drastic policy changes. While there may be pressure to adjust, dismantling or backtracking on progress could set the field back years. Leaders should be strategic and careful, staying informed about the law and the long-term implications of their decisions.
Prepare for the Future with a Broader Tent:
 The pendulum will swing again, and when it does, it’s important to be ready with a new, inclusive playbook. We need to be introspective, learn from past mistakes, and ensure that when future opportunities arise, we approach the conversation with a broader perspective, avoiding exclusionary messages, and fostering a more inclusive dialogue.
Have more questions about this topic or others? Contact us:
 
Karen Brown
, 
Bridge Arrow, LLC
Email:
 
Karen@bridgearrow.com
Book
: 
The Leaders You Need
Schedule a call:
 
Calendly
 
Hugo Balta
, 
The Fulcrum

hugo@thefulcrum.us

,

info@jenniferbrownspeaks.com

pbrown@mindsetpowerguru.com
Telephone: 854.900.4080

,

Sample attendee feedback
 
✔️“The guidance was powerful and inspiring.”
✔️“Thank you for this insightful hour.”
✔️“It was great because the topic was current, the speakers were practical, and the chat was vibrant.”
✔️“This call was great! Fantastic conversation!"
