subject: Common Mistakes People Make When Seeking 8(a) Certification
body:
Common Mistakes People Make When Seeking 8(a) Certification                                         
Common Mistakes People Make When Seeking 8(a) Certification
 
Common Mistakes People Make When Seeking 8(a) Certification
Learn More
 
Navigating the 8(a) certification process can be a complex journey for small business owners, and many fall into common pitfalls that can derail their applications. From misunderstanding revenue sources to mishandling personal and business finances, these mistakes can have significant consequences. In this guide, we highlight the ten most frequent errors encountered during the 8(a) certification process, providing clarity and insights to help you avoid these missteps and successfully position your business for growth and opportunity. Whether you’re just starting or seeking to enhance your application, understanding these key points will empower you to make informed decisions and increase your chances of success.
#1:
 Leaving their employer but still generating the majority of their revenue from that past employer. In reality, no more than 25% of your firm's revenue can come from your former employer.
#2:
 Filing a tax return that shows no profit. It's common for accountants to utilize accelerated depreciation, leading the business to appear as having a loss.
#3
: Relying on a single client for all your business. No more than 70% of your firm's revenue can come from one source.
#4:
 Transferring cash from the business to a personal checking account, which may lead to exceeding the net worth threshold.
#5:
 Establishing a new company to conduct business with the government. This creates issues with control and dedication; the government prefers your 8(a) firm to be your primary business.
#6:
 Overstating past legal troubles. Generally, if you have been off probation for five years, the SBA is unlikely to object to your application, provided the issues are fully disclosed.
#7:
 Assuming that statistical disparities (e.g., minorities or women making less than men) suffice for your social disadvantage narrative. The SBA is more interested in the specific social disadvantages you have experienced.
#8:
 Forming a joint venture prior to entering the 8(a) program. While small businesses are allowed to create joint ventures for small business work, doing so beforehand creates control issues. It's best to wait until after you've entered the 8(a) program to form a JV.
#9:
 Putting the company in the name of a spouse who is not the primary operator of the business. If the 51% owner of the firm is not fully devoted to the business, the application may be rejected. Once in the 8(a) program, government buyers will want to meet the firm's owner, which can hinder marketing efforts.
#10:
 Trying to conceal assets or failing to disclose an arrest to the SBA. They conduct credit checks and background investigations as part of the application process to uncover missing assets or integrity issues.
Successfully navigating the 8(a) certification process requires careful attention to detail and a thorough understanding of the potential pitfalls. By being aware of the common mistakes outlined above, you can better prepare your business for a successful application and maximize your opportunities for growth and government contracts.
If you find yourself overwhelmed or unsure about the next steps in your 8(a) journey, EZ8A is here to help. Our team of experts specializes in guiding small businesses through the certification process, providing tailored advice and support to ensure that you avoid these common missteps. Don’t leave your future to chance—reach out to us today to learn how we can assist you in achieving your 8(a) certification and unlock the doors to new opportunities!
Mark Ryan & Todd Luttenegger
859-442-3300
www.ez8a.com
ez8a
10500 Norbotten Dr
Florence Kentucky 41042
United States

subject: Ranking baseball's Top 10 lineups
body:
Plus: The 1 player Korean stars rely on
Tuesday, March 11
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS
 
Ranking the top 10 lineups heading into 2025
 
Last year, we ranked the Dodgers as having the top lineup -- and it worked out pretty well for them. With the Mets adding Juan Soto and the Braves getting back Ronald Acuña Jr., can either of them outrank the champs?
 
Cole to undergo season-ending Tommy John surgery
Tatis homers like he never has -- off Greene's 99.4 mph heat
What's next in the unique career of Jacob deGrom?
Imanaga makes final start before 'special' Tokyo Series
'Sky's the limit' for newly inked Butler. Is the same true of upstart A's?
Sale never shakes off his catcher, so a prospect better learn fast
'Everyone's littlest brother': Cheers to Jackson Chourio on his 21st birthday
Helsley developing cutter to add to an already impressive arsenal
Dodgers agree to extension with Dave Roberts (report)
MORE TOP NEWS
 
MLB MORNING LINEUP PODCAST
 
 
 
PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!
 
MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
Who has gift of gab? Players make their picks
 
With all the chatter around the batting cage, in the dugout and on the bases, many players have developed a feel for who's podcast-host material. So, we asked them which of their peers needs to host a podcast or talk show after his playing career ends.
 
Ohtani (and Decoy!) to be in Fortnite
 
Global sensations in the world of baseball and video games are about to collide when Shohei Ohtani comes to Fortnite’s Icon Series.
 
Snell on mentoring friends from Korea: 'I take a lot of pride in that'
 
Back in late 2020, Blake Snell joined a new squad -- as new Padres teammate Ha-Seong Kim adjusted to a new country. Snell and Kim became fast friends, and the two-time Cy winner has since helped two other Korean stars with their journeys.
 
Prospects with the best tools in Spring Breakout
 
Whether it's power at the plate, speed on the basepaths or a particular pitch type, if you want to know which prospects will bring the best tools to Spring Breakout later this week, MLB Pipeline has you covered.
 
A different farm system makes for family fun at Twins camp
 
In a break from the spring routine, Rocco Baldelli organized a petting zoo for his players and their families. It was an enjoyable day for all but especially the skipper himself, who is a huge fan of llamas.
 
Baltimorange is back and better than ever in O's land
 
The Orioles are turning the clock back to the 1970s, introducing an alternate all-orange uniform that hasn't been used regularly for over 50 years: "I think we'll look pretty sharp in them," said Jackson Holliday.
 
Jam-packed Tuesday on MLB Network
 
It’s the Mets vs. the Astros at 1 p.m. ET (available in Mets market) followed by Brewers vs. Cubs at 4 (available in Brewers market). Then, 30 Clubs in 15 Days presented by T-Mobile stops in Braves camp at 7 and Reds camp at 8.

subject: Chicago could play into papal politics
body:
Plus, another effort to put Harriet Tubman on the $20 bill. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
WBEZ is a community-supported, nonprofit newsroom.
 
 
Become a Member
Monday - March 10, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Esther Bergdahl
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon! While Bianca is out, I’ll be heading up your daily digest for the next few weeks. Feel free to drop a line with any thoughts about dogs or K-dramas. As for the rest of the news, here’s what you need to know today. 
  
1.
Influential bishops with Chicago ties will have a hand in picking the next pope
 
Catholics worldwide have been following Pope Francis’ health scare, which left him hospitalized with double pneumonia for weeks. The Vatican 
offered cautious optimism
 that the 88-year-old pontiff has recovered, but the institutions he leads are nonetheless preparing for what might come next, my colleague Lauren Fitzpatrick reports for the Sun-Times.
Among the men who will determine whether the Catholic church continues Francis’ pastoral service for all or swing back to a conservative interpretation are three influential bishops tied to Chicago: Cardinal Blase Cupich, the archbishop of Chicago, and Chicago-born Cardinals Robert Prevost and Wilton Gregory, who would be part of the papal conclave that elects a new pope.
Of the 137 cardinals eligible to vote for the next pope, 109 of them were appointed by Francis, who made a point to elevate bishops from underrepresented places and backgrounds. Despite the influence wielded by Chicagoans overall at the Vatican, the odds are long that one of them will succeed Francis on St. Peter’s throne.
“They’ve all given very good service to the church,” one local seminarian observed. “But I just think it would be very difficult to elect an American cardinal, especially at this time, with the church and with the fraught nature of the politics and of the person in our country who resides in the White House." [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
2.
New data breach exposes info for 700,000 CPS students
 
Cleo, a file transfer software vendor used by Chicago Public Schools, was the subject of a cyberattack late last year in which student data was accessed and published to the dark web, CPS said in a statement.
The data breach affected roughly 700,000 students dating back to the 2017–2018 school year, CPS said. Students’ names, dates of birth, genders and their CPS student ID numbers were accessed. Students enrolled in Medicaid also had their Medicaid ID number and dates of eligibility exposed.
Social Security numbers, financial data and health information were not exposed in the breach, the school district said.
“At this time, there is no evidence to suggest that any student data has been misused. No staff information was involved in this incident,” CPS said. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM MEDGLOBAL
Providing Lifesaving Healthcare
MedGlobal is a Chicago-based 
medical charity
 that supports the most vulnerable in disaster regions providing maternal healthcare and malnutrition programs in Gaza, Sudan and Syria. Your Zakat in the month of Ramadan will provide healing. 
Learn how you can help.
3.
As Medicaid cuts loom, patients and officials defend care for chronic pain, behavioral health and addiction
 
Idalys Montijo is one of the more than 770,000 Illinois residents — and 78 million Americans — who could lose their health care coverage if Congress passes $880 billion in Medicaid cuts. She has spent hours of her life doubled over with back pain so intense, it would make her vomit.
“I was able to survive because with my [current] insurance, I got covered,” she told my colleague Violet Miller at the Sun-Times. “I would choose to die before I went through that pain again.”
​​As part of a bid to avoid a government shutdown in two weeks — and after ruling out cuts to Medicare and Social Security — congressional Republicans have set their sights on a potential $880 billion in cuts from Medicaid over the next decade to help finance $4.5 trillion in tax cuts.
Current Illinois law would automatically end Affordable Care Act Medicaid expansions if federal funding is cut, significantly reducing who qualifies for the coverage. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
4.
‘Two pilots from Southwest saved the day,’ aviation expert says about last month’s close call at Midway
 
A couple of seconds and a pair of “well-trained” pilots likely made the difference in saving lives and preventing catastrophe during 
last month’s near-collision
 between a Southwest Airlines jet and a business aircraft at Midway Airport, an aviation expert recently told the Sun-Times.
Allied Pilots Association spokesperson Dennis Tajer’s initial reaction upon seeing video of the incident was “Wow, that was close.”
The Southwest 737 plane arriving Feb. 25 from Omaha, Nebraska, was in its final stage of descent about 8:50 a.m. and almost touched down on the runway when the pilot of a Flexjet business aircraft appeared to misunderstand an air traffic controller’s instructions and crossed onto the runway in the Southwest flight’s path. Fortunately, pilots train for uncertain scenarios like this.
“Are the winds a little bit squirrely? Is your left wing a little bit too low? Do you feel confident in being able to successfully execute that landing?” one aviation professor said. “If you’re ever in doubt, you can always initiate that go-around procedure and come back and try again.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
On Harriet Tubman Day, a new effort to place the abolitionist on the $20 bill launches
 
Today’s announcement is the latest push to honor Tubman on the currency, following a decade of previous attempts, including legislation that has stalled in Congress. The announcement coincides with Harriet Tubman Day, which honors the woman who led enslaved people to freedom on the Underground Railroad.
The "Harriet Tubman Tribute Act of 2025" calls for the Treasury secretary to include the abolitionist's face on all $20 bills printed after Dec. 31, 2030, according to a draft of the bill obtained by NPR. Andrew Jackson, the country's seventh president and a slaveholder, would be removed from the $20 bill.
The proposed legislation also stipulates that production of these bills cannot be delayed more than two years, unless it is determined that issuing the bills after the designated date "would create an unacceptable risk of counterfeiting or to the safe, secure, and speedy functioning of the United States economy.'' [
NPR
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
Banker-turned-politician Mark Carney will succeed Justin Trudeau as Canada’s next prime minister. [
NPR
]
U.S. immigration agents arrested a Columbia University protest organizer with permanent U.S. residency over the weekend, part of a crackdown against “Hamas supporters” on which President Donald Trump campaigned. [
Reuters
]
English Premier League soccer clubs, including Manchester United, West Ham United and Everton, will play a double-header at Soldier Field in July. [
Block Club Chicago
]
Tesla facilities across the U.S. are facing protests and vandalism in response to the political role owner Elon Musk has played in the Trump administration. [
BBC
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
A structure that used to house what is now the Wilson Red Line stop could soon be a grocery store owned and operated by customers.
Uptown Station is a stunning relic of the 1920s, when getting around the city and suburbs by train was the norm and the neighborhood was a stylish place to be. But the building didn’t look this good for its entire 102-year history. In fact, that arched top, the pediment, is a late 2010s recreation: There was an arch like this on the station when it opened in 1923, but it was chopped off in the 1950s.
In May 2018, CTA officials signed a lease with the Chicago Market, a grocery cooperative that, at the time, said it would take about 18 months to build out the space — meaning it would open sometime in 2020. Now, in 2025, Grant Kessler, the board’s president, told my colleagues at WBEZ’s Reset the establishment is “working hard to be open by the end of the year.” [
WBEZ
]
 
Tell me something good
 
Chicago can expect temperatures approaching 70 degrees by the end of the week. The nice weather has most of us champing at the bit for the grown-up equivalent of having class outside, even if it 
feels too early
 in the year. My hound and I will probably find a new-to-us dog park, and my colleagues are already trading gardening tips. How are you planning to embrace milder climes and more hours of daylight?
Feel free to email me, and your response may be included in the newsletter this week.
Thanks for reading and have a nice night! I'll see you tomorrow.
— Esther Bergdahl
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting.

subject: *Date Correction* - ADVOCACY ALERT:  Government Contract Terminations and Shutdown Risks
body:
Message Preheader Content 
Having trouble viewing this email?
View this email in a web browser
.
 
As government contractors, navigating contract terminations and the risks associated with a potential government shutdown requires preparation, strategic response, and a clear understanding of federal policies. Join us for this exclusive webinar, where we will examine:
  
Termination for Convenience
 – What it means for your contract, your rights, and how to mitigate financial and operational impact.
Pending Government Shutdown
 – Current policy updates, potential disruptions, and strategies for contractors to sustain operations.
Proactive Measures
 – How to prepare, respond, and protect your business from contract uncertainty.
Guest speaker Alphonso David, social and economic justice advocate and lawyer serves as President and CEO of the Global Black Economic Forum. He brings more than two decades of experience in the private, public and not-for-profit sectors working to advance the rights of marginalized communities through policy, legislation, litigation and advocacy.
  
This session will provide expert insights and guidance to ensure you are prepared to safeguard your business in the face of federal contract changes. Whether you are a prime contractor or a subcontractor, understanding these key issues is essential for business continuity and long-term success in government contracting.
  
We look forward to your participation in this important discussion.
  
We invite you to join us on 
Thursday, March 13, 2025, at 2:00 PM ET
 for this timely and critical conversation. Bring your questions and concerns—we’re here to help!
RSVP for the conversation.
 
Women Impacting Public Policy (WIPP)
1120 Connecticut Ave NW Suite 200
Washington, D.C. 20036

DIRECT OCEAN VIEW – PREMIUM BEACHFRONT CONDO AT THE STRAND RESORT!
Welcome to Unit 1053 at The Strand Resort, an exclusive oceanfront retreat offering unparalleled views of the Atlantic! This beautifully updated 1-bedroom, 1-bathroom condo is the perfect blend of luxury, comfort, and investment potential. From the moment you step inside, you'll be captivated by the breathtaking ocean views from both the living and sleeping areas, plus your private oceanfront balcony—perfect for soaking in the sights and sounds of the shoreline.
This fully furnished, turnkey condo has been thoughtfully upgraded with modern finishes throughout. The seller has removed the popcorn ceilings, repainted the entire unit, and replaced all outlets and switches for a fresh, polished look. The kitchen boasts granite countertops and tile flooring, while LVP flooring runs throughout the living spaces, offering both style and durability. The bathroom also features granite countertops, complementing the upscale aesthetic.
Located in one of Myrtle Beach’s most sought-after resorts, The Strand offers top-tier amenities, including:
✔ Oceanfront pool deck & hot tub
✔ Fitness center
✔ Beachfront lounging areas
✔ On-site restaurant & bar
With only 87 exclusive units, The Strand Resort offers a boutique-style experience with all the benefits of a high-end vacation destination. Nestled in the heart of Myrtle Beach, you're just minutes from Broadway at the Beach, the SkyWheel, the boardwalk, world-class golf courses, shopping, and dining—not to mention a short drive from Myrtle Beach Airport!
With competitive HOA fees, strong rental potential, and an unbeatable oceanfront location, Unit 1053 is a rare gem that won’t last long. Don’t miss this incredible opportunity to own a piece of paradise!

subject: Tax-Savvy Tips for Women Supporting Israel
body:
Do Good & Do Well
To view this email as a web page, go 
here.
 
Do Good & Do Well
donate
   
read
   
plant
   
travel
Doing Good While Doing Well:
JNF-USA Women for Israel
This month, for Women's Month
, we are focusing on how the women of Jewish National Fund-USA support Israel in ways that help them save taxes, earn income, and provide more for their loved ones.
These women are not only deeply committed Zionists; they are the heads of their households, leaders in their communities, compassionate, kind, and incredibly smart – and they are leading the way in rebuilding communities in the North and South of Israel that were devastated by October 7 and the ensuing war.
Here are some of their stories.
 
Beth was concerned that her adult children and grandchildren were not committed to Israel. 
She opened a 
Donor Advised Fund
 with Jewish National Fund, creating a charitable giving bank account that grows tax-free. She gets a charitable tax deduction whenever she puts money, 
stocks
, or other assets in the fund. Beth allocates a certain amount of money from her fund each year for her kids and grandkids to recommend grants consistent with her values. Her family now talks about philanthropy throughout the year, and they think about how they can make a difference for Israel and for their other favorite charities, as well.
More About DAF
 
Shelly was worried that she would not have enough income in retirement.
 She decided to supplement her retirement income by funding a 
Charitable Gift Annuity
 with Jewish National Fund. She will receive income for life at payout rates which are the highest they have been in over 15 years. Her annuity income will be largely tax-free, and her charitable income tax deduction will be substantial. 
More About CGA
She can even fund a Charitable Gift Annuity using her 
Individual Retirement Account (IRA)
, satisfying her Required Minimum Distribution (RMD) while receiving income for life. 
More About IRA Charitable Rollover
 
Alice wanted to sell a vacation home that her family no longer uses.
 She bought the home 25 years ago and it is now worth four times what she paid for it. She will pay significant capital gains tax if she sells the home. Alice learned that she could use the home to fund a 
Charitable Remainder Trust
 that will provide her with decades of generous income, while avoiding capital gains tax. It was not complicated to set up this Trust, and Alice was thrilled to learn that she would be able to benefit Israel this way.
More About Charitable Remainder Trust
 
Judith is redoing her will and she wants to provide for her loved ones while 
leaving a legacy for Israel
.
 She has some real estate, an IRA, a stock portfolio, 
life insurance
, and 
Bitcoin
. She wants to find the best way to do something special for Israel and take care of her family. She set up a meeting with her estate planning attorney, her financial advisor, and a Planned Giving Specialist at Jewish National Fund to talk about her options. Together, they came up with a perfect plan that would also make a meaningful impact for the people of Israel.
More About Wills
 
Beth, Shelly, Alice, and Judith, and many other women are “doing good while doing well” 
- building Israel for the future, while building security for their loved ones from generation to generation.
 
Call 800.562.7526
to speak with any of ourJewish National Fund Planned Giving Specialists
plannedgiving@jnf.org
 
•
 
jnflegacy.org
We look forward to hearing from you!
P.S.: We have exciting news! 
The film, 
October 8
 (formerly titled 
OCTOBER H8TE
), which JNF-USA executive produced and screened at our Global Conference for Israel, will be in AMC, Regal, Laemmle, and other theaters across the country beginning March 13. The film is about the explosion of antisemitism on college campuses, on social media, and in the streets of America in the aftermath of Hamas's attack on Israel on October 7, 2023.
Executive Producer Debra Messing appears in the film with other high profile people, including Congressman Ritchie Torres, Michael Rapaport, Dan Senor, Sheryl Sandberg, Mosab Yousef. Noa Tishby, Scott Galloway, U.S. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, Douglas Murray, Einat Wilf, Ambassador Deborah Lipstadt, Shai Davidai, Rabbi David Wolpe, Jonathan Schanzer, Tessa Veksler, and others.
Help us spread the word. Show up. Stand strong. Make an impact. Cities and theater screening information can be found on the film's website: 
october8film.com
. The list is updated daily.
 
 
 
 
 
Copyright © 2025 Jewish National Fund-USA, All rights reserved.
JNF mailing address is:
42 East 69th Street New York, New York 10021
jnf.org
 | 800.JNF.0099 | 
customerservice@jnf.org

subject: ADVOCACY ALERT:  Government Contract Terminations and Shutdown Risks
body:
Message Preheader Content 
Having trouble viewing this email?
View this email in a web browser
.
 
As government contractors, navigating contract terminations and the risks associated with a potential government shutdown requires preparation, strategic response, and a clear understanding of federal policies. Join us for this exclusive webinar, where we will examine:
 
Termination for Convenience
 – What it means for your contract, your rights, and how to mitigate financial and operational impact.
Pending Government Shutdown
 – Current policy updates, potential disruptions, and strategies for contractors to sustain operations.
Proactive Measures
 – How to prepare, respond, and protect your business from contract uncertainty.
Guest speaker Alphonso David, social and economic justice advocate and lawyer serves as President and CEO of the Global Black Economic Forum. He brings more than two decades of experience in the private, public and not-for-profit sectors working to advance the rights of marginalized communities through policy, legislation, litigation and advocacy.
 
This session will provide expert insights and guidance to ensure you are prepared to safeguard your business in the face of federal contract changes. Whether you are a prime contractor or a subcontractor, understanding these key issues is essential for business continuity and long-term success in government contracting.
 
We look forward to your participation in this important discussion.
 
We invite you to join us on 
Wednesday, March 13, 2025, at 2:00 PM ET
 for this timely and critical conversation. Bring your questions and concerns—we’re here to help!
RSVP for the conversation.
 
Women Impacting Public Policy (WIPP)
1120 Connecticut Ave NW Suite 200
Washington, D.C. 20036
  
WIPP thanks our Corporate Partners:
  
American Edge Project | American Express | Capital One | EY | Lockheed Martin | Meta | Comcast NBCUniversal | Parabilis | PhRMA | Southwest | Public Private Strategies | Walmart | Wells Fargo | Womble Bond Dickinson

body:
Register Now for Our March 12th Global Trust Webinar! ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Global Trust
Registration now for this March 12th Webinar!
 
 
 
 
March 12, 2025 @ 11:30AM ET
 
 
 
 
 
Data from international surveys sheds light on the following questions: What is trust and why does it matter? How profitable is trust? How much real trust is there in the world? How is trust created across cultures? Using a case study, this session is designed to provide practical insights and actionable takeaways that participants can apply in their personal and professional contexts. This Global Trust session will deliver ideas about one of the most fundamental cross-cultural challenges and about building real bridges. 
 
Daylight Savings Time begins in the U.S. on March 9 and in Europe on March 30, so please double-check your time zone to avoid confusion for our March 12 webinar.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
MEMBER REGISTRATION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NON-MEMBER REGISTRATION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
PRESENTER:
 
Based in Russia, 
Maria Todosiychuk
 is an old friend and colleague of SIETAR USA. She is known for her educational games such as Diversity Space Meeting, Culture Shock, The Global Team, and Intercultural Minefield which are used by many interculturalists across Europe and the USA for intercultural training. Honed over 15 years of working with major Russian and international corporations, Maria has her own style and views on how to teach tricky and complicated intercultural topics.

body:

New to the Market
2701 N Ocean Blvd, Unit 1053, Myrtle Beach SC
$209,000
 
 
 
 
 
DIRECT OCEAN VIEW – PREMIUM BEACHFRONT CONDO AT THE STRAND RESORT!
Welcome to Unit 1053 at The Strand Resort, an exclusive oceanfront retreat offering unparalleled views of the Atlantic! This beautifully updated 1-bedroom, 1-bathroom condo is the perfect blend of luxury, comfort, and investment potential. From the moment you step inside, you'll be captivated by the breathtaking ocean views from both the living and sleeping areas, plus your private oceanfront balcony—perfect for soaking in the sights and sounds of the shoreline.
This fully furnished, turnkey condo has been thoughtfully upgraded with modern finishes throughout. The seller has removed the popcorn ceilings, repainted the entire unit, and replaced all outlets and switches for a fresh, polished look. The kitchen boasts granite countertops and tile flooring, while LVP flooring runs throughout the living spaces, offering both style and durability. The bathroom also features granite countertops, complementing the upscale aesthetic.
Located in one of Myrtle Beach’s most sought-after resorts, The Strand offers top-tier amenities, including:
✔ Oceanfront pool deck & hot tub
✔ Fitness center
✔ Beachfront lounging areas
✔ On-site restaurant & bar
With only 87 exclusive units, The Strand Resort offers a boutique-style experience with all the benefits of a high-end vacation destination. Nestled in the heart of Myrtle Beach, you're just minutes from Broadway at the Beach, the SkyWheel, the boardwalk, world-class golf courses, shopping, and dining—not to mention a short drive from Myrtle Beach Airport!
With competitive HOA fees, strong rental potential, and an unbeatable oceanfront location, Unit 1053 is a rare gem that won’t last long. Don’t miss this incredible opportunity to own a piece of paradise!

subject: 1 intriguing position battle for each team
body:
Plus: 10 STACKED Spring Breakout rosters
Monday, March 10
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS
 
1 remaining position battle each team needs to settle
 
With only weeks to go before Opening Day, here is one position battle at each Spring Training camp that could go down to the wire.
 
Tucker launches home run for first spring hit with Cubs
Mets catcher Alvarez to miss 6-8 weeks with fractured left hand
Yankees' pitching depth being tested early by injuries
Kershaw's favorite current left-hander? Blake Snell
Caglianone listening, learning -- and mashing 444-foot HRs -- at Royals camp
Father-to-be Cortes feels 'different intensity' in spring debut for Crew
Thompson (6 HR!) hoping to parlay hot streak into roster spot
Holmes racks up 8 K's as transition to starting progresses
MORE TOP NEWS
 
MLB MORNING LINEUP PODCAST
 
 
 
PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!
 
MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
MLB players choose who they want closing out a Game 7
Who would you want on the mound with a winner-take-all game on the line? We asked the players themselves in our latest survey and received a wide range of answers.
 
Ranking the Top 10 Spring Breakout rosters
 
Now that we know who will be participating in the second annual Spring Breakout this upcoming weekend, here are the rosters that boast the most star power.
 
This beats a call to the bullpen
 
Some of baseball's biggest stars give each other shoutouts -- plus a critique of one slugger's golf game -- during a game of "Pass the Phone."
 
Jeter is kid at heart at PLAY BALL event
More than 100 kids in Miami received instruction from a Hall of Famer when Derek Jeter's Turn 2 Foundation teamed up with PLAY BALL to host a baseball clinic.
 
30 Clubs in 15 Days: Blue Jays & Brewers
Siera Santos and Jake Peavy are in Blue Jays camp at 4 p.m. ET, while Brian Kenny and Mark DeRosa are in Brewers camp at 9 as 30 Clubs in 15 Days presented by T-Mobile continues on MLB Network.
 
Spring Training baseball on MLB Network
Kevin Gausman is slated to make his second spring start for the Blue Jays against the Astros at 1 p.m. ET (available in Astros market), then catch Cardinals vs. Mets at 6 (available in Cardinals market).
 
MORE STORIES

subject: "Be The Drops"
body:
An excerpt from a Roots of Change Media podcast  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
March 10, 2025   |   
Read Online
"Be The Drops" 
An excerpt from the roots of change podcast 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello friends,
It's been about a year since my last 
podcast conversation
 with Sam Chavez at the roots of change agency. When we were talking about a follow-up, we discussed Black joy, rest, resistance and community, so naturally my sister 
Lisa Hurley
 had to be part of the conversation. 
In this excerpt, we talk about abundance, our responsibility in these times and how we can view ourselves as part of a whole (with an analogy I'm pretty happy with). And we take a swipe at capitalism, too. Check out this excerpt from Sam's private podcast:
Sam
: What you're describing is like abundance. We do have limited resources on a finite planet. But what is abundant is what we can give: our joy, how we love. And I think so many folks are afraid that if they give their pot will be empty, 
Lisa
: They're depleting themselves. 
Sharon
: That is not how it works. No, that is not how it works. 
Lisa
: Nature abhors a vacuum. As soon as you give, something is coming. 
Sharon
: The universe is abundant. And this is the thinking that is the antithesis of the capitalist mindset. Yes, once we realize that the universe is abundant, then that changes how we are able to show up. I'm not being unrealistic, right? We're still living in this capitalist hellscape. There are certain things that have to be done. Bills have to be paid. 
Lisa
: You gotta pay your bills. You gotta pay your bills. 
Thank you for being on the free list for Sharon’s Anti-Racism Newsletter. I can’t do this work without the support of readers like you. But most of all, I rely on those of you who upgrade to premium subscriptions. You can find pricing options here: 
Show me how I can support SARN 
Sharon
: But still, given that, you know, there are ways that we can show up for people, there's support that we can give. You know, sometimes it's a repost, sometimes it's $10, sometimes it's an introduction. You know, there are things that we can do. We all have things that we can do. 
Lisa
: We all have things that we can do, contribute, give. All of us have something, all of us. Having money in the bank account and the abundance of the universe are two different things. You know, money is not the only wealth. 
Sam
: There are people who are very morally bankrupt and have a lot of money, 
Sharon
: They are sending rockets into space. They are deporting people. They are pulling up ladders and closing doors behind them. You know, they're doing all these kinds of things. And it is just, it's so inhumane. Really makes me sick. There is no need for anybody on the planet to be hungry. There is no need for anybody on the planet not to have shelter, right? 
Lisa
: Poverty actually does not need to exist. It really doesn't. I know that's beyond the scope of this show, but we're going to talk about all the things, right? But it really does not. 
And yes, Sharon, you're right. There are people you know, tangerine hued people among others, who have means, right? And just are using their means and privilege in the worst possible ways. 
But there is an alternate approach possible, you know. And so my thing is, just like, look around in your circle, right? Start small. 
Sharon
: The scale is so large, and then they get worried about that. But you know, what can you do where you are? Who's the person living next door to you that you can help? Yeah, on your online social network that you can help? On your team, in your office, who's that person? 
We change the world by taking action where we are. Every drop leads to a trickle leads to a flood, leads to a whatever. You know, it's like water is in drops, but water created the Grand Canyon, right? That was water. That was drops of water working together. We can be the drops. 
I hope you enjoyed that short excerpt. How does the idea of being one of the drops that leads to an anti-racist flood resonate with you?
You can listen to the 
first part of this conversation
, about resilience, and support Sam’s work on the 
roots of change podcast page
.
Thanks for reading,
Sharon
Note: poll feedback is private - if you’re happy to share your thoughts in public, then please also 
leave a comment
.

Indulge in breathtaking Atlantic Ocean views from your private double balcony in this beautifully furnished 1-bedroom, 1-bath oceanfront condo at Grande Cayman Resort—one of Myrtle Beach’s premier destinations. subject: Registration Now Open - Leading with Style: A Fireside Chat with Rebecca Minkoff, 04/22/2025
body:
Dear Monica,
Leading with Style:
 
A Fireside Chat with Rebecca Minkoff
Join us for an exclusive conversation with fashion industry pioneer, bestselling author and Real Housewife of New York,
 
Rebecca Minkoff
 
as she unpacks insights from her book "
Fearless: The New Rules for Unlocking Creativity, Courage, and Success
." 
Rebecca will share her journey from fashion outsider to global brand builder, revealing the unconventional strategies that propelled her success. Whether you’re an aspiring entrepreneur, creative professional, or just looking to up-level your career, this conversation will explore breaking through creative blocks and self-doubt, turning setbacks into comeback opportunities and building a powerful network authentically.
Get ready for an inspiring conversation filled with actionable takeaways, real-world examples, and Rebecca's signature straight-talking advice. Participants will have the opportunity to engage in a live Q&A session.
Register today!

subject: We heard you! RTR is doubling our inventory in 2025!
body:
| Rent the Runway gives you access to thousands of designer styles for less than the price of one. Finally, a closet that moves and grows with you, no matter what.
Dear RTR Community,
 
I’m excited to share that we are making the biggest inventory investment in Rent the Runway history by 
DOUBLING THE NEW INVENTORY coming onto the platform in 2025
. I’ve listened to your feedback and I hear you: You want way more availability of the items you heart and you want more styles from your favorite brands.
  
I’m thrilled to announce that starting today, you can expect to see 
hundreds of new arrivals weekly
 and the beginnings of other major changes to the Rent the Runway experience.
 
 
Here's what you can expect:
Twice as much new inventory! 
75%+ more new styles and increased availability of each style, making the most coveted items and brands on RTR easier to rent. This means we have a lot more workwear, dresses, vacation and 
casual, everyday clothing 
(especially styles that work in the dead of summer—an area where we know we can do better)!
 
3-4X more inventory from your 25 favorite brands: 
We’re going bigger than ever on the brands you love and wear the most, like Staud, Veronica Beard, Reformation, Ulla Johnson, A.L.C., Sandro and more.
 
 
Exclusive designer collaborations: 
We’re launching 15 incredible, fashion-forward, exclusive-to-RTR collections. Keep an eye on your email and our social channels for more information on these big launches in the coming weeks. 
 
90+ Amazing new brands
: We’re refreshing our assortment by launching 
dozens of new brands 
on RTR that you’ve been asking for like Jacquemus, Cult Gaia, FRAME, SIR. and Cala de la Cruz.
 
New and top-requested product features:
 Every month we will be rolling out features that you’ve been asking for, including waitlisting, “back-in-stock” notifications for out-of-stock items, better reviews, and in-product ways for customers to communicate with one another. 
In 2025, my most important goal is to honor the community of women who got us here (all of you) and work hard to deliver what you’ve been asking for. Thank you to our loyal supporters. I promise to continue to listen to your ideas on how to improve RTR. To those of you who’ve left, paused, or have friends who have paused, I’m confident this new inventory will excite you and I’d love to welcome you back as a Rent the Runway subscriber. RTR’s mission has always been about empowering women to feel amazing every day and I hope that our inventory transformation in 2025 brings joy, fun and self-expression to you and our entire community. 
I would love for you to try the new RTR. The code 
SPRING40
 will give you 
40% off your first month 
of 
subscription
.
 
If you have questions or feedback, you can always reach out to me at 
JH@renttherunway.com
 (my actual email). I promise to always be listening and learning. Start hearting our 
new arrivals today.
 
 
Warmly,
Rent the Runway | 10 Jay St | Brooklyn, NY 11201

Privacy Policy

At the end of the promotional month, your RTR Membership will renew automatically each month at the then applicable membership price listed in your membership settings (additional taxes and fees may apply). RTR Memberships can be paused or canceled at any time by visiting your membership settings. Additional taxes and fees may also apply. Code must be redeemed by 3/25/25 at 3:00 AM EST. Cannot be applied to PRO, one-time item rentals, or retail purchases and has no cash value. Code cannot be combined with other offers. Enter Code at checkout; additional terms may apply. subject: Players pick their surprise teams for 2025
body:
Plus: deGrom, Scherzer in vintage form
Sunday, March 09
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS
 
Who will be this year's surprise team? We asked the players
 
In our survey last season, Major League players picked the Royals to be 2024's surprise team. After nailing that prediction, here is who they see stepping up this year.
 
Vintage deGrom tosses 2 perfect frames in spring debut
Cole 'concerned' about elbow discomfort, waiting on diagnosis
Scherzer in peak form with 14 K's, 0 walks in 3 spring starts
Soto fitting in just fine: 'It feels like he's been here a while'
Profar leaves game with left wrist injury, will undergo MRI
Yelich homers for first time since back surgery
Tigers sign Urquidy to 1-year deal with club option
Strider nearing spring debut after facing hitters
MORE TOP NEWS
 
MLB MORNING LINEUP PODCAST
 
 
 
PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!
 
MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
15 nasty new pitches we've seen this spring
Spring Training is the ideal time for pitchers to develop new offerings and add them to their repertoires, and these pitches look like they might be here to stay.
 
'Here’s my stuff. If you hit it, great'
MLB Pipeline No. 5 overall prospect Jackson Jobe decided to challenge Vladimir Guerrero Jr. with fastballs the second time he faced him yesterday, and struck him out on three pitches.
 
8 game-changing women in baseball
International Women's Day was this weekend, and these women are currently making their mark in a variety of different roles around baseball.
 
Pitcher celebrations 101
 
If hitters can bat flip, pitchers should be able to celebrate a big out. That being said, Brewers relievers have a lot of thoughts on the do's and don'ts of mound etiquette.
 
Spring Training baseball on MLB Network
Watch an afternoon doubleheader as the Jays battle the Rays at 1 p.m. ET, followed by D-backs vs. A’s at 4 (available in D-backs market). Then 30 Clubs in 15 Days presented by T-Mobile continues with Siera Santos and Jake Peavy from Rays camp at 7, and Adnan Virk and Mark DeRosa from Royals camp at 8.

Instant Savings:
 Instant Savings offers are subject to availability and are valid in U.S. clubs with a U.S. membership, excluding Puerto Rico. Prices shown are pre-tax amounts. State and local laws may require sales tax to be charged on the pre-discounted price. For Curbside Pickup orders, savings will be based on and limited to the Instant Savings offers available to the paying member on the date of online payment. No money will be returned to the member if the price of the item falls below zero after applying Instant Savings discount. Multiple offers will not be combined for any item. If more than one Instant Savings offer is available for an item, the most recent offer on that item will apply first. Visit 
SamsClub.com/TermsandConditions
 or see an associate for additional details. Offers valid March 12-April 6, 2025. 
Rx Savings Powered by America's Pharmacy: 
DISCOUNT ONLY – NOT INSURANCE. The Program as offered by Sam's Club is only available to Sam's Club members. There are no additional fees for Sam's Club members to use the Program. Discounts are available exclusively through participating pharmacies. The range of discounts will vary depending upon the type of prescription and the pharmacy you choose; the program delivers average savings of 65%, with potential savings of up to 80% off of the regular retail prices based upon 2022 national program savings data. The program cannot be used with any insurance plan or government funded program such as Medicare or Medicaid. Program prices are not available to the general public and do not constitute Sam's Club usual and customary prices. The drug formulary is open. Prescription prices may vary from pharmacy to pharmacy and are subject to change. The pricing estimates given are based on the most recent information available and may change based on when you actually fill your prescription at the pharmacy. Members are required to pay for all health care services. America's Pharmacy is not a pharmacy; we do not engage in the practice of pharmacy, including but not limited to, we do not counsel consumers about prescription medications, and we do not dispense any prescription medications. Discounted prescriptions available through the program are dispensed by licensed pharmacies who have agreed to participate in our prescription discount program offering. You may cancel at any time or file a complaint by calling the toll-free customer care number at 
1-844-863-0353
. If a Member remains dissatisfied after receiving MedImpact's response to a complaint, the Member may contact the Member's state department of insurance. The program is administered by MedImpact Healthcare Systems, Inc. 10181 Scripps Gateway Ct., San Diego, CA 92131. For additional program details see the member agreement and terms of use. 
Sam's Club Plus Program:
 The Sam's Club Plus Program is not insurance and cannot be combined with any insurance. This program is only available to Sam's Club Plus Members at participating Sam's Club Pharmacy locations. Not available on 
SamClub.com
. Visit 
SamsClub.com/RxSavings
 
to see the drug price, formulation, strength, and quantity available for Plus Members. Covered drugs may vary. Program prices are limited to a 30 day supply. There will be an additional cost for quantities greater than listed quantity. The Plus Member price is not available if a drug is part of a compounded prescription or for purchases submitted to any health benefit program, pharmacy benefit program, insurer, or state/federal government health care program. Program prices are not available to the general public and do not constitute Sam's Club usual and customary prices. May not combine with other offers. Free drugs are only available at no additional cost to Sam's Plus Members. The Free drug benefit is not available in AZ, CA, MN. Free drugs available to Sam's Club Plus Member only at select Sam's Club Pharmacy locations. In Arizona, California, and Minnesota, drugs listed in the Free drug benefit are available for $2 for a 30 day supply. Discount savings are based on the dispensing Sam's Club Pharmacy's regular retail cash price. Program pricing is limited to in stock items by select manufacturers of a covered drug at the dispensing pharmacy. Taxes or other fees may apply. Other restrictions apply. Terms subject to change without notice. See 
SamsClub.com
 or your local Sam's Club Pharmacy for details.

subject: Honoring Women’s Leadership During International Women's Day - And Fighting for What’s Ours
body:
​
​
​
Hi there,
Women’s leadership has always been at the heart of change. 
Challenging systems, building movements, and making space for voices that might otherwise go unheard. 
And yet, this work is far from over.
Let’s name what’s happening: Women are feeling less and less called to the table. Our rights—the very things we have fought for, the progress we have made—are being threatened. We watched a woman dragged out of a town hall by men who refused to identify themselves. Women’s reproductive rights are on the line.
And I want to be honest with you—
I am angry.
I am typically an optimist. I believe in progress, in the arc of change, in the possibility of a better future. But today, as a woman, I am mad. And I am ready to fight.
Because we don’t back down.
On 
International Women’s Day
, I want to take a moment to celebrate the women who have shaped me, inspired me, and paved the way for so many of us. But I also want to say this:
This is not just a day of celebration. It is a call to action.
We Honor Women By Continuing the Fight
We fight for the women whose voices are ignored in rooms where decisions about them are being made.
We fight for the women who are being told that their safety, their autonomy, their choices are up for debate.
We fight for the women who are exhausted, who feel like they have been screaming into the void, who are wondering if anyone is still listening.
I hear you. I see you. And I am standing with you.
As we mark this day, I invite you to reflect:
Who are the women who have shaped your journey?
What lessons have they passed on that you carry with you today?
How are we ensuring that progress isn’t just a moment, but a movement?
If you feel called, I’d love for you to share your thoughts with me. Who do you want to honor today? Reply to this email, or join me on 
LinkedIn
 where I’ll be sharing more reflections throughout the day.
Continuing the Conversation
If you’re looking for a space to connect, we’ll be hosting a 
community call
 this month to continue the conversation on women’s leadership, resilience, and the fight ahead. Stay tuned for details. I’d love for you to be part of it.
More than ever, I believe in the power of women’s voices. I believe in the power of your voice. And I am so grateful to be in this fight alongside you.
​
In solidarity,
​
Jennifer Brown
CEO & Founder, 
Jennifer Brown Speaks
​
Author, 
Inclusion
, 
How to Be an Inclusive Leader
, and 
Beyond Diversity
​
Host, 
The Will To Change
 Podcast
​

subject: Celebrating International Women’s Day: March Forward for Gender Equality
body:
Hi Monica,
This International Women's Day, we are inspired by the theme 
"March Forward"
—a reminder that gender equity is not a destination but a journey. It’s a call to continue moving forward, breaking barriers, and driving change for the better.
 
Today, we celebrate the women who lead, innovate, and pave the way for future generations. But we also acknowledge that our progress depends on the collective effort to invest in women. 
 
At the heart of this progress is the 
ripple effect
—investing in women doesn’t just empower them; it sparks a 
broader transformation that enhances performance, innovation, and organisational success for everyone.
 
When we support women’s growth and leadership, we create positive momentum that extends beyond the individual, touching entire teams and entire companies. This ripple effect is one of the most powerful ways to drive inclusivity, and it’s something we should continue to invest in, each and every day.
 
Let’s continue to make strides towards a gender-equal world.
 
SCHEDULE TIME TO TALK
 
LEARN MORE
 
Symmetra Pty Ltd, Quay Quarter Towers, Level 2, 50 Bridge Street, Sydney, NSW 2000 Australia, hello@symmetraglobal.com

subject: The new No. 1 farm system is …
body:
Plus: T. Swift helps prospect learn English
Saturday, March 08
View In Browser
 
TOP NEWS
 
Which MLB stars would excel in another sport? We asked the players!
 
Whether they have an enormous frame, are incredibly fast or have any other athletic gift, it's fun to wonder which big leaguers could go pro in another sport. Over 100 MLB players weighed in, and here's what they think.
 
Cole undergoing diagnostic tests on throwing elbow (report)
Kershaw takes big step with bullpen session
'I'm feeling OK': Why Tucker, Cubs aren't worried about spring results
Kirby likely to start season on IL with right shoulder inflammation
Devers penciled in for 2025 Grapefruit League debut
Braves' RF candidates trying to make decision hard
Astros relieved by MRI results on Walker's sore left oblique
Crew shortstop still TBD: 'Can't put a deadline on it'
'Just be you’: Rox prospect Karros soaking in 1st Spring Training
MORE TOP NEWS
 
MLB MORNING LINEUP PODCAST
 
 
 
PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!
 
MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
There's a new No. 1 in farm system rankings
 
After a three-year run atop the preseason farm system rankings, the Orioles have relinquished the throne.
 
You're on your own, kid: Prospect thanks Taylor Swift for help with English
 
Roberto Campos used to talk with English-speaking media with help from an interpreter. Not anymore, thanks to listening to popular music and paying attention to the lyrics. “Thanks, Taylor Swift,” he said. “She’s incredible.”
 
Everything you need to know about Year 2 of Spring Breakout
 
In less than a week, fans will have a chance to watch top prospects from every club battle it out on a big-league diamond -- and with some special rules!
 
Naquin switched from outfield to mound in a hurry. 'It was pretty quick'
 
After playing five games in 2023 with the White Sox, free agency loomed for Tyler Naquin. He was at a friend's gym when he declared he was going to try something new. “I just looked at him and I said, ‘I think I'm gonna pitch.’”
 
How MVP 2005 revolutionized baseball video games
 
It ranks as one of the greatest video games ever, a classic that became the foundation for current hit "MLB The Show." Did the artists and developers know they were creating an all-time game while they were creating it? Well, yes, kind of.
 
Jackie Robinson Foundation scholars gather to honor No. 42 -- and their own success
 
Robinson's legacy was remembered at the Jackie Robinson Foundation Scholars luncheon as young people from some of the top colleges and universities gathered at MLB Network studios to celebrate their accomplishments.
 
Spring Training on MLB Network
 
Watch an afternoon doubleheader with Jays-Phillies at 1 p.m. ET (available in Blue Jays market) and Mariners-Cubs at 3 (available in Mariners market). Then 30 Clubs in 15 Days presented by T-Mobile continues with Lauren Shehadi and Chris Young from Twins camp at 6, and Adnan Virk and Mark DeRosa from Cubs camp at 7.

subject: A Chicago rent time machine
body:
Plus the latest news from Chicago's NPR station.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
 Donate
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
Photo: Andjela Padejski/WBEZ
WBEZ NEWS
If you could go back in time, would renting in Chicago be more affordable?
WBEZ’s lookup tool allows you to find out which of the city’s communities you could afford if you were renting in a different decade.
READ MORE
WBEZ NEWS
 
Photo: Mariah Woelfel/WBEZ
Behind the scenes at Mayor Brandon Johnson’s congressional grilling
Johnson had a gameplan of what he wanted to stress to congressional Republicans in his testimony. In fact, he made his point at least 18 times.
READ MORE
 
Photo: Anthony Vazquez/Chicago Sun-Times
How Trump's deportation threat is upending two Chicago families
The president is ending protected status for Venezuelans. The uncertainty is straining relationships and intensifying pressure on business owners.
READ MORE
 
Photo: Mendy Kong/WBEZ
How Chicago disco-funk artist Ric Wilson built his iconic and international style
The locally rooted, globe-trotting musician and activist shares his wardrobe secrets. Rule one: Be “dance-ready.”
READ MORE
 
Photo: WBEZ
TRAILER: Stories Without End
WBEZ’s 
Making
 podcast delves into daytime soaps in an all-new season.
READ MORE
 
SPONSORED BY MODE MOBILE
The ‘Uber’ Disruption of the $500 Billion Smartphone Industry
Uber did it to cars, Airbnb did it to homes… And now, 
Mode Mobile
 is doing it to the $500 billion smartphone industry. 
Turning phones from an expense into an income stream, they’ve put $325M back in customers’ pockets. With record-breaking 32,481% revenue growth, they 
are gearing up for a possible Nasdaq listing (ticker: $MODE).
Here’s how you can invest at just $0.26/share.
 
Disclaimers
1 Mode Mobile recently received their ticker reservation with Nasdaq ($MODE), indicating an intent to IPO in the next 24 months. An intent to IPO is no guarantee that an actual IPO will occur.
2 The rankings are based on submitted applications and public company database research, with winners selected based on their fiscal-year revenue growth percentage over a three-year period.
3 A minimum investment of $1,950 is required to receive bonus shares. 100% bonus shares are offered on investments of $9,950+.
UPCOMING EVENTS
 
WBEZ Present: An Evening with Roxane Gay & Sasha-Ann Simons
Date/Time: 
Wednesday, March 26 at 7:30 p.m.
Location:
 Athenaeum Center -  2936 N Southport Ave, Chicago, IL 60657
WBEZ invites you in conversation with New York Times best-selling author and feminist icon Roxane Gay at the Athenaeum Center for Thought & Culture on March 26. Gay will discuss her newest title, 
The Portable Feminist Reader
, with the host of WBEZ’s Reset, Sasha-Ann Simons.
The Portable Feminist Reader
 dives into the history of American feminism as Gay considers multicultural perspectives and intersectional issues like ecofeminism, feminism, disability, and Black feminism. Each ticket comes with a signed copy of 
The Portable Feminist Reader
.  
Use code BOGO for buy one get one half off tickets. 
TICKETS
 
Get in the Game! Fearless Women. Fierce Daughters.
Date/Time:
 Thursday, March 13, 2025 at 6 p.m. 
Location:
 Sanctuary - 10 W. Hubbard St., Chicago, Illinois 60654
Join a bold panel of women as they explore the importance of cultivating fearlessness —how they’ve navigated their careers, overcome challenges, and embraced bold choices in work and in life. The event includes a five cuisines, five course dinner with premium Italian wines. Curated by Sanctuary & Let's Talk Womxn. Use code 
WBEZ25
 for $25 off. 
TICKETS
 
The Podcast Salon
Date/Time:
 Friday, March 21, 2025 at 6 p.m.
Location:
 Nobody’s Darling - 1744 W Balmoral Ave, Chicago, IL 60640
Ready to discover your next favorite podcast?
The Podcast Salon is for those who love podcasts and those who are ready to find out what the talk is all about. We'll feature the best podcasters from across the country in conversation with Chicago’s own award-winning podcast host & producer Anna DeShawn, showcase indy podcast in a never-before-seen Podcast Open Mic, and be in community where you can make new connections.
TICKETS

In bite-sized episodes every weekday, we’ll keep you informed and tickled and on Chicago’s news, culture and people.

subject: First Pitch Event
body:
Good Evening Everyone,
Just want to say thank you again for your support of the boys and the DePaul baseball program last night.  What a great turnout and great opportunity for families to get out and meet one another.  I want to thank the Hecht and Flom families once again for their contributions to the raffle items.  And of course, congrats to the big winners:
Dana MacMillan:  DePaul Spirit Basket and 4 Cubs tix
Mickey MacMillian:  Whiskey Basket
Larry Liss:  P.O.S.H Basket
Tom Horenkamp:  Weller Raffle
Brian Daly:  50/50 Raffle
Thank you again and good luck to all of the boys in the upcoming season.
Mike

subject: A larger property tax burden for neighborhoods
body:
Plus, how to ease into Daylight Saving. Here’s what you need to know today.
 
.
To view this email as a web page, click 
here.
WBEZ is a community-supported, nonprofit newsroom.
 
 
Become a Member
Friday - March 7, 2025
Today's 
Rundown
 is brought to you by WBEZ members and
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
by Bianca Cseke
 
 
 
 
 
 
Good afternoon, and happy Friday! Heads up that I’ll be traveling the next couple weeks. But don’t worry — my colleagues will still bring you the newsletter. Here’s what you need to know today.
  
1.
Amid Loop vacancies, Chicago’s property tax burden is shifting to neighborhoods
 
The pandemic left the heart of the Loop with vacant offices and stores as workers and customers stayed home and more people began working remotely. Then, citing the impact of that lost business, the owners of those vacant offices won huge tax breaks from Cook County officials.
The taxes paid by the once-bustling but now-struggling 
Water Tower Place
, for instance, have plunged from $16 million annually to $6.8 million last year.
But the taxes are still needed to pay for government services and salaries. City Hall and other government agencies have been asking property owners to pay more overall.
Since the onset of the pandemic, all but four of Chicago’s 63 ZIP codes have seen increases in property tax billings, my colleague Tim Novak reports for the Chicago Sun-Times. 
The Near West Side, Logan Square and Bronzeville neighborhoods have been particularly hard hit, much of that as a result of new commercial and residential developments. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
2.
The Small Business Administration is closing its Chicago office, citing ‘sanctuary city’ status
 
In coming months, SBA regional offices in Chicago, Atlanta, Boston, Denver, New York City and Seattle “will be moved to less costly, more accessible locations that better serve the small business community and comply with federal immigration law,” the agency said in a news release.
The closures punish cities that don’t comply with the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s efforts to detain immigrants, as President Trump urges mass deportations and tighter borders, Amy Yee writes for the Chicago Sun-Times.
The move also comes the day after Mayor Brandon Johnson testified before the House Oversight and Government Reform committee over Chicago’s sanctuary city policy, along with the mayors of New York, Boston and Denver.
The SBA does not issue financing to small businesses directly, as people typically apply for SBA-backed loans through participating banks and lenders. But advocates say closing the SBA’s Chicago office harms small businesses that need support. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
SPONSOR MESSAGE FROM LOYOLA UNIVERSITY CHICAGO
Positively Impact People and the Planet
Climate change has dire implications for the world's water resources—worsening droughts and flooding imperil communities worldwide, while warmer waters harm aquatic ecosystems and damage fisheries. More than half the world's population faces water insecurity.
Loyola University Chicago's 2025 Climate Change Conference will explore global, regional, and local strategies for developing just solutions to the emerging water crisis.
Register now!
3.
Hazel Johnson launched an environmental movement in Chicago that President Donald Trump is trying to end
 
Environmental justice was born in Chicago, and Johnson is remembered as the movement’s “mother.” But advocates say Trump is creating a new narrative to demonize programs and policies aimed at helping vulnerable communities, Brett Chase reports for the Chicago Sun-Times.
Trump is cutting jobs at the Environmental Protection Agency, and he’s all but eliminated the Office of Environmental Justice within the office, which grew sixfold under former President Joe Biden. Trump equates environmental justice to diversity, equity and inclusion programs, which he has disparaged and sought to end.
Hazel, who died at age 75, had said she worked for all vulnerable people plagued by toxic pollution. Her activism persuaded former President Bill Clinton to recognize environmental justice in an executive order, which Trump ended in January.
“We’ve been knocked down before,” her daughter, Cheryl, told the Sun-Times. “I’m going to carry on to my last breath in my body, and I’m going to continue to fight for the inequalities that happen in our neighborhoods.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
4.
How to ease the time change when we ‘spring forward’ this weekend
 
Clocks will “spring forward” as daylight saving time takes effect at 2 a.m. Sunday, jumping ahead by one hour. While the extra evening sunlight might be welcome, the lost hour of sleep can leave many feeling groggy and out of sync.
Clara Peek, an expert on circadian rhythms, says small changes — like shifting sleep and meal times — can make a big difference.
Her tips include eating breakfast at a consistent time relative to when you wake up, and, on Sunday, getting outside in sunlight as soon as possible. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
5.
The Shedd Aquarium announced the name of its beluga whale calf
 
The newest member of the aquarium now has a name — Opus.
The animal care team suggested names for aquarium members to choose from, and more than 1,000 votes were cast.
Opus means a musical composition or set of compositions usually numbered in the order of its issue, the Shedd said in a news release. The name is also a nod to the calf’s dad, Beethoven, and the vocalizations beluga whales make. [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
 
Here's what else is happening
 
President Trump is seeking a new nuclear deal with Iran. [
AP
]
Walgreens agreed to be acquired by a private equity firm for almost $10 billion. [
AP
]
International Women’s Day is tomorrow. [
AP
]
Lady Gaga’s new album, 
Mayhem
, was released today. [
Billboard
]
 
Oh, and one more thing...
 
A new Field Museum exhibit features more than 180 works from artists spanning more than 20 countries in Africa, and the pieces are presented in the context of the continent’s political and cultural history. 
Africa Fashion
 shares personal stories of designers, highlights their innovation, and demonstrates their global impact. A companion exhibition, 
Connecting Threads
, features African fashions created by Chicago designers.
“The show is about agency,” said lead curator Christine Checinska, who also serves as the senior curator of African and diaspora textiles and fashion at the Victoria and Albert Museum. “It’s about abundance. It’s about unbounded creativity. And I want people to really catch a glimpse of the magnificence of African creativity when they come to the show.” [
Chicago Sun-Times
]
 
Tell me something good
 
I’ve got some long plane rides coming up and a stack of books ready to go, but I’m curious, what are your favorite ways to pass the time on a long flight or car ride?
Jill writes:
“My favorite way to pass the time on a long flight? Listening to podcasts of 
Wait Wait Don’t Tell Me!
 I look through the WWDTM archive for past broadcasts I had missed, then download them before heading out so there’s no need to worry about dropped wi-fi connections. The only problem is keeping myself from laughing out loud while listening to them in-flight.”
Seán writes:
“I tend to listen to podcasts or audiobooks on long car rides. They keep my mind off the length of the drive on a given day. As for flights: if there isn’t an IFE system available I’ll bring the last few issues of National Geographic or a book or two to read. Even on noise cancellation mode I find it’s hard to hear audio through my AirPods on planes.”
Stephen writes:
“It always makes me sad seeing adults playing mindless games or watching mindless TV when they're on a flight. Read a book. Grow your intellect by borrowing someone else's brain. It’s a great way to enjoy some alone time even when you're surrounded by strangers.”
And Deb writes:
“Reading, then sleeping, then walking to the restroom, ordering a drink and snack, working a crossword puzzle, drawing what you see out of the window or profiles of those around you, ordering another drink, writing about your trip and other travel plans, returning to sleeping, an aisle walk to the galley, a stop in the restroom, returning to your seat to gather up your belongings, and voila! You are there! 
P.S. If your seatmate is amenable, you can punctuate the previous with short chats.”
Thanks for all the responses this week! I’m sure some of the tips will be helpful during the multiple 10-plus-hour flights I have this month.
Thanks for reading and have a nice weekend! Esther will see you on Monday.
— Bianca Cseke
The Rundown is reader-funded. 
Your gift of any amount helps power this newsletter and all of WBEZ’s reporting.

body:

Friday, March 07

TOP NEWS
 
The ultimate prospect showcase has rosters loaded with talent
 
The Spring Breakout participants have been announced, featuring 72 of MLB Pipeline's top 100 prospects, and the next wave of big league stars is ready to roll.
 
Shohei slows down pitching, won't face hitters until after Tokyo Series
Brazil grabs final berth in 2026 World Baseball Classic
Butler agrees to 7-year, $65.5M extension with A's (source)
Schwellenbach's '24 wasn't just good. It was historic

MORE TOP NEWS
 
MLB MORNING LINEUP PODCAST
 
 
 
PLAY A SPORCLE BASEBALL QUIZ!
 
MORE FREE GAMES AT MLB PLAY
 
STAFF PICKS
 
Picking the MVP favorites ... and dark horses ... for 2025
 
You can probably guess the frontrunners for this award entering the season. They look a lot like the ones who won it last year. But how about some more outside-the-box contenders to consider?
 
Cubs, Dodgers get 'Demon Slayer' treatment
 
MLB and the anime series "Demon Slayer" have teamed up to release an anime-style short film to celebrate the upcoming Tokyo Series, featuring superstars from the two clubs alongside series characters.
 
Senga the summer? A 'Ghost Fork' single just dropped
 
Japanese artist Yusuke Kamiji -- who played high school ball with Daisuke Matsuzaka -- released a new song with a nod to Kodai Senga's signature pitch, and it just might replace "OMG" at Citi Field this year.
 
He's no blockhead: Dreyer teaching way of the Rubik's Cube
 
Jack Dreyer became hooked on solving Rubik's Cubes when he was a sophomore in high school, and now he's bonding with Dodgers teammates and creating art with the 3D puzzles.
 
Meet the Blue Jays' assistant managers, the Schneider boys
 
John Schneider’s sons have been fixtures at the ballpark since he took over as manager in the middle of the 2022 season. Now, they’re growing up with their dad in the manager’s chair.
 
30 Clubs in 15 Days: Pirates & A’s
 
Lauren Shehadi and Chris Young are at Pirates camp at 5 p.m. ET, while Adnan Virk and Mark DeRosa are with the A’s at 9 as 30 Clubs in 15 Days presented by T-Mobile continues on MLB Network.
 
Spring Training Baseball on MLB Network 
It's the Phillies vs. the Pirates at 1 p.m. ET (available in Phillies market), followed by the Orioles vs. the Tigers at 6 (available in Orioles market).

subject: THE STREETS CANNOT BE QUIET
body:
Let's make a lot of NOISE! Organize a Protest Now!
 
 
JOIN A PROTEST! 
CAN'T FIND ONE? 
DIY Protest!
 
THE STORY OF ONE PROTEST
A few weeks ago I read a headline that shook me to the core. It said:
"Trump dismantles democracy and the streets are quiet."
My feet began to burn. They wanted to march. My arms wanted to hold a sign. My voice wanted to shout my rage. My brain screamed, "The streets must be noisy! VERY, VERY noisy."
 
So I stood up at a Women's Democratic Club meeting and asked if there was a protest coming up. There 
wasn't one. 
So I publicly, on-the-spot volunteered to host a protest. The room immediately zapped with excitement. In ten minutes we had decided when, where, how and why we would protest on President's Day in Sarasota.
SIX days later,
 we held the BIGGEST protest in Sarasota's history. It was all bottled up inside. The anger, the humiliation, the disbelief, the fear. 2,000 people showed up with almost no notice and protested for three hours along Route 41, with cars honking continuously in support.
We brought homemade signs that were clever, earnest, big, small -- a walking museum of originality and passion. The park filled with young and old, families and neighbors, gay, trans and straight, glamorous and casual. Some people carpooled over an hour to get there. We made new friends and bumped into old ones.
 
 
 
 
 
WHY WE PROTEST
"Protesting is like a muscle," said Julie Forestier, President of the Sarasota Democratic Women's Club. 
If you protest regularly, people learn how to do it. They start to expect it. And whenever big and bad things happens, we will be ready. When we hear a national group call for protest, our town, our group will take up the task. We will be organized. We will know how to get a lot of people into the streets!
Protesting Gives People Hope
We are not alone in our outrage about the destruction of our country. We are able to find each other at the protest. We give each other energy that is otherwise bottled up inside, looking for an outlet. We learn how others express their thoughts. We hone our talking points. We feel engaged and attached, rather than isolated and surrounded. 
We Bolster Our Self-Confidence
And we are going to need it. 
 
Attention is Paid
If the streets are quiet, assumptions are made. No one sees our hand wringing and gnashing of teeth. They do see our protests, big or small. And they string them together in news reports. 
Rachel Maddow 
has been showing clips of protests in all corners of our country on her show. It is impressive, and meaningful. 
We can move fast, and react to events
Private citizens can say and do things that the elected officials usually cannot. We can hold a sign that says "Trump Is a Russian Asset." An elected most likely can't. But we can. We can go full throttle, full throated in protest against the lies, the destruction, the chaos and the loss. And we must.
 
 
 
 
 
ACTIVATE YOUR COMMUNITY: 
TEN EASY STEPS TO CREATE A 
DO-IT-YOURSELF PROTEST
I didn't know you could start your own protest in your community, town or state, but apparently you can...because I did it. Who knew?
Don't wait for someone else to organize a protest, rally or march. Here's a Do-It-Yourself Kit for making it happen!
Step One
: Go to 
www.mobilize.us
 to see if there are any protests near you. If the answer is YES, GO to that protest and get involved with the group hosting it.
 
Step Two
: If the answer is NO, volunteer to host it yourself. Find out where protests are usually held in your town. Look for a group or groups to work with. I suggest organizations like these:
Local Democratic Women's Club
Local Democratic HQ
Local Democratic Caucuses
Indivisible group
Women's March online (get on their mailing list)
March for Our Lives
50501
Step Three:
 TELL one of the groups that you are planning a protest and you want to work with them. Run the details by them to see if they agree this would be a good time, place and theme. They may know a lot more than you about protesting in your town, and that's great. Find what will work.
Step Four
: Ask the group to broadcast the news of the protest to any groups they know. Make sure someone with administrative rights puts the news on 
www.mobilize.us
. Word spreads fast.
Step Five: 
Contact the police station in your community to tell them you are going to have a sign-waving rally. Tell them you are the individual organizer and that you're working with several groups. Ask for a number you can call if you need to speak to someone during the protest, and give them your number. It's good for the police to have advance notice so that they can be ready if Trumpers come by.
Step Six
: Know your rights and the rules. 
The ACLU recently published a brief summary of your protest rights
.
You can hold a rally in any public park or space
You do not need a permit if you are marching on public streets or sidewalks, as long as you don't obstruct car or pedestrian traffic
Be sure you are not on private property
The police are in charge of your safety and their number one rule is "Don't stand in the street, even to take pictures."
 
Step Seven
: Scope out the protest location. Walk around and think of issues that might arise. Where will people park (most commonly asked question)? Is there shade? If people have wheelchairs or canes will they be safe on the terrain?
Step Eight
: Do you want to have speeches? With a good bullhorn you can make speeches almost anywhere. Bullhorns are great for chants as well -- but in some places, sound equipment at a large rally does require a permit, so find out. Make sure your have volunteers who want to speak or lead chants. You don't have to have speeches. And you don't have to march. Standing on a busy sidewalk with 100 people where cars can see you is a good rally.
Step Nine:
 On the day of the event, be available to anyone who might need you. Ask other organizers to be ready to answer questions or show people where to stand.
Step Ten:
 Estimate the number of people and start telling everyone right away if you are happy with the number. When people leave they will go home and say "There were 500 people there!"
 
 
 
 
 
THIS SATURDAY: JOIN THE INTERNATIONAL WOMEN'S DAY 
﻿
OF ACTION IN SARASOTA, FL
 
 
 
100 Days for Harris | 
96 Knauth Rd
 | 
Asheville, NC 28805 US

subject: Take control of your debt with a HELOC
body:
Free up cashflow and focus on your financial goals.
 
 
Make room for what really matters.
 
Apply now
 
 
Hi Monica, 
 
Are high-interest payments making it harder to reach your financial goals? A Home Equity Line of Credit (HELOC)¹ is a smarter, more affordable way to consolidate your debt into a single payment with a lower interest rate. 
 
 
Here's how a HELOC works for you: 
 
 
 
Lower monthly payments 
by replacing high-interest debt with one manageable rate. 
 
 
 
Save on interest 
over time while simplifying your financial life.²
 
 
 
Flexible access to funds 
— use only what you need, when you need it.
 
 
 
Here's what debt consolidation could look like:³
